results.name: TechCrafters
results.title: TechCrafters Camp
results.subtitle: Penn State Abington
results.description: TechCrafters Camp is a 3D design and print extravaganza held at the MakerSpace for students ages 12 to 17. Participants engage in hands-on, creative activities using a diverse range of tools and technologies to solve unique real-world challenges. Students gain proficiency in maker skills such as art, design, and engineering while learning to operate equipment like 3D printers, vinyl cutters, and laser cutters. Advanced participants explore the full fabrication process by utilizing design tools such as Tinkercad and InkScape to create graphics and personalized prototypes. Through these sessions, students build their own projects including laser etchings and textile embroidery, which can be applied to items like t-shirts and water bottles.

results.name: Summer Research Program
results.title: Summer Research Program
results.subtitle: The Young Scientist Foundation
results.description: The Summer Research Program provides high school and undergraduate students with an immersive opportunity to conduct biomedical research within a professional laboratory environment. Participants are paired with experienced mentors, such as graduate students or post-doctoral fellows, to work on projects focused on cancer treatments and other diseases. Students engage in hands-on activities including working with cell cultures, performing molecular biology experiments, and analyzing scientific data. In addition to technical lab skills, the program emphasizes the development of communication and presentation abilities through weekly meetings and a final research presentation. The experience aims to foster independence in young scientists while offering financial support through student stipends and laboratory awards.

results.name: University of Texas at Dallas
results.title: UT Dallas Biology Camps for Middle & High School Students
results.subtitle: The University of Texas at Dallas
results.description: The Biology Camps for Middle & High School Students are virtual programs organized by the Department of Biological Sciences to provide students with deep exploration into the field of biology. These sessions offer rigorous academic content and hands-on experiences within a dynamic virtual environment specifically designed for middle and high school learners. The curriculum includes AP Biology camps taught by subject matter experts who cover critical syllabus topics and provide dedicated time for solving test questions to prepare participants for advanced coursework and standardized exams. Classes are structured as interactive sessions held via Microsoft Teams, ensuring students can participate effectively outside of their regular school hours. All registered participants gain exclusive access to session recordings to support their ongoing study and mastery of the material.

results.name: Pre-College

deadlines.label: Summer 2026 Application Deadline for International Students
Summer 2026 I-20 Forms Due for International Students
Summer 2026 Application Deadline for U.S. and Online Students

results.title: NYU Precollege
results.subtitle: New York University
results.description: NYU Precollege provides rising 11th and 12th grade high school students with the opportunity to earn college credits and explore academic interests that shape their futures. Through this program, students participate in intellectually rigorous courses taught by award-winning faculty in subjects ranging from business and STEM to the humanities and social sciences. Participants engage with peers from around the world and benefit from full access to campus resources, including university libraries, peer tutoring, and dining services. Additionally, the program offers a series of workshops on the college admissions process and financial aid to help students transition effectively to higher education.

results.name: Pre-College

program_dates.label: Pre-College: On-site Residential and Commuter Session 1
Pre-College: On-site Residential and Commuter Session 2

results.title: Pre-College
results.subtitle: New York School of Interior Design
results.description: The Pre-College program provides high school students from 9th to 12th grade with an immersive introduction to the professional world of interior design through both on-site and online tracks. Participants have the opportunity to earn one college credit while learning fundamentals such as drafting, color theory, and spatial flow from industry-leading professional designers. The curriculum includes specialized courses in interior design, art and design portfolio development, and photography, allowing students to build creative pieces for their future college applications. In addition to classroom instruction, the experience incorporates exclusive visits to showrooms, museums, and private tours of design studios to offer real-world inspiration. Students engage in capstone projects such as designing residential apartments or hospitality spaces to transform their passion into a potential profession.

results.name: HealthLink
results.title: HealthLink
results.subtitle: UCSF School of Medicine
results.description: HealthLink is a free, year-long program designed for first-generation college-bound high school students who are looking to explore careers in healthcare and research. Participants are paired with graduate student mentors from various health professional schools to receive guidance and support throughout the academic year. The curriculum includes hands-on workshops that examine the human body alongside career-focused sessions that help students navigate the path from high school to graduate school. Mentors serve as a long-term resource to help participants set themselves up for success in their academic and extracurricular activities. By connecting students with current professionals in fields such as nursing, pharmacy, and medicine, the initiative seeks to advance diversity and inspire the next generation of health leaders.

results.name: Math Camp

deadlines.label: PZMC Number Theory Camp Application Due Date
PZMC Number Theory Camp Rolling Admissions Start
PZMC Number Theory Camp MathPrograms Application Deadline

results.title: PZMC Number Theory Camp
results.subtitle: PZ Math
results.description: PZMC Number Theory Camp is a residential program designed for mathematically gifted high school students who have completed or are currently enrolled in Algebra 2 or its equivalent. The primary focus of the experience is Number Theory and the art of mathematical thinking, where students learn to explore patterns, make conjectures, and prove their scientific results. Participants learn through a combination of interactive lectures, group problem-solving sessions, and final projects led by award-winning faculty. Beyond technical instruction, students are exposed to various areas of mathematics through guest colloquia and panel discussions exploring collegiate majors and careers in the field.

results.name: Jindal School of Management
results.title: Young Scholars Program
results.subtitle: The University of Texas at Dallas
results.description: The Young Scholars Program is a collaborative partnership between the Naveen Jindal School of Management at The University of Texas at Dallas and the Dallas Independent School District. Designed to support the academic, social, and emotional development of high school students, the initiative focuses on improving readiness for success in higher education and future careers. Participants have access to various resources including monthly informational sessions with experts, professional mentoring from university students and faculty, and free SAT and ACT test preparation. Additionally, eligible students who participate fully throughout high school may compete for a comprehensive scholarship to pursue a degree at the university. This program encourages students to establish the habits and skills needed for postsecondary success through campus visits and interaction with current university scholars.

results.name: ExploraVision
results.title: ExploraVision: A National Science Competition for High School Students & Middle School (K-12)
results.subtitle: Toshiba/NSTA
results.description: ExploraVision is a comprehensive national science competition for K-12 students across the United States and Canada that focuses on real-world problem solving and innovation. Students participate in teams of two to four under the guidance of a teacher or coach to research current technologies and envision their potential development ten or more years into the future. Each team must prepare a project submission consisting of a title, a detailed abstract, an eleven-page description, a bibliography, and five sample web pages illustrating their concept. This initiative encourages collaborative brainstorming and emphasizes proficiency in various fields related to science, technology, engineering, and mathematics. Successful participants have the opportunity to earn diverse awards ranging from savings bonds and electronic devices to national recognition and certificates of achievement.

results.name: Advanced Physics Summer Program
results.title: Advanced Physics Summer Program
results.subtitle: University of Maryland
results.description: The Advanced Physics Summer Program is designed for rising 9th through 12th graders interested in exploring high school and college-level physics topics. Participants engage in a variety of hands-on activities, including physics demonstrations, soldering, coding, and robotics. The curriculum introduces students to specialized subjects such as Einstein's thought experiments and modern code-breaking applications that are not typically covered in a standard high school classroom. Students also have the opportunity to visit cutting-edge research labs, speak with faculty and graduate students, and learn about diverse science career pathways through speaker panels and group discussions. The application process requires a thoughtful personal essay and a letter of recommendation from a science or math teacher to be considered for admission. This non-residential program includes skill-building projects and allows participants to meet current undergraduates while practicing new skills through relevant projects.

results.name: Music Technology & Production Camp
results.title: Music Technology and Production Camp
results.subtitle: Oregon State University
results.description: The Music Technology and Production Camp at Oregon State University is a one-week program designed for students aged 13 to 18 of all experience levels. Participants explore various approaches to music production through solo and collaborative projects, covering areas like songwriting, sound design, and effects processing. Throughout the week, each camper creates at least six different audio projects and has the opportunity to showcase original work in a culminating concert. The camp offers two distinct levels, including a beginner session focused on recording and beat creation, and an advanced session that incorporates studio recording and STEAM projects. Students can choose to attend as day campers or opt for a residential experience in the university's residence halls with provided meals.

results.name: Reconstructive Surgery Internship
results.title: STaRS Internship Program
results.subtitle: Stanford Medicine
results.description: The Science, Technology, and Reconstructive Surgery (STaRS) Summer Program provides exceptional students with an immersive research experience focused on the challenges and creativity of careers in healthcare. Interns work side-by-side with experienced clinician and scientist mentors to conduct hands-on biomedical research projects and master essential lab techniques such as histology, imaging, and genotyping. The curriculum features interactive lectures and skill-building workshops intended to guide participants on their first steps toward professional scientific careers. Applicants must be at least 16 years old and are required to submit a letter of recommendation for consideration. While the program seeks curious and tenacious individuals, prior laboratory experience is not a prerequisite for admission.

results.name: Summer Science & Engineering Program
results.title: Summer Science & Engineering Program
results.subtitle: Smith College
results.description: The Summer Science & Engineering Program is a selective residential experience designed for exceptional high school students entering grades 9 through 12 who possess strong interests in science and engineering. Participants engage in hands-on, lab-based courses led by faculty across various disciplines, including human genetics, robotics, chemistry, and neuroscience. The curriculum emphasizes an investigative approach where students work in small cooperative teams to conduct actual experiments and develop critical thinking skills. This learning environment provides access to faculty and undergraduate interns, helping participants understand college-level expectations in various scientific fields. Admissions are determined by academic achievement, a personal essay, and a teacher recommendation, ensuring a community of motivated students ready to tackle intensive scientific inquiry.

results.name: University of Delaware
results.title: Level Up Academics Summer Program
results.subtitle: University of Delaware
results.description: The Level Up Academics Summer Program is designed for high school students who wish to enhance their college readiness and leadership skills. Participants engage in coursework focused on academic writing, research development, and the creation of college entrance essays. The curriculum also integrates presentation skill-building and provides opportunities for students in IB programs to work toward their CAS requirements. Beyond classroom instruction, the program features social activities and excursions that foster an understanding of culture and allow for peer networking. Students who successfully complete the requirements receive a certificate of completion and a formal transcript showing their academic progress.

results.name: Research in Science & Engineering Program
results.title: RISE Internship/Practicum
results.subtitle: Boston University
results.description: The RISE Internship/Practicum is a highly selective six-week program designed for high school students entering their senior year who are US citizens or legal permanent residents. Participants can choose between two tracks, with Internship students conducting research in a university laboratory under a faculty mentor and Practicum students engaging in computational research focused on neurobiology or data science. The program includes weekly workshops covering scientific careers and college admissions, as well as site visits to explore the local biotechnology industry. Upon completion, all students receive a certificate of completion, and Practicum participants also obtain a letter of evaluation from their instructor. Admission is competitive and based on academic transcripts, standardized test scores, essays, and recommendations from STEM teachers or research supervisors.

results.name: User Experience Design
results.title: User Experience Design
results.subtitle: New York University
results.description: The User Experience Design summer program at New York University provides high school students with an intensive exploration of the intersection between art, design, and technology. Participants gain a foundational understanding of UX principles and best practices by applying design thinking to create solutions for various digital products and services. Students develop essential technical skills using industry-standard software such as Adobe Creative Cloud and Figma to build high-fidelity prototypes and interfaces. Through collaborative projects, the curriculum emphasizes user research, problem framing, and the synthesis of information to better understand stakeholder needs. This program is ideal for students interested in pursuing undergraduate majors in STEM, human-computer interaction, or creative applications of technology design.

results.name: Camp Arch
results.title: Camp ARCH
results.subtitle: Texas A&M University College of Architecture
results.description: Camp ARCH is an immersive summer program for high-achieving high school students that allows them to explore professional disciplines within the built environment. Participants spend a week attending stimulating classes led by renowned faculty and working on hands-on design projects that mirror professional studio settings. The curriculum offers focused tracks in architecture, construction science, landscape architecture, and urban planning, fostering skills in visualization, critical thinking, and collaborative problem-solving. Eligible incoming tenth, eleventh, and twelfth-grade students must complete a comprehensive application process involving a high school transcript, a video essay, and a letter of recommendation. The program fee covers dormitory accommodations, all meals, social activities, and necessary class supplies for every camper.

results.name: Urban Journalism Workshop
results.title: NYU Urban Journalism Workshop
results.subtitle: New York University
results.description: The NYU Urban Journalism Workshop is a free, non-credit program designed to develop the next generation of journalists by equipping high school students with essential skills. Participants receive hands-on training in reporting, news writing, and multimedia journalism under the guidance of university faculty and visiting professionals. The curriculum includes professional site visits to major newsrooms such as the New York Times and CNN, culminating in the production of an online multimedia news site called The Spectrum. Eligible students must be at least sixteen years old and reside in the tri-state area. Additionally, the program offers valuable insights into the college admissions process and provides a residential experience where students live in campus dormitories.

results.name: University of Maryland

deadlines.label: Accessibility and Disability Service Request Deadline

results.title: Terp Young Scholars
results.subtitle: University of Maryland
results.description: Terp Young Scholars is a competitive academic program designed for high school students ranging from rising sophomores to graduating seniors who wish to experience the rigors of university life. Participants enroll in one three-credit course, where they attend classes, work on specialized projects, and interact with faculty and undergraduate students to earn credits that are recorded on an official transcript. The program offers two distinct learning paths, allowing students to choose between a commuter-based campus experience or a fully online instructional format. To be eligible for admission, applicants must be at least 13 years old and maintain a minimum unweighted academic average of 3.0. This immersive experience helps students discover new fields of study while providing a jump-start on their college careers through intense academic inquiry and professional faculty engagement.

results.name: Math Academy

deadlines.label: Rolling admission for any remaining open slots

results.title: Prove it! Math Academy
results.subtitle: Colorado State University
results.description: Prove it! Math Academy is a residential mathematics program designed for motivated and talented high school students looking to transition from computational math to proof-based competition and research. The curriculum emphasizes mathematical rigor and proof-writing skills within a problem-solving context to prepare participants for advanced contests and university-level study. Eligible applicants must be currently attending high school in the United States or Canada and generally fall between the ages of 14 and 18. The admission process requires students to complete a challenging admissions test and submit an online application for consideration by the expert instructors. Tuition for the program covers dormitory accommodations, meals, instruction, and various educational field trips.

decisions_date.label: You will be notified of your admission status by

results.name: Summer Camp
results.title: Summer Camps
results.subtitle: Bellisario College of Communications
results.description: The Bellisario College of Communications offers high school students between the ages of 14 and 18 the opportunity to participate in fully immersive, hands-on summer camps focused on various media disciplines. Participants can choose from five distinct tracks including Broadcast Journalism, Film Production, Podcasting, Social Media and Content Creator, and Visual Storytelling. Students reside in campus housing and work in a state-of-the-art media center while learning from university faculty and experienced industry professionals who provide expert mentorship. Throughout the program, campers engage in practical activities such as producing news stories in professional studios, planning film projects, and creating professional-quality audio features. This experience allows aspiring creators to build a network of peers and develop marketable skills across a broad variety of modern communications fields.

results.name: Summer Music Clinic

deadlines.label: Summer Music Clinic and Summer Arts Clinic Payment Deadline
Other Summer Programs Payment Deadline (First Half)
Other Summer Programs Payment Deadline (Second Half)

results.title: Summer Music Clinic
results.subtitle: UNIVERSITY of WISCONSIN-MADISON
results.description: The Summer Music Clinic provides middle and high school students with an immersive week-long experience focused on artistic growth and creative expression. Participants can choose from specialized paths such as Band, Choir, Orchestra, Piano, and Modern Expressions, with further opportunities to explore electives like jazz, music theory, and musical theatre. The program offers both residential and daily commuter options, allowing students to experience campus life through housing in residence halls or by attending during daytime hours. Instruction is led by experienced music professionals and educators who guide students through a challenging yet supportive curriculum that culminates in final performances. Limited need-based scholarships are available for eligible students, and applications are typically accepted on a rolling basis during the spring semester.

results.name: Center for English Language and Orientation Programs

program_dates.label: AIM Session 2 Residential (Medicine, Business, & Creative Writing)
AIM Session 2 Commuter (Medicine, Business, & Creative Writing)

results.title: Pre-College And Youth Summer Programs
results.subtitle: Boston University
results.description: The Pre-College and Youth Summer Programs provide middle and high school students with the opportunity to explore academic interests and gain valuable experience through intensive study. High school students entering their junior or senior year can choose from programs such as Academic Immersion, which offers deep dives into medicine, psychology, creative writing, or business, or High School Honors, where they can earn college credits. The Summer Challenge program is also available for rising sophomores, juniors, and seniors to engage in project-based seminars and an informative admissions workshop. These programs feature a mix of classroom learning, experiential activities like simulations and lab work, and organized social events that help students build new connections. Participants have the choice between residential and commuter tracks while benefiting from the institution's world-class faculty and specialized academic resources.

results.name: W. P. Carey School of Business

deadlines.label: Final deadline to apply to be considered

results.title: ASU Fleischer Scholars Program
results.subtitle: Arizona State University
results.description: The ASU Fleischer Scholars Program is a free pre-college initiative designed for Arizona high school juniors seeking to enhance their strategic thinking and leadership capabilities. Participants engage in virtual workshops focused on academic success, career opportunities, and financial literacy through the specialized Building Your Mental Balance Sheet curriculum. Student selection is based on several factors including involvement in community service, academic performance with a minimum 3.0 GPA, and demonstrated financial need. This transformative experience provides admitted students with early access to university staff and alumni connections to help them navigate the college admission and scholarship process. The program ultimately aims to empower future leaders to graduate and invest their skills back into their local communities.

results.name: Cooper Union

deadlines.label: Early Decision - The Albert Nerken School of Engineering
Early Decision - The School of Art and The Irwin S. Chanin School of Architecture

results.title: Service Scholars
results.subtitle: The Cooper Union
results.description: Service Scholars is a leadership and community service internship program designed for high school students in their sophomore or junior years. Participants must have prior experience in an out-of-school STEM enrichment program to be eligible for this specialized opportunity. The curriculum includes learning engineering through a dedicated class alongside leadership and skill-building workshops. Students collaborate with collegiate mentors on community service projects at various partner sites to apply design and engineering principles to real-world issues. Successful participants benefit from professional development, communication skill improvement, and a stipend with a full fee waiver for their studies.

results.name: XR Through Virtual Worlds

deadlines.label: XR Through Virtual Worlds Preferred Deadline
XR Through Virtual Worlds Final Application Deadline

program_dates.label: XR Through Virtual Worlds Session 1 Orientation
XR Through Virtual Worlds Session 1 Program
XR Through Virtual Worlds Session 2 Orientation
XR Through Virtual Worlds Session 2 Program

results.title: XR Through Virtual Worlds
results.subtitle: New York University
results.description: XR Through Virtual Worlds is a two-week program that introduces high school students in grades 9 through 11 to the fundamentals of designing and developing augmented reality experiences. Participants gain practical skills in development using Unity and ARCore while learning to build immersive user experiences and user-friendly interfaces. The curriculum covers both marker and markerless prototypes, the use of open-source 3-D models, and best practices in design research and usability testing. Competitive applicants must have a minimum 3.0 GPA, have completed Algebra 2, and possess some computer programming experience in any language. Students work collaboratively on daily assignments and weekly projects and have the opportunity to engage in organized social activities to connect with peers from around the world who share their intellectual curiosity.

results.name: STEM + M Connect

program_dates.label: Mini-Med School / Lab Science Investigations Session 2 (Residential)

results.title: STEM+M CONNECT Program
results.subtitle: Tufts University School of Medicine
results.description: The STEM+M CONNECT Program offers highly motivated high school students a unique one-month summer experience that combines a residential pre-college track with a multi-tiered mentoring program. Participants can choose to focus on Mini-Med School or Lab Science Investigations, engaging in hands-on activities such as microbiology labs, clinical simulations, and anatomy dissections. The curriculum includes five key strands focusing on relationship building, professional life skills, diversity in STEM fields, and scientific review sessions. Students work closely with undergraduate mentors and Tufts faculty to build professional networks while completing a filmmaking or research-based capstone project. This paid initiative is specifically designed to support first-generation college students and those from low-income backgrounds by providing a full scholarship for housing and meals along with a significant completion stipend.

results.name: Principles of Engineering

program_dates.label: D&D: Adventures on the Astral sea
Teen Med Camp 2: Beyond the Basics Session 1
Teen Med Camp 2: Beyond the Basics Session 2
D&D: Escapades in the city of Waterdeep

results.title: Summer Camps: High School
results.subtitle: The University of Texas at Arlington
results.description: The University of Texas at Arlington offers a diverse array of summer camps for high school students in grades 9 through 12 through its Kids & Teens University program. Participants can engage in specialized academic and creative subjects, including analogue photography using pinhole cameras, collaborative storytelling in Dungeons & Dragons, and foundational medical concepts in Teen Med Camp. Additional sessions provide hands-on experience in the principles of engineering, 3D printing techniques within the Fab Lab, and the professional process of publishing a book. These programs are designed to foster personal growth, teamwork, and critical thinking while helping students explore potential career paths in STEM, the arts, and healthcare. Enrollment is managed through an online portal where parents register using their child's name, and full refunds are available for requests made at least two weeks prior to the camp start date.

results.name: Apprenticeship Program
results.title: Science and Engineering Apprenticeship Program (SEAP)
results.subtitle: Office of Naval Research
results.description: The Science and Engineering Apprenticeship Program (SEAP) places high school students in Department of Navy laboratories where they take part in real Naval research for eight weeks. This competitive program is designed for academically talented sophomores, juniors, and seniors who demonstrate interest and ability in science and engineering. Selected interns receive first-class mentoring from top scientists and engineers while learning about Naval research and technology. Participants are chosen based on academic achievement, personal statements, recommendations, and research interests, and they receive a stipend for the duration of the apprenticeship.

decisions_date.label: Award and Non-Award Letters Sent Out

results.name: ISEF Competition
results.title: Regeneron International Science and Engineering Fair
results.subtitle: Society for Science
results.description: The Regeneron International Science and Engineering Fair is a research-based high school competition that serves as a premier global stage for students in grades 9-12. To participate, students must first compete in a Society-affiliated science fair and earn the opportunity to present their independent research across 22 different scientific categories. Finalists at this prestigious event compete for nearly $9 million in awards, prizes, and scholarships, with work evaluated by approximately 1,000 science and engineering professionals. All participants must adhere to strict international rules and guidelines designed to ensure scientific integrity, safety, and ethical research practices. This competition provides a unique platform for young innovators to showcase their inventions while connecting with professional organizations and industry experts.

results.name: Engineering Possibilities in College

deadlines.label: Early admission offer acceptance or decline
Regular admission offer acceptance or decline
All required material electronically signed and submitted

results.title: Engineering Possibilities in College (EPIC)
results.subtitle: California Polytechnic State University
results.description: Engineering Possibilities in College (EPIC) is a one-week residential summer camp for students in grades 6-11 that introduces them to various engineering fields through hands-on labs taught by university professors and industry professionals. Participants explore diverse disciplines such as aerospace, biomedical, civil, and software engineering by engaging in labs where they design, build, and test their own projects. Campers experience life on a university campus and learn about advanced developments like satellites, prosthetic hands, and autonomous robots from student mentors. The curriculum includes a speaker series featuring industry experts and admissions panels, along with an engineering design team project and a variety of social activities. Acceptance is based on a student essay and academic performance, with scholarship opportunities available to support female, first-generation, and low-income students interested in pursuing engineering career paths.

decisions_date.label: Early admission decision notifications go out / Online application closes
Regular admission decision notifications go out

results.name: Self-Paced Program
results.title: Girls Who Code
results.subtitle: Girls Who Code
results.description: Girls Who Code invites individuals to join a massive community of over 670,000 participants dedicated to computer science. The organization offers specific pathways for both adult and student learners who are interested in developing their technical skills. To participate in the network, individuals must be at least thirteen years of age when signing up for updates and resources. The program focuses on fostering a global community through its digital platform and various educational offerings.

results.name: CBI
results.title: High School Research Internship
results.subtitle: University of Notre Dame
results.description: The High School Research Internship program provides local high school juniors and seniors with the opportunity to earn high school credit by conducting research in a university laboratory. Participants work closely with graduate or postdoctoral student research mentors within various STEM-focused faculty labs to gain hands-on experience and develop skills for future collegiate success. In addition to their lab work, students attend weekly group classes to engage in discussions regarding research findings and explore relevant college preparation topics. The program aims to foster a professional identity in STEM fields and increase student confidence through a deeper understanding of complex scientific topics. Since its inception, the initiative has grown to include several partner schools and organizations while expanding its research scope beyond energy-related projects.

results.name: Young Scholars Research
results.title: Young Scholars Summer STEMM Research Programs
results.subtitle: University of Illinois Urbana-Champaign
results.description: The Young Scholars Summer STEMM Research Programs offer rising 10th through 12th graders from selected Midwestern states an authentic six-week research experience at a world-class university. Participants engage in hands-on activities within cutting-edge fields such as bioengineering, artificial intelligence, neuroscience, and physics while working alongside faculty and graduate student mentors. Beyond laboratory work, student researchers attend weekly professional development seminars focused on college readiness, scientific communication, and the creation of research posters for a final symposium. As an IDEA initiative aimed at broadening participation, the program provides housing, meals, and a monetary award to all selected scholars at no cost to the participants.

results.name: Research Apprentice Program
results.title: High School Student Research Apprentice Program
results.subtitle: UConn Health
results.description: The High School Student Research Apprentice Program provides eleventh-grade students with a unique five-week summer research experience in basic science or clinical laboratories. This initiative is tailored for individuals interested in medicine, dental medicine, or biomedical research and offers an earned stipend for successful completion. Applicants must be Connecticut residents who have finished their junior year with a 'B' average or better and are at least 16 years old by the program's start. Priority consideration is given to pipeline participants, particularly those who are first-generation college, low-income, or educationally under-resourced. The application process requires submitting a completed form, official transcripts, two letters of recommendation with at least one from a science teacher, and federal income tax documentation.

results.name: Research Internships
results.title: Research Internships and Observation for High School Students
results.subtitle: Penn State College of Medicine
results.description: The Research Internships and Observation for High School Students program at the Penn State College of Medicine provides opportunities for students to engage in short-term shadowing or long-term internships within a laboratory setting. Participants must be living in the United States and are responsible for identifying their own prospective faculty supervisor through the institution's research networking directory before submitting an application. The program offers both paid and unpaid experiences where students receive professional instruction while adhering to strict safety guidelines regarding hazardous materials and laboratory conduct. To ensure a safe environment, all activities require the presence of two adults at all times, and students must complete mandatory training and background clearance documentation before starting their work. Applicants must submit a completed application form and insurance documentation to be considered for these supervised research experiences.

results.name: WVU
results.title: Brain Camp
results.subtitle: West Virginia University
results.description: Brain Camp is an immersive co-ed summer experience designed for high school students entering the 11th and 12th grades to explore the field of neuroscience. Participants engage in hands-on activities, presentations, and demonstrations led by university faculty and graduate students covering topics such as neuroanatomy, addiction, stroke, and human neuro-psych testing. The curriculum delves into advanced areas including neurophysiological assessments, motion capture, and computer simulations of the human body while emphasizing the scientific process and research ethics. This residential program limits enrollment to 36 students on a first-come, first-served basis and provides a comprehensive package that includes housing, meals, transportation, and social evening programs. Limited financial aid is available upon request to help ensure the program remains accessible to a diverse group of aspiring scientists.

results.name: High School Internship Program
results.title: Summer High School Internship Program
results.subtitle: Fred Hutchinson Cancer Center
results.description: The Summer High School Internship Program (SHIP) is a competitive, full-time paid opportunity specifically designed for students entering their senior year of high school who have not yet had extensive research experience. Participants begin the eight-week experience with two weeks of intensive hands-on training covering fundamental laboratory techniques, safety protocols, and an introduction to scientific inquiry. Following the initial training, interns are paired and immersed within a professional research group to engage in mentored scientific activities and attend seminars led by established scientists. The program also incorporates professional development workshops focused on college and career readiness, alongside social activities to build a cohort community. The internship concludes with formal presentations where students share their findings with researchers, family, and friends.

results.name: Gerard K. O’Neill Space Settlement Contest
results.title: NSS Gerard K. O’Neill Space Settlement Contest
results.subtitle: National Space Society
results.description: The NSS Gerard K. O’Neill Space Settlement Contest, sponsored by the National Space Society, challenges students to develop and submit projects focused on the creation of permanent space settlements. Participants are required to design orbital habitats that serve as generational homes rather than temporary outposts, focusing on free space environments rather than planetary surfaces. The competition accepts a wide variety of submission formats, including technical designs, original research, essays, models, and artwork. All entries must be entirely student-produced, though instructors and mentors may provide guidance on core concepts and resources. The contest enforces strict guidelines regarding academic integrity, requiring explicit citation for any AI-generated components and limiting most primary submissions to a maximum of fifty pages.

results.name: Summer Academy
results.title: Meta Summer Academy 2024
results.subtitle: Meta
results.description: The Meta Summer Academy 2024 is an educational program that provides students with foundational knowledge and experience within a professional environment. Candidates utilize an online portal to complete their applications and submit necessary documentation for review by the program's evaluators. The application system includes features for users to manage their work, save progress, and receive confirmation once their submission is successfully locked. This initiative aims to engage participants in a structured summer experience focused on growth and learning within the technology sector.

results.name: Media & Sports Academy
results.title: High School Summer Discovery
results.subtitle: UCLA Anderson School of Management
results.description: High school students in grades 9-12 can explore future careers through the High School Summer Discovery program, which offers four intensive academies focused on sports business, digital marketing, music business innovation, and the media industry. Participants engage in hands-on learning taught by experienced university instructors and industry experts, moving beyond traditional lectures to master 21st-century skills like teamwork and communication. The curriculum covers essential business frameworks, including finance, strategy, and economics, supplemented by real-world case studies and site visits to major organizations. Students have the option of residential or commuter enrollment for sessions lasting two, three, or five weeks, culminating in a final team project and the receipt of a Certificate of Completion.

results.name: Stanford E-China Program
results.title: Stanford Pre-Collegiate Global Learning
results.subtitle: Stanford Program on International and Cross-Cultural Education (SPICE) at Stanford University
results.description: The Stanford Pre-Collegiate Global Learning program offers distance-learning courses conducted by the Stanford Program on International and Cross-Cultural Education (SPICE). These courses are designed for high school students located in the United States, Japan, and China who are interested in international and cross-cultural education. Since its inception in 2003, the program has provided students with the opportunity to engage in rigorous academic study from a distance. Prospective applicants are encouraged to review specific course descriptions and eligibility requirements to find the curriculum that best fits their interests. The application process is managed online, requiring students to register and complete their submissions through the dedicated site portal.

results.name: FinDS Summer Program
results.title: FinDS
results.subtitle: UC San Diego
results.description: FinDS is a three-week summer program designed to provide high school students with a strong foundation in the mathematical principles underlying data science. The curriculum is divided into two tracks, offering a Beginner’s level for those with an Algebra 2 background and an Advanced track covering complex topics in algorithms and machine learning. Students explore essential subjects such as probability, graph theory, calculus, and linear algebra under the guidance of world-renowned professors from multiple top-tier universities. Admission requires a formal application consisting of a personal statement, unofficial transcripts, and a letter of recommendation from a STEM teacher. While tuition fees are required for participants, financial assistance and generous scholarships from the National Science Foundation are available to those with justified need.

results.name: Design, Invent & Innovate
results.title: Design, Invent & Innovate (DII)
results.subtitle: New York University
results.description: Design, Invent & Innovate (DII) is a two-week, full-day summer program open to high school students in grades 9 through 12 who have completed Algebra 2 and have prior computer programming experience. Competitive applicants typically maintain a minimum 3.0 GPA and are interested in learning fundamental principles of innovation in science and engineering. Participants gain hands-on experience at NYU Tandon's Makerspace, where they learn to use rapid prototyping tools and computer-aided design (CAD) modeling to build solutions for real-world problems. The curriculum focuses on teaching transferable engineering skills through the study of historical and contemporary examples in fields like medicine and electronics. Students engage in fieldwork to identify societal challenges and ultimately present their final inventions and working prototypes to their peers. This non-credit program offers both residential and commuter tracks, allowing attendees to participate in campus activities and connect with a global community of scholars.

results.name: High School Conservatory
results.title: AMDA
results.subtitle: AMDA
results.description: AMDA provides students with an intensive immersion into the world of performing arts through various training programs. Participants can choose from different artistic disciplines such as acting, dance, and musical theatre to refine their performance techniques. The program features instruction from experienced industry professionals and Broadway veterans who offer insight into the entertainment field. Students engage in a rigorous schedule of workshops and rehearsals designed to develop audition skills and prepare them for professional careers.

results.name: WISE Summer College
results.title: Summer College
results.subtitle: UVA Wise
results.description: UVA Wise offers more than 30 summer courses designed to help students complete general education requirements or fulfill elective needs across two distinct sessions. These courses are open to both current UVA Wise students and non-degree seeking individuals, including those from other institutions. Classes are taught by full-time faculty and maintain small enrollment sizes, typically between 12 to 15 students, to provide personalized individual guidance. Participants may register for up to 14 total credits across the summer term, with academic departments providing instruction in diverse fields such as natural sciences, business, and performing arts. Registration for non-degree students is available through a streamlined online application process that requires choosing the appropriate student status.

results.name: Fordham University
results.title: Summer Leaders Academy
results.subtitle: Fordham
results.description: Fordham's Summer Leaders Academy is an immersive pre-college program designed for rising high school sophomores, juniors, and seniors to engage in innovative academic coursework and professional development. Participants can choose from a wide range of immersion tracks covering STEM, business, the arts, and social sciences, with options to earn college credit available for eligible seniors. Beyond academics, the program provides comprehensive college application preparation, including admission strategies and essay writing techniques, alongside career exploration insights into fields like law and medicine. Students can choose between residential and commuter options, both of which offer access to state-of-the-art facilities and organized excursions to cultural landmarks. The curriculum emphasizes the development of leadership, communication, and problem-solving skills rooted in the Jesuit tradition of service to others.

results.name: Neuroscience Internship

deadlines.label: Harris Neuroscience Internship Letter of Recommendation Deadline
Stanford Neuroscience Journal Club Application Period

results.title: The Harris Neuroscience Internship
results.subtitle: Stanford Medicine
results.description: The Harris Neuroscience Internship is a program designed for high school students within the United States who have an interest in exploring careers in neuroscience and neurosurgery. Participants engage in various educational components including weekly Grand Rounds, a virtual Neuroscience Journal Club, and a scholarly project of their choice to increase their field-specific knowledge. Students also participate in community-based projects that promote increased engagement and exposure within the neurosciences. Applicants must secure a letter of recommendation from a math or science teacher and go through a formal application process to be considered for this competitive opportunity founded by Dr. Odette Harris.

results.name: Senate Page Program
results.title: U.S. SENATE PAGE PROGRAM
results.subtitle: United States Senate
results.description: The United States Senate Page Program introduces high school students from diverse backgrounds to the legislative process through a hands-on experience within the federal government. Selected pages play a vital role in daily operations by delivering legislative materials, preparing the Chamber for sessions, and assisting senators during floor debates and roll call votes. Applicants must be 16 or 17 years old, maintain a minimum 3.0 GPA, and obtain sponsorship from a senator to be considered for a position. Participants are paid on an annual salary basis, live in shared residential housing during the school year, and must adhere to a rigorous schedule that includes mandatory school sessions and a strict code of conduct. This competitive program emphasizes personal responsibility and time management while providing unique access to prominent national leaders and historical political debates.

results.name: Summer Theatre Institute

program_dates.label: High School Honors Residential Program starts
High School Honors Classes begin; residential and commuter orientation
High School Honors Classes & program end

results.title: Pre-College And Youth Summer Programs
results.subtitle: Boston University
results.description: Boston University offers a variety of pre-college and youth summer programs designed for middle and high school students to explore academic interests and gain valuable experience. High school juniors and seniors can participate in the Academic Immersion program, which focuses on subjects like medicine, psychology, business, and creative writing through a combination of classroom work and experiential activities. The High School Honors program allows students to earn up to eight college credits by taking undergraduate courses alongside university students, while the Summer Challenge program provides rising sophomores, juniors, and seniors with a two-week exploration of diverse seminars and college admissions workshops. Additional offerings include specialized institutes in performing and visual arts, STEM-focused research internships, and recreational camps for younger students. These programs are available in residential, commuter, and sometimes online formats, providing participants with opportunities to build new friendships and gain insight into potential career paths.

results.name: Summer Session
results.title: Pre-College Students
results.subtitle: Yale University
results.description: Yale Summer Session invites motivated high school juniors and seniors to enroll in rigorous undergraduate courses alongside current college students. Participants must be at least 16 years of age and are held to the same high academic standards as all Yale students while earning college credit. The application process requires an online form, high school transcripts with at least 2.5 years of grades, and two letters of recommendation from teachers or counselors. Students choosing in-person study are required to live on campus in residential colleges, where they receive support from Yale undergraduate residential counselors and must adhere to specific safety regulations. While standardized test scores are optional under a test-flexible policy, applicants are encouraged to submit them to provide additional insight into their academic background.

results.name: AIM Summer Program

deadlines.label: Session Registration and Scholarship Application Deadline
Tuition Payment and Enrollment Paperwork Due

results.title: AIM Summer Program
results.subtitle: Coast Guard Academy
results.description: The AIM Summer Program is a one-week orientation exclusively for students entering their senior year of high school who are interested in serving their country. Participants immerse themselves in Academy life through six nonstop days of rigorous mental and physical challenges, including academic study, competitive activities, and military training. The program offers both on-campus sessions with a tuition fee of $750 and a free virtual session consisting of two full days of programming with admissions officers and current cadets. Eligible applicants must be U.S. citizens between ages 16 and 18, and they are required to submit high school transcripts and a guidance counselor recommendation by the April 1st deadline. During the experience, attendees explore various academic majors such as engineering and government while discovering if they have the fortitude necessary to succeed at the service academy level.

results.name: Engineering Discovery for Girls
results.title: Engineering Discovery for Girls
results.subtitle: Oklahoma State University
results.description: Aspiring engineers and tomorrow’s problem solvers are invited to participate in this extraordinary residential camp hosted by the College of Engineering, Architecture and Technology. The program is geared toward rising 9th through 12th-grade students and is open to all participants regardless of gender. Participants engage in a week of learning through hands-on activities, exploration of significant engineering projects, and collaborative group problem-solving. The experience also emphasizes networking with peers and includes evening functions and activities designed for young, forward-thinking individuals who want to discover what engineering can do for them.

results.name: UPRISE
results.title: Understanding Power, Resisting Injustice, Summer Experience (UPRISE)
results.subtitle: UMass Lowell
results.description: Rising high school juniors and seniors can participate in UPRISE, a three-week summer program designed to help students become effective agents of social change while earning college credit. Participants spend the first two weeks engaging in on-campus learning led by faculty from the Department of Sociology and Labor Studies, followed by a final week of group project collaboration and faculty meetings. Students attend classes with experts on issues like climate change, reproductive rights, and union organizing to develop the analytical tools needed to understand social problems and the skills to resist injustice. Upon completion, students earn three credits for the SOCI.1150 Social Problems course and present their group work at a formal showcase for the university community and families.

results.name: College Prep Program

deadlines.label: Scholarship Deadline (College Prep and Summer College)

results.title: College Prep Program
results.subtitle: Georgetown University
results.description: The College Prep Program is a five-week credit-bearing experience designed for current high school students from 9th to 12th grade who maintain at least a 3.0 GPA. Participants enroll in undergraduate courses from a curated list of subjects, studying alongside university students to earn official college credit. In addition to coursework, students must attend College Prep Seminars focused on SAT and ACT test-taking strategies led by Capital Educators, as well as workshops on the college search and admissions process. The program offers both residential and commuter formats, providing access to the University Writing Center and optional application assistance workshops for rising seniors. Successful students receive a Certificate of Participation upon completion of the required seminars and academic coursework.

results.name: City of Rochester

program_dates.label: ROC Your Job After School Employment Program

results.title: Summer of Opportunity Program (SOOP)
results.subtitle: City of Rochester, New York
results.description: The Summer of Opportunity Program (SOOP) provides youth between the ages of 14 and 20 with paid work experience and skill-building opportunities through diverse internships. Participants gain real-world exposure by working with organizations across the public, private, faith-based, and not-for-profit sectors within the community. The program requires a six-week commitment where students work up to 20 hours per week and are referred to interviews based on a two-step online application process. Eligibility is based on residency within the city, regardless of school enrollment type or family income level. Applicants must provide essential documentation, including a work permit, Social Security Card, valid photo identification, and a recent official report card to be considered for placement.

results.name: Ladders for Leaders

deadlines.label: NYC Ladders for Leaders Application Deadline

results.title: Ladders for Leaders
results.subtitle: Department of Youth & Community Development
results.description: Ladders for Leaders is a competitive professional internship program designed for high school juniors, seniors, and college students between the ages of 16 and 24. As a component of the Summer Youth Employment Program, this initiative matches job-ready applicants with paid summer internships at leading corporations, non-profit organizations, and government agencies. To qualify, participants must demonstrate prior paid or volunteer work experience and be legally allowed to work in the United States. The program includes up to 30 hours of mandatory pre-employment training covering resume preparation, interview techniques, business etiquette, and financial literacy. Interns work between 25 and 40 hours per week for a duration of six weeks, earning a minimum of $16.50 per hour while gaining access to an extensive professional alumni network.

results.name: University of Minnesota

deadlines.label: M-ASCEND Undergraduate Summer Internship Application Deadline
M-ASCEND Undergraduate Summer Internship Letters of Recommendation Deadline

results.title: Minnesota Advancing Science and Cancer Education Discoveries (M-ASCEND)
results.subtitle: University of Minnesota
results.description: The Minnesota Advancing Science and Cancer Education Discoveries (M-ASCEND) program provides a comprehensive pathway for students and educators to explore cancer-focused research and health equity. High school participants from partner schools engage in academic-year programming and a paid summer internship that combines laboratory work with community service-learning. Undergraduate students receive a nine-week, full-time paid position conducting hands-on research under the guidance of academic mentors while participating in professional development seminars and mentoring younger students. Furthermore, the program offers science teachers intensive lab experiences designed to help them build robust science curricula for their high school students. All participants are matched with mentors and attend workshops focused on career readiness, clinical pathways, and the root causes of health disparities.

results.name: Summer Session
results.title: Credit Course Options
results.subtitle: Summer Session
results.description: Duke University's Summer Session allows current 10th and 11th grade students to earn undergraduate college credit by enrolling in various courses across the arts and sciences. To be eligible, applicants must meet a minimum age requirement by the start of the term and be prepared for the academic rigor of studying alongside undergraduate college students. The program offers flexible learning formats, including online courses for international or remote students and commuter options for local residents, though on-campus housing is not available for high school participants. Interested students must complete an online application process that requires a resume, personal statement, high school transcripts, English proficiency scores if applicable, and an application fee. Admitted participants are responsible for tuition and a one-time transcript fee that provides unlimited lifetime access to their official records.

results.name: Biomedical Research Lectures

program_dates.label: Week 4: Careers in Science and Medicine

results.title: Stanford EXPLORE Lecture Series
results.subtitle: Stanford School of Medicine
results.description: The Stanford EXPLORE Lecture Series is an exploratory program for high school students designed to cover fundamental concepts and current research in various biomedical fields. Participants engage in lectures led by faculty, graduate students, and postdoctoral fellows that mirror the collegiate academic experience. The curriculum focuses on diverse specialties including immunology, neuroscience, regenerative medicine, cancer biology, bioengineering, and bioinformatics. Eligible applicants must be U.S. citizens or permanent residents currently in grades 9 through 12 who have completed at least one year of high school biology with strong academic performance in science courses. The program offers both in-person and virtual participation formats, though students must commit to a minimum of two weeks of the series. Financial aid opportunities are specifically available for the online version of the program to assist students who lack the means to pay course fees.

results.name: Discover Architecture
results.title: Discover Architecture
results.subtitle: School of Architecture
results.description: Discover Architecture is a one-week intensive residential program designed for aspiring architects from across the nation and beyond. Open to rising high school sophomores through seniors, the program provides a studio-focused workshop where participants explore introductory drawing, sketching, and modeling. Participants engage in hands-on exercises such as creating folded paper modules, drafting 1:1 scale floor plans with tape, and building spaghetti bridges to test structural truss design. The curriculum includes field trips to significant architectural landmarks and concludes with an exhibition of student work. The comprehensive program fee includes lodging and meals, and financial assistance is available through the Kenneth Jacobs Memorial Scholarship for eligible applicants.

results.name: Medicine Summer Research Program
results.title: Stanford Institutes of Medicine Summer Research Program
results.subtitle: Stanford Medicine
results.description: The Stanford Institutes of Medicine Summer Research Program (SIMR) is an eight-week initiative that invites high school juniors and seniors to perform hands-on basic research on medically-oriented projects. Participants work under the guidance of faculty and postdoctoral mentors to understand the scientific process while increasing their interest in biological sciences. The program requires a commitment of approximately 40 hours per week, consisting of lab work, morning lectures, and a final poster session where students present their findings to the community. Eligibility is restricted to U.S. citizens or permanent residents who are at least 16 years old and currently attending high school in the United States. While a standard application fee applies, there is no cost to attend the program once selected, and limited need-based stipends are available for those with demonstrated financial need.

results.name: Fordham University

deadlines.label: Last day for non-matriculated student registration for Summer Session I

results.title: College Courses For High School Students
results.subtitle: Fordham University
results.description: The College Courses For High School Students program at Fordham University is a selective initiative designed for rising high school seniors with a cumulative G.P.A. of 3.0 or better. Participants enroll in one credit-bearing undergraduate course alongside current college students, with options available for both in-person and online study. The application process requires an unofficial transcript, an academic writing sample with citations, and a seventy-five dollar deposit that is credited toward enrollment upon acceptance. Students can choose from a variety of subjects including biology, chemistry, computer science, and business, and those accepted must confirm their intent to enroll through a tuition deposit. This program provides secondary students with valuable college experience and connections while earning credits that typically transfer easily to other institutions.

results.name: Summer Session

deadlines.label: High School Early Decision submission deadline
High School Regular Decision submission deadline
High School Late Application submission deadline
University Level Early Decision submission deadline
University Level Regular Decision and Merit-based Tuition Grant deadline
International Applicant (needing an I-20) submission deadline
University Level Rolling Admission submission deadline

results.title: Summer Session
results.subtitle: Stanford University
results.description: Stanford Summer Session provides high-achieving and ambitious students with a transformative educational experience at a world-class university. The program offers foundational core courses and specialized classes from over thirty departments, including areas such as natural sciences, computer science, engineering, and social sciences. Students can choose to live on campus or commute while participating in a rich array of extra-curricular programming designed to foster global responsibility and academic excellence. Academic support is readily available through the Summer Academic Resource Center, which provides tutoring and advising to help participants succeed throughout their studies. Students also have the unique opportunity to delve into entrepreneurship and problem-solving methodologies while learning alongside regular university undergraduates and visiting students from around the world.

results.name: Summer Session
results.title: Summer Session
results.subtitle: University of Maryland
results.description: Summer Session at the University of Maryland allows students to make academic progress and earn college credits through flexible three- or six-week sessions. The program offers courses in multiple delivery formats, including in-person and online options, to accommodate current, incoming, former, and visiting students. Participants can complete major or General Education requirements, explore high-demand courses via a wish list system, or engage in special programs like the Summer Language Institutes. While current university students can simply register, all other students must first complete an application process to participate in these credit-bearing opportunities. Additional offerings include pre-college opportunities for high schoolers, such as Terp Young Scholars and various K-12 non-credit summer camps.

results.name: Doodle Competition
results.title: Doodle for Google
results.subtitle: Google
results.description: Doodle for Google is an annual student art contest open to K-12 students across the United States. Participants are invited to create an original Doodle for a chance to have their artwork featured on the google.com homepage. The competition offers significant rewards, including a $55,000 college scholarship for the winner and a $50,000 technology package for their school. Now in its 17th year, this initiative celebrates culture, holidays, and heroes through creative expression. Past winners of the contest have leveraged this opportunity to transition into careers as professional artists.

results.name: Emerging Scholars Academy

deadlines.label: Early Action and University Honors Program Priority Deadline
Early Action Major Change Request Deadline
Spring Admissions Major Change Request Deadline
Regular Decision Major Change Request Deadline
Final Dual Enrollment College Transcript Submission Deadline

results.title: Pre-College Programs
results.subtitle: NC State University
results.description: NC State University offers pre-college programs designed for students of all ages to develop academic skills and prepare for college enrollment. Participants have the opportunity to conduct research, investigate potential career paths, and build professional portfolios while experiencing college life. The university provides diverse programming across various disciplines, including STEM, agriculture, business, design, education, and the social sciences. Specific opportunities mentioned include the Summer Textile Exploration Program and VetCAMP, which is a multi-day summer camp specifically for high school students interested in veterinary medicine. These programs aim to provide students with hands-on experience and a foundation for future academic success by allowing them to explore various academic colleges and departments.

results.name: Management & Technology Summer Institute
results.title: MANAGEMENT & TECHNOLOGY SUMMER INSTITUTE
results.subtitle: The University of Pennsylvania
results.description: The Management & Technology Summer Institute (M&TSI) is a rigorous for-credit summer program for rising high school seniors and select juniors interested in integrating technological concepts with management principles. Hosted by the Jerome Fisher Program in Management & Technology in partnership with Penn Engineering and the Wharton School, the curriculum features classes taught by leading faculty and successful entrepreneurs. Participants engage in intensive team prototyping projects where they develop a go-to-market plan for a high-tech venture and present it to seasoned investors for feedback. Attendees gain hands-on experience through industry-led simulations and receive one full college credit from the School of Engineering and Applied Sciences upon successful completion. The program selects approximately 75 students based on academic achievement and leadership, with need-based scholarships available for eligible participants.

results.name: Science Explorations Program
results.title: Simons-NYU Science Explorations Program
results.subtitle: New York University
results.description: The Simons-NYU Science Explorations Program is a free, three-week residential intensive designed for academically motivated high school students, including rising juniors, seniors, and recent graduates with a passion for the physical and life sciences. Participants explore an overview of college-level concepts across five major disciplines including biology, chemistry, neural science, physics, and psychology. During the program, students attend lectures and participate in hands-on laboratory workshops led by distinguished faculty and innovative researchers. To be eligible, applicants must be at least 16 years old, reside in the United States, and be U.S. citizens or permanent residents. This non-credit program is fully funded by the Simons Foundation, covering all costs for tuition, housing, dining, and transportation to ensure accessibility for all admitted students. The application process is free and requires the submission of a high school transcript along with one to two letters of recommendation.

results.name: CAALS3D
results.title: Wellness
results.subtitle: College of Agriculture and Life Sciences
results.description: CALS Wellness provides comprehensive health and well-being resources for students, faculty, and staff within the university community. The program offers access to a dedicated counselor, specialized workshops, and various learning opportunities designed to help individuals succeed in a high-stress academic environment. Participants can engage with community groups or take part in stress busters and social activities like crafting and yoga to enhance their daily lives. For urgent needs, the initiative connects members to emergency services including the campus counseling center and the national suicide and crisis lifeline.

results.name: SSRP
results.title: Summer Science Research Program
results.subtitle: Hofstra University
results.description: Hofstra University's Summer Science Research Program offers high school sophomores and juniors the opportunity to conduct on-campus research under the guidance of faculty mentors in disciplines ranging from biology and chemistry to engineering and social sciences. Participants engage in full-time research for four weeks, developing projects that culminate in a formal poster session attended by families and teachers. To be eligible, applicants must be at least 15 years old, U.S. citizens or permanent residents, and have completed at least one year of a high school research course. The competitive selection process includes an online application, a personal statement, a teacher recommendation, and virtual interviews to assess academic potential and independent work skills. Students also participate in weekly seminars and lunches to foster collaboration and deepen their understanding of their selected research areas.

results.name: SEEing Art

deadlines.label: Wrapped Up in Reading: Last day to return reading diary

program_dates.label: Sunday FUNday: Write like an Egyptian: Hieroglyphs
Artful Stories for ages 3-6: Salmon Boy
Artful Stories for ages 3-6: Kwesi and Nana Ruby Learn to Swim
Artful Stories for ages 3-6: One Small Spark

results.title: Children's and Family Programs
results.subtitle: Michael C. Carlos Museum
results.description: The Michael C. Carlos Museum provides a variety of educational initiatives including Children's and Family Programs that encourage participants to look closely at art and create their own works through workshops and camps. Families can participate in Sunday FUNdays featuring free studio activities or attend Artful Stories sessions where literature is paired with hands-on projects related to the museum’s collections. Younger learners can utilize SmARTy Packs and collectible Family Guides to explore antiquities like Egyptian coffins and Greek vases, while Camp Carlos offers guidance from practicing artists for children ages 5-12. Additionally, the museum supports academic growth through school tours, teacher resources, and the Wrapped Up in Reading summer program which rewards children for exploring curated book lists.

results.name: ENLACE Summer Research
results.title: ENLACE
results.subtitle: University of California, San Diego
results.description: ENLACE is a summer research program designed for high school students in the 11th grade and university students interested in the sciences and engineering. Participants join a specific research laboratory at the host institution to engage in hands-on projects and foster international friendships. The comprehensive application process requires two-page letters of recommendation from both a teacher and a parent, current school transcripts, and a typed two-to-three-page essay in English. While the participation fee is $7,500 USD to cover housing, food, and field trips, students may apply for financial support or competitive chaperone roles that provide a full scholarship.

results.name: Summer Session

deadlines.label: College Prep and Summer College Scholarship Deadline

results.title: Hoya Summer High School Sessions
results.subtitle: Georgetown University School of Continuing Studies
results.description: Hoya Summer High School Sessions offer highly motivated 8th through 12th graders the opportunity to experience university life through accelerated Academies, a College Prep Program, or undergraduate Summer College courses. Students can choose from a wide range of subjects including American politics, artificial intelligence, business leadership, and medical immersion. Admission is based on high school grades, recommendation letters, and personal statements, with decisions made on a rolling basis. Both residential and commuter options are available, and the university provides F-1 visa support for international students enrolled in full-time credit-bearing courses. Limited need-based scholarships are offered to eligible applicants for tuition costs, and registration is generally conducted on a first-come, first-served basis.

results.name: Discover Nursing and Its Vital Role in Healthcare
results.title: Nursing: Explore Advanced Practice Nursing
results.subtitle: Georgetown University
results.description: Nursing: Explore Advanced Practice Nursing is an online course from Georgetown University designed for high school students aged 13 and up who are interested in exploring nursing as a career pathway. Participants delve into various nursing specialties such as nurse-midwife, nurse anesthetist, and nurse practitioner while learning about innovations like high-fidelity mannequins and medical simulations. The curriculum covers core skills including health assessment, medication dosage calculation, and documentation through dynamic video lessons and patient care simulations. The program is 100% online and asynchronous, requiring approximately 30 hours of total instruction supported by expert mentors who provide guidance on assignments. Students conclude the course with a Final Capstone Project to demonstrate their knowledge and earn an official Certificate of Completion from the university.

results.name: Business Summer Institutes
results.title: Business Summer Institutes for High School Students
results.subtitle: C. T. Bauer College of Business
results.description: The Business Summer Institutes for High School Students, including the EXPLORE Institutes, are designed for prospective students interested in the undergraduate programs at the C. T. Bauer College of Business. High school students can participate in activities such as a Business Plan Competition, which allows them to delve into entrepreneurial concepts and showcase their skills. The college provides resources for future freshmen, including assured admissions requirements that are higher than general university standards and dedicated business academic advisors to help select courses. Participants can also learn about various scholarship opportunities and programs like the Emerging Leaders Academic Success Program, which supports the transition from high school to a four-year business institution. The application process for interested students involves using The Common Application, submitting official transcripts, and optionally providing ACT or SAT scores under a test-optional policy.

results.name: Student Leaders
results.title: Bank of America Student Leaders® program
results.subtitle: Bank of America
results.description: The Bank of America Student Leaders® program is an initiative designed to prepare community-minded high school juniors and seniors for the workforce through leadership training and practical work experience.
