Participants engage in an eight-week paid internship at local nonprofit organizations where they gain first-hand experience in serving their communities while working 35 hours per week. In addition to the local internship, selected students attend a national leadership summit to learn how the nonprofit, government, and business sectors collaborate to address critical needs. To be eligible for this competitive program, applicants must be high school students in good standing who are legally authorized to work in the United States. The program covers all expenses associated with the summit and provides students with valuable civic, social, and business leadership skills.

results.name: Smash Academy
results.title: SMASH Residential
results.subtitle: SMASH
results.description: SMASH Residential is a free, one-year intensive program designed for current 10th and 11th graders who are passionate about STEM, innovation, and making a social impact. This flagship initiative provides students with a tuition-free summer experience where they immerse themselves in a curriculum featuring Computer Science, college success strategies, and various STEM electives. Participants build valuable relationships with facilitators and industry professionals while gaining true mentorship and developing the confidence to pursue future tech and science careers. Applicants must maintain a minimum 3.0 GPA, demonstrate strong mathematics skills, and attend a public high school or a private school through a scholarship. The program fosters a vibrant community of peers, offering networking events and long-term support to help scholars master technical and computational thinking skills.

results.name: Research Experiences
results.title: Research Experiences in Astronomy at CIERA for High School Students
results.subtitle: Center for Interdisciplinary Exploration and Research in Astrophysics
results.description: High school students in grades 10 through 12 participate in an interactive astronomy research program that emphasizes team-style learning and mentorship from professional scientists. The curriculum begins with a three-week Core program focused on intensive Python programming training and astronomical data analysis, functioning similarly to a coding bootcamp. Participants engage in hands-on research projects covering topics such as black holes, planetary systems, and supernovae while attending extracurricular events like career panels and solar observing. Students who complete the initial phase may apply for an extended session to conduct independent, one-on-one research under the supervision of a dedicated mentor. No prior experience in computer programming or astronomy is required to apply, and the program offers tuition assistance to help broaden access for all interested applicants.

results.name: SSU Innovation
results.title: Verizon Innovative Learning
results.subtitle: Kricker Innovation Hub
results.description: The Verizon Innovative Learning STEM Achievers program is a free summer enrichment opportunity specifically designed for middle school students in grades six through eight. Participants engage in hands-on learning activities that focus on modern technologies and concepts such as 3D printing, augmented reality, and design thinking. The curriculum also incorporates social entrepreneurship and mentorship to help students build a diverse pipeline for future careers in science, technology, engineering, and math fields. No prior knowledge or experience is required to join this three-week session, which aims to provide all students with access to a better future through digital inclusion.

results.name: National Science Bowl
results.title: National Science Bowl® (NSB)
results.subtitle: U.S. Department of Energy Office of Science
results.description: The National Science Bowl® (NSB) is a nationwide academic competition that tests students’ knowledge across all areas of science and mathematics using a fast-paced question-and-answer format. Middle and high school student teams are comprised of four students, one alternate, and a teacher who serves as an advisor and coach. These teams face off in rigorous matches covering disciplines such as biology, chemistry, Earth science, physics, energy, and math. Organized by the U.S. Department of Energy Office of Science, the program begins with regional tournaments where winning teams eventually advance to the national finals. Since its creation in 1991, more than 350,000 students have participated in this initiative, making it one of the nation’s largest science competitions.

results.name: Pediatrics Internship Program

program_dates.label: Pediatrics Internship Program at Stanford (PIPS) Summer 2026

results.title: Pediatrics Internship Program at Stanford
results.subtitle: Stanford Medicine
results.description: The Pediatrics Internship Program at Stanford (PIPS) is a seven-week introductory research experience designed for rising high school juniors and seniors who are at least 16 years old. Interns commit to a schedule that combines hands-on research in maternal and child health with a structured curriculum focused on leadership, career exploration, and college application preparation. Each participant is paired with a faculty mentor to complete a research project and a scientific poster, which is showcased at a concluding symposium for the research community. The program also features a Near Peer Mentor program, providing weekly sessions with university students and alumni to discuss academic and professional goals. Applicants must maintain a minimum unweighted high school GPA of 3.0 and submit a letter of recommendation from a science or math teacher. Participation in the program is free of charge, and students demonstrating financial need are eligible for a stipend to support their participation.

results.name: UCSF

deadlines.label: Internal MSTP Application Deadline for MS1 Students
Admissions Process Completion and Withdrawal Deadline

program_dates.label: Optional First-Year Summer Lab Rotation Start Date

results.title: Lowell High Summer Program and Symposium
results.subtitle: University of California San Francisco
results.description: The Lowell High Summer Program and Symposium is a collaborative initiative between Lowell High School and the University of California San Francisco designed to introduce students to the world of scientific discovery. Founded by a physics teacher and a medical student, the program teaches participants essential laboratory techniques while engaging them in original scientific research. Students develop professional skills necessary for successful scientific careers through an after-school program and a competitive summer internship where they work directly in university laboratories. The experience culminates in an annual symposium where interns present their research findings through short talks and poster sessions to a community of mentors and peers. Beyond technical training, the program aims to ignite a passion for research and create a vibrant mentorship network involving university faculty and medical scientist trainees.

results.name: CreateTech Camp
results.title: Create Tech
results.subtitle: Computing Catalyst at UMD
results.description: Create Tech is a two-week non-residential summer program designed for rising 8th–12th graders interested in an introduction to computing. Participants engage in hands-on learning by creating wearable and interactive technology using Python, Circuit Playground Express, and various makerspace equipment. Throughout the program, students collaborate with current undergraduate computing students and participate in lab visits, campus tours, and guest speaker sessions. Applicants must submit an unofficial transcript and provide contact information for two references, including at least one math or science teacher. The program carries a registration fee of $500, which covers all necessary materials and activity costs.

results.name: Robotics Camp
results.title: Robotics Camp
results.subtitle: Institute for Transformative Education
results.description: The Robotics Camp is a week-long summer program designed for middle and high school students ranging from 8th to 12th grade. Participants engage in hands-on activities such as assembling and practicing with MBot Mega robots, learning to fly and program drones, and developing coding skills in Scratch and Python. The curriculum introduces students to critical technical fields including artificial intelligence, cybersecurity, and renewable energy through guest speakers and STEM lab visits. This no-cost initiative requires interested students to submit an application and obtain a recommendation from a STEM teacher to be considered for participation.

results.name: Pre-College
results.title: Pre-College Program in American History
results.subtitle: William & Mary
results.description: The Pre-College Program in American History offers high school students a three-week residential experience that integrates academic instruction with immersive, site-based learning. Participants engage in a curriculum designed by faculty that combines public and social history, bridging the gap between historical readings and real-world encounters at museums and historic sites. The program features a hands-on approach where students participate in seminar discussions, speak with museum professionals, and engage in activities such as archaeological digs and English country dancing. By exploring diverse narratives, students learn to connect human-scale experiences with larger historical patterns and scholarly arguments. This academic initiative provides a unique opportunity for history enthusiasts to build a community while gaining insight into vocations like curation, archaeology, and museum education.

results.name: Teen Wellness Connection
results.title: Teen Wellness Connection
results.subtitle: Science & Health Education Partnership | UCSF
results.description: The Teen Wellness Connection is a leadership program that empowers high school students to explore and communicate about health issues affecting their peers. Participants collaborate with UCSF scientists and health researchers to study specific topics, such as mental health, and develop effective methods for sharing that knowledge. This program features a summer intensive followed by regular meetings throughout the school year to facilitate organization and planning. It culminates in a student-led summit where participants showcase their skills by hosting guest speakers, panel discussions, and interactive activities for a large audience of their high school peers.

results.name: DHC Program

deadlines.label: Shades for the Future Application Deadline

results.title: Mentorship & Workforce Development Programs
results.subtitle: Ann & Robert H. Lurie Children’s Hospital of Chicago
results.description: Mentorship & Workforce Development Programs at Lurie Children’s offers thirteen distinct tracks designed to introduce students to diverse healthcare careers through clinical shadowing, internships, and skill-building workshops. Participants can engage in specialized offerings such as Discovering Healthcare Careers for paid summer clinical internships or the CHAMP program which focuses on public health and community health research. The initiative serves a wide demographic ranging from middle school students in Chicago Public Schools to undergraduate and graduate students pursuing nursing or medical education. Beyond clinical exposure, these programs emphasize professional development by providing training in resume writing, leadership, mental health awareness, and essential workplace soft skills.

results.name: USAJMO
results.title: United States of America Junior Mathematical Olympiad
results.subtitle: Mathematical Association of America
results.description: The United States of America Junior Mathematical Olympiad (USAJMO) is a premier proof-based competition used to identify top students on the path toward representing the United States at the International Mathematics Olympiad. Approximately 250 students qualify for this examination based on their high performance on the AMC 10 and AIME exams. The competition consists of six complex problems administered over two days, requiring students to demonstrate correctness, completeness, and clarity in their written responses. Participants must have a solid command of algebra, geometry, number theory, and combinatorics while utilizing rigorous methods such as induction and proof by contradiction. The highest-scoring individuals are often invited to the Math Olympiad Summer Program, an intensive multi-week training session for the country's most advanced young mathematicians.

results.name: Design Pre-College
results.title: Design
results.subtitle: Carnegie Mellon University
results.description: Pre-College Design is an intensive program for high school sophomores and juniors who have at least a 3.0 grade point average and are 16 years of age. Students explore the discipline through a curriculum modeled after the first-year college experience, focusing on studio-based learning for products, communications, and environments. Participants engage in guided work sessions with faculty to develop skills in design drawing, photography, and research methods while utilizing their own personal studio space. Throughout the program, students build professional portfolio pieces that receive critique from School of Design faculty, culminating in a final showcase of their creative work. Both residential and commuter options are available, and students are provided with a specialized Design Kit, though they must provide their own camera and a laptop capable of running Adobe Creative Cloud software.

results.name: PULSE
results.title: PULSE Program
results.subtitle: Penn State College of Medicine
results.description: The PULSE Program is a competitive semester-long educational outreach initiative designed for high school students in grades 9-12 who are interested in healthcare and biomedical sciences. Participants engage in a 12-week longitudinal curriculum featuring interactive lectures, problem-based learning sessions, and clinical shadowing opportunities alongside medical students and practicing clinicians. This hybrid experience primarily utilizes live virtual sessions focused on anatomy, common disorders, and health care systems, supplemented by mentorship and college preparation discussions. Selection is based on a scored essay evaluation, and students are expected to maintain consistent attendance to receive a final certificate of completion.

results.name: NC Youth Institute
results.title: NC Youth Institute
results.subtitle: NC State Extension
results.description: The NC Youth Institute is an educational initiative for high school students designed to ignite a passion for solving global hunger through the exploration of agriculture and food systems. Participants engage in the program by researching a global issue and writing a three-to-five-page challenge paper under the supervision of a mentor, such as a teacher, parent, or extension agent. Students also create a research poster to share with peers and a panel of judges during an event featuring hands-on workshops, field trips, and career development opportunities. To support their work, attendees can join an online research mentoring cohort that pairs them with graduate students to discuss research questions and ideas. Top-performing students are competitively selected as delegates to represent the state at the Global Youth Institute, where they interact with Nobel and World Food Prize Laureates.

results.name: Business Research
results.title: Business Research for Innovation, Design, Growth, and Entrepreneurship (BRIDGE)
results.subtitle: UC San Diego
results.description: This pre-college program is designed for current high school students entering 9th through 12th grade who maintain a minimum 3.3 GPA. Participants explore foundational principles of business innovation, venture financing, and growth strategy through a combination of in-class discussions, real-life venture case studies, and simulations. The course curriculum includes reviewing research papers on innovation and creativity to help students understand the academic research process while developing analytical and entrepreneurial leadership skills. Delivered live-online via Zoom, this course offers 3.00 non-credit-bearing pre-college units and requires approximately 30 hours of student work. Interested individuals can enroll directly on a first-come, first-served basis without a formal application process.

results.name: Summer Art Camps
results.title: Summer Art Camps
results.subtitle: Adele H. Stamp Student Union
results.description: Summer Art Camps provide opportunities for participants to explore their creativity, develop artistic skills, and express themselves through various mediums. Although the traditional weekly format is transitioning into new programming, the initiative continues to offer public artistic education programs and special events designed to inspire creativity. New opportunities include a variety of engaging activities for all ages and a workshop series specifically designed for family participation throughout the season. Parents who previously registered can access tax information and receipts through a dedicated online dashboard. These updated programs focus on fostering artistic growth and community engagement through diverse creative outlets.

results.name: EAOP
results.title: Pre-College Academy
results.subtitle: Early Academic Outreach Program
results.description: The Pre-College Academy is a six-week college preparatory program designed for students from partner schools to provide intensive academic preparation for their university and professional futures. Participants enroll in two rigorous courses: a theme-based writing class and a mathematics course tailored to the level they will enter in the following academic year. Math options include Geometry, Advanced Algebra, and Pre-Calculus, while writing themes often explore Environmental Justice, Ethnic Studies, and various storytelling genres. This enrichment program is free of charge and provides all required books and materials, though it does not offer high school credit. Interested students must submit an online application along with their high school transcript to be considered for enrollment in this community of scholars.

results.name: Sports Business Academy
results.title: High School Summer Discovery
results.subtitle: UCLA Anderson School of Management
results.description: High School Summer Discovery at UCLA Anderson provides students in grades 9-12 with a foundation for careers in media, entertainment, and sports through expert-led instruction. Participants choose from four intensive academies focusing on the business of entertainment, sports management, digital marketing, or innovation within the music industry. The curriculum emphasizes hands-on learning, business frameworks, and 21st-century skills like teamwork and communication through case studies and site visits to industry organizations. Enrollment options include two, three, or five-week sessions available in both residential and commuter formats, culminating in a Certificate of Completion. Beyond the classroom, the program integrates collegiate life with recreational activities and professional networking opportunities with leading industry experts.

results.name: International Physics Olympiad
results.title: International Physics Olympiad
results.subtitle: International Physics Olympiad
results.description: The International Physics Olympiad (IPhO) stands as the most prestigious international physics competition specifically for secondary school students. Its primary objective is to evaluate participants on their mastery of theoretical and experimental physics, focusing on critical thinking, problem-solving, and analytical presentation. Each participating nation sends a team consisting of up to five of its most capable physics students and two designated team leaders. The event challenges students to demonstrate hands-on skills and advanced knowledge across a broad range of physical concepts. By bringing together top talent from around the world, the competition fosters excellence and international collaboration within the scientific community.

results.name: Genomics Research
results.title: Genomics Research Internship Program at Stanford (GRIPS)
results.subtitle: Stanford Medicine
results.description: The Genomics Research Internship Program at Stanford (GRIPS) provides highly talented high school students with a research-intensive experience focused on genetics and genomics. Participants are placed in a research laboratory to conduct projects under the supervision of a lab mentor while engaging in professional development and community building opportunities. This entry-level hybrid program involves a commitment of four hours per day for five days per week, including laboratory activities and weekly cohort sessions. Applicants must be at least 16 years old with an unweighted GPA of at least 3.0 and some prior knowledge in biology, chemistry, or computer programming. While there is an application fee, the program itself is free of charge and offers need-based scholarships and fee waivers to ensure accessibility.

results.name: Computational Biology Research
results.title: 2026 CB Camp
results.subtitle: miRcore
results.description: The 2026 CB Camp is designed for academically motivated high school and incoming ninth-grade students who have an interest in computers, mathematics, science, and medicine. Participants focus on the roles of the genome and transcriptome in diseases and symptoms by performing computational biology research using patient RNA expression data to identify relevant biomarkers. Throughout the program, small groups work together to select a specific disease and utilize scientific research tools to identify novel diagnostics or treatment options. Completion of the camp is a prerequisite for students wishing to become miRcore volunteers or lead Genes in Diseases and Symptoms (GIDAS) school clubs. A personal computer is required for participation, and students are expected to have a basic understanding of first-year high school biology concepts like transcription and translation before the start of the session.

results.name: UCSF
results.title: Summer Biomedical Internship Program
results.subtitle: UCSF Fresno
results.description: The Summer Biomedical Internship Program is an educational initiative offered by UCSF Fresno that focuses on scientific discovery and the translation of research to improve health. As a world leader in life sciences, UCSF provides a collaborative environment where participants can explore disciplines related to patient care and medical research. The program emphasizes a multi-disciplinary approach to education and discovery, supporting the university's broader mission to advance scientific knowledge. Interested candidates can find additional details regarding program specifics and application procedures by visiting the official SJV Pre-Med website.

results.name: Computer Science Summer Academics
results.title: UT Computer Science Summer Academies
results.subtitle: The University of Texas at Austin
results.description: The UT Computer Science Summer Academies provide a unique learning experience for high school students entering grades 10 through 12. These one-week residential programs are taught by university faculty and focus on specialized areas of computing, offering hands-on experiences and expert mentorship. Students can choose from various tracks covering topics such as Game Development, iOS App Development, Machine Learning, and Robotics. The curriculum includes Scholars Academies, which are free residential programs aimed at expanding access to computing education and building confidence in future innovators. Participants engage in project-based work ranging from building mobile apps and exploring artificial intelligence tools to programming robots and developing interactive games.

results.name: Kent State University
results.title: Emerging Engineer Camp
results.subtitle: College of Aeronautics and Engineering
results.description: The Emerging Engineer Camp offers middle school students in grades 6-8 and high school students in grades 9-12 a summer of discovery focused on STEM fields. Participants engage in hands-on experiments and explore real-world engineering applications while completing a comprehensive design project. This upcoming session features a specific theme centered around aerospace to inspire future innovators in the field. To support students during the full-day sessions, lunch is provided for all attendees throughout the duration of the camp. Interested families can contact Cassy Mendenhall for more information regarding the daily schedules and program specifics.

results.name: Cornell University
results.title: Summer Research Scholars Program
results.subtitle: Cornell AgriTech
results.description: The Summer Research Scholars Program at Cornell AgriTech provides undergraduate students with the opportunity to participate in specialized projects focused on agricultural research, food and beverage entrepreneurship, and business development. Participants engage directly with faculty members, graduate students, postdocs, and senior-level staff to gain hands-on experience in their chosen fields. This internship program is designed to jumpstart future career paths by immersing students in real-world professional environments and scientific discovery. The curriculum involves active mentorship and project-based learning to help students develop a strong talent pipeline for the agricultural and food industries.

results.name: NASEP
results.title: KEYS Research Internship Program
results.subtitle: University of Arizona
results.description: The KEYS Research Internship Program is a unique summer opportunity designed for motivated Arizona high school students with a strong interest in bioscience, engineering, environmental health, or biostatistics. Interns work side-by-side with top faculty in laboratories to gain hands-on experience in interdisciplinary biomedical science, data science, and environmental health research. Participants receive specialized training in biotechnology skills, science literacy, ethics, and communications that typically exceed standard classroom instruction. The program emphasizes the development of essential capabilities including teamwork, creativity, problem-solving, and emotional competence to prepare students as future leaders.

results.name: UWM
results.title: Quest Project
results.subtitle: University of Wisconsin-Milwaukee
results.description: The Quest Project is a pre-college program designed to educate and motivate middle and high school students and their parents to prepare for and attend college. The program provides information, support, and encouragement to help participants successfully complete high school and transition into higher education. During the academic year, participants engage in workshops covering diverse topics such as college preparation, career exploration, and leadership development. In addition to workshops, the program offers educational field trips and hands-on learning opportunities to further enhance student growth. There are no fees for participation, though students must meet specific eligibility requirements or have attended a designated summer partner program at a UW-System campus to register.

results.name: University of Wisconsin-Madison
results.title: Engineering Summer Program
results.subtitle: University of Wisconsin-Madison
results.description: The Engineering Summer Program (ESP) is a free, three-week residential experience designed for rising high school juniors and seniors who are interested in exploring engineering careers. Participants engage in a rigorous core curriculum encompassing mathematics, physics, chemistry, and introductory engineering design taught by university faculty. The program includes hands-on workshops, industry site visits to various engineering companies, and professional development sessions covering college admissions and financial aid. To be eligible, applicants must maintain a minimum unweighted GPA of 3.0, have completed algebra and geometry, and demonstrate a strong passion for science and math. Beyond academic coursework, attendees reside in campus residence halls where they receive mentoring from faculty and supervision from undergraduate counselors while building connections with their peers.

results.name: University of Vermont
results.title: Summer Enrichment Scholars Program (SESP)
results.subtitle: The University of Vermont
results.description: The Summer Enrichment Scholars Program (SESP) is a free two-week pre-orientation initiative designed specifically for first-time, first-year students to ease their transition into higher education. Participants engage in a residential college experience that provides comprehensive support in academic achievement, personal growth, and intercultural development. Throughout the program, scholars explore the university campus and the surrounding community while learning about the hidden curriculum and establishing sustainable habits for success. This immersive experience fosters a strong sense of belonging by connecting students with institutional resources and a cohort of peers before the official start of the academic year.

results.name: Washington & the World Academy
results.title: Washington & the World Academy
results.subtitle: Georgetown University School of Continuing Studies
results.description: The Washington & the World Academy is a one-week intensive program for high school students designed to explore the future of American leadership and global politics in a changing world. Participants engage in a rigorous schedule of classroom lectures, hands-on activities, group discussions, and off-site visits led by renowned Georgetown School of Foreign Service professors. The curriculum covers diverse topics such as the U.S. relationship with great powers like China and Russia, the role of the American Constitution in foreign policy, and the future of the Atlantic Alliance. Students gain practical experience by participating in a crisis simulation of the National Security Council and hearing directly from seasoned practitioners in the field. Upon successful completion of the academy, attendees receive a Certificate of Participation to recognize their academic engagement and broadened global perspective.

results.name: CReSIS
results.title: Summer Camps with CReSIS
results.subtitle: The University of Kansas
results.description: Through the ARISE grant, high school students have the opportunity to participate in a STEM camp that is offered totally free of charge. Participants engage in the study of math, physics, aerospace engineering, and computer science alongside accomplished scientists and engineers. The program provides valuable exposure to hands-on research while allowing students to build a solid understanding of fundamental principles through practical experience. Students also benefit from living with their peers in campus dorms and become eligible for future scholarships and research opportunities upon completion of the camp.

results.name: Anson L. Clark Scholars Program
results.title: The Anson L. Clark Scholars Program
results.subtitle: Texas Tech University
results.description: The Anson L. Clark Scholars Program is an intensive seven-week summer research program designed for highly qualified high school juniors and seniors. This selective opportunity admits only twelve students each year to participate in hands-on research across a variety of academic disciplines. Participants gain valuable experience by engaging with faculty and utilizing university resources to further their scholarly pursuits. The application process requires students to submit specific components and meet established eligibility criteria for consideration.

results.name: Tri-Valley Clinical Academy
results.title: Stanford Tri-Valley Clinical Academy
results.subtitle: Stanford Medicine
results.description: The Stanford Tri-Valley Clinical Academy is an educational program primarily designed for rising high school juniors and seniors who are at least 16 years of age. College applicants interested in pursuing medicine as a career path may also be considered for admission based on the program's availability. Prospective students must submit a formal application including a school transcript and resume, along with a non-refundable application fee. Accepted participants are required to submit a deposit to hold their place and must finalize their enrollment by providing health information and tuition payments.

results.name: Learn How Entrepreneurs Identify and Solve Problems
results.title: Becoming an Entrepreneur: An Inside Look at Innovation
results.subtitle: Georgetown University
results.description: Becoming an Entrepreneur: An Inside Look at Innovation is an online pre-college course designed for students ages 13 and older who are interested in the fundamentals of launching a business. Participants explore the history of entrepreneurship, learn to identify market needs, and develop business models for both non-profit and for-profit ventures. The curriculum emphasizes practical skills such as identifying target customers, practicing networking techniques to gain financial support, and mastering the art of the business pitch. Throughout the program, students receive guidance from mentors and complete a final capstone project involving a video presentation of their unique value proposition and business story. This flexible learning experience includes approximately 20 to 30 hours of instruction and can be completed in one, two, or four-week session formats for a fee of $1,895.

results.name: UTA
results.title: Gateway to Engineering and Bridge to Engineering Summer Programs
results.subtitle: University of Texas at Arlington
results.description: The Gateway to Engineering and Bridge to Engineering Summer Programs are one-week residence camps designed for junior and senior high students entering grades seven through ten. Participants receive broad exposure to diverse engineering disciplines such as aerospace, biomedical, civil, computer science, electrical, environmental, materials science, and mechanical engineering. Instruction is provided by teams of engineering professors alongside graduate and undergraduate students to ensure a comprehensive learning experience. The curriculum combines classroom-based activities with educational field trips to supplement the academic content.

results.name: Summer Prep
results.title: Penn Arts and Sciences High School Programs
results.subtitle: University of Pennsylvania
results.description: Penn Arts and Sciences High School Programs offer a variety of rigorous academic opportunities for high school students during the summer and academic year. Participants can choose from specialized two-week and three-week academies focusing on subjects like biomedical research, economics, experimental physics, and social justice. The offerings include residential pre-college programs, online seminars, and research-heavy academies that challenge students to engage with ivy-league level coursework. Students have the chance to explore diverse fields such as forensic science, neuroscience, and global food systems while developing leadership and university-readiness skills. These programs are designed to provide a taste of college life and foster intellectual growth through hands-on labs, collaborative projects, and academic writing.

results.name: Yale
results.title: Our Programme at Yale
results.subtitle: Oxford Royale
results.description: Oxford Royale provides a summer educational program for students aged 12-18, allowing them to experience life on an Ivy League campus while following in the footsteps of world leaders. Participants engage in 35 hours of expert-led teaching, including hands-on workshops, exhibition challenges, and academic curricula designed by subject experts. The program includes residential accommodation in historic colleges where students have access to state-of-the-art facilities, mentoring, and 24/7 support. Beyond the classroom, students participate in enrichment extras such as guest lectures from world-leading experts, a journalism club, and a sports program featuring football and competitive team challenges. The experience culminates in a formal graduation ceremony and celebration dinner to recognize student accomplishments and foster lifelong connections.

results.name: Screenwriters Workshop
results.title: Tisch Online High School Screenwriters Workshop
results.subtitle: NYU Tisch School of the Arts
results.description: The Tisch Online High School Screenwriters Workshop is a dynamic course designed to introduce students to the fundamentals of scriptwriting for film and television. High school freshmen, sophomores, juniors, and seniors engage in intensive writing exercises to develop story ideas, characters, film language, and script structure. This program is delivered through an asynchronous model using pre-recorded lectures, while also featuring scheduled synchronous live meetings with faculty, teaching assistants, and peers. Participants earn four college credits and should be prepared to dedicate six to ten hours per week to coursework and daily deliverables. To be eligible for admission, applicants must maintain a minimum 3.0 GPA and submit a personal statement, creative résumé, and official transcripts.

results.name: HPREP
results.title: Health Professions Recruitment & Exposure Program
results.subtitle: Harvard Medical School
results.description: The Health Professions Recruitment & Exposure Program is an educational initiative designed for high school students in the 9th through 12th grades who are interested in exploring careers in science and medicine. This program specifically targets students who may face roadblocks in entering these fields and aims to provide a supportive environment through a holistic admissions process. Participants gain unique exposure to various healthcare topics and interact with mentors, including current graduate, medical, and dental students who serve as volunteers. To apply, students must complete several essays that range from 50 to 500 words to demonstrate their passion and commitment to pursuing the health professions.

results.name: Kentucky Forest Leadership Program
results.title: Kentucky Forest Leadership Program
results.subtitle: University of Kentucky
results.description: The Kentucky Forest Leadership Program provides high school students with specialized training in natural resources, entomology, water quality, and wildlife management. Students can select a specific focus area from available tracks including forestry, entomology, or wildlife options. The program fee includes all necessary instructional materials in addition to room and board for all participants. To support accessibility, scholarships are often sponsored by county Conservation Districts and the Kentucky Woodland Owners Association.

results.name: Apprenticeships in Science & Engineering
results.title: Apprenticeships in STEAM Exploration (ASE)
results.subtitle: Saturday Academy
results.description: The Apprenticeships in STEAM Exploration (ASE) program connects motivated high school students with mentors for pre-professional internships in science, technology, engineering, and math. Designed for rising sophomores, juniors, and seniors, these positions typically last between four to eight weeks and offer both part-time and full-time opportunities. Participants work alongside professionals in various settings, including universities, hospitals, research institutions, and private companies, to contribute to and learn from their mentor's work. The competitive application process seeks students who are eager to engage in hands-on learning, with many past interns having been listed on published research or assisted in the design of commercial products.

results.name: SDSU
results.title: Summer Leadership Academy
results.subtitle: Institute for Transformative Education
results.description: The Summer Leadership Academy (SLA) is a week-long leadership experience designed for students in grades 8-12. Participants engage with peers and advisors through team-building activities to enhance leadership skills, self-advocacy, and socio-emotional development. The curriculum includes academic and personal development workshops, guest speaker presentations, and campus tours to explore college environments such as classrooms and dining halls. Students focus on building social capital by forming new relationships and developing study tactics necessary for success in an academic setting. Additional programming features various outdoor activities and social events to celebrate the completion of the academy.

results.name: Plant Signal Transduction and Reproduction

program_dates.label: Plant Signal Transduction and Reproduction (Cheung Lab)

results.title: Plant Signal Transduction and Reproduction (Cheung Lab)
results.subtitle: University of Massachusetts Amherst
results.description: This competitive research intensive program invites rising high school juniors and seniors to work in professional labs alongside distinguished faculty and graduate students. Participants in the Cheung Lab focus on understanding plant reproduction and growth through experimental approaches including molecular biology, genetics, cell biology, and biochemistry. Students gain hands-on experience generating genetically transformed plants, using molecular genotyping methods like polymerase chain reaction, and purifying proteins to study their biochemical properties. Throughout the six-week schedule, students learn university-level research methodologies and ultimately present their findings via a research poster to faculty and peers. This program offers six credits and provides a comprehensive introduction to the field of biochemistry while illustrating undergraduate opportunities at a major research university.

results.name: High School Research Program
results.title: High School Research Program (HSRP)
results.subtitle: Brookhaven National Laboratory
results.description: The High School Research Program (HSRP) is a highly competitive six-week educational initiative designed for students interested in pursuing studies in science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM). Participants collaborate with Brookhaven National Laboratory’s scientific and technical staff on hands-on research projects that support the Department of Energy’s mission to address energy and environmental challenges. The program requires students to be at least 16 years old and have completed 11th grade, and applicants must be U.S. citizens or Lawful Permanent Residents with active health insurance. Selected students commit to a full-time schedule, participate in weekly meetings, and conclude their experience by presenting their work in a poster session or oral presentation. Mentorship and teamwork are central to the experience, as students contribute to shared research goals rather than conducting independent projects.

results.name: Mathematics Project
results.title: RUSMP's Summer Camps and Programs for Students
results.subtitle: Rice University School Mathematics Project
results.description: The Rice University School Mathematics Project offers a variety of summer camps and programs designed to enrich student mathematics backgrounds and prepare them for upcoming courses such as Precalculus and Calculus. Each class is uniquely taught by a collaborative team consisting of one university math faculty member and one experienced master teacher. The curriculum emphasizes conceptual understanding and authentic, real-world problem solving through active learning and mathematical communication. Students will explore mathematical topics not typically emphasized during the school year while also focusing on proof, justification, and the responsible use of AI to reinforce learning. Registration requires parents to first create a family account and then add the student as a member before selecting specific courses.

results.name: American Legion Camp
results.title: Boys’ State
results.subtitle: The American Legion Department of New York
results.description: American Legion Boys’ State is a week-long immersive program designed for high school youth who are currently completing their junior year. Participants engage in intensive citizenship and leadership training while learning the practical aspects of government as it exists in New York State. The curriculum emphasizes the importance of the individual to the character and success of government, supplemented by physical fitness activities and teamwork guided by American Legion counselors and U.S. Marines. Prospective attendees must first be sponsored by a local American Legion Post before completing an online application that includes a notarized commitment statement and school certification. Participants also have the opportunity to apply for the Samsung Scholarship as part of their involvement in the program.

results.name: Discovery Program
results.title: Microsoft Discovery Program
results.subtitle: Microsoft
results.description: The Microsoft Discovery Program is a four-week paid internship designed for graduating high school seniors who are rising first-year students in a bachelor’s degree program with an interest in technology. Participants gain hands-on project experience within a small team, exploring disciplines such as software engineering, product management, and UX design while practicing a growth mindset. The curriculum focuses on the product development design phase, where interns work to understand customer needs and build out product solutions under the mentorship of Microsoft employees. To be eligible, applicants must have completed pre-calculus or an equivalent course and must be able to work full-time onsite for the duration of the program. The application process requires a resume, information regarding college acceptance and intended major, and a short essay describing a collaborative project experience.

results.name: DSAP Program
results.title: College of Agricultural, Consumer & Environmental Sciences
results.subtitle: University of Illinois
results.description: The College of Agricultural, Consumer & Environmental Sciences offers a wide selection of academic paths including undergraduate and graduate degrees, alongside professional certificates in fields like Agribusiness and Wetland Science. Students can participate in various extracurricular activities such as student clubs, the Student Leadership Council, and the Global Ambassador Program. Comprehensive support services are available to the community, including academic advising, embedded counseling, and organizations such as MANNRS. The institution also emphasizes research excellence in areas related to agriculture, the environment, and data technology, while providing opportunities for internships and study abroad experiences. Additionally, the college offers honors programs like the ACES James Scholars and specialized resources for international students and visitors.

results.name: Scholastic Press Association Contests

deadlines.label: 2025 High School Individual Awards Payment Deadline
2025 High School Individual Awards Submission Deadline
2025 Junior High-Middle School Individual Awards Deadline
NSPA Leadership Award Scholarship Application Deadline

program_dates.label: JEA/NSPA Fall National High School Journalism Convention (Nashville)
JEA/NSPA Spring National High School Journalism Convention (Minneapolis)
JEA/NSPA Fall National High School Journalism Convention (Orlando)

results.title: Contest overview & rules
results.subtitle: National Scholastic Press Association
results.description: The National Scholastic Press Association offers a variety of prestigious journalism contests, including the Pacemaker, Individual Awards, and the Clips & Clicks competition. These awards recognize overall excellence in student media such as broadcasts, yearbooks, newspapers, and online sites for both high school and middle school levels. Participants can compete in numerous categories ranging from news and feature writing to photojournalism, digital storytelling, and informational graphics. Specific scholarships, such as the Wikoff Scholarship for Editorial Leadership, are also available to high school seniors who demonstrate outstanding journalistic contributions. Most competitions require the publication to hold an NSPA membership, though some specific categories like the Diversity, Equity & Inclusion awards are open to non-members.

results.name: GenCyber Summer Camp
results.title: Early Outreach
results.subtitle: University of Nevada, Las Vegas
results.description: UNLV Early Outreach provides comprehensive college and career readiness programming specifically designed for K–10 students and their families. The initiative aims to help students navigate their path to higher education through a variety of engagement opportunities including school visits and year-round campus events. Participants can take part in age-appropriate group tour experiences to discover campus life or join the Young Rebels program for unique academic and social enrichment. This program encourages students to build critical thinking skills, engage with university faculty, and develop academically minded friendships within a higher education setting.

results.name: OUHSC
results.title: SPARK Summer Program
results.subtitle: OU College of Medicine
results.description: The SPARK Summer Program is a designated offering for high school students through the OU College of Medicine. This initiative is organized by the Office of Access and Community Engagement to provide specialized educational opportunities. Participants can explore various aspects of the medical field and learn about professional pathways within healthcare. The program emphasizes community involvement and academic enrichment for students pursuing future roles in medicine.

results.name: Cancer Epidemiology and Genetics Internship
results.title: Summer Internships
results.subtitle: Division of Cancer Epidemiology and Genetics (DCEG)
results.description: The Division of Cancer Epidemiology and Genetics (DCEG) offers a summer research internship for students interested in careers involving cancer epidemiology, biostatistics, and genetics. Open to a wide range of academic levels, the program welcomes college students, postbaccalaureates, and graduate-level individuals, including those in medical or dental school. Successful participants spend at least eight weeks working under the direct supervision of a Division researcher as part of the broader NIH Summer Internship Program in Biomedical Research. Interns receive a monthly stipend based on their academic level and gain exposure to professional development through seminars, career training, and participation in research poster days. Applicants must be U.S. citizens or permanent residents to be eligible for this research-intensive opportunity within the National Cancer Institute.

results.name: The World Order — and Where It’s Heading
results.title: International Relations: How the World Works
results.subtitle: Georgetown University
results.description: Designed for students ages 13 and up, this program explores the intricate systems of global politics, international law, and economics through both enrichment and college credit tracks. Participants engage in dynamic video lessons led by renowned Georgetown faculty, covering critical topics such as human rights, the evolution of international law, and the impact of technological change on global systems. The curriculum features a final capstone project where students assume the role of the U.S. President to navigate a simulated global crisis, requiring the development of a professional policy paper. Throughout the experience, learners receive guidance from mentors and teaching assistants while benefiting from a 100% online, flexible schedule that accommodates various learning paces. Depending on the selected modality, students can earn either a certificate of completion or official college credit documented on a Georgetown transcript.

results.name: Learn How Investors Create Wealth
results.title: Becoming an Investor: An Inside Look at Finance
results.subtitle: Georgetown University
results.description: Georgetown University offers Becoming an Investor: An Inside Look at Finance, an online program designed for students ages 13 and older who are interested in the mechanics of financial markets. Participants explore the foundations of wealth creation while learning how to use valuation models to determine a company’s worth and its impact on stock prices. The curriculum covers modern financial trends such as fintech, cryptocurrencies, and NFTs, alongside traditional portfolio management and risk evaluation. Throughout the 20 to 30 hours of total instruction, students receive guidance from mentors and work toward a final capstone project where they analyze a public company’s potential. Upon finishing the flexible video-based lessons and assignments, students earn a Certificate of Completion from the university.

results.name: Summer Scholars Program
results.title: Broad Summer Scholars Program
results.subtitle: Broad Institute
results.description: The Broad Summer Scholars Program (BSSP) is a six-week mentored research initiative designed for highly motivated high school rising seniors with a strong interest in science. Participants are matched with staff scientists to conduct original, cutting-edge research projects in specialized fields such as cancer biology, psychiatric disease, computational biology, and infectious disease. Beyond laboratory work, students explore various scientific careers, attend professional talks, and participate in training sessions focused on creating and presenting scientific posters. This no-cost program provides a $3,600 stipend and transportation reimbursement to eligible applicants who demonstrate academic excellence in math and science classes. No previous research experience is required, though students with limited exposure to STEM are especially encouraged to apply for this competitive opportunity.

results.name: Mentor Assistance Program for High School Students
results.title: UCSD Mentor Assistance Program for High School Students
results.subtitle: San Diego Supercomputer Center
results.description: The UCSD Mentor Assistance Program for High School Students is a campus-wide initiative designed for motivated students in grades 10 through 12 to engage in a 1:1 mentoring relationship with university experts. Participants can seek guidance on science fair projects, explore specific research interests, or visit lab spaces to learn about potential career paths in fields ranging from nanoengineering to biochemistry. While the program is not a tutoring or standard internship, it offers an eight-month commitment where students typically spend two to four hours per week interacting with faculty or post-doctoral mentors. Registration fees are required for research projects, though financial assistance and transportation support through MTS ComPASS cards are available for eligible participants.

results.name: Math Tournament
results.title: Stanford Math Tournament
results.subtitle: Stanford University
results.description: The Stanford Math Tournament (SMT) is a high school math competition organized and run entirely by students at Stanford University. As one of the largest university-run math contests globally, the event is supported by the Stanford Undergraduate Mathematics Organization and the Stanford Department of Mathematics. The program offers a high-quality and challenging experience for students interested in mathematics, featuring both an in-person tournament and an online version to increase accessibility. The online competition is specifically designed to reach middle and high school students from anywhere in the world to spread mathematics education. Participants have the opportunity to solve complex problems and engage with a mission focused on improving the reach of competitive math tournaments.

results.name: Upward Bound Math Science
results.title: VPSE Science Technology Engineering Math (STEM)
results.subtitle: Penn VPSE
results.description: The VPSE Science Technology Engineering Math (STEM) program provides K-12 students with unique opportunities to engage in innovative academic projects. Participants focus on developing essential skills in the core disciplines of science, technology, engineering, and mathematics. The curriculum emphasizes hands-on learning experiences and collaborative environments to foster growth and discovery. Students work together on various initiatives designed to prepare them for future success in technical and scientific fields.

results.name: Ohio University
results.title: J'COB College Experience Summer Program
results.subtitle: Ohio University
results.description: The J'COB College Experience Summer Program is a week-long residential opportunity designed for rising high school seniors with a minimum 3.0 GPA to explore various career possibilities within the business industry. Participants engage in experiential learning and leadership development while living in residence halls and networking with university professors and industry professionals. The curriculum introduces students to the United Nations’ Sustainable Development Goals and features creative problem-solving training to prepare them for complex global challenges. Students collaborate in teams to participate in a high-energy hackathon, culminating in a final presentation of innovative business solutions to a panel of community leaders and faculty. Housing and meals are provided as part of the immersion experience, which aims to equip students with the skills and confidence to pursue future academic studies in fields like sports management and entrepreneurship.

results.name: National Security & Intelligence Academy
results.title: National Security & Intelligence Academy
results.subtitle: Georgetown University School of Continuing Studies
results.description: The National Security & Intelligence Academy is a one-week program for high school students that leverages government and international relations resources to explore critical security and intelligence issues. Participants study how policies enhance national security, examine methods for preventing foreign adversary access to information, and analyze the collection and dissemination of intelligence. The curriculum covers diverse subject areas including homeland security, international politics, cybersecurity, drug trafficking, and the impact of artificial intelligence on national defense. Students engage in a blend of classroom lectures, hands-on activities, and guest speaker sessions, alongside field trips to distinguished government institutions and the International Spy Museum. The program culminates in a capstone simulation project where students act as top policymakers or security advisors to develop feasible responses to security crises.

results.name: Sibling Circles
results.title: Sibling Circles
results.subtitle: Sadie Nash Leadership Project
results.description: Sibling Circles is a drop-in workshop series designed for young women and gender-expansive youth ages 14-22 who are current or previous participants of the Sadie Nash Leadership Project. The program focuses on mental health and well-being through educational healing spaces where attendees can engage in open discussion and creative expression. Participants work on building socio-emotional skills, exploring mind-body connections through meditation, and examining personal values to guide their daily decisions. These mostly virtual sessions are led by Bachelor and Masters of Social Work students from various New York and New Jersey universities to provide a safe environment for collective care. There are no academic or skill criteria for admission, making the program accessible to all eligible Nashers looking to process life events.

results.name: Simmons Research
results.title: Simons Summer Research Program
results.subtitle: Stony Brook University
results.description: The Simons Summer Research Program is an outreach initiative for high school juniors that matches participants with faculty mentors to conduct hands-on research. Fellows join a specific research group or team where they assume responsibility for an individual project while experiencing life at a major research university. Throughout the apprenticeship, students produce a written research abstract and a professional research poster to showcase their findings. Participants also attend weekly faculty research talks, engage in special workshops, and join organized tours and events designed to enhance their academic growth. Applicants must be US citizens or permanent residents who demonstrate independence and creativity, and those who complete the program receive a stipend award at a closing symposium.

results.name: Summer Session
results.title: UVA Advance Pre-College Program
results.subtitle: University of Virginia
results.description: The UVA Advance Pre-College Program offers high school students a unique opportunity to jumpstart their academic journey by experiencing university life at the University of Virginia. Participants can explore a diverse range of undergraduate courses and earn college credit while engaging with current UVA students and visiting scholars. The program provides comprehensive academic resources, including access to the UVA Writing Center where students can collaborate with professional consultants both in-person and online. In addition to standard enrollment, students may explore specialized tracks such as the Summer Language Institute, Archaeology Field Schools, or technical courses at the Mountain Lake Biological Station.

results.name: Nursing Academy
results.title: Nursing Academy
results.subtitle: Georgetown University School of Continuing Studies
results.description: The Nursing Academy is an immersive one-week program designed for high school students aged 15 and older who want to explore the fundamentals and diverse career paths of the nursing profession. Participants examine a wide range of topics, including healthcare ethics, cultural competencies, and various nursing specializations such as anesthesia, women's health, and acute care. Students engage in faculty-led instruction and gain hands-on clinical experience using lifelike patient simulators at the O’Neill Family Foundation Clinical Simulation Center. The curriculum integrates classroom lectures with field trips to policy organizations, guest speaker sessions, and group discussions regarding contemporary young adult health issues. Both residential and commuter options are available, with daily schedules featuring academic programming followed by residential living activities and a final capstone project.

results.name: Miami SAO
results.title: High School Volunteer Internship Program
results.subtitle: Office of Miami-Dade State Attorney Katherine Fernandez Rundle
results.description: The High School Volunteer Internship Program, offered by the Office of Miami-Dade State Attorney Katherine Fernandez Rundle, provides students with hands-on experience in the criminal justice system. Participants engage in various professional duties such as researching case law, evaluating evidence for prosecution, and assisting the public with criminal or civil matters. Interns may be placed in specialized departments like the Criminal Intake Unit, Domestic Violence Unit, or the Victim/Witness Unit where they take sworn testimony and help victims with injunctions for protection. Applicants must commit to 16–20 hours per week for at least three months and are required to pass a criminal background check before acceptance into the program. The program includes an initial training period covering professional ethics, court procedures, and legal practice to ensure volunteers are well-prepared for their assignments.

results.name: Summer Math Program for Young Scholars

program_dates.label: Summer Math Program for Young Scholars

results.title: Summer Math Program for Young Scholars
results.subtitle: New York University
results.description: The Summer Math Program for Young Scholars is an intensive three-week course offered to high school students in grades 9 through 11 who demonstrate a strong interest in mathematics and maintain a B- grade or higher in math coursework. Participants explore college-level topics such as number theory, graph theory, topology, combinatorics, and computer science through lectures led by faculty and graduate students. The program features collaborative problem-solving sessions, mathematical games, and guest presentations focused on professional careers in the mathematical sciences and the college admissions process. As a commuter-only program that does not provide on-campus housing, it requires a comprehensive application process including a short essay, high school transcripts, and a letter of recommendation. While students do not receive academic credit, they can earn a certificate of completion and request a non-credit transcript upon successfully passing the course.

results.name: Anime/Manga Session

program_dates.label: D&D: Adventures on the Astral sea (Grades 9-12)
Teen Med Camp 2: Beyond the Basics (Grades 9-12) Session 1
Teen Med Camp 2: Beyond the Basics (Grades 9-12) Session 2
D&D: Escapades in the city of Waterdeep (Grades 9-12)

results.title: Summer Camps: High School
results.subtitle: The University of Texas at Arlington
results.description: The University of Texas at Arlington offers a diverse range of summer camp programs specifically designed for high school students in grades 9 through 12. Participants can explore creative fields such as analogue photography and book publishing or delve into technical subjects like the principles of engineering and 3D printing in the Fab Lab. For those interested in the healthcare field, the Teen Med Camp series provides both introductory and advanced sessions covering foundational and complex medical concepts. The curriculum also includes unique elective options like Dungeons & Dragons adventures, catering to a wide variety of student interests and hobbies. These educational sessions are organized by University Compliance Services and aim to provide enriching extracurricular experiences during the summer break.

results.name: UCLA
results.title: Neurocamp (Grades: 9-12)
results.subtitle: UCLA Brain Research Institute (BRI)
results.description: Neurocamp (Grades: 9-12) is a free summer outreach program designed for highly motivated high school students interested in the field of neuroscience. Participants are introduced to fundamental concepts and basic laboratory techniques in molecular neurobiology, neurophysiology, and neuroanatomy through an instructional course. Students engage in hands-on activities such as dissecting sheep brains and cow spinal cords, performing experiments with earthworms, and mastering the use of laboratory equipment like pipettes. The curriculum is delivered through captivating lectures from faculty and guidance from undergraduate volunteers to provide an immersive introduction to scientific research. Prospective students must submit a resume, a statement of interest, and a letter of recommendation from a teacher or mentor to be considered for one of the limited spots in the cohort.

results.name: NJIT
results.title: Student Research Opportunities
results.subtitle: Ying Wu College of Computing
results.description: The Ying Wu College of Computing offers diverse research opportunities to students ranging from ninth-grade high schoolers to doctoral candidates. Participants can engage in specialized topics such as Applied AI, Large Language Models, Cryptocurrency, and human-centered security. Prospective researchers must possess a working knowledge of at least one common programming language, such as Python, Java, or C++, and maintain a professional work attitude including timely communication and consistent progress. Projects can be completed for either financial compensation or academic credit through specific independent study or thesis course registrations. These hands-on experiences allow students to collaborate directly with professors on innovative projects that enhance professional resumes and prepare them for research-intensive careers.

results.name: Cellular Construction Workshop
results.title: Cellular Construction Workshop
results.subtitle: Science & Health Education Partnership | UCSF
results.description: The Cellular Construction Workshop is a 10-day summer program designed for high school students and teachers to explore the emerging field of cellular engineering. Open specifically to students from SFUSD or San Francisco charter schools, this paid workshop engages participants in design challenges and collaborative experiments to observe how cells function and make decisions. Participants work in teams to utilize robots and coding to mimic cellular processes, aiming to solve real-world problems using their newfound knowledge of biological systems. No prior experience in robotics or coding is required to participate, and the application process requires a letter of recommendation. The program is supported by the National Science Foundation as part of the Center for Cellular Construction and emphasizes learning, partnerships, and building a sense of belonging within the scientific community.

results.name: Pre-Collegiate Summer Scholars Program
results.title: Fall & Spring Study
results.subtitle: Cornell SCE
results.description: Non-degree students have the opportunity to take almost any Cornell course and study directly with university faculty. This program allows participants to enroll in regular university courses to earn academic credits that can be applied toward future educational goals. Students engage in the same rigorous curriculum and learn from the same distinguished faculty as degree-seeking students. The curriculum is broad, enabling learners to explore diverse subjects or fulfill specific academic requirements across various departments. This initiative facilitates academic growth for visiting students and those interested in lifelong learning through a wide selection of courses.

results.name: Strategize Like a Marketer
results.title: Marketing
results.subtitle: Georgetown University
results.description: Georgetown University offers a Marketing course designed for students ages 13 and up that explores the dynamic role of traditional and digital channels in promoting products and services. Participants can choose between an enrichment track resulting in a certificate of completion or a college credit track that provides a Georgetown transcript upon finishing additional coursework. The program covers brand building, consumer spending habits, and the development of customer personas while providing students with access to mentors and video lessons by renowned faculty. Throughout the course, students engage in a final capstone project where they analyze company strategies and identify target audiences to demonstrate their understanding of marketing as both an art and a science.

results.name: University of Washington
results.title: Summer Stretch: 7-10th grade
results.subtitle: UW Robinson Center for Young Scholars
results.description: Summer Stretch is an academic program designed for highly motivated students currently in the 7th through 10th grade. The program offers a variety of accelerated and enrichment courses that provide an intensive, hands-on, and educational experience. Classes are kept small and are led by instructors who are specialists in their respective fields to ensure high-quality learning environments. To increase access and equity, the program utilizes a lottery admissions process for all interested applicants. Participants engage in rigorous coursework during the multi-week session which operates four days per week.

results.name: Research Mentorship Program
results.title: Research Mentorship Program
results.subtitle: University of California, Santa Barbara
results.description: The Research Mentorship Program is a competitive summer initiative that engages qualified, high-achieving high school students from around the globe in interdisciplinary, university-level research. Participants are paired with a dedicated mentor, such as a faculty member, postdoc, or graduate student, to collaborate on a chosen project from an extensive list of academic disciplines. Throughout the experience, students learn advanced research techniques and gain valuable insights into professional research-based opportunities while maturing their specific academic goals. The program also features the GRIT talks lecture series, connecting students with leading minds in the research community to learn about ground-breaking technology and innovative developments. Beyond the laboratory, students are immersed in university life and have the opportunity to network with a cohort of equally ambitious and curious peers.

results.name: Tisch Future Artists
results.title: Tisch Future Artists
results.subtitle: Tisch School of the Arts
results.description: Tisch Future Artists is a free, 14-week pre-college program for high school freshmen, sophomores, and juniors interested in pursuing professional-level arts training. Participants can choose from seven distinct artistic tracks, including Dance, Dramatic Writing, Filmmaking, Game Design, Photography, Music Business, and Theatre Arts. The curriculum offers the same rigor and training found in undergraduate departments, allowing students to study with faculty and develop their creative voices through workshops and technical training. Designed specifically for students who would qualify for financial aid and may lack access to arts programs in their own communities, this commuter program requires a significant weekly commitment for the duration of the course. The application process includes an online form, personal statement, creative résumé, and high school transcripts to be considered for admission.

results.name: Biomedical Research Internship
results.title: High School Programs
results.subtitle: Cincinnati Children’s
results.description: Cincinnati Children’s sponsors several biomedical outreach programs for high school and college students considering careers in biomedical research and clinical practice. The mission of these activities is to encourage talented students to pursue careers in pediatric healthcare and scientific discovery. The High School Summer Internship Program specifically offers graduating seniors a paid, part-time position to gain insight into clinical research and medical professions. Through these various outreach opportunities, students can explore the laboratories of pediatric faculty and engage with professional mentors in the field.

results.name: Threading the Past + Present
results.title: Michael C. Carlos Museum
results.subtitle: Emory
results.description: The Michael C. Carlos Museum provides a wide array of educational programming including specialized sessions for university students, faculty, and K-12 teacher resources. Participants can explore the institution's permanent collection and special exhibitions through guided tours and various digital programs. The museum places a strong emphasis on conservation and provenance research, offering unique opportunities to study the history and care of artistic acquisitions. Through publications and digital projects like the Den of Antiquity blog, the museum facilitates deep engagement with art history and cultural responsibility.

results.name: Swarthmore College
results.title: Student research - overview
results.subtitle: Swarthmore College
results.description: Students participating in this research program engage in running simulations using Matlab or Python, analyzing mathematical models, and organizing visualization data while reading relevant scientific literature in neuroscience and hearing science. Participants develop advanced computational skills and learn mathematical techniques while interacting with peers and research groups at the institution and beyond. While there are no specific prerequisites, students are most prepared if they have knowledge of differential equations and familiarity with scientific computing software. Participants are expected to work independently or collaboratively on original research, culminating in a written summary, organized simulation code, and a presentation at departmental talks or poster sessions. Throughout the experience, Professor Goldwyn provides guidance through regular meetings, provides necessary research resources, and mentors students on scientific communication and future career endeavors.

results.name: Summer Program for Verbally and Mathematically Precocious Youth
results.title: VAMPY
results.subtitle: Western Kentucky University
results.description: VAMPY is a residential camp designed for high-ability students who have completed grades 7–10, providing an immersive environment where participants focus on a single course of their choosing. Students attend intensive classes each weekday along with a mandatory study hall, all taught by highly motivated university faculty and experienced high school teachers. Beyond the rigorous academic schedule, campers live in supervised residence halls and participate in various community-building activities such as team games, weekend cookouts, and social dances. Prospective applicants must submit ACT or SAT scores to demonstrate eligibility for this challenging program that emphasizes both academic growth and the development of lifelong friendships among diverse peers from across the nation and world.

results.name: North Carolina State University (NCSU)
results.title: Summer Textile Exploration Program (STEP)
results.subtitle: NC State University
results.description: The Summer Textile Exploration Program (STEP) is a week-long residential camp designed for rising high school seniors interested in fields such as fashion, engineering, polymer science, and business marketing. Participants engage in hands-on projects within state-of-the-art labs and studios, choosing from concentrations like marketing, design, or chemistry. Throughout the session, students experience college life by living in residence halls, dining on campus, and touring industry-leading manufacturers and brands. The program also provides opportunities to connect with faculty and alumni while learning about admissions processes and scholarship opportunities. Admission is competitive, with selection based on academic achievement, extracurricular activities, and a demonstrated interest in textile-related disciplines.

results.name: Coding for Game Design
results.title: Coding for Game Design High School Summer Program
results.subtitle: NYU Steinhardt
results.description: This intensive program invites high school students entering their sophomore, junior, or senior years to master the principles of game design through hands-on development. Participants utilize C# and Unity scripting to create original 2D games while working closely with professional game designers and developers in a collaborative team environment. Applicants must possess an intermediate understanding of programming, typically demonstrated by completing at least one formal coding course with a B+ or higher.
