The curriculum integrates traditional coding fundamentals with a modern workshop on the ethical and effective use of Generative AI in the game development process. Students engage in daily lessons covering mechanics, aesthetics, and level design, culminating in a final game showcase where teams present their finished products.

results.name: Summer Session
results.title: High School Summer Pre-College Opportunities
results.subtitle: UC Santa Cruz
results.description: High school students can begin their college journey early through this for-credit pre-college pathway by enrolling in genuine UC undergraduate courses alongside current university students. Participants earn official UC credits that are transferable to future colleges and universities while building an academic transcript before high school graduation. Learning formats are flexible, offering online synchronous, online asynchronous, and in-person commuter options to accommodate different student needs across various subject areas. Students experience the rigor of university-level work and gain firsthand exposure to college expectations, academic culture, and various potential majors. Commuter students also gain access to university resources like libraries and fitness centers, although on-campus housing is not provided for high school participants.

results.name: Pre-College Scholars Program
results.title: Pre-College Scholars Program
results.subtitle: A. James Clark School of Engineering, University of Maryland
results.description: The Pre-College Scholars Program is designed to recruit talented high school students to the A. James Clark School of Engineering by focusing on those with an interest in mathematics, science, and engineering. Open to rising juniors and seniors in Maryland and Washington, D.C., with a minimum 3.5 GPA, the curriculum includes extensive SAT preparation in small classroom settings and workshops on college admissions and financial aid. Over the course of three weeks, participants receive approximately 49 hours of instruction, including departmental presentations from eight engineering departments and one-on-one assistance with the college application process. Students are required to attend all sessions, including mandatory orientation and pre- and post-tests, while utilizing personal laptops and online resources from the College Board and Khan Academy. The program cost is $400 per student, with scholarships available based on demonstrated financial need to ensure accessibility for qualified applicants.

results.name: Pre-College
results.title: The Upward Bound Program
results.subtitle: Pre-College Programs
results.description: The Upward Bound Program is a federally funded and state-supported educational initiative designed to provide academic and counseling services to students in preparation for post-secondary education. The initiative supplements the secondary school experience by creating opportunities for academic, social, and emotional development through both summer and academic year sessions. Participants can engage in robotics classes to learn fundamental programming and coding for Sphero Robots, as well as utilize 24/7 tutoring via Photostudy for subjects ranging from Algebra to SAT preparation. The program also offers access to mind mapping software to assist with research papers, citations, and assignment timelines to enhance college readiness. These comprehensive services are designed to mitigate economic and social inequities while maintaining high student retention and persistence rates.

results.name: Summer Science Academy
results.title: Summer Science Academy
results.subtitle: Emory School of Medicine
results.description: The Summer Science Academy is a two-week science enrichment day program designed for incoming 9th and 10th grade students interested in healthcare and STEM fields. Participants engage in a series of hands-on lectures, laboratory sessions, and field experiences that explore topics such as biotechnology, natural science, and medical research. The program is led by qualified medical students, health professionals, and teachers who focus on introducing fundamental scientific principles and various career paths in science. This non-residential academy operates from 9:00 am to 3:30 pm on weekdays, and while all learning supplies are provided, students are responsible for bringing their own daily lunches. Registration requires the completion of liability and media release forms, with enrollment fees payable via major credit cards.

results.name: AggieSTEM

deadlines.label: Last day to submit roommate requests
Last Day to submit Scholarship Applications

program_dates.label: Aggie STEM 2026 AI + Lesson Study Immersive PD

results.title: Aggie STEM
results.subtitle: A collaboration between Texas A&M’s College of Education and Human Development and the faculty of the College of Engineering
results.description: Aggie STEM offers a variety of summer programs, including overnight camps for middle and high school students as well as day camps for elementary students. These camps focus on project-based learning in diverse fields such as engineering design, advanced technological tools, and mathematical modeling. In addition to student-focused sessions, the program provides an immersive professional development opportunity for educators to integrate artificial intelligence tools into their teaching frameworks. Participants engage in classes led by STEM professionals and university faculty, exploring real-world scientific problems through hands-on activities. The curriculum is designed to encourage advanced students to explore STEM-related fields while building lasting connections through interactive social events.

results.name: PME University of Chicago
results.title: Summer Lab and Research Experiences
results.subtitle: Pritzker School of Molecular Engineering
results.description: The UChicago PME hosts a variety of summer programs designed for participants to engage in authentic, immersive, and intensive mentored research experiences. These opportunities cater to a wide audience including undergraduate students looking to advance research skills, community college students exploring STEM degrees, high school teachers interested in quantum technologies, and high school students ready for real-world research. Specific offerings include the Research Experience for Undergraduates (REU), the City Colleges of Chicago Summer Program, the After School Matters STEM Lab Internship, and the TeachQuantum program. Participants receive structured and formal mentorship to support their learning within a professional laboratory environment. These initiatives focus on providing exposure to emerging technologies and practical applications while fostering professional development in scientific fields.

results.name: Yale Global Scholars
results.title: Yale Young Global Scholars
results.subtitle: Yale University
results.description: Yale Young Global Scholars is an academic enrichment program designed for outstanding high school students from across the globe. Participants select from interdisciplinary tracks including Innovations in Science & Technology, Politics of Law & Economics, and Solving Global Challenges. The program brings together a diverse cohort of students representing over 150 countries and all 50 U.S. states to form a global learning community. Students engage in rigorous academic activities such as lectures and collaborative sessions focused on addressing complex issues through a multi-faceted lens. This residential experience allows scholars to immerse themselves in an environment that prioritizes intellectual growth and meaningful international connections.

results.name: Summer Scholars
results.title: Summer Scholars
results.subtitle: University of Notre Dame
results.description: Summer Scholars participants spend two intensive weeks taking a challenging college-level course taught by University of Notre Dame faculty. The program maintains small class sizes to ensure high levels of personal attention while providing a rigorous and rewarding preview of college academics. Students may earn one transferable college credit upon the completion of a program track and are expected to collaborate on coursework outside of designated class times. Beyond the classroom, participants engage in the social facets of college life and have opportunities to participate in community service projects.

results.name: Future Leaders Program
results.title: Future Leaders Summer Program
results.subtitle: UC San Diego School of Global Policy and Strategy
results.description: This immersive program invites domestic and international high school students entering 10th through 12th grade to develop critical diplomacy and problem-solving skills focused on global affairs. Participants select a specialized track in climate crisis, artificial intelligence, digital influence, or energy innovation to research real-world leaders and represent their perspectives in hands-on negotiations. Throughout the experience, students work in small teams to analyze global data, develop actionable solutions, and produce a collaborative action research report. In addition to attending lectures from renowned scholars and visiting world-class research labs, attendees earn one unit of pre-collegiate credit and reside in campus dormitories while building a network of peers interested in social impact. The curriculum concludes with a formal final presentation day where teams share their innovative ideas with the broader community and invited guests.

results.name: Nurse Camp
results.title: Early Outreach
results.subtitle: University of Nevada, Las Vegas
results.description: UNLV Early Outreach provides college and career readiness programming specifically designed for K–10 students and their families. The initiative helps participants navigate their path to college through community programming that includes school visits for college fairs, career days, and family nights. Students can participate in year-round events focused on building curiosity about future careers and connecting with university and community partners. Additionally, the Young Rebels component offers academic and social enrichment where students engage in critical thinking and interact directly with university faculty and students. These varied engagement opportunities aim to help students envision themselves in a higher education setting while building academically minded friendships.

results.name: Pathways Research Internship
results.title: Yale Pathways Research Internships
results.subtitle: Yale University
results.description: Yale Pathways Research Internships (YPRI) connects qualified public high school students with scientific research labs for a seven-week summer program. These research experiences are designed to excite students about scientific investigation while enabling them to explore various new scientific fields. The initiative aims to increase college preparedness among participants and foster long-term relationships between laboratories and students enthusiastic about pursuing careers in research. Participating interns gain valuable exposure to the professional scientific environment by working directly in host labs.

results.name: TRIO Upward Bound Math & Science
results.title: Upward Bound Math & Science Center
results.subtitle: University of Nevada, Las Vegas
results.description: The Upward Bound Math & Science Center is a federally funded college preparatory program designed for first-generation and income-qualified students between the ages of 13 and 19. This free program focuses on identifying and motivating participants from select target high schools to complete secondary education and graduate from post-secondary institutions. Students receive comprehensive support during the academic year, including specialized instruction in math and science, tutoring, ACT/SAT preparation, and career exploration. Additionally, participants can engage in a six-week summer residential program that offers a university life experience, rigorous STEAM curriculum, and opportunities for mentorship with faculty and internships.

results.name: Reflections Competition
results.title: Reflections Arts Program
results.subtitle: National PTA
results.description: The Reflections Arts Program is a long-standing arts education initiative that invites students in pre-K through grade 12 to explore their thoughts and develop artistic literacy. Participants create original works of art based on an annual student-selected theme across six categories: Dance Choreography, Film Production, Literature, Music Composition, Photography, and Visual Arts. The program offers several participation levels including Primary, Intermediate, Middle School, High School, and an Accessible Arts division designed specifically for students with disabilities. Successful entries move from local PTA units through state levels to reach the national competition, where students are eligible for recognition such as the Award of Excellence and the Award of Outstanding Interpretation.

results.name: Bentley University
results.title: Analytics Academy
results.subtitle: Bentley University
results.description: Bentley's Analytics Academy is a week-long pre-college program designed for rising juniors and seniors in high school to explore the vast potential of data. Participants gain insights into the world of data sciences through engaging presentations from guest speakers and intensive hands-on learning opportunities. Students work on a comprehensive capstone project that allows them to apply their newly acquired skills and knowledge to a real-world setting. The curriculum focuses on developing practical data analytics skills while ensuring a positive and discovery-oriented environment for all attendees. Under the guidance of experienced instructors, the program emphasizes both theoretical discovery and the practical application of data-driven insights.

results.name: YTI Online
results.title: YTI Online
results.subtitle: Emory Youth Theological Initiative
results.description: YTI Online is a program designed for youth to engage in weekly one-hour discussions centered around significant theological and social questions. Participants explore topics such as justice, the Bible, and ways to improve the world through shared reading materials provided by the initiative. The group is student-driven, allowing members to decide how the program proceeds and which books are selected for study. Facilitated by adults who engage with participants as equals, the program offers a supportive space for asking complex questions about faith and society. Although the program is currently on hiatus, it remains focused on fostering an environment where all inquiries are considered essential to the development of a healthy faith.

results.name: Summer Journalism

deadlines.label: Application deadline for U.S. and online visiting students for Session 2 (recommended)

results.title: Summer Journalism @ NYU
results.subtitle: Arthur L. Carter Journalism Institute
results.description: Summer Journalism @ NYU offers a variety of intensive credit-bearing courses for high school rising juniors and seniors, visiting undergraduate students, and lifelong learners. Participants can enroll in two- or four-credit classes covering specialized topics such as fashion industry reporting, newsroom production, and film journalism. The precollege track allows high school students to experience university life while earning credits, while the visiting student program welcomes international applicants and working professionals. Prospective students must submit an online application once the portal opens, with international participants required to demonstrate strong English proficiency due to the writing-intensive nature of the curriculum. On-campus housing is available for students, though it is important to note that financial aid is not offered to those in the visiting student category.

results.name: USA Computing Olympiad
results.title: USACO
results.subtitle: USACO
results.description: The USACO identifies, motivates, and trains high school students in computing through a series of online programming contests and educational resources. This program features four levels of competition—bronze, silver, gold, and platinum—allowing participants to progress as they improve their programming and computational problem-solving skills. A certified scoring system is implemented in advanced divisions to provide high credibility for results used in determining promotion and further selection. Top-performing students are invited to a proctored championship contest and an intensive summer training camp for advanced instruction and team selection. Based on these results, the organization selects representatives for prestigious international competitions, including the International Olympiad in Informatics and the European Girls' Olympiad in Informatics. Additionally, the program provides hundreds of hours of free online training resources and historical contest problems with solutions to support student learning worldwide.

results.name: Summer Seminar
results.title: Summer Programs
results.subtitle: U.S. Naval Academy
results.description: The Summer Programs at the U.S. Naval Academy provide students entering grades 9 through 12 with the opportunity to experience academic, athletic, and professional training in a collegiate environment. The Summer Seminar specifically targets rising 12th graders, offering a taste of life at the Academy while helping participants kick-start their official application process during a week of immersive training. For younger students, the Summer STEM program focuses on rising 9th to 11th graders interested in problem-solving, exploratory learning, and critical thinking within technical fields like science and technology. Throughout these sessions, attendees from around the world engage in team-building exercises and develop lifelong friendships while exploring the various majors and career opportunities available at the institution. These programs are designed to help prospective candidates understand the unique challenges and rewards of a Naval Academy education through hands-on activities and peer collaboration.

results.name: R Programming & Machine Learning Camp
results.title: 2026 ACB Camp
results.subtitle: miRcore
results.description: The Advanced Computational Biology Camp, offered to academically motivated high school and exceptional 8th-grade students, is a research-intensive program focused on identifying cancer biomarkers using microRNA expression data. Participants utilize the R programming language and machine learning packages to analyze big data from The Cancer Genome Atlas (TCGA) and generate professional scientific graphics for publications or science fairs. Students with varying levels of coding experience are grouped together to develop individual research projects while receiving support from multiple teaching assistants. The program requires active engagement in both technical learning and group activities, culminating in a Friday presentation of research projects developed throughout the week. Interested applicants must submit an essay for review and pay an application fee, with limited partial scholarships available for those demonstrating financial need.

results.name: GSTEM Online Data Science
results.title: GSTEM Online Data Science Course
results.subtitle: NYU
results.description: The GSTEM Online Data Science Course is a non-credit program designed for 11th and 12th-grade students with a strong academic background and a demonstrated interest in STEM fields. Developed and taught by NYU professors, the curriculum allows students to gain proficiency in gathering, processing, analyzing, and visualizing data using Python and mathematical principles. Participants engage in lectures featuring special guest speakers, including professional data scientists and prominent women in STEM. To be eligible for admission, applicants must have completed or be currently enrolled in Pre-Calculus and an introductory computer science course such as AP Computer Science Principles. The program costs $2,500 and requires an online application that includes high school transcripts and two short essay responses.

results.name: Terp Young Scholars
results.title: Terp Young Scholars
results.subtitle: University of Maryland Extended Studies
results.description: The Terp Young Scholars program offers a transformative three-week pre-college experience for high school students from rising grade 10 through graduating grade 12. Participants have the opportunity to earn three university credits while exploring new academic fields and connecting with experienced faculty members. The program provides flexible learning options, including an immersive campus experience and interactive virtual classes that can be completed online from any location. This rigorous environment is designed to challenge students' academic curiosity and provide a realistic introduction to the expectations of university-level coursework.

results.name: International Relations Academy
results.title: International Relations Academy
results.subtitle: Georgetown University School of Continuing Studies
results.description: The International Relations Academy offers high school students a comprehensive one-week immersive experience exploring global issues and contemporary foreign policy challenges. Participants learn directly from world-renowned faculty, specialists, and practitioners through a blend of academic lectures, off-site visits, and hands-on activities. The curriculum covers diverse subject areas such as international law, the instruments of foreign policy, intelligence, and the future of the international system. Students engage in small discussion groups to examine in-depth issues and participate in a collaborative international crisis simulation. Upon successful completion of the program, every participant receives a Certificate of Participation.

results.name: Summer Session
results.title: Summer Session
results.subtitle: Rutgers–New Brunswick
results.description: Summer Session at Rutgers–New Brunswick provides an opportunity for students to get ahead on degree credits through a diverse array of academic offerings. Participants can choose from more than 1,600 courses, including internships, travel opportunities, and specialized research experiences. The program is designed to accommodate a variety of learners, specifically current Rutgers students, visiting students, international participants, and pre-college scholars. Enrolled individuals can utilize numerous university resources, including financial aid, scholarships, and the Office of the Registrar to manage their academic progress.

results.name: Engineering Program
results.title: Engineering Summer Program
results.subtitle: Institute for STEM Education (I-STEM)
results.description: The Engineering Summer Program, offered by the Institute for STEM Education (I-STEM), is designed for high school students who have completed at least the ninth grade. Participants explore the fundamentals of digital electronics and physical computing through hands-on labs using the Arduino Microcontroller. Throughout the course, students learn to program microcontrollers, wire electronic components, and use analog signals to control devices like sensors and motors. No prior experience in programming or electronics is necessary for enrollment, though the curriculum remains technically rigorous and focuses on real-world engineering challenges involving motors and driver boards. The program concludes with a student-designed final project where participants build automated mechanisms or smart devices to demonstrate their problem-solving and engineering design skills. Interested students must submit an application form along with recommendation forms from both a math and a science teacher.

results.name: Oakland University
results.title: Emerging Scholars Program
results.subtitle: Oakland University
results.description: The Emerging Scholars Program at Oakland University offers a two-semester conditional admission to high school students who demonstrate academic strength but do not meet general admission requirements. To remain in the program, students must enroll full-time in both fall and winter semesters and successfully complete at least 67 percent of their attempted credits. Academic standards for participants include earning a minimum of 28 credits during the first year and maintaining a cumulative GPA of 2.0 or higher. Participants are further required to attend new student orientation, engage in mandatory advising sessions, and meet with a success coach on a weekly basis. Students must also enroll in Collegiate Communication (COM 1100) to foster essential academic skills and prepare for full admission to the university.

results.name: ChemiCo
results.title: ChemiCo
results.subtitle: StemCo
results.description: ChemiCo is an international Olympiad-style Chemistry competition that operates as part of the broader StemCo framework. This program is specifically designed to catalyze the discovery and development of student competencies through expertly crafted assessment tools. Participation is open to secondary school students ranging from grades 7 to 12 with no specific age restrictions. The competition is accessible to a global audience and is offered in several languages, including English, Russian, French, Portuguese, and Romanian. Participants have the opportunity to utilize sample questions and a syllabus outline to prepare for the challenge of competing against peers internationally.

results.name: Scripps College of Communication
results.title: High School Media Workshop
results.subtitle: Ohio University
results.description: The High School Media Workshop offers aspiring creatives a hands-on opportunity to explore various production paths including video production, animation, music technology, and audio for cinema. Participants work alongside university professors and current students to create original projects using professional studios and lab equipment. This overnight residential experience includes lodging in university residence halls and meals in dining facilities to provide a complete taste of campus life. Throughout the program, students gain technical skills in digital cinematography and post-production while building community with like-minded peers from across the country. All skill levels are welcome to participate in this immersive environment designed to help future media professionals find their creative direction.

results.name: The Cutting-Edge of Biological Discovery
results.title: Biology: The Science of Cells and Innovation
results.subtitle: Georgetown University
results.description: This online biology program for students ages 13 and older examines cellular frameworks, microscopy, and the intersection of cell organization and human disease. Students select from two modalities: a 20- to 30-hour enrichment track or a 128-hour college credit track that recommends high school biology as a prerequisite. Both options feature 100% online flexible video lessons from university faculty, dedicated mentorship from TAs, and a final capstone project to demonstrate mastery of course material. Depending on the chosen track, participants earn either a certificate of completion or a formal Georgetown transcript with a letter grade for their academic work.

results.name: Girls in Math
results.title: Yale Math Competitions
results.subtitle: Yale
results.description: Yale Math Competitions involves a series of academic events focused on the field of mathematics. The program provides an opportunity for students to engage with challenging problems that test their quantitative and analytical abilities. Participants can showcase their mathematical skills in a competitive environment designed to promote academic growth. These competitions are associated with Yale and aim to foster a community of students interested in the mathematical sciences.

results.name: Filmmakers Workshop
results.title: Tisch Online High School Filmmakers Workshop
results.subtitle: NYU Tisch School of the Arts
results.description: The Tisch Online High School Filmmakers Workshop provides high school freshmen, sophomores, juniors, and seniors with the opportunity to develop professional skills in writing, directing, shooting, and editing. Students participate in an asynchronous learning environment, watching pre-recorded video lectures at their own pace while completing daily or weekly assignments on the Smashcut platform. Throughout the program, participants produce a variety of short films, including a crew-based documentary, a music video, and a final narrative film. While students must supply their own filming technology and computer equipment, they engage in real-time video meetings with instructors and film crews to foster collaboration. Upon successful completion of the workshop, students earn four college credits and receive instruction from a faculty of experienced industry professionals.

results.name: University of Cincinnati
results.title: Medical Sciences Summer Institute
results.subtitle: University of Cincinnati College of Medicine
results.description: The Medical Sciences Summer Institute offers immersive summer workshops for rising high school juniors and seniors interested in medicine, healthcare, and biomedical research. Participants can choose from specialized tracks focusing on molecular biology, cellular topics, or medical informatics, which includes instruction on artificial intelligence and data science. The curriculum provides hands-on experience in a state-of-the-art environment, covering areas such as recombinant DNA, gene expression, and machine learning using healthcare data. Admission to the program requires a resume highlighting academic and leadership history, a personal statement, and a fee of $1100, though limited scholarships and financial aid are available to eligible applicants. Applicants must be at least 16 years old by the program start date to participate in these week-long full-day sessions.

results.name: Summer Research Experience
results.title: Clemson & PARI
results.subtitle: Clemson University and the Pisgah Astronomical Research Institute
results.description: Middle and high school students participate in hands-on explorations of astronomy and space science through this partnership between Clemson University and the Pisgah Astronomical Research Institute. Participants utilize state-of-the-art STEM technology, including NASA-built radio telescopes and research-grade optical telescopes, to conduct both independent and group research under the mentorship of professional scientists. The program offers unique opportunities for campers to earn an official research certificate and have their work published in summer research proceedings with possibilities for conference submission. In addition to technical scientific work, students engage in STEM challenges like rocketry competitions and visit cutting-edge research labs to interact with university professors and explore diverse career paths in exploration and discovery.

results.name: Academic Summer Camps
results.title: Grades 6 - 12 Academic Summer Camps at Northwestern University
results.subtitle: Northwestern Center for Talent Development
results.description: The Northwestern Center for Talent Development offers intensive academic summer camps for high-achieving students entering grades 6 through 12, featuring both one-week and three-week sessions with residential or day attendance options. Participants engage in fast-paced enrichment or credit-bearing courses that cover a wide range of subjects including mathematics, science, technology, writing, and leadership. Under the guidance of master teachers and industry experts, students tackle advanced concepts and produce tangible outcomes such as original apps or community action plans. The program fosters a global community of like-minded peers, providing opportunities for individual talent development and preparation for college and future careers. Eligibility is determined through a tiered system based on academic achievement or standardized test scores, and need-based financial aid is available to qualified applicants.

results.name: Marching Band Camp

program_dates.label: D&D: Adventures on the Astral sea (Grades 9-12)
Teen Med Camp 2: Beyond the Basics (Grades 9-12) Session 1
Teen Med Camp 2: Beyond the Basics (Grades 9-12) Session 2
D&D: Escapades in the city of Waterdeep (Grades 9-12)

results.title: Summer Camps: High School
results.subtitle: The University of Texas at Arlington
results.description: The University of Texas at Arlington offers a diverse selection of summer camps specifically designed for high school students entering grades 9 through 12. These programs provide specialized instruction in a variety of fields, including medical sciences through the Teen Med Camp series and technical exploration in Principles of Engineering and 3D printing. Creative students can engage in sessions focused on analogue photography and the professional process of publishing a book. Additionally, the university hosts immersive tabletop gaming experiences with Dungeons & Dragons adventures set in unique narrative environments. Each session is structured to provide high schoolers with hands-on learning and professional insights into their chosen subjects.

results.name: Georgia State

program_dates.label: SciSynth: A Journey into Scientific Computing - Summer Camp

results.title: SciSynth: A Journey into Scientific Computing - Summer Camp
results.subtitle: Advanced Research Computing Technology, Innovation & Collaboration
results.description: SciSynth: A Journey into Scientific Computing is a summer camp designed for high school students and undergraduates to explore the practical applications of computational skills across diverse fields such as medicine, aerospace, and meteorology. Participants develop a foundation in Python programming and data analysis while working with essential libraries like NumPy, Pandas, and Matplotlib. The curriculum covers complex subjects including numerical solutions to ordinary differential equations, machine learning, and the fundamentals of distributed and parallel computing. Students engage in collaborative hands-on projects where they research real-world problems and write tailored programs for tasks like simulating heat transfer, developing autonomous vehicle prototypes, or analyzing crime and census data. Expert workshop staff provide mentorship throughout the program, which carries a registration cost with limited support available for those who apply by the mid-April deadline.

results.name: Human Resources Intern
results.title: MAIN PAGE
results.subtitle: Loading...
results.description: The provided documentation for this entry is currently in a loading state and does not contain specific details about the program or its offering institution. No information is available concerning the target audience, the nature of the extracurricular activity, or the specific logistics. Without more descriptive text, it is impossible to identify the goals or curriculum of this offering. Further details are required to construct a full informational profile for this activity once the content becomes available.

results.name: Project Ignite
results.title: Project Ignite
results.subtitle: CMU
results.description: High school students participate in Project Ignite to pursue hands-on projects outside their typical schoolwork under the mentorship of college students. Participants have the option to either propose their own project ideas or join pre-proposed themes developed by the project advisors. Throughout the program, students take the lead in dictating the direction and outcome of their work while gaining experience in budgeting, time management, and teamwork. College advisors from various academic backgrounds provide guidance during regular workshops, helping high schoolers develop critical thinking and problem-solving skills. The program requires participants to dedicate time to both the interactive sessions and independent research to explore new fields or deepen existing interests.

results.name: Columbia Writing Academy: Summer
results.title: Columbia University Pre-College Programs
results.subtitle: Columbia University
results.description: Columbia University Pre-College Programs offer high school students an academic platform to engage with challenging university-level coursework. Participants must utilize a secure login system requiring a Columbia UNI and password to access the program's restricted digital content. This portal serves as the primary interface for students to manage their authentication credentials and view essential program information. By maintaining a centralized access point, the institution ensures that all educational materials and administrative features remain available to authorized users throughout their pre-college experience.

results.name: Healthcare Exploration
results.title: Buffalo Healthcare Exploration
results.subtitle: Roswell Park Comprehensive Cancer Center
results.description: The Buffalo Healthcare Exploration program, offered through the Roswell Park ATLAS program, provides high school students in grades 9 through 11 with an immersive opportunity to explore various medical disciplines within a fast-paced clinical environment. Participants engage in hands-on research activities, tour specialized laboratories, and experience simulated robotic surgery while learning directly from leading healthcare professionals and researchers. The curriculum emphasizes both technical and interpersonal development, allowing students to obtain certifications in CPR and Stop the Bleed while learning about the patient journey and necessary soft skills for healthcare careers. This learning experience is built upon six core pillars: innovation, compassion for community, empathy, visualization of complex concepts, education, and career path understanding. While the program carries a registration fee, full scholarships are available for students who qualify for the National School Lunch Program to ensure accessibility for all aspiring medical professionals.

results.name: Illini Summer Academies
results.title: Illini Summer Academies
results.subtitle: University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign
results.description: Illini Summer Academies is a personal development experience hosted for high school students to explore their potential and broaden their horizons through immersive learning. This program combines hands-on activities, expert-led workshops, and engaging discussions to inspire curiosity and build practical skills across disciplines like science, technology, the arts, and social sciences. Participants engage in specialized academies led by university professors and faculty covering diverse topics such as AI and machine learning, veterinary medicine, engineering, business, and sustainability. Students experience life as college students during the day while enjoying a camp-like atmosphere in the evenings within a world-class university setting. The program connects like-minded peers and provides access to top university resources to help students gain insights and develop their talents for the future.

results.name: Business Opportunities Summer Session
results.title: Business Opportunities Summer Session (BOSS)
results.subtitle: Smeal College of Business
results.description: The Business Opportunities Summer Session (BOSS) is a two-week residential program designed for high school juniors from the United States and Puerto Rico who are interested in pursuing a business education. Participants stay in residence halls and engage in business fundamentals courses taught by college faculty while experiencing a real campus living environment and interacting with academically driven peers. The curriculum includes hands-on learning components such as a business pitch group presentation and site visits to corporate environments and various local business operations to see how they function. To apply, students must submit a personal statement, high school transcripts, standardized test scores, and a letter of recommendation from a teacher or counselor. A program fee is required only after a student has been accepted into the session.

results.name: Entrepreneurship Challenge
results.title: Diamond Challenge
results.subtitle: Paul & Linda McConnell Youth Entrepreneurship Initiative
results.description: The Diamond Challenge is an international entrepreneurship competition designed for high school students who want to create solutions for issues they are passionate about. Participants compete in either the business innovation or social innovation tracks, with the top three teams in each category receiving substantial prize funding to further their entrepreneurial journeys or support their education. In addition to the main awards, teams can win specialized topical prizes for innovations in sustainability, technology, and human well-being. Every participant benefits from joining a global community where they receive feedback from over 2,000 industry professionals and have the chance to grow their network for future collaborations.

results.name: Forensics Investigators
results.title: Forensics Investigators Program
results.subtitle: Rice University
results.description: The Forensics Investigators Program is an immersive experience designed for middle and high school students in grades 7-10 who are interested in crime scene investigation and scientific inquiry. Participants engage in hands-on learning to unravel mysteries behind crime scenes while developing critical thinking skills essential for a future in forensic science. Students acquire practical skills ranging from evidence collection to the identification, classification, and analysis of various evidence types such as fingerprints, DNA, and blood. The program includes a daily lunch for all attendees, and a limited number of scholarships are available for those who apply by the required deadline. Registration requires the completion of participant agreements and release forms, with spots filled on a first-come, first-served basis.

results.name: Athena Summer Innovation Institute
results.title: Athena Summer Innovation Institute
results.subtitle: Barnard Pre-College Programs
results.description: The Athena Summer Innovation Institute is an intensive three-week boot camp where students develop the practical skills and knowledge needed to launch impactful ventures. Working in collaborative teams, participants design new startup businesses, non-profit organizations, or advocacy campaigns aimed at disrupting traditional industries and creating social good. The curriculum includes engaging workshops on product ideation, customer research, branding, marketing, and startup finances led by seasoned entrepreneurs and instructors. Students benefit from personalized mentorship, public speaking practice with Speaking Fellows, and site visits to successful companies to observe real-world innovation. The program culminates in a final Pitchfest, where teams present their developed concepts and receive feedback on their refined elevator pitches.

results.name: Health Professions Program
results.title: Northwestern University Feinberg School of Medicine
results.subtitle: Northwestern University
results.description: The Northwestern University Feinberg School of Medicine offers more than 200 clinical, graduate, and professional programs designed to foster a diverse environment of medical training and scientific discovery. Faculty and students contribute to a dynamic research enterprise that produces breakthroughs in human health, including advancements in treating genetic brain disorders and understanding immune evasion strategies. For advanced trainees, the Starzl Academy provides formal mentorship, specialized training programs, and resources to support residents and fellows in their journey to becoming physician-scientists. The institution focuses on advancing health equity and medical technology, such as engineering the world’s smallest cardiac pacemaker, through an extensive network of departments and centers. Additionally, participants are connected to top-tier healthcare systems, enabling a seamless integration of academic scholarship and clinical care.

results.name: FIU
results.title: Summer Research Internship
results.subtitle: FIU College of Arts, Sciences & Education
results.description: The Summer Research Internship is an eight-week cardiovascular health program designed for South Florida high school students as well as incoming first-year and transfer students at the university. Participants are matched with faculty research mentors to engage in interdisciplinary laboratory work spanning fields such as biology, chemistry, engineering, and physics. The program requires a commitment of at least 15 research hours per week alongside a curriculum component featuring case studies, journal clubs, and professional development workshops. Interns must complete mandatory safety training and enrollment in an internship course before producing a final abstract and presenting their research project at a symposium.

results.name: Summer Pre-College at the UMass Mount Ida Campus

program_dates.label: Summer Design Academy (Residential @ Mount Ida Campus)

results.title: Summer Pre-College at the UMass Mount Ida Campus
results.subtitle: University of Massachusetts Amherst
results.description: Summer Pre-College at the UMass Mount Ida Campus offers rising high school sophomores through seniors the opportunity to engage in college-level coursework across multiple disciplines, including psychology, design, and veterinary technology. Participants can choose between residential and commuter options, with all students gaining access to university dining services, recreation centers, and specialized co-curricular activities. Residential students live in modern dormitories and receive support from trained live-in program assistants who facilitate community building through planned social events. The curriculum is designed to be academically rigorous, allowing students to learn directly from university faculty while experiencing the daily realities of campus life. This program helps students explore potential career paths in architecture, health sciences, and the social sciences through immersive, hands-on learning experiences.

results.name: LUC
results.title: Social Justice Internship
results.subtitle: Loyola University Chicago
results.description: The Social Justice Internship Grant Program provides a year-long, cohort-based experiential learning opportunity where students complete between 250 and 275 hours of service at partner non-profit organizations. Participating undergraduates engage with various community partners such as Catholic Charities, Misericordia, GirlForward, ONE Northside, or Forging Opportunities for Refugees in America. During the fall semester, the group meets for community building and reflection, while the spring semester requires enrollment in the EXPL 390 internship seminar to earn three hours of academic credit. Eligible rising sophomores, juniors, and seniors with a minimum 3.0 GPA can receive a $4,000 grant applied to their educational costs upon successful completion of the program requirements. Selection for the thirteen available positions is determined through a competitive application process based on submission quality and demonstrated financial need.

results.name: Yale
results.title: Prospective High School Interns
results.subtitle: Yale University
results.description: The Social Robotics Lab offers a summer internship program where high school students work alongside the PI, staff, and graduate students on special research projects. This competitive educational opportunity focuses on training, skill development, and gaining a deeper understanding of concepts through hands-on application in the fields of robotics and human social behavior. The program is open to rising juniors and seniors who are at least 16 years of age and can commit to a minimum of six weeks. Participants are selected based on their interests and skills relative to the current lab workload, though no housing or compensation is provided for the duration of the internship.

results.name: Summer Study
results.title: Babson Summer Study for High School Students
results.subtitle: Babson College
results.description: Babson Summer Study for High School Students is an intensive three-week pre-college program designed for rising juniors and seniors to develop an entrepreneurial mindset as innovators and changemakers. Participants enroll in a formal college course, EPS1110: Introduction to the Entrepreneurial Experience, earning four academic credits while exploring social, economic, and environmental challenges through the lens of the United Nations Global Goals. The curriculum integrates essential business disciplines such as marketing, finance, and business communication using the institution's unique Entrepreneurial Thought & Action methodology. Students collaborate in global teams on social impact projects and receive personalized guidance from academic mentors who are current graduate and undergraduate student leaders. Available in both fully online and in-person formats, the program provides unique access to world-class faculty and a network of innovative leaders from a top-ranked entrepreneurial ecosystem.

results.name: Ann Arbor Entrepreneurship
results.title: San Diego Flagship Entrepreneurship
results.subtitle: LaunchX
results.description: This flagship summer initiative offers high school students aged 14 to 18 the opportunity to gain hands-on experience by launching a real startup. Students progress through a rigorous curriculum involving identification, ideation, iteration, and implementation to bring their business ideas to life. Participants are matched into teams based on a unique formula that pairs complementary skill sets, fostering collaboration within a global community of like-minded peers. Throughout the experience, students receive continuous feedback from industry expert mentors and work toward achieving customer sales and a final presentation at Demo Day. Financial awards are available for qualified applicants to ensure the program remains accessible to a diverse range of talented young entrepreneurs.

results.name: STRIDE Bioengineering
results.title: Summer Training and Research Inspiration for Diverse Pipeline Engagement toward Advancing Stem Cell Treatment
results.subtitle: MARLAN AND ROSEMARY BOURNS COLLEGE OF ENGINEERING
results.description: The Summer Training and Research Inspiration for Diverse Pipeline Engagement toward Advancing Stem Cell Treatment (STRIDE) is a five-week research training program designed for high school students who are at least sixteen years old. Participants engage in hands-on laboratory research projects focused on stem cells and regenerative medicine within fields such as bioengineering, neuroscience, and toxicology. Trainees are paired with diverse mentors, including undergraduate and medical students, to help build a pathway toward advanced scientific careers. Beyond technical research, the curriculum includes core workshops on communication skills, invited speakers, and professional development panels to prepare students for the STEM workforce. This initiative aims to diversify the professional pipeline by providing intensive educational activities and exposure to unmet medical needs.

results.name: High School Summer Internship Program
results.title: High School Summer Internship Program
results.subtitle: USC Dornsife Center for the Political Future
results.description: The High School Summer Internship Program, offered by the USC Dornsife Center for the Political Future in partnership with the USC Wrigley Institute for Environment and Sustainability, is a prestigious online opportunity for high school students. Interns are required to complete two major projects, including a legislative policy memo and a legislative process analysis, centered on environmental policy or sustainability bills at the local, state, or federal level. Participants must attend five mandatory check-in sessions, submit written assignments within deadlines, and refine their work based on feedback from program administrators. Eligibility requirements include maintaining a minimum GPA of 3.5 and being a current high school student who is not a graduating senior. Successful completion of the program results in public recognition as an official research intern and the publication of one of the student's assignments online.

results.name: Forensics Exploration
results.title: Explorations in Forensics Camp
results.subtitle: Institute for STEM Education (I-STEM)
results.description: The Explorations in Forensics Camp is an intensive summer program designed for students who have completed the 9th grade but have not yet taken a formal forensics course. Participants explore the application of biology, chemistry, and physics to legal matters through interactive, hands-on investigations and the study of noteworthy historical criminal cases. Throughout the week, students develop specialized skills in areas such as DNA fingerprinting, toxicology, and blood splatter analysis, culminating in the processing of a mock crime scene. The $750 program selects a maximum of 24 participants based on academic records, essays, and two teacher recommendations. This workshop serves as a challenging environment for inquisitive students to apply scientific principles and determine their interest in further forensic studies.

results.name: Pre-College
results.title: Rice University Precollege Program
results.subtitle: Rice University
results.description: The Rice University Precollege Program offers high school students ages 13 and up the opportunity to explore advanced subjects through flexible, 100% online courses. Students can choose from a variety of disciplines including genome engineering, aerospace, law, and business, all featuring dynamic video lessons delivered by renowned university faculty. Throughout the 20 to 30 hours of instruction, participants receive guidance and support from expert mentors who assist with assignments and the final capstone project. To earn a Certificate of Completion, students must finish a capstone presentation that demonstrates their learning using their choice of media such as video, photography, or text. The application process is designed to be accessible, requiring no transcripts or letters of recommendation to begin the program.

results.name: UWM
results.title: Future Success Program
results.subtitle: University of Wisconsin-Milwaukee
results.description: The Future Success Program at the University of Wisconsin-Milwaukee aims to increase postsecondary attendance by helping students meet college admission requirements and providing a foundation for academic success. Students in grades 9-12 participate in monthly workshops, tutoring, and career exploration activities, alongside specific initiatives like the Metro Business Accounting Club and ACT exam preparation. The summer portion features a five-week instructional curriculum in core subjects like math, science, and English, plus exposure to STEM-related career paths such as architecture, nursing, and business. Comprehensive support services also include financial aid guidance, scholarship application assistance, campus visits, and financial literacy seminars to ensure students are fully prepared for higher education. Participants must be committed to attending regular academic year sessions and are eligible for DPI scholarships if they qualify for free or reduced-price lunch.

results.name: Tufts University

deadlines.label: Deadline to confirm acceptance of award

results.title: Summer Scholars Program
results.subtitle: Tufts University
results.description: The Summer Scholars Program at Tufts University provides funding for rising juniors and seniors to undertake ten-week independent research projects under the guidance of a faculty mentor. Participants from across all disciplines, including the fine arts and sciences, receive a $4,000 award for living expenses and a $1,000 research budget to support their work. This full-time commitment requires students to present their findings three times, including at an end-of-summer conference, a fall poster session, and a spring symposium. Applicants must be currently in their second or third year of study with a minimum GPA of 3.0 and must secure a commitment from a Tufts faculty member to serve as a mentor. The program often serves as a foundation for a senior honors thesis, allowing students to focus intensely on a specific research obsession without the distractions of summer classes or external employment.

results.name: Health & Biomedical Camp
results.title: Health & Biomedical Sciences Camp
results.subtitle: Lebanon Valley College
results.description: Designed for rising high school sophomores, juniors, and seniors, this residential program introduces students to the fundamentals of molecular biology, neuroscience, physiology, pharmacology, and immunology. Participants engage in hands-on laboratory investigations and lectures led by faculty to see how science translates into improved human health. Beyond classroom work, students interact with practicing professionals from various fields including physical therapy, toxicology, genetic counseling, and biomedical research. The all-inclusive tuition covers lodging in a college residence hall, meals, and all necessary laboratory supplies. Throughout the experience, campers are mentored by resident advisors who are current college science majors, providing a glimpse into the academic and social life of an undergraduate student.

results.name: CED Summer Institute

deadlines.label: Priority and financial assistance application deadline

results.title: Summer Institute
results.subtitle: CED
results.description: The Summer Institute provides an accelerated path for individuals with a bachelor's degree to explore careers in environmental design through specialized cohorts in architecture, city planning, and landscape architecture. This post-baccalaureate program welcomes young professionals and international students without prior design experience to develop a competitive portfolio for graduate school under faculty mentorship. Participants immerse themselves in the culture of design and planning studios while completing a rigorous schedule of lectures, media workshops, and site visits. Upon successful completion, attendees receive a certificate and official UC Berkeley transcript credit for their coursework. Admission to the program requires an online application consisting of a statement of intent, resume, academic transcripts, and an essay.

results.name: Bentley University

program_dates.label: Session E: Pathways for Women in Business

results.title: Pathways for Women in Business
results.subtitle: Bentley University
results.description: The Pathways for Women in Business program is a women-focused initiative designed to introduce high-school students to diverse and rewarding career opportunities within the business sector. Participants engage in interactive sessions, field trips, and mentoring workshops led by representatives from the Pulsifer Career Development Center, the Gloria Cordes Larson Center for Women and Business, and Bentley faculty members. Through various skills and values assessments, students explore potential majors and industries while building a strong foundation of leadership to enhance their future academic and professional journeys. The curriculum is offered in both residential and commuter formats and concludes with a formal presentation to parents.

results.name: Tulane University
results.title: Explorations in Architecture and Design
results.subtitle: Tulane Pre-College Programs
results.description: Explorations in Architecture and Design is a studio-based pre-college program designed for rising high school juniors and seniors who want to analyze design fundamentals and investigate the built environment. Participants engage in a comprehensive curriculum featuring lectures, field trips, critiques, and dedicated studio time under the guidance of university faculty. Students develop a professional portfolio of projects including models and drawings while earning three hours of transferable college credit that can apply toward an undergraduate degree. The application process requires a high school transcript, an interest essay, and a teacher recommendation, with admission decisions made on a rolling basis. Beyond formal class sessions, participants can access assigned studio desks during additional open hours to receive support from teaching assistants who are current architecture students.

results.name: College Edge: Summer
results.title: College Edge: Summer
results.subtitle: Columbia University Pre-College Programs
results.description: High school students in grades 11 and 12 participate in the College Edge program to earn university credit by enrolling in undergraduate courses alongside current college students. Participants receive comprehensive support through academic advisement, professional development opportunities, and specialized workshops designed to explore personal values and leadership skills. The curriculum is taught by world-class faculty and requires students to commit to significant independent study time, typically two to three hours for every hour spent in class. Beyond the classroom, the program offers seminars and lectures aimed at preparing students for the academic rigors of university life while helping them develop lasting connections with a global peer group.

results.name: Quantitative Skills Program
results.title: SPARC
results.subtitle: Summer Program for Applied Rationality and Cognition Inc.
results.description: SPARC, the Summer Program for Applied Rationality and Cognition, is a specialized educational program organized as a registered 501(c)(3) nonprofit organization. The curriculum focuses on the domains of applied rationality and cognition, offering students a unique opportunity to engage with these complex subjects through structured activities. Prospective participants are required to submit their admissions applications through a designated online form to be considered for the program. Interested individuals can also subscribe to an email newsletter to receive official camp-related updates and news directly from the organizers. For further inquiries or specific details regarding the curriculum, the organization provides a dedicated contact email address for direct communication.

results.name: Laboratory for Laser Energetics
results.title: Summer High School Research Program
results.subtitle: Laboratory for Laser Energetics
results.description: The Summer High School Research Program is an eight-week paid internship designed for high school students entering their senior year who have a strong interest in science and a demonstrated academic aptitude. Participants are assigned to individual research projects where they are supervised by staff scientists and engineers, contributing to work involving world-class laser systems like the OMEGA and OMEGA EP lasers. Throughout the program, students engage in hands-on research in fields such as laser physics and materials science while attending specialized weekly seminars on technical topics and scientific communication. The experience culminates in a symposium where students present their findings and produce a final report that can be used to leverage college admissions and scholarship applications. To apply, students must provide a letter of interest, an essay describing their science background and future goals, a teacher recommendation, and academic transcripts.

results.name: Summer Design Academy
results.title: Summer Design Academy
results.subtitle: University of Massachusetts Amherst
results.description: The Summer Design Academy provides rising sophomores through seniors an opportunity to explore professions in architecture, landscape architecture, and urban or interior design. Students participate in interactive educational experiences including sketching, model-making, and an introduction to professional graphic and 3D computer programs. Throughout the program, participants attend lectures, join reading discussions, and visit an architecture office to gain insight into university-level design activities. The curriculum focuses on creating strong portfolio material that can be used for future college applications to design and architectural programs. Participants can earn three college credits and choose between residential, commuter, or online formats to suit their preferences.

results.name: Unveiling the Sugary Armor of Mycobacterial Cells

program_dates.label: Unveiling the Sugary Armor of Mycobacterial Cells (Morita Lab)

results.title: Unveiling the Sugary Armor of Mycobacterial Cells (Morita Lab)
results.subtitle: University of Massachusetts Amherst
results.description: This competitive six-week Research Intensive program invites high-achieving rising high school juniors and seniors to work in professional labs alongside distinguished faculty and graduate students. Participants in the Morita Lab will utilize techniques in molecular biology, biochemistry, and genetics to investigate how mycobacteria survive in the human body and resist antibiotic treatments. Students conduct research on mutants of a nonpathogenic model Mycobacterium species, specifically focusing on growth and survival mechanisms under various stress conditions. This specific lab section accommodates up to four students, all of whom will learn essential skills in basic microbiology and cell biology. Each participant will conclude their experience by creating and presenting a formal research poster at a session for faculty and family while earning six university credits.

results.name: National High School Game Academy
results.title: National High School Game Academy
results.subtitle: Carnegie Mellon University
results.description: The National High School Game Academy (NHSGA) is a six-week multidisciplinary program where high school students learn current industry best practices for video game development. Participants experience a blend of hands-on team projects and in-depth traditional classwork covering disciplines such as 2D and 3D art, software development, music composition, and game design. Students are organized into collaborative teams to create two original game prototypes, which often serve as high-quality pieces for college application portfolios. This rigorous residential program requires a full-time commitment, including mandatory in-person attendance and substantial evening and weekend homework using personal laptops. Applicants can apply for specific tracks including software development, visual arts, sound design, or game generalist roles based on their creative interests and technical skills.

results.name: Congressional Art Competition
results.title: Congressional Art Competition
results.subtitle: Congressional Institute
results.description: The Congressional Art Competition is a nationwide visual art contest designed to recognize and encourage the artistic talent of high school students across every congressional district. Participating students submit their original entries directly to their representative’s office for review by panels of local district artists who select the winning pieces. Winners receive recognition within their home districts and are honored at an awards ceremony celebrating their achievements. The top winning works from each district are showcased in a prestigious exhibition for public viewing. To enter, students must contact their specific representative to confirm participation, review the official competition rules, and submit the required student release form with their materials.

results.name: ASU
results.title: RISE Summer Leadership Institute
results.subtitle: RISE Leadership Institute | Educational Outreach and Student Services
results.description: The RISE Summer Leadership Institute is a residential career and college readiness program designed for students entering their junior or senior year of high school. Participants engage in a variety of workshops and interactive sessions led by professionals and educators who highlight the history and achievements of Black and African American leaders. The curriculum covers essential topics such as college readiness, choosing a major, financial wellness, and community networking to foster personal growth and self-care. While the application process is free, accepted students are required to pay a non-refundable registration fee to secure their spot in the program. This initiative encourages students to embrace their strengths and take meaningful steps toward their leadership and academic goals.

results.name: NextGen High School Internship
results.title: NextGen High School Internship Program
results.subtitle: Emory University School of Medicine
results.description: The NextGen High School Internship Program is a paid summer initiative designed for rising high school juniors and seniors who have a demonstrated interest in STEM fields. Hosted by the Department of Human Genetics, the program provides students with a multifaceted experience including informative lectures and rotations through various research labs and clinical settings. Participants gain hands-on experience in both laboratory and clinical environments while exploring diverse career opportunities within the healthcare and scientific communities. Beyond the intensive summer sessions, the program continues to engage students with various activities and programs throughout the school year to sustain their interest in science and medicine. Applicants must be at least 16 years old and show a commitment to advancing STEM education across diverse backgrounds.

results.name: Summer Stem
results.title: Cooper Union Summer STEM 2026
results.subtitle: The Cooper Union
results.description: Summer STEM offers high school students who have completed their 9th, 10th, or 11th-grade years a selective opportunity to engage with college-level engineering and computer science topics through intensive coursework. Participants can choose between three-week or six-week sessions that cover diverse subjects such as digital fabrication, circular design for sustainability, water quality engineering, and iOS app development using Swift. The curriculum emphasizes hands-on learning through activities like 3D modeling with CAD tools, circuit prototyping on breadboards, and utilizing numerical methods for scientific computing with Python. Students work in small teams on projects that explore faculty research or mimic activities performed by undergraduate students, culminating in polished design portfolios or functional hardware-software prototypes. While the program is open to international applicants and encourages students of all experience levels to apply, it is important to note that residential housing is not provided for participants.

results.name: International Linguistics Olympiad
results.title: International Linguistics Olympiad
results.subtitle: International Linguistics Olympiad
results.description: The International Linguistics Olympiad is an annual international competition designed for secondary school students to engage with the fields of linguistics through rigorous problem-solving. Participants are challenged to analyze the grammar, structure, culture, and history of diverse languages by solving complex puzzles that do not require any prior linguistic knowledge. The competition emphasizes logical ability, patient work, and creative thinking as students navigate tasks that test their language analysis skills. By fostering an environment that encourages imagination and cross-cultural understanding, the program aims to develop future experts and contribute to the growth of the academic linguistic community.

results.name: High School Summer Program

program_dates.label: Program Start (Graduation on or before May 30)
Program Start (Graduation on or after May 31)

results.title: Carl B. & Florence E. King Foundation High School Summer Program in Biomedical Sciences
results.subtitle: MD Anderson Cancer Center
results.description: The Carl B. & Florence E. King Foundation High School Summer Program in Biomedical Sciences is a 10-week initiative open to current Texas high school seniors who are at least 18 years old. The program introduces students interested in allied health careers to a professional research environment at a leading cancer center. Selected participants are paired with faculty mentors to conduct hands-on research projects in various biomedical disciplines within clinical and research laboratories. Students work full-time, attending supplemental seminars, preparing abstracts, and participating in poster and elevator speech competitions to build professional confidence. A financial stipend is provided to participants, though they are responsible for their own housing, transportation, and daily meals.

results.name: PennRSSA
results.title: Penn Rising Scholar Success Academy (PennRSSA)
results.subtitle: Penn VPSE
results.description: The Penn Rising Scholar Success Academy (PennRSSA) is a free, college preparatory and career exploration program designed for eligible high school students. Participation is open to students enrolled in school district, public charter, and archdiocese high schools regardless of their previous academic record. Participants engage in a blend of virtual learning and in-person experiences that focus on building foundational investment knowledge and navigating the postsecondary application and enrollment processes. The program provides engaged mentorship from university students, staff, and faculty within interactive settings to foster academic rigor and student achievement. Additionally, the academy utilizes trauma-informed practices and radical pedagogy to expand students' skills, confidence, and motivation for future success.

results.name: Summer Camp LLNL
results.title: SAGE
results.subtitle: Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory
results.description: Science Accelerating Growth and Engagement (SAGE) is a free, one-week summer day camp designed specifically for public high school students between the ages of 14 and 17. Led by passionate scientists and engineers, the program provides participants with hands-on discovery and authentic STEM experiences. Students build community and spark new interests while gaining valuable insights into potential future careers through connections with professionals who turn big ideas into innovations. In partnership with other Department of Energy national laboratories, the camp works to broaden participation in technical fields and inspire the next generation of scientific leaders and problem-solvers.

results.name: Pre-Law and Mock Trial Summer Academy
results.title: Pre-Law and Mock Trial Summer Academy
results.subtitle: Rutgers–New Brunswick
results.description: The Pre-Law and Mock Trial Summer Academy is a residential, in-person program designed for high school sophomores and juniors interested in the legal field and government. Taught by distinguished law faculty, participants engage in immersive lessons covering civil and criminal law, legal terminology, and the creation of laws. Students sharpen their advocacy and public speaking skills through interactive courtroom visits, guest lectures from legal professionals, and collaborative mock trial competitions. Participants can choose to focus on civil cases, criminal cases, or both, gaining hands-on experience in trial practice, witness examination, and case analysis. Upon successful completion of the academy, students earn a Rutgers Pre-College Digital Badge to recognize their achievement in mastering fundamental trial strategies and legal concepts.

results.name: Pollinator Health and Ecology
results.title: Pollinator Health and Ecology (Adler Lab)
results.subtitle: UMass Amherst
results.description: This competitive Research Intensive program allows high-achieving rising high school juniors and seniors to work in a professional lab environment alongside distinguished faculty and graduate students. Participants in the Adler Lab study how floral traits such as shape and size influence pollinator health, pathogen transmission, and species interactions. Students utilize a combination of field and laboratory experimental manipulations to investigate how pollen and nectar affect pollinator behavior and disease dynamics. Throughout the program, each student develops and presents a research poster to showcase their findings to faculty, peers, and family. The experience provides firsthand exposure to university-level research methodologies at a major R1 university while earning college credits.

results.name: Artificial Intelligence Academy
results.title: Artificial Intelligence Academy
results.subtitle: Georgetown University School of Continuing Studies
results.description: The Artificial Intelligence Academy offers high school students an immersive exploration into the scientific foundations and societal impacts of AI through a blend of lectures, guest speakers, and guided discussions. Participants delve into the science of AI, its historical origins, and emerging frontiers while exploring the ethical, social, and governance implications of these technologies. Students engage in hands-on exercises and applied projects to experiment with AI tools, test simple models, and analyze real-world use cases across diverse professional contexts. The curriculum focuses on identifying ethical considerations like bias and transparency, comparing global regulatory frameworks, and proposing design or policy solutions within the AI domain. This intensive program also features academic programming including off-site visits and capstone projects, with options for both residential and commuter students to participate.

results.name: Case Western Reserve University
results.title: Youth Engaged in Science
results.subtitle: Case Comprehensive Cancer Center
results.description: Youth Engaged in Science (YES) is a National Cancer Institute-funded summer program that provides eligible high school students with the opportunity to pursue research in cancer care and biology. Participants spend seven weeks working full-time in professional laboratories under the mentorship of university scientists, gaining hands-on experience for 35 hours each week. The curriculum begins with a foundational bootcamp covering laboratory safety and research techniques, followed by daily instructional sessions focused on career development, college preparation, and scientific writing. Students receive a $2,500 stipend for successful completion of the program and conclude their experience by presenting their research results at a formal end-of-summer celebration. Additional opportunities through the Scientific Enrichment Opportunity provide enhanced support and advocacy for scholars from specific partner school districts to ensure future success.

results.name: SCUDEM - SIMIODE Challenge
results.title: SCUDEM — SIMIODE Challenge Using Differential Equations Modeling
results.subtitle: SIMIODE
results.description: SCUDEM is a three-student group modeling challenge where participants utilize differential or difference equations to address complex real-world issues.
