Teams select from challenge problems categorized into physics and engineering, chemistry and life sciences, or social sciences to develop their mathematical models. The competition culminates in the production of a ten-minute video presentation that is evaluated by a panel of at least three judges. Submissions are recognized with rankings of Outstanding, Meritorious, or Successful based on the depth of the model and the quality of the presentation. Registered participants are provided with complimentary MATLAB and Simulink licenses through MathWorks to support their modeling efforts.

results.name: Rice University
results.title: Tribomechadynamics Research Camp
results.subtitle: Rice University
results.description: The Tribomechadynamics Research Camp (TRC) is a month-long research collaboration designed for students ranging from the postdoctoral level to the high school level. Participants with diverse technical backgrounds from around the world work in small teams on projects germane to interfacial mechanics and the dynamics of coupled structures. There is no registration fee for the program, and accommodation is provided free of charge for participants through corporate sponsorship provided by MTU Aero Engines. Research activities involve both experimental and computational investigations, such as studying time forecasting for hysteretic systems or the dynamics of friction-damped structures under complicated resonance scenarios. Applicants are required to submit a CV, a letter of recommendation from their advisor, and a cover letter detailing their research interests and project preferences.

results.name: Women's Technology
results.title: Women's Technology Program
results.subtitle: MIT
results.description: The Women's Technology Program is a rigorous four-week summer academic experience designed for high school students who have just completed their junior year. This program introduces participants to the field of engineering through a combination of hands-on classes, laboratory work, and collaborative team-based projects. It specifically targets students who have demonstrated excellence in math and science but have had little to no prior exposure to engineering disciplines. The curriculum is intended to help students who are uncertain about their future plans determine if engineering is the right fit for their academic interests. This experience provides a supportive environment for exploration and encourages students to consider future studies in technical fields.

results.name: AI-Scholars Pre-College
results.title: AI Scholars
results.subtitle: Carnegie Mellon University
results.description: AI Scholars is a fully funded, merit-based residential program designed for rising high school seniors interested in exploring artificial intelligence and computing concepts through college-level courses and research projects. Participants engage in a rigorous four-week curriculum that includes classroom instruction led by university faculty, industry field trips, and hands-on group projects culminating in a public capstone symposium. The program provides comprehensive support by covering all costs for tuition, housing, and meal plans, while also offering mentorship and college preparatory seminars focused on admissions and writing application essays. Eligible students must be at least 16 years old and in the 11th grade at the time of application, with a specific focus on supporting those from underrepresented backgrounds or those demonstrating financial need. In addition to technical instruction, scholars benefit from a virtual pre-program Python course and personal development workshops to prepare them for future academic and career pathways in tech.

results.name: Summer Language Institute
results.title: Summer Language Institutes (SLI)
results.subtitle: University of Maryland Extended Studies
results.description: The Summer Language Institutes (SLI) features intensive in-person learning for Beginner, Intermediate, and Advanced level language training through the School of Languages, Literatures, and Cultures. This program is open to a broad range of students, including pre-college learners, current university students, visiting undergraduates, and professionals. Participants can select from 12-credit, 6-credit, or 3-credit tracks, allowing for varying levels of commitment ranging from nine weeks to just ten days. All students must complete an application for the institute and are responsible for tuition at a per-credit rate plus mandatory campus services and program fees. The curriculum utilizes a strict plus/minus grading system, and options for online learning, pass-fail, or auditing are not permitted.

results.name: Science of Smart Cities
results.title: Science of Smart Cities (SoSC)
results.subtitle: New York University
results.description: The Science of Smart Cities (SoSC) is an immersive program for New York City students aged 12 to 14 that focuses on engineering, computer science, and technology to enhance urban sustainability and safety. Participants work in collaborative teams to design and build projects using microcontrollers, sensors, and circuitry while learning fundamental coding and electronics skills. This full-scholarship, non-credit program features instruction from university faculty and graduate students through highly interactive, hands-on sessions. Beyond technical training, students participate in the mandatory Irondale initiative, where theater artists use improv techniques to enhance public speaking and communication abilities. The curriculum culminates in final presentations where student teams demonstrate creative, innovative solutions to real-world challenges in a resource-rich environment.

results.name: Auburn University
results.title: Engineering Summer Programs
results.subtitle: Samuel Ginn College of Engineering
results.description: The Engineering Summer Programs at the Samuel Ginn College of Engineering invite students to explore the profession through interactive sessions and real-world problem-solving challenges. Programs include the Summer Engineering Expo for rising 9th-11th graders and a dedicated senior-level event that highlights various disciplines and the college admission process. For those interested in specialized fields, the Paper & Bioresource Engineering Camp offers firsthand experience with papermaking experiments and insights into the industry. Faculty members, staff, and current students facilitate these activities to ensure participants gain a comprehensive understanding of how engineering can lead to diverse careers in technology, business, and science.

results.name: TCNJ
results.title: Camp Innovate and Investigate
results.subtitle: School of Science
results.description: This immersive pre-college summer program is designed for motivated high school students entering grades 10 through 12 who have a strong interest in the sciences. Participants engage in hands-on experiments and real-world research at the intersection of biology, chemistry, physics, math, and computer science. Beyond technical lab work, the curriculum includes college preparation workshops covering personal statements and career development, alongside collaborative projects with industry professionals and faculty. Applicants must have completed one year of high school math and science and are required to submit a teacher recommendation and a short interest statement to be considered. The program cost is $475, and admitted students must follow a lab-safe dress code while utilizing the provided meal services throughout the week.

results.name: SARAS
results.title: SARAS
results.subtitle: Renaissance School of Medicine at Stony Brook University
results.description: SARAS is an educational program hosted by the Renaissance School of Medicine at Stony Brook University designed to provide students with insights into the world of biomedical sciences. Participants engage with experts across various medical and research fields through a series of lectures and presentations. The program aims to foster interest in healthcare careers and clinical research by exposing students to diverse specialties and professional pathways. Attendees have the opportunity to interact with faculty members and medical professionals to gain a deeper understanding of the medical school environment and laboratory research methodologies.

results.name: University of Georgia
results.title: Young Dawgs Program
results.subtitle: University of Georgia
results.description: The University of Georgia Young Dawgs Program is a high school internship program designed to prepare high-achieving juniors and seniors for post-secondary education and future careers. To be eligible for participation, students from public, private, or home schools must maintain a minimum 3.8 GPA. Participants can earn high school credit for their involvement through coordination with their school's Work-Based Learning Program or Gifted Program. This initiative allows students to explore their specific areas of interest and gain professional experience to help determine their future academic and career paths.

results.name: Summer Session
results.title: Approved Courses for High School Students
results.subtitle: UCLA
results.description: High school students have the opportunity to enroll in one or two approved courses alongside university students to earn college credit. Participants can select from a wide range of subject areas, including STEM fields, humanities, and performing arts, with a maximum limit of ten units per term. Enrollment involves a non-refundable registration fee and the creation of a student account to manage class selection and billing via the official university system. Students may choose between letter grading or a Passed/Not Passed basis, both of which result in a formal academic transcript reflecting their course performance. While coursework is generally transferable, students are encouraged to consult their home institutions for credit approval before registering for these courses.

results.name: Design Discovery Program
results.title: Design Discovery Youth Summer Program
results.subtitle: University of Virginia School of Architecture
results.description: Design Discovery is an immersive six-day program hosted for rising high school sophomores through seniors to explore the design process and experience design school. Participants engage in hands-on design and build workshops, visit local architecture firms, and tour active construction sites to gain real-world perspective on the building industry. The curriculum features a daily 'I See Me' lunch series where students interact with a diverse group of faculty and professionals, culminating in a public exhibition of their work for family and community partners. Enrollment options include both day and overnight tracks with dormitory stays, and a tiered tuition model ensures accessibility through merit-based scholarships and income-based fee waivers. This initiative aims to empower youth through design-thinking while introducing various career pathways within architecture and environmental planning.

results.name: American Politics Academy
results.title: American Politics Academy
results.subtitle: Georgetown University School of Continuing Studies
results.description: In the American Politics Academy, students engage in an in-depth exploration of the three branches of government through a combination of lectures, group discussions, and debate exercises. Participants examine how political parties, public opinion, and special interest groups influence political behavior while exploring the impacts of cultural shifts on national and local policies. The program provides unique access to guest speakers including key elected officials, Capitol Hill staff, and lobbyists who lead discussions on congressional campaigns and legislative priorities. Students put their knowledge into practice through hands-on activities such as congressional simulations and capstone projects. Upon successful completion of the academy, participants receive a Certificate of Participation to recognize their academic engagement with contemporary political debates.

results.name: Accelerated Learning Program (ALP)
results.title: Accelerated Learning Program (ALP)
results.subtitle: UNIVERSITY of WISCONSIN-MADISON
results.description: The Accelerated Learning Program (ALP) offers high school students finishing grades 9–12 an immersive three-week experience featuring fast-paced, rigorous, and hands-on academic exploration. Participants enroll in a single non-credit course led by expert instructors in specialized fields such as computer science, engineering, medical sciences, and international law. The program provides both residential and commuter options, allowing students to engage in small, personalized classes supported by undergraduate and graduate teaching assistants. Beyond the classroom, the curriculum fosters critical thinking and collaboration through experiential education, while residential staff coordinate social activities ranging from art-focused projects to athletic challenges. Admission requires a minimum 3.2 unweighted GPA, completed essays, and high school transcripts, with limited need-based scholarships available for qualified applicants.

results.name: Young Executive Scholars Hospitality and Tourism Program
results.title: Early Outreach
results.subtitle: University of Nevada, Las Vegas
results.description: UNLV Early Outreach provides comprehensive college and career readiness programming specifically designed for K–10 students and their families. The program aims to help students navigate their path to higher education through community programming, including school visits to participate in college fairs and career days. Participants can engage in year-round events that foster curiosity about future careers and provide opportunities to connect with campus and community partners. Through the Young Rebels initiative, students take part in academic and social enrichment activities that involve critical thinking and interactions with university faculty and students. These age-appropriate experiences, such as group campus tours, allow younger learners to envision themselves in a higher education setting while building academically minded friendships.

results.name: Future Scholars
results.title: Rutgers Future Scholars
results.subtitle: Rutgers, The State University of New Jersey
results.description: Rutgers Future Scholars is a comprehensive college access program designed to provide first-generation and low-income students with the necessary tools to navigate higher education. The program offers a multi-faceted support system that includes mentoring, tutoring, and academic enrichment services to ensure participants are prepared for the rigors of university life. Scholars benefit from diverse social and cultural experiences alongside general guidance intended to help them succeed both academically and personally. By fostering a "college-minded and life-ready" approach, the initiative empowers promising students with life-changing opportunities and long-term support to get them to and through college.

results.name: Design Media Arts

program_dates.label: DMA Summer Institute Commuter Program (Session A3)
DMA Summer Institute Virtual Program (Session B3)

results.title: DMA Summer Institute
results.subtitle: UCLA Design Media Arts
results.description: The DMA Summer Institute is a three-week program designed for highly motivated high school students interested in multidisciplinary media creation and innovative thinking. Participants explore foundational design practices across four core areas: 2D image and typography, creative coding for the web, 3D worldbuilding using game engines like Unity, and experimental motion graphics. Instructors from the UCLA graduate program lead the curriculum, which includes morning and afternoon classes that culminate in a final exhibition and a portfolio-ready body of work. Enrolled students earn four units of pass/no pass UC credit while gaining a unique preview of college life in a top-tier design department.

results.name: Summer Challenge
results.title: Summer Challenge
results.subtitle: Boston University
results.description: Summer Challenge is a two-week program designed for rising high school sophomores, juniors, and seniors to experience life on a college campus and take on new academic challenges. Participants select two seminars from an extensive catalog, participating in lectures, discussions, and project-based assignments that provide individual attention from experienced college instructors. The curriculum is supplemented by an admissions workshop designed to give students valuable insight into the complexities of the college application process. Open to both residential and commuter students, the program fosters a close-knit social community where participants can explore their interests and discover new academic passions.

results.name: Big Idea Competition
results.title: BIG Idea Competition
results.subtitle: Big Idea SD
results.description: The BIG Idea Competition is an initiative designed for young entrepreneurs to develop and present innovative business solutions for real-world problems. Participants are encouraged to use creative thinking and technology to address challenges they hear about in the news or experience personally. The program offers significant incentives for high school students, including nearly $55,000 in total cash prizes and scholarships. In addition to general awards, there are special categories such as the Agriculture Innovation prize sponsored by the SD Agriculture Foundation. Students can access various resources through the platform, including lesson plans, brainstorming tips, and judging instructions, to help refine their project submissions.

results.name: Summer Engineering Experience
results.title: SEE: Summer Engineering Experience
results.subtitle: College of Engineering at Carnegie Mellon University
results.description: The Summer Engineering Experience (SEE) is a week-long program designed for rising 8th through 11th graders who have a strong interest in math and science. Participants are divided into sessions, with younger students focusing on the concepts of design and problem-solving through creative making projects, while older students explore the interdisciplinary field of biomedical engineering. During the advanced session, students learn about biomechanics, robotics, and 3D bioprinting through academic presentations and hands-on laboratory work. While the program is free for selected students, participants are responsible for their own daily travel arrangements and must be able to commit to the full daily schedule. This outreach initiative aims to expose students to various engineering disciplines through interactive projects and professional educational presentations.

results.name: Teen Med Camp

program_dates.label: D&D: Adventures on the Astral sea (Grades 9-12)
Teen Med Camp 2: Beyond the Basics (Grades 9-12) Session 1
Teen Med Camp 2: Beyond the Basics (Grades 9-12) Session 2
D&D: Escapades in the city of Waterdeep (Grades 9-12)

results.title: Summer Camps: High School
results.subtitle: The University of Texas at Arlington
results.description: The University of Texas at Arlington offers a diverse selection of summer camps specifically designed for high school students entering grades 9 through 12. Academic and creative offerings include specialized tracks such as Analogue Photography, Principles of Engineering, and Teen Med Camps that cover introductory to advanced medical concepts. Students interested in technology and literature can participate in programs focused on 3D printing in the Fab Lab or learn the professional process of how to publish a book. Additionally, the university hosts immersive role-playing experiences through Dungeons & Dragons themed adventures. These programs provide high schoolers with unique opportunities to explore potential career paths and develop new skills in a collegiate environment.

results.name: Climate Science at UNL
results.title: YNS Summer Programs
results.subtitle: University of Nebraska System
results.description: The YNS Summer Programs offer students immersive opportunities to gain hands-on experience in various STEM fields through summer camps and high school research positions. Participants can explore subjects like food science or engage in intensive laboratory research that fosters professional development and career inspiration. Interested students must apply through an online platform, ensuring they use their own contact information to receive status updates and correspondence from the outreach coordinator. The High School Researcher application specifically requires a teacher recommendation and allows students to save their progress before the final submission deadline. Additionally, the program offers need-based scholarships to support accessibility for all students, with application status notifications usually sent within one week of submittal.

results.name: Math Meet
results.title: Purple Comet! Math Meet
results.subtitle: PurpleComet
results.description: The Purple Comet! Math Meet is a team mathematics competition designed specifically for middle and high school students. Conducted annually since 2003, this event attracts massive international participation, including thousands of registered teams from dozens of countries. Participating teams work together to solve complex mathematical problems during the competition period. Registered supervisors manage the process for their students and can log into specialized accounts to download certificates and view results. The program also provides access to historical contest problems and answers to help students prepare for future meets.

results.name: Tulane University
results.title: Explorations in Architecture and Design
results.subtitle: Tulane University
results.description: Explorations in Architecture and Design offers high school students an intensive introduction to architecture through lectures, studio time, digital workshops, and field trips led by university professors and local architects. The program is primarily designed for students who have completed their sophomore year, though high school graduates and mature younger students are also welcome to apply. Participants engage in regular design exercises and critiques to explore the unique blend of visual orientation and professional training required in architectural education. Tuition covers the full cost of instruction, activities, required materials, and meals, while students reside in on-campus residence halls with access to recreation centers. High school students who pursue a degree at the institution can earn three college credit hours per session that may be applied toward major requirements in architectural degree programs.

results.name: Yale University
results.title: ITS High School Internship Program
results.subtitle: Yale University
results.description: The ITS High School Internship Program is a paid opportunity designed to attract and nurture young people's interest in the field of information technology. The initiative targets high-achieving high school students from specific eligible communities who attend participating schools. Participants are immersed in a professional office environment within Yale’s Information Technology Services, where they work closely with managers to contribute to the organization and the university. In addition to their work responsibilities, interns participate in career-building workshops and events that introduce them to the campus environment. Instead of applying directly, students must be nominated by representatives from their participating high schools, with final selections involving interviews to match students with roles that suit their goals.

results.name: Florida International University
results.title: Young Scholars Summer Research Experience (YS)
results.subtitle: Florida International University
results.description: The Young Scholars Summer Research Experience (YS) at Florida International University provides high school students with the opportunity to explore multidisciplinary research areas within the ASTERIX Consortium. Participants engage in hands-on activities designed to foster awareness and development of analytical and technical skills specifically related to Department of Energy projects. Throughout the program, students interact closely with ASTERIX graduate students and faculty members to gain insight into advanced academic research environments. Although the program is currently paused and not accepting new applications, it typically offers assignments that challenge students to apply their knowledge in a professional lab setting while building professional networks.

results.name: UTEP
results.title: ExciTES Summer Institute
results.subtitle: The University of Texas at El Paso
results.description: The ExciTES Summer Institute offers rising 3rd through 11th graders the opportunity to explore diverse careers in engineering and computing through inquiry-based and team-oriented projects. Participants engage in activities developed by faculty and facilitated by undergraduate students, covering specialized topics such as robotics, artificial intelligence, and mining engineering. Specialized tracks are also available for students with disabilities through the ExploreSTEAM program, as well as immersive transportation research for dual credit and AP students. The application process requires students and parents to apply online, with program fees collected only after official acceptance into a session.

results.name: Davidson College
results.title: Summer Promise Program
results.subtitle: Davidson College
results.description: The Summer Promise Program is an annual free, week-long residential college readiness initiative designed for rising 9th through 12th graders. Participants experience a snapshot of the holistic college journey by living in residence halls and engaging with various co-curricular facilities. Students attend courses co-taught by Davidson College faculty and teachers from Charlotte-Mecklenburg Public Schools to build confidence for higher education. Beyond student academics, family representatives receive valuable information regarding the college admissions process, financial aid requirements, and scholarship opportunities. The program aims to empower young scholars to unlock their potential and strengthen their enthusiasm for persisting through high school.

results.name: Pre-College

deadlines.label: Early Application & Priority Financial Aid Deadline

results.title: Pre-College Summer School Program for High School Students
results.subtitle: Harvard Summer School
results.description: The Pre-College Summer School Program for High School Students is an intensive two-week, non-credit academic experience designed for mature and motivated rising juniors and seniors. Participants immerse themselves in a single subject through college-level courses with an average class size of 15 students, taught by Ivy League scholars. Students can choose from nearly 30 subjects across disciplines like law, psychology, business, and computer science while engaging in a variety of social and college readiness activities. The program focuses on building advanced academic skills such as note-taking and participating in class discussions without the pressure of letter grades. In addition to coursework, the curriculum includes workshops on navigating the college admissions process, writing application essays, and understanding financial aid. Upon successful completion of all requirements, students receive a written instructor evaluation and a transcript to support their future college applications.

results.name: USA BIOlympiad
results.title: USA Biolympiad
results.subtitle: Center for Excellence in Education
results.description: The USA Biolympiad (USABO) is a premier biology competition for high school students in the United States that enriches life science education for nearly 12,000 participants annually. Open to every school in the country, the program provides students with motivation, curricular resources, and specialized skills training to help them reach a level of international competitiveness. After completing two rounds of challenging exams, twenty finalists are selected to participate in a residential training program where they study advanced biological concepts and develop exacting lab skills. Ultimately, four students are chosen to represent the United States at the International Biology Olympiad (IBO), a global competition involving teams from over seventy countries. The program has a record of immense success, with every member of the USA Biolympiad Team medaling at the international level since the Center for Excellence in Education began administering the competition.

results.name: Democracy Scholars
results.title: Democracy Scholars
results.subtitle: NYU
results.description: Democracy Scholars is a tuition-free program designed for New York City students entering their senior year of high school, with preference given to those who will be first-generation college-goers. This intensive initiative features discussion-based seminars taught by university faculty in areas such as political philosophy, humanities, and the social sciences. Beyond the classroom, participants gain real-world experience as student leaders and community activists while participating in field trips and a nine-month after-school civic leadership project. Throughout their senior year, students receive ongoing support for the college admissions process, including mentorship from dedicated advisors and a specialized workshop series. Successful completion of the program earns students a college letter of recommendation from a university professor and helps them build essential skills in critical thinking and academic writing.

results.name: Duke Math Meet
results.title: Duke Math Meet
results.subtitle: Department of Mathematics
results.description: The Duke Math Meet is a regional mathematics competition for high school students organized by the Duke University Mathematics Union and sponsored by the Duke Mathematics Department. Each team consists of six members who compete in diverse formats including a proof-based Power Round, a numerical Team Round, and an Individual Round. Participants also engage in a Relay Round where groups of three pass answers to one another and a non-competitive Devil Round designed for meeting peers from other schools. While there is no registration fee thanks to sponsors, schools are required to provide one proctor per team and ensure all participants submit a signed minors participation agreement. Registration is handled on a first-come, first-served basis with a specific cap on the total number of teams allowed to participate.

results.name: OSU

deadlines.label: Emergency contact, medical information, and consent forms deadline

program_dates.label: Eco-Printmaking: Sustainable Art for People and the Planet
Leadership: What It Is and How to Get It

results.title: Arts and Sciences Summer Exploration Program
results.subtitle: College of Arts and Sciences
results.description: The Arts and Sciences Summer Exploration Program provides middle and high school students with one-week intensive academic enrichment courses taught by university faculty, staff, and graduate students. These non-credit courses are designed for self-motivated learners and feature active, hands-on instructional methods that encourage engagement among participants and the instructional team. Eligible students entering grades 7 through 12 can explore diverse subjects ranging from the biological sciences and human perception to sustainable printmaking and leadership development. The program includes daily lunch and snacks at campus dining facilities, along with all necessary course materials and activities. Throughout the sessions, participants engage in scientific inquiry, creative arts workshops, and skill-building exercises intended to prepare them for future academic and professional pursuits.

results.name: University of Kansas
results.title: Summer Venture in Business
results.subtitle: School of Business
results.description: Summer Venture in Business is a pre-college academy for high school students interested in exploring the field of business and the college experience. Eligible rising 11th- and 12th-grade students from Kansas or the Kansas City Metro area participate in academic sessions with faculty, workshops with campus partners, and industry tours. The curriculum is designed to equip participants with the tools and knowledge needed to apply to university, succeed in higher education, and prosper in their future careers. Participants are housed in university residence halls with professional staff and provided with meals at on-campus dining facilities. While there is a standard participation fee, need-based waivers are available to ensure accessibility for all qualified students.

results.name: Fab Lab: 3D Printing

program_dates.label: D&D: Adventures on the Astral sea (Grades 9-12)
Teen Med Camp 2: Beyond the Basics (Grades 9-12) Session 1
Teen Med Camp 2: Beyond the Basics (Grades 9-12) Session 2
D&D: Escapades in the city of Waterdeep (Grades 9-12)

results.title: Summer Camps: High School
results.subtitle: The University of Texas at Arlington
results.description: The University of Texas at Arlington offers a diverse array of summer camps specifically designed for high school students in grades 9 through 12. Students can explore specialized topics such as Analogue Photography, Principles of Engineering, and 3D printing in the Fab Lab. For those interested in healthcare, the Teen Med Camp series provides both introductory and advanced curriculum through sessions like "Beyond the Basics." Creative programs are also available, including workshops on how to publish a book and themed Dungeons & Dragons adventures. These educational opportunities are organized into various morning and afternoon blocks to accommodate different participant interests.

results.name: Begin Your Medical Research Journey
results.title: Medical Research: Clinical Trials Resulting in Medical Discoveries
results.subtitle: Georgetown University
results.description: Designed for students ages 13 and up, this course introduces the essential processes of evidence-based medicine and clinical research used to develop vaccines and treatments. Participants explore foundational principles like the PICO method, biostatistics, and epidemiology while investigating the ethical considerations of medical studies. The curriculum includes a specific focus on cancer research, covering diagnostics, prevention, and the analysis of professional scientific articles. For the final capstone project, students create a video presentation demonstrating the scientific method, supported by personalized guidance from university mentors. This flexible online program provides 20 to 30 hours of total instruction, making it ideal for high schoolers considering future paths in medicine, pharmacology, or STEM.

results.name: UCR
results.title: Research in Science & Engineering (RISE)
results.subtitle: University of California, Riverside
results.description: The Research in Science & Engineering (RISE) program is a 10-week summer research initiative designed for continuing students and incoming transfer students. Participants work under the supervision of a faculty mentor on cutting-edge research projects to help them attain foundational skills and knowledge. This paid opportunity features faculty mentoring, professional development, and an immersive experience in the scientific community. The program focuses on shaping undergraduate students' research identities and enhancing scientific communication through various activities, including a final undergraduate symposium.

results.name: UConn
results.title: Pre-College Academic Enrichment Program: UConn Storrs
results.subtitle: UConn Health
results.description: The Pre-College Academic Enrichment Program: UConn Storrs is a five-week summer initiative designed for college pre-freshmen who will be matriculating at UConn. The program specifically targets first-generation, low-income, and educationally under-resourced students who demonstrate high motivation for careers in medicine, dental medicine, or biomedical research. Participants engage in intensive coursework covering Chemistry, Biology, Physics, and Calculus to strengthen their scientific, mathematical, communication, and test-taking skills before starting their undergraduate studies. Organized by Health Career Opportunity Programs in collaboration with the School of Engineering's BRIDGE program, students receive room and board while participating in academic activities and visiting health-related facilities. Applicants are required to have a minimum B average and must submit official transcripts, SAT or ACT scores, and recommendation letters from teachers to be considered for admission.

results.name: Dune Neuroscience Experience
results.title: Duke University Neuroscience Experience (DUNE)
results.subtitle: Duke Institute for Brain Sciences
results.description: The Duke University Neuroscience Experience (DUNE) provides high school students with the opportunity to engage in full-time research within professional neuroscience laboratories. Participants work alongside scientist mentors to develop an original research project and gain practical laboratory skills. The program is specifically designed for high school sophomores and juniors who meet specific enrollment and residency criteria, including those without any prior research experience. In addition to scientific work, the curriculum includes professional development workshops that cover scientific communication, college application guidance, and career exploration in fields like medicine and academia. Students receive a stipend for their participation and conclude the experience by presenting their research findings to the scientific community.

results.name: Summer Academy for Math & Science
results.title: Summer Academy for Math and Science
results.subtitle: Carnegie Mellon University
results.description: The Summer Academy for Math and Science (SAMS) provides high school juniors with a rigorous curriculum designed to deepen their understanding of STEM through traditional classroom instruction and hands-on projects. This three-part program consists of a required virtual skill-building jumpstart, a six-week in-person academic session, and ongoing virtual engagement experiences to sustain connections with university mentors. Students complete quantitative and computational skill seminars in subjects such as math, biology, and chemistry, while participating in a credit-bearing course focused on the transition from high school to college. Throughout the experience, participants conduct faculty-advised STEM research projects which are showcased during a capstone research symposium. Additionally, scholars attend weekly writing workshops to prepare college application essays and engage in small-group mentoring and academic coaching.

results.name: Youth Leadership Program
results.title: 2024 AAU Summer High School Leadership Program
results.subtitle: AAU
results.description: The 2024 AAU Summer High School Leadership Program is a specialized summer initiative designed specifically for high school students. This program is organized by AAU and focuses on the development of leadership skills among its young participants. High school students are given the opportunity to engage in curriculum-based activities focused on personal growth and professional readiness. The program structure is intended to support and empower the next generation of leaders through various educational and collaborative opportunities.

results.name: California State University Sacramento (CSUS)
results.title: Summer Youth Academies
results.subtitle: College of Continuing Education at Sacramento State
results.description: The Summer Youth Academies offer an immersive opportunity for students entering 7th through 12th grades to explore a wide range of academic disciplines and career pathways. Participants engage in hands-on career exploration, interactive projects, and coaching led by university faculty, staff, alumni, and industry experts. These noncredit weeklong courses cover various subjects such as computer science, engineering, business, and performing arts to provide a preview of the college experience. Students also benefit from meeting industry professionals and guest speakers who share real-world insights into modern career fields. The program structure includes weekday sessions designed to foster new skills, gain self-confidence, and build social connections with intellectual peers.

results.name: Neubauer Phoenix Scholars
results.title: Neubauer Phoenix STEM Summer Scholars
results.subtitle: University of Chicago
results.description: The Neubauer Phoenix STEM Summer Program is designed for outstanding current 11th grade students from diverse backgrounds who are interested in exploring academic and research opportunities in STEM fields. This hybrid experience begins with a virtual mathematics course hosted by schoolhouse.world, followed by a residential component where participants reside in campus housing. During the program, students engage in model classes and visit cutting-edge research facilities such as the Argonne National Laboratory, Fermilab, and the Pritzker School of Molecular Engineering. Participants also have the opportunity to hear from world-renowned faculty and alumni specializing in molecular engineering, mathematics, and computer science. Applicants must submit a transcript, essays, letters of recommendation, and a writing sample to be considered for this selective enrichment opportunity.

results.name: Trapped Ions and Photonics Research

program_dates.label: UMass⁺ Trapped Ions and Photonics (Niffenegger Lab)

results.title: UMass⁺ Trapped Ions and Photonics (Niffenegger Lab)
results.subtitle: University of Massachusetts Amherst
results.description: This competitive Research Intensive program places high-achieving rising high school juniors and seniors in professional working labs to assist faculty and graduate students on ongoing research studies. Participants in the Niffenegger Lab contribute to trapped ion quantum computing research by microfabricating chips in cleanrooms and studying qubit gate fidelity to help build scalable quantum computers. Possible projects involve software development for qubit control, coding simulations of ion traps, 3D printing for optics, or building electronics such as amplifiers and PID feedback systems. Throughout the program, students learn research methodologies and gain firsthand experience with university-level engineering while earning six credits. The experience concludes with each participant creating and presenting a research poster to faculty, peers, and family at a final poster session.

Visiting Domestic & General Public - Session B
Visiting Domestic & General Public - Session C

Visiting Domestic & General Public - Session E
Visiting Domestic & General Public - Session F

results.title: Pre-College Scholars Program
results.subtitle: Berkeley Summer Sessions
results.description: The Pre-College Scholars Program at Berkeley Summer Sessions is designed for high school students who are 16 and 17 years old to engage with university-level coursework. Participants can choose from several distinct tracks, including residential, commuter, virtual, and non-credit options, to fit their specific academic goals and interests. The curriculum provides access to a diverse array of classes such as field studies, language courses, and online offerings that are typically available to degree-seeking students. International students are encouraged to participate, provided they meet specific English language proficiency requirements and complete necessary visa documentation. Prospective students must follow a dedicated application process separate from the general summer sessions portal and adhere to deadlines that vary by track.

results.name: IAS Computes
results.title: IACS Computes!
results.subtitle: Institute for Advanced Computational Science
results.description: IACS Computes! is an initiative organized by the Institute for Advanced Computational Science to facilitate community engagement with computational topics through a structured event platform. The program utilizes a digital interface where participants can browse through available sessions using a summary or grid view to find activities that suit their interests. To streamline the experience, users have the ability to search for specific opportunities such as workshops and boot camps using keywords and a wide range of category filters. Individuals interested in participating can sign into the system to manage their personal schedule and access the full suite of community features offered through this educational forum.

results.name: Summer Research Scholars Program
results.title: LHI-AHA Summer Research Scholars Program
results.subtitle: University of Minnesota
results.description: The LHI-AHA Summer Research Scholars Program provides competitive scholarships for students to engage in basic science research focused on cardiovascular disease. Participants are assigned a dedicated faculty mentor and a laboratory to conduct intensive basic or clinical research projects. Beyond laboratory work, scholars explore clinical, industrial, and academic medicine through a series of hands-on experiences, field trips, and seminars. Weekly sessions led by faculty and industry professionals offer valuable perspectives on career paths in cardiovascular science and medicine. This program is designed to foster interest in medical and scientific careers by providing financial support and high-level exposure to the field.

results.name: Secondary School

deadlines.label: Early Application & Priority Financial Aid Deadline

results.title: Secondary School Program
results.subtitle: Harvard Summer School
results.description: Harvard Summer School’s Secondary School Program (SSP) provides motivated high school students with the opportunity to earn college credit through rigorous, intensive coursework taught by Harvard faculty. Participants can choose between a 4-week residential format or a flexible 7-week option available in residential, online, or commuting formats. Eligibility is restricted to students who are at least 16 years old and will graduate from high school between 2026 and 2028. Beyond academics, the program includes a variety of creative and social activities, sports, and college readiness workshops designed to help students navigate the admissions process. Students also have access to academic support resources such as tutoring and the Writing Center while managing a balance between advanced studies and independent living.

results.name: College-Bound STEM Academy
results.title: College-Bound STEM Academy
results.subtitle: Penn State Abington
results.description: The College-Bound STEM Academy is a high school enrichment program provided through a partnership between Penn State Abington and KleinLife to enhance educational outcomes for neighborhood students. Participants in grades 9 through 12 can engage in seven-week after-school workshops focusing on project-based skills such as programming with electronics, sensors, robotics, and Python coding. The academy offers specialized math courses covering Algebra and Trigonometry to prepare students for the rigor of AP, IB, and college-level coursework. Qualified 11th and 12th grade students may also apply for dual enrollment college courses, including Calculus, General Physics, and Elementary Statistics, to earn university credit at a discounted rate. While some workshops require a placement test or a minimum GPA for eligibility, the program provides hands-on learning experiences and potential scholarship opportunities for participating families.

results.name: Wharton Investment Competition

deadlines.label: Advisors set up student team accounts
Requirement: Final report and school documentation submission

results.title: Wharton Global High School Investment Competition
results.subtitle: The Wharton School, University of Pennsylvania
results.description: The Wharton Global High School Investment Competition is a free, experiential challenge designed for students in grades 9 through 12 and their teacher advisors. Participants form teams of four to six members to manage a portfolio of virtual cash using the Wharton Investment Simulator. Throughout the competition, students collaborate to meet the long-term investment goals of a specific client featured in a professional case study. Teams are evaluated on the strength and articulation of their investment strategies and industry analysis rather than the total growth of their portfolios. This program emphasizes the development of critical skills in teamwork, communication, risk assessment, and financial diversification.

results.name: ICaRE Summer Science
results.title: ICaRE Summer Science Program
results.subtitle: SUNY Old Westbury
results.description: The ICaRE Summer Science Program at SUNY Old Westbury provides current 9th through 12th graders with an immersive opportunity to study the molecular biology of cancer, immunology, biochemistry, neuroscience, and microbiology under faculty mentorship. Participants engage in investigative experiences to understand the scientific method and learn how laboratory science translates into improved human health outcomes. Throughout the program, students gain hands-on laboratory methodologies, practice critical reading of peer-reviewed literature, and develop skills in presenting scientific work through both writing and oral presentations. To apply, interested students must submit an application form, school transcript, resume, a 500-word essay on their scientific interests, and a recommendation letter from a science teacher. The program involves a tuition fee for the week-long session, and while sessions include live lectures and group work, students are responsible for bringing their own lunches.

results.name: University of Delaware

deadlines.label: Priority application deadline (Rising 11th and 12th grade students)
Priority enrollment forms deadline (Rising 11th and 12th grade students)
Priority application deadline (Rising 9th and 10th grade students)
Priority enrollment forms deadline (Rising 9th and 10th grade students)

results.title: College Readiness Scholars Institute
results.subtitle: University of Delaware
results.description: The College Readiness Scholars Institute is a free, selective program designed to equip Delaware high school students with the tools necessary for academic success and personal growth. This multi-year initiative is open to rising freshmen through seniors who are first-generation college students or meet low-income qualifications while maintaining a minimum 2.5 GPA. Participants engage in academic seminars with university faculty, attend college-readiness workshops focused on the application process and essay writing, and take part in various personal development sessions. To ensure a transformational experience, the program requires full-time participation without outside commitments such as sports or jobs, and applicants must submit academic transcripts, a recommendation form, and a video essay.

results.name: Pre-Collegiate
results.title: Stanford Pre-Collegiate Studies
results.subtitle: Stanford University
results.description: Stanford Pre-Collegiate Studies provides academically motivated students in grades 1 through 12 with the opportunity to explore advanced subjects rarely taught in typical high school curricula. The program offers both online and residential enrichment options during the summer and throughout the academic year to foster an intellectual community among peers, instructors, and staff. Participants can dive deep into cutting-edge topics ranging from bioscience to philosophy, leveraging world-class resources to grow as scholars and global citizens. This mission-driven programming attracts a diverse student body from over 50 countries, focusing on creating inclusive and accessible learning environments for the next generation of learners. These offerings are designed to challenge intellectually curious students through academically rigorous learning opportunities that enhance their educational journey.

results.name: UH

deadlines.label: Architecture Program for High School Students Regular Application Deadline

program_dates.label: Architecture Program for High School Students

results.title: Design Experience Summer Programs
results.subtitle: Gerald D. Hines College of Architecture and Design
results.description: The Design Experience Summer Programs offer a hands-on, learning-by-doing introduction to architecture, interior architecture, and industrial design for high school students, college students, and degreed professionals. Participants engage in design projects and portfolio workshops led by college faculty to prepare for the undergraduate or graduate application process. Specialized tracks like From the Ground Up and The Idea Factory allow students to explore architectural theory or product design through creativity, materials, and fabrication methods without requiring any prior experience. The curriculum is enriched by lectures on history and technology, building case studies, and field trips to structures of special interest. While the programs involve tuition fees, need-based scholarships are available for eligible high school participants.

results.name: Clinical Anatomy
results.title: Clinical Anatomy Summer Program (CASP)
results.subtitle: Stanford University
results.description: The Clinical Anatomy Summer Program (CASP) provides high school students with an immersive introduction to the study of human anatomy and various health-related professions, including medicine, surgery, and biomedical engineering. Participants attend lectures led by medical faculty and engage in hands-on anatomy lab activities that incorporate real human anatomical specimens and cadavers. The curriculum includes surgical skills workshops where students practice dissection and suturing techniques on animal tissue, as well as opportunities to meet guest speakers from diverse clinical specialties. This non-residential program requires applicants to be at least fifteen years old and submit an application including transcripts for consideration on a rolling basis. Prospective students should be prepared for an authentic exposure to medical practice, as some instructional components involving surgical demonstrations may be emotionally challenging.

results.name: Art Museum Summer Academy
results.title: Princeton University Art Museum Summer Academy
results.subtitle: Princeton University Art Museum
results.description: This two-week program offers high school students the opportunity to learn about various careers in art museums and the visual arts while working alongside professional mentors and artists. Participants engage deeply with original works of art to explore complex themes such as identity, power, and social justice. Designed for rising sophomores, juniors, and seniors who enjoy creating and discussing art, the academy requires no prior experience or specific knowledge of art history. The program is offered at no cost to participants, including a waived application fee and provided transportation for students from Trenton Central and Ewing High Schools. The experience culminates in an exhibition where students showcase their own original artwork during a closing celebration.

results.name: Summer Session

deadlines.label: First Session - All other summer visitors
Second Session - Rising high school seniors
Second Session - All other summer visitors

results.title: Visiting High School: Dual Enrollment
results.subtitle: The University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill
results.description: Honor roll students who have completed their junior year of high school are eligible to apply for dual enrollment to earn college credit through the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill. The application requires a current transcript, a personal statement detailing the purpose for taking specific courses, and a letter of recommendation from a school official. Students are limited to a maximum of four credit hours per summer session and must be prepared for a rigorous workload that includes several hours of daily out-of-class study. High school participants must maintain a high grade point average to remain in good standing and are ineligible to enroll if their own high school offers the same or a comparable course. Additionally, those under seventeen must confirm they will live with a parent or legal guardian, and all students will be integrated into classes with adult learners.

results.name: Brown University
results.title: Brown Experiential Education: Barcelona
results.subtitle: Brown University
results.description: Students completing grades 10 to 12 engage in a dual-course curriculum focusing on language proficiency and architectural history. The program includes the Intermediate Immersive Spanish course, requiring three years of prior study, alongside an exploration of iconic urban landmarks that represent the social and political development of the region. Participants reside in single rooms within a supervised residence hall, benefiting from a community-focused environment that includes cultural events, cooking classes, and site visits to historic Roman remains and gothic cathedrals. This experiential program prioritizes learning over formal grades, providing students with a Course Performance Report and a Digital Certificate of Completion upon finishing.

results.name: GENIUS Olympiad
results.title: GENIUS Olympiad
results.subtitle: Terra Science and Education
results.description: GENIUS Olympiad is an international high school project competition focused on environmental issues, organized by Terra Science and Education. The competition encompasses multiple disciplines including Science, Art, Business, Coding, Robotics, Music, Short Film, Speech, and Artificial Intelligence. Students participate by submitting projects that address environmental challenges through research, artistic expression, or innovative technological solutions. Finalists are invited to present their work to a panel of judges and can compete for gold, silver, and bronze medals, along with renewable scholarships for higher education. The program also provides opportunities for participants to publish their research in a peer-reviewed academic journal and take part in a cultural fair to share ethnic traditions with a global audience.

results.name: RITMS Research Program
results.title: Rutgers Institute for Translational Medicine and Science Summer Research Program
results.subtitle: Rutgers Institute for Translational Medicine and Science
results.description: The Rutgers Institute for Translational Medicine and Science Summer Research Program is a tuition-free educational opportunity designed for high school and college students pursuing careers in science or medicine. Participants engage in hands-on laboratory research as members of a scientific team, where they learn to plan experiments, conduct analyses, and present their findings through written reports and oral presentations. High school applicants must be at least 16 years old and entering their sophomore, junior, or senior year, while undergraduate applicants must be enrolled in an accredited university with a demonstrated interest in biomedical fields. Mentorship is provided by professional scientists and faculty, offering students first-hand experience in top-tier research environments to strengthen future graduate or medical school applications. Successful candidates are expected to complete human resources paperwork and required online safety trainings including lab and radiation safety before beginning their training.

results.name: Aspiring Scholars Directed Research Program
results.title: THE ASPIRING SCHOLARS DIRECTED RESEARCH PROGRAM
results.subtitle: Olive Children Foundation
results.description: The Aspiring Scholars Directed Research Program offers high school students the opportunity to engage in professional-level research across diverse fields including chemistry, biology, computer science, and engineering. All students currently enrolled in or entering 9th through 12th grade are eligible to apply, provided they demonstrate an appetite for learning and a desire to be a scientist. Admission to the program is competitive and based on application quality, though prior research experience and letters of recommendation are not required. Participants work within specialized clusters such as astrophysics or biomedical research and often choose to continue their work year-round for multiple years. To ensure that financial constraints are not a barrier to participation, the program offers partial and full scholarships for students from underrepresented backgrounds.

results.name: Arizona Cancer Center
results.title: High School Students & Teachers
results.subtitle: Cancer Center
results.description: High school students and teachers can access a diverse range of cancer-related educational activities and training programs offered through this center. Initiatives like the Cancer Center Training and Education Summer (CACTES) and the Mobile Oncology Training, Education, and Recruitment (MOTER) programs provide professional development and curriculum support for educators. Students have opportunities to participate in research-intensive experiences such as the Keep Engaging Youths in Science (KEYS) internship, STAR Labs, and the Summer Institute on Medical Ignorance (SIMI). Additional offerings include clinical preparation through Med-Start, sun safety education via Project SASS, and competitive research recognition through the Southern Arizona Science and Engineering Fair. Immersive health science lab experiences are also available through Steps 2 STEM for students in bioscience programs.

results.name: Engineering, Math and Science Camp
results.title: Penn GEMS | Engineering, Math and Science Camp
results.subtitle: University of Pennsylvania
results.description: Penn GEMS is a week-long day camp targeting middle school students in 7th, 8th, and 9th grade. The program focuses on specialized areas of study such as bioengineering, nanotechnology, materials science, graphics, and computing. Participants engage in hands-on activities designed to foster interest in applied science, technology, and engineering. Through these practical experiences, the camp aims to provide middle schoolers with a foundation in technical and scientific disciplines.

results.name: UTEP
results.title: Project ACE: Action for Equity
results.subtitle: The University of Texas at El Paso
results.description: Project ACE: Action for Equity offers high school students a unique opportunity to engage in academic summer research. Participants work alongside university faculty and staff within the College of Liberal Arts to gain hands-on experience in their fields of interest. The program provides access to undergraduate scholarship information and various educational workshops designed to support college readiness. Interested applicants must submit a completed application form, which is available in both Word and PDF formats for ease of access. This initiative aims to foster equity and academic growth through intensive mentorship and professional development for young scholars.

results.name: UCA Cheer Camp

program_dates.label: D&D: Adventures on the Astral sea (Grades 9-12)

results.title: Summer Camps: High School
results.subtitle: The University of Texas at Arlington
results.description: The University of Texas at Arlington offers a diverse range of summer camps specifically designed for high school students in grades 9 through 12. Academic and creative offerings include specialized sessions such as Teen Med Camp, Principles of Engineering, and Fab Lab: 3D Printing 101. Students interested in the arts and humanities can participate in courses focused on Analogue Photography or learn the professional process of how to publish a book. The curriculum also features unique interactive workshops like Dungeons & Dragons adventures set in various fantastical environments. These programs provide high schoolers with opportunities to explore potential career paths in STEM, medicine, and the visual arts while engaging in hands-on learning experiences.

results.name: Foreign Policy Academy
results.title: Foreign Policy Academy
results.subtitle: Georgetown University School of Continuing Studies
results.description: Georgetown's Foreign Policy Academy introduces high school students to the diverse components that inform and create U.S. foreign policy through a combination of lectures, group discussions, and crisis simulations. Participants develop critical thinking skills by examining international crises, analyzing the factors that affect decision-making processes, and exploring the theories used to implement policies in a global arena. The curriculum covers a wide range of topics, including American defense policy, terrorism threats, the influence of non-governmental organizations, and international trade policy. Throughout the program, students engage with guest lecturers such as influential policymakers, foreign service professionals, and university faculty to gain insights into potential careers in the field. Beyond classroom sessions, the experience includes off-site visits to foreign embassies and hands-on workshops where students participate in simulation exercises and panel presentations.

results.name: Leadership Project
results.title: SUMMER INSTITUTE
results.subtitle: Sadie Nash Leadership Project
results.description: Summer Institute is an award-winning six-week program designed for high school-aged young women and gender-expansive youth to explore leadership and social justice. Throughout the program, participants engage in workshops focused on identity and critical thinking while meeting accomplished leaders from fields like government, business, and the arts. The curriculum includes diverse topics such as the anthropology of gender and art-based activism, supplemented by field trips to museums and college campuses. There are no academic or skill-based requirements for admission, and all participants are eligible to receive a $450 stipend based on their active participation. Classes are held four days a week, providing a consistent environment for students to build community and develop tools for transforming their lives.

results.name: Pre-College
results.title: Summer 2026 Programs
results.subtitle: Barnard Pre-College Programs
results.description: Barnard Pre-College Programs offer a variety of academic experiences for motivated students looking to explore specific fields of study while getting a taste of college life. Students can choose from exploratory institutes such as the NextGen Leadership Institute or the Athena Summer Innovation Institute, which focuses on entrepreneurship and leadership. The offerings also include specialized tracks like the Health and Society Institute and the Plate + Planet Lab for those interested in health and sustainability. For students seeking a more rigorous academic challenge, the Pre-Baccalaureate Program provides the opportunity to earn college credits by studying alongside current undergraduates. Courses are led by renowned faculty members who provide academic guidance and insights into their respective professional fields.

results.name: Biotechnology Intern

results.name: Blum Center at UCI
results.title: Summer Scholars Program
results.subtitle: Blum Center
results.description: The Summer Scholars Program is designed for high school students who want to develop essential research skills in the fields of engineering and social ecology. Participants work under the guidance of expert faculty to master technical abilities such as plotting, visualization, trend analysis, programming, and spatial analysis. The curriculum places a specific focus on real-world issues like climate change and social impact by studying the environmental trends of Orange County beaches. Students receive training relevant to university engineering admissions, including an introduction to MATLAB and hands-on data collection techniques. Throughout the experience, scholars engage with industry experts and assemble their findings into dynamic, shareable portfolios to showcase their academic work.

results.name: TRIO Pre-College
results.title: TRIO Pre-College at UC Riverside
results.subtitle: University of California, Riverside
results.description: UC Riverside's TRIO Pre-College programs motivate and equip low-income and potential first-generation college students from select Riverside and San Bernardino County high schools to successfully enroll in and graduate from postsecondary institutions. Participants in the Educational Talent Search and Upward Bound programs receive free services such as one-on-one academic advising, tutoring, and assistance with college admissions and financial aid applications. Enrichment activities include college campus visits, educational field trips, and Saturday sessions providing supplemental instruction in subjects like Math and English. Intensive summer programs allow students to experience college life in residence halls while receiving academic support, career information, and mentorship from university staff.

results.name: High School Law Institute
results.title: High School Law Institute
results.subtitle: New York University
results.description: The High School Law Institute is a student-run organization at New York University that serves talented and motivated high school students. This free, non-credit program offers specialized courses in constitutional law, criminal law, and speech and debate. Current NYU Law and undergraduate students teach the classes while receiving support and training from the university's law faculty. Participating students are encouraged to think critically, advocate effectively, and work collaboratively through discussion-based lessons tailored to their interests. Eligible applicants include students entering or currently enrolled in the 9th through 12th grades who complete an online application consisting of academic history and short essay questions.

results.name: UAB
results.title: Summer Science Institute
results.subtitle: The University of Alabama at Birmingham
results.description: The Summer Science Institute is a multi-summer research program designed for high school students in their freshman, sophomore, junior, or senior years who are interested in pursuing real science careers. Participants progress through a structured curriculum starting with introductory cellular and molecular biology experiments during their first summer in the program. In the subsequent summer, students engage in advanced biochemical investigations and neurobiology focused on specific biologically important proteins. For the final stage of the initiative, students serve as research interns within campus laboratories to conduct original projects under the direct supervision of university faculty and staff. This comprehensive experience is sponsored by the Center for Community Outreach Development and Birmingham City Schools to help build the next generation of scientists.
