results.title: Vanderbilt Summer Academy
results.subtitle: Vanderbilt University
results.description: Vanderbilt Summer Academy offers accelerated summer courses for gifted students entering grades 7 through 12, providing an environment tailored for high academic achievement. The admission process requires students to demonstrate their eligibility through either standardized test scores in the 90th percentile or a comprehensive portfolio including educator recommendations, transcripts, and a resume. Tuition for the program varies based on grade level and session length, with costs ranging from $2,150 to $2,750 for various one-week and two-week formats. To ensure diverse participation, the program provides need-based financial assistance and utilizes a need-blind review process that evaluates students solely on their academic fit.

decisions_date.label: VSA Admissions Notification Window for Priority Applicants

results.name: Summer Medical Career Program
results.title: Eve and Gene Black Summer Medical Career Program
results.subtitle: Los Angeles Pediatric Society
results.description: The Eve and Gene Black Summer Medical Career Program is a medical mentorship initiative designed to encourage high school students to pursue professional paths in the health sector. Participants engage in daily interactive sessions with a variety of medical experts, including general pediatricians, surgeons, radiologists, and specialists in infectious disease. The curriculum provides broad exposure to diverse roles such as nursing, pharmacy, dietetics, and various forms of therapy like occupational or speech therapy. Every student earns a certificate of completion at the end of the term, and the program also awards a competitive $500 scholarship to one participant. This initiative aims to provide life-changing career insights through direct interaction with clinical professionals and healthcare staff.

results.name: Academic Connections
results.title: Academic Connections
results.subtitle: UC San Diego
results.description: UC San Diego Academic Connections provides a pre-college summer experience designed for high-achieving, college-bound high school students who are motivated to explore diverse academic fields. Managed by the Division of Extended Studies, the program allows participants to engage with committed instructors while examining the world as inquisitive academic scholars. Students can choose from various commuter courses covering specialized topics such as neuroscience, data science, public health, and creative writing. The curriculum aims to help young people cultivate their academic skills and gain exposure to exciting research and study areas at a top-ranked public institution. Participants will prepare for their future college careers by working as independent individuals in a socially and academically enriching environment.

results.name: Summer Debate Program
results.title: Yale Summer Debate Program
results.subtitle: New Haven Urban Debate League
results.description: The Yale Summer Debate Program is an intensive five-day experience open to middle and high school students ranging from grades 6 through 12. Participants engage in a rigorous curriculum focused on the parliamentary debate style, training with a staff of world-class Yale debaters and coaches at a student-to-instructor ratio of 1:10 or better. Instruction covers essential skills such as argument construction, public speaking, and refutation, alongside focused discussions on topics like international relations, criminal justice, and moral philosophy. In addition to core curriculum sessions, students choose from various daily electives and participate in a concluding tournament where they receive feedback from experienced judges. The program is designed to accommodate all skill levels, from absolute beginners to national champions, and offers financial aid to ensure accessibility for all families.

results.name: FAU
results.title: H2O to Go Residential Summer Research Institutes
results.subtitle: Florida Atlantic University
results.description: The H2O to Go Residential Summer Research Institutes offer high school students the opportunity to participate in week-long programs focused on environmental research and the complexity of South Florida water systems. Participants work directly alongside professional scientists to explore environmental challenges and gain hands-on experience with research tools engineered by university experts. Designed for students interested in fields such as life science, engineering, and oceanography, the program provides a professional environment that gives attendees a competitive edge in their future academic pursuits. In addition to scientific field work, certain sessions offer dual enrollment credits and integrate recreational activities like boating, hiking, and canoeing into the curriculum. These institutes are made possible through partnerships between the education center and various university, state, federal, and local agencies.

results.name: Robinson Center
results.title: Transition School
results.subtitle: UW Robinson Center for Young Scholars
results.description: The Transition School is a distinctive one-year college preparatory program designed for students who engage with learning at an advanced level. It provides a specialized pathway for early entry into the university as fully matriculated undergraduates through the Early Entrance Program. Prospective students apply during their 8th-grade year to participate in this immersive curriculum during the time they would typically spend in 9th grade. The academic framework emphasizes advanced critical thinking, interdisciplinary exploration, and intellectual independence to prepare learners for success beyond conventional educational boundaries. Additionally, the program fosters a supportive learning community that values diversity and provides scholarships to ensure exceptional students from various backgrounds can thrive.

results.name: UCSF
results.title: UCSF Fresno Doctors Academy Programs
results.subtitle: University of California San Francisco
results.description: The Doctors Academy operates in partnership with local school districts to support students interested in health careers, particularly those who are first-generation college-bound. Participants receive comprehensive college preparation, professional mentoring, and career exploration opportunities to help them successfully launch a path in healthcare. This program provides students with the academic and professional support needed to navigate the transition into medical and health-related higher education. To ensure a successful experience, interested students should review specific eligibility requirements and prepare to apply during designated annual application windows. Through these coordinated efforts, the initiative helps cultivate a diverse and well-prepared healthcare workforce for the future.

results.name: POETS
results.title: SpHERES High School Research Program
results.subtitle: Carle Illinois College of Medicine
results.description: The SpHERES High School Research Program provides high school students with an authentic research experience working alongside faculty mentors to complete clinically-focused projects. Scholars gain a deep understanding of the intersection of medicine, science, and engineering while exploring diverse fields such as bioengineering, neuroscience, and sociology. In addition to laboratory work, participants attend weekly seminars covering professional development topics like college readiness, innovation, entrepreneurship, and clinical skills. Students benefit from multiple layers of mentorship from faculty, medical students, and physicians and receive a $2,400 stipend for their participation in the program.

results.name: Clarkson University
results.title: Young Scholars
results.subtitle: The Clarkson School
results.description: The Young Scholars program is an interdisciplinary summer experience designed for motivated high school sophomores, juniors, seniors, and incoming college freshmen. Participants engage in collaborative research projects that challenge them to solve complex problems from multiple perspectives, including technical feasibility, healthcare implications, and broader social impacts. Students work alongside faculty from diverse fields such as engineering, business, applied math, and education to develop their communication skills and cooperative problem-solving abilities. The program accommodates a maximum of 40 students who reside in campus dormitories and receive full room and board as part of their tuition. While the cost covers all instructional fees, scholarships are available for those with demonstrated economic hardship, and successful completion grants participants a continuing education scholarship toward future undergraduate studies at the institution.

results.name: Marine Science Research

deadlines.label: Winter 2026 Payment Deadline (for students accepted after Jan 23)

results.title: Marine Science
results.subtitle: UC San Diego
results.description: Marine Science is a program designed to equip high school students with the knowledge and skills to become environmental advocates through interdisciplinary and experiential learning. Students move through a tiered sequence of courses, starting with a foundation in ocean sciences and marine biology before advancing to hands-on research alongside graduate students and industry professionals. The curriculum emphasizes the development of critical competencies such as problem-solving, creative thinking, and leadership while offering participants the opportunity to strengthen their scientific communication and analytical skills. In the advanced stages of the program, scholars may even have the opportunity to publish their work in a dedicated research journal and explore past student projects via a poster archive. These non-credit-bearing pre-college courses are offered on a rolling basis, and participants may be able to transfer units for secondary school credit depending on their school's policies.

results.name: Discovering Engineering
results.title: Discovering Engineering
results.subtitle: A. James Clark School of Engineering, University of Maryland
results.description: Discovering Engineering is a one-week residential summer program where participants work in university facilities to explore various engineering disciplines. The program is designed for students entering the 11th or 12th grade who have an interest in applying their math, science, and engineering skills. Students participate in a range of activities, including laboratory work, demonstrations, lectures, computer instruction, and a collaborative team design project. Participants live on campus, visit eight different engineering departments, and engage in evening social activities to build self-confidence and professional networks. The application process requires an online form, a personal statement, a teacher recommendation, and a high school transcript, with scholarships available for those with demonstrated financial need.

results.name: Visual Arts Summer Institute
results.title: Pre-College And Youth Summer Programs
results.subtitle: Boston University
results.description: Boston University offers a wide range of pre-college and youth summer programs designed for middle and high school students to gain valuable academic experience and enhance their existing skill sets. These offerings include immersive tracks in biotechnology, mathematics, and engineering, alongside opportunities for original research through specialized internship and practicum programs. Students interested in the arts can participate in intensive institutes for theatre and visual arts, while younger participants can join recreational camps such as Camp Terrier. The programs are structured to allow students to explore what they love doing in a challenging and fun environment. This diverse selection of activities ensures that students from various disciplines can find a program that suits their interests and future academic goals.

results.name: Pre-College
results.title: Pre-College Summer Residential Program
results.subtitle: Stevens Institute of Technology
results.description: The Pre-College Summer Residential Program offers high school students an immersive introduction to campus life through one- and two-week non-credit academic courses focused on hands-on learning. Participants work directly with faculty on engaging projects and collaborate with a global cohort of peers to build academic confidence and explore potential career paths. The all-inclusive program covers housing, meals, and signature extracurricular events, providing a comprehensive preview of the undergraduate experience. Additionally, program alumni who are later admitted to the university may receive merit-based scholarships renewable for up to eight semesters. This residential experience is designed to offer students a balance of structured independence and rigorous academic exploration within a supportive community.

results.name: Business Basics
results.title: Online Survey Software
results.subtitle: Qualtrics Survey Solutions
results.description: Qualtrics Survey Solutions offers specialized online survey software designed to facilitate comprehensive data collection and analysis. The platform allows users to create complex questionnaires with various logic paths to suit specific project needs. This tool is widely utilized for conducting academic research and gathering market insights across diverse fields. It provides a structured environment for managing responses and generating detailed reports to interpret findings effectively.

results.title: Summer Camps: High School
results.subtitle: The University of Texas at Arlington
results.description: The University of Texas at Arlington offers a variety of summer camp programs tailored for high school students in grades 9 through 12. Students can participate in specialized sessions such as Analogue Photography, Principles of Engineering, and multiple levels of Teen Med Camp that cover introductory and advanced medical topics. Additional unique offerings include workshops on how to publish a book, 3D printing in the Fab Lab, and themed Dungeons & Dragons adventure sessions. These camps are organized into half-day blocks, providing students with concentrated learning experiences in fields ranging from STEM and medicine to the visual arts and creative writing.

results.name: EnvironMentors
results.title: Penn State EnvironMentors
results.subtitle: The Pennsylvania State University
results.description: The Penn State EnvironMentors program invites high school students to participate in hands-on STEM research under the guidance of experienced mentors. Participants must be willing to learn new skills and commit to meeting with their mentors for one to three hours, several times per month. Throughout the program, students develop a research project and prepare findings to be showcased at a formal Research Symposium. Mentees also have the chance to engage in field trips and various campus events designed to broaden their understanding of scientific fields. High school participants work alongside undergraduate and graduate students, as well as faculty and staff, to develop their academic and professional skills.

results.name: The NextGen Leadership Institute
results.title: NextGen Leadership Institute
results.subtitle: Barnard Pre-College Programs
results.description: The NextGen Leadership Institute invites students to explore diverse academic interests through three distinct tracks: STEMinist, Writing and Literature, or Global Humanities. In small classes taught by expert instructors and faculty, participants conduct laboratory experiments, draft original creative works, and analyze primary historical sources. Alongside their track-specific coursework, all students participate in the weekly Leadership in Action series to develop practical tools for strategic thinking and inclusive collaboration. The curriculum emphasizes the connection between academic theory and real-world application through curated learning experiences such as museum studies, research lab visits, and guest talks from sector changemakers. By the conclusion of the program, participants will have refined their quantitative and qualitative skills while building a versatile toolkit for use in their schools and local communities.

results.name: Summer Session
results.title: Columbia University Summer Session
results.subtitle: Columbia University School of Professional Studies
results.description: Columbia University Summer Session provides visiting undergraduate, graduate, and postbaccalaureate students with access to diverse academic offerings at an Ivy League institution. The program features several specialized tracks, including Arts in the Summer, Special Foreign Language Programs, and various professional certificates. To apply, candidates must submit an online application form accompanied by a nonrefundable fee and unofficial transcripts from all previously attended post-secondary schools. While most programs require a current résumé, non-native English speakers are also mandated to provide official proficiency test scores from recognized providers such as TOEFL, IELTS, or Duolingo. Once admitted, students are responsible for ensuring that their home institutions send certified electronic transcripts to the university to finalize the enrollment process.

results.name: Outreach Ambassador Program
results.title: UCSD Outreach Ambassador Program
results.subtitle: San Diego Supercomputer Center
results.description: The UCSD Outreach Ambassador Program involves student volunteers who help spread information regarding the San Diego Supercomputer Center's extensive outreach efforts and STEM dissemination. Participants represent numerous schools across the county and meet monthly to coordinate communication plans for their individual educational communities. Through a partnership with the Picky Eats Charitable Foundation, students can have their volunteer hours certified to qualify for The President’s Volunteer Service Award. The program typically certifies a minimum of five hours per month, subject to approval from the program director. This initiative aims to empower the next generation of scientists, technologists, and engineers by engaging them in leadership and educational outreach roles.

results.name: Quantum School
results.title: Quantum School for Young Students
results.subtitle: Institute for Quantum Computing
results.description: The Quantum School for Young Students is a unique enrichment program for high school students designed to explore the intersection of mathematics, physics, computer science, and engineering through the lens of quantum information. Participants engage in a blend of expert-led lectures, interactive group discussions, and problem-solving sessions while receiving mentoring from world-leading quantum researchers. The curriculum covers advanced topics such as quantum superposition, entanglement, complex numbers, and quantum cryptography, providing students with the mathematical background necessary to tackle modern physics challenges. This program offers networking opportunities with a community of motivated peers and provides exposure to both the theoretical and experimental sides of quantum technology.

results.name: “Blender” Camp

deadlines.label: Summer Veterinary Experience Secondary Application Deadline

program_dates.label: NW Cyber Camp - High School Edition

results.title: High school summer camps
results.subtitle: Oregon State University
results.description: Oregon State University offers a diverse range of interactive summer programs for high school students entering grades 9 through 12. Students can explore specialized fields such as 3D graphics and animation in Blender Camp, or delve into the environmental impacts of chemicals during the Toxicology Camp. The curriculum also includes the NW Cyber Camp for those interested in cybersecurity and problem-solving, as well as the Color Innovation Workshop which focuses on design concepts and branding. Older students entering their junior or senior years may apply for the Summer Veterinary Experience to gain hands-on knowledge of animal health and clinical skills through hospital tours and lab sessions. These camps emphasize teamwork, curiosity, and real-world applications across various scientific and creative disciplines.

results.name: Computer Science for Cyber Security
results.title: Computer Science for Cyber Security (CS4CS)
results.subtitle: NYU Tandon School of Engineering
results.description: Computer Science for Cyber Security (CS4CS) is a summer program at the NYU Tandon School of Engineering designed to introduce students to the fundamentals of computer science and cybersecurity. The curriculum, taught by NYU faculty and graduate students, covers specialized topics such as digital forensics, steganography, “white-hat” hacking, and cryptography. This program is open to students currently enrolled in the 8th, 9th, 10th, or 11th grade who live in New York City or neighboring areas like Jersey City, Newark, or Hempstead. Participants do not need any prior experience in computer science or cybersecurity to be eligible for the program. Offered as a tuition-free opportunity with full scholarships, the program requires a commitment to the full duration of the curriculum. Interested applicants must submit an online application that includes their academic history and two short essay responses.

results.name: Food Science Camp

program_dates.label: NW Cyber Camp - High School Edition

results.title: High school summer camps
results.subtitle: Oregon State University
results.description: The High school summer camps offered through the Stem Academy provide students entering grades 9-12 with opportunities to explore diverse fields including computer graphics, toxicology, cybersecurity, and veterinary medicine. Participants can engage in hands-on learning through activities like 3D modeling and animation using free software, conducting toxicology experiments to study environmental impacts, or tackling cybersecurity challenges involving digital forensics and encryption. The programming includes specialized offerings such as a design-focused workshop on color theory and branding, as well as an intensive veterinary experience for upperclassmen that requires a secondary application and strong academic performance in science classes. Most sessions emphasize teamwork and allow students to work alongside college mentors and industry professionals to solve real-world problems. Needs-based scholarships are available for many programs, and registration is conducted through a central online system to provide access for all interested learners.

results.name: Biotechnology Lab Techniques
results.title: Lab Techniques in Biotechnology
results.subtitle: Institute for STEM Education (I-STEM)
results.description: This program introduces motivated high school students to the advanced techniques and equipment utilized in modern biotechnology research to build a strong foundation for future scientific endeavors. Participants must have completed ninth grade and possess a background in biology, while a background in chemistry is also suggested for success in the course. Throughout the session, students work in cooperative groups to explore model systems such as E. coli, C. elegans, and D. melanogaster while mastering skills like bacterial transformations and gel electrophoresis. The curriculum further covers plasmid engineering, PCR analysis, DNA/RNA extraction, and RT-PCR analysis to provide a comprehensive lab experience. The program cost is $700, and applicants must submit a formal application along with recommendations from both a science teacher and one other teacher.

results.name: Student Intern Program
results.title: The Werner H. Kirsten Student Internship Program
results.subtitle: National Cancer Institute
results.description: The Werner H. Kirsten Student Internship Program is an educational initiative designed to provide students with exposure to scientific and research environments. The program is currently undergoing a comprehensive redesign to align with updated NIH Internship policy and requirements. Prospective applicants can find additional information regarding general eligibility requirements for all NIH internships on the official program page. Participants typically engage in research-related activities under the guidance of the National Cancer Institute and other health-related departments. This program serves as a training ground for students interested in pursuing careers within the biomedical and cancer research fields.

results.name: NYC Residential Summer
results.title: NYC Residential Summer
results.subtitle: Columbia University Pre-College Programs
results.description: This immersive residential program allows students aged 15 and older to experience college life while living in on-campus residence halls under the supervision of resident advisors. Participants choose from more than 70 courses across a dozen subject areas, attending four hours of daily instruction led by expert faculty who encourage critical and independent thinking. The experience includes access to extensive campus resources like libraries and gyms, alongside co-curricular programming such as college prep workshops and health and wellness events. Upon successful completion, students earn a Columbia University Certification of Participation and a formal evaluation letter to support their future college applications.

results.name: Fire Protection Discovery Program
results.title: Fire Protection Discovery
results.subtitle: Oklahoma State University
results.description: Students entering the 9th through 12th grades have the opportunity to explore fire safety through hands-on learning in the "Burn to Learn - The Engineering Systems to Keep it Safe" program. Participants apply fundamental engineering principles to design specialized systems for safe building evacuations as well as fire detection and suppression. The program fee covers all essential accommodations, daily meals, a camp shirt, and the various supplies required for individual and group design projects. Outside of core instructional hours, students engage in organized evening functions and interactive activities to further their discovery. Because seat availability is limited, interested applicants should complete their registration and required forms promptly to secure a spot.

results.name: Consider Engineering Summer Camp
results.title: The Chip Moody Consider Engineering Program
results.subtitle: UMaine Pulp + Paper Foundation
results.description: The Chip Moody Consider Engineering Program is a competitive four-day overnight summer experience designed for high school juniors interested in exploring the field of engineering. Participants engage in hands-on engineering experiments and problem-solving challenges while networking with faculty and practicing industry professionals. This free-of-charge program is open to students from across the United States who demonstrate academic excellence in math and science along with strong leadership and communication skills. Admission is highly selective, requiring an application that includes a high school transcript, a letter of intent, a list of extracurricular activities, and a teacher recommendation. During their stay, students receive provided food and lodging to get a realistic taste of campus life and professional engineering pathways.

results.name: Summer Internship Program
results.title: High School Summer Internship Program
results.subtitle: DH Career Institute
results.description: The High School Summer Internship Program at DH Career Institute offers rising juniors and seniors an opportunity to explore diverse healthcare career pathways through a combination of paid work, mentoring, and experiential learning. Utilizing a rotational model, participants gain exposure to two or three different departments, such as pharmacy, radiology, medical laboratories, or facilities and engineering, to understand the inner workings of a major medical center. In addition to departmental tasks, interns participate in a professional development curriculum designed to strengthen core competencies in teamwork, communication, problem-solving, and initiative. Applicants must be at least 16 years old and willing to commit to a full-time schedule for the duration of the seven-week experience. Prospective candidates are required to submit a current resume along with one letter of recommendation to be considered for this competitive cohort-based program.

results.name: Summer Research
results.title: Summer Research Program - 2026
results.subtitle: Stony Brook University
results.description: The Summer Research Program - 2026 provides high school students with the opportunity to join research groups focused on polymer science and engineering. Eligible applicants must be at least 16 years old, maintain an unweighted GPA of 3.8 or higher, and have completed honors or advanced coursework in subjects like chemistry, physics, and mathematics. Students engage in sophisticated projects involving polymer blends, composite materials, and theoretical modeling, with the potential to publish findings in refereed research journals. The application requires a two-part submission process, three letters of recommendation, official transcripts, and a non-refundable registration fee. While participants are responsible for a laboratory usage fee, the university offers optional room and board packages through campus residences for those requiring housing.

results.name: University at Albany
results.title: Science Research in the High School
results.subtitle: University at Albany
results.description: The Science Research in the High School program, sponsored by the University at Albany, enables students to perform original scientific research and earn college credits while still in high school. Participating sophomores, juniors, and seniors engage in multi-year sequences including Intermediate and Advanced Methods of Research, which require a minimum commitment of 250 hours per school year. Students must secure a professional mentor with doctoral-level credentials to guide their work and help them develop a research plan or hypothesis. Throughout the program, participants maintain detailed laboratory notebooks and portfolios, culminating in a mandatory end-of-year symposium where they present their findings through posters and PowerPoint presentations. In addition to local presentations, students are encouraged to enter competitive venues and pursue publication of their finished scientific papers.

results.name: OSU

program_dates.label: Eco-Printmaking: Sustainable Art for People and the Planet
Leadership: What It Is and How to Get It

results.title: Arts and Sciences Summer Exploration Program
results.subtitle: College of Arts and Sciences
results.description: The Arts and Sciences Summer Exploration Program offers middle and high school students one-week intensive academic enrichment courses taught by Ohio State faculty, staff, and graduate students. These hands-on classes are designed for self-motivated learners and cover diverse subjects ranging from the science of vision and eco-printmaking to leadership and adaptable STEM skills. Participants engage in active learning through lectures, experiments, and creative workshops, such as dissecting animal tissues or utilizing professional printmaking studios. The program fee covers all course materials, daily lunch, and snacks, though participants are expected to bring their own basic academic supplies and personal laptops for specific sessions.

results.name: Summer Engineering Seminar
results.title: Summer Engineering Seminar (SES)
results.subtitle: Santa Clara University
results.description: The Summer Engineering Seminar (SES) is a free, five-day immersive summer experience for high school sophomores and juniors interested in exploring the field of engineering through workshops and hands-on projects. Participants attend introductory sessions led by university faculty and undergraduate students that cover diverse disciplines, including bioengineering, civil engineering, computer science, and mechanical engineering. This residential program allows students to experience university life by living in dormitories and interacting with the academic community, with all on-site fees, housing, and meals provided at no cost. The program specifically targets students from underrepresented groups, such as first-generation, low-income, and non-binary individuals, who may lack access to engineering coursework in their own communities. Admission is competitive and evaluated based on academic performance in math and science, as well as an essay outlining the applicant's passion and curiosity for the field.

results.name: University of Colorado Denver
results.title: CU Denver GenCyber Summer Camp for High School Students
results.subtitle: CU Denver Business School
results.description: The GenCyber Summer Camp program at the CU Denver Business School provides exciting, hands-on cybersecurity experiences for high school students across Colorado. Participants explore diverse topics such as ethical hacking, social engineering, computer and digital forensics, networking fundamentals, and cybersecurity ethics. This entirely free program provides all necessary materials, including Raspberry Pi kits, virtual labs, and games to facilitate an engaging learning environment. Students gain insight into cybersecurity careers and online safety while earning a Certificate of Achievement upon completion. The initiative is supported by the National Security Agency and National Science Foundation to address the significant workforce need in the field.

results.name: Young Innovators Climate Program
results.title: Young Innovators: Climate & Energy
results.subtitle: University of Chicago
results.description: This one-week residential program is designed for current 11th-grade students interested in the intersection of climate science and energy policy. Participants engage in rigorous discussion-based classes, readings, and collaborative hands-on projects led by faculty from the Energy Policy Institute and the Climate Impact Lab. The curriculum addresses global energy challenges, focusing on the need for reliable energy to foster economic growth while mitigating environmental damage. Students also gain professional development through panels with industry experts from Invenergy, highlighting diverse career opportunities available to those with STEM degrees. Required application materials include a transcript, two short essays, a writing sample, and a letter of recommendation.

results.name: Pirates Pitch Competition
results.title: Pirates Pitch Competition for High School Students
results.subtitle: Seton Hall University
results.description: The Pirates Pitch Competition for High School Students is an entrepreneurial contest designed to teach teenagers the basics of idea generation and business creation. Eligible participants include current high school sophomores, juniors, and seniors who maintain a minimum grade point average of 3.0. To enter, students must submit a written business idea of 350 words or less or provide a three-minute video pitch explaining their product's solution, revenue model, target audience, and competitive advantage. Finalists are invited to deliver a five-minute oral presentation to a panel of independent judges for a chance to win cash prizes and significant scholarships to attend the university. The competition rewards outstanding entrepreneurial know-how and provides a platform for young innovators to showcase their startups in a "Shark Tank" style environment.

results.name: University of Colorado Boulder
results.title: Teen Internship Program 2016-2025
results.subtitle: University of Colorado Boulder
results.description: The Teen Internship Program offers high school students an immersive opportunity to participate in an empathy-driven engineering and design project focused on creating accessible materials for blind or visually impaired clients. Participants engage with Maker technologies such as 3D modeling and printing, laser cutters, and computer programming to develop tactile and multi-modal learning tools. The internship emphasizes Universal Design principles and requires students to apply critical problem-solving skills to meet the specific needs of their clients. In addition to technical training, student interns build professional workplace skills including communication and collaboration while contributing to a larger research study on STEM identities and career perceptions.

results.name: Institute of Biomedical Research

program_dates.label: Summer Commuter Workshop: Biomedical Research (Alameda) - Session 1
Summer Commuter Workshop: Biomedical Research (Alameda) - Session 2
Online Introduction to Cellular and Molecular Medicine
Winter Break: Online Medical Bioinformatics and Medicinal Chemistry

results.title: BIOMEDICAL CAMPS
results.subtitle: Rosetta Institute
results.description: These molecular medicine workshops are designed for high-achieving middle and high school students interested in pursuing careers in medicine, biomedical research, drug development, or nursing. Taught by PhD-level instructors, the curriculum utilizes engaging lectures and hands-on laboratory sessions to explore normal molecular biology and how these processes are disrupted during the development of various diseases. Students focus heavily on experimental design, modern drug development, and the emergence of personalized medicine throughout their coursework. To conclude the program, participants apply their knowledge by creating an original research project centered on a specific gene or molecular process of their choice. Available in residential, commuter, and online formats, the workshops allow attendees to build their college portfolios and explore potential career paths while interacting with mentors and peers from around the world.

results.name: Pre-College
results.title: Emory Pre-College Program
results.subtitle: Emory University
results.description: The Emory Pre-College Program provides current high school sophomores and juniors with an academic and residential experience at a top-ranked liberal arts university. Students have the opportunity to explore over 100 different courses taught by university faculty, ranging from noncredit options to credit-bearing sessions. Specific tracks such as the Pre-Med Institute allow participants to engage in specialized areas of study while getting a taste of college life. The program utilizes a rolling admissions process, meaning that complete applications are reviewed as soon as they are submitted by prospective students.

results.name: CED Build Camp
results.title: Design + Build Bootcamp
results.subtitle: CED
results.description: The Design + Build Bootcamp is a specialized educational program offered through CED that emphasizes the practical integration of design theory and construction techniques. This curriculum is situated within a department that also oversees studies in architecture, landscape architecture, and sustainable environmental design. Although this specific bootcamp is currently on hiatus, the institution provides alternative paths for exploration such as the embARC Summer Design Academy. Participants are encouraged to utilize available resources including fabrication labs, research centers, and academic advising to further their understanding of the built environment.

results.name: Student Interactions with Science, Technology, Engineering and Mathematics
results.title: Early Outreach
results.subtitle: University of Nevada, Las Vegas
results.description: Early Outreach provides comprehensive college and career readiness programming tailored specifically for K–10 students and their families. The program facilitates its mission through diverse community engagement opportunities, including year-round events that help students build curiosity about their futures and career paths. Participants can engage in age-appropriate campus tours or schedule school visits for college fairs, career days, and family nights to connect with the university team. A specialized component called Young Rebels offers academic and social enrichment, fostering critical thinking skills and positive interactions with university faculty and students. These initiatives are designed to help young learners envision themselves in a higher education setting while building academically minded friendships.

results.name: Discover the Exciting World of Surgery
results.title: Becoming a Surgeon: Skills, Specialties, and Diseases
results.subtitle: Georgetown University
results.description: Becoming a Surgeon: Skills, Specialties, and Diseases is an online course from Georgetown University designed for students ages 13 and up who are interested in pursuing medical careers. Participants explore various surgical fields and study conditions such as diverticulitis, appendicitis, and gastric cancer while learning about diagnostic tests and surgical interventions like laparoscopic procedures. The program provides 20 to 30 hours of total instruction through video lectures and simulations, offering students access to mentors who assist with assignments and the development of a Final Capstone Project. Students gain hands-on experience by creating anatomical models and instructional videos to demonstrate their learning, ultimately earning a Certificate of Completion upon finishing the flexible curriculum. The enrollment process is streamlined with no transcripts or recommendation letters required, and students may choose between multiple session lengths to accommodate their schedules.

results.name: RIBS - Research in Biological Sciences
results.title: Research in the Biological Sciences
results.subtitle: UChicago Summer Session
results.description: Research in the Biological Sciences is a four-week intensive training program designed for 10th and 11th-grade students who have completed at least one year of high school biology. Participants are immersed in a project-based curriculum that covers a wide range of molecular, microbiological, and cell biological techniques utilized in modern research laboratories. After two weeks of foundational lab training, students spend the remainder of the session conducting an independent research project and maintaining a detailed lab notebook. The program includes weekly lunch seminars with research faculty, group presentations on original research articles, and a final research forum where students present their project results. Successful completion of this residential experience provides participants with the skills and confidence necessary to work effectively in a professional laboratory setting.

results.name: Art Camp
results.title: Art Camp
results.subtitle: Penn State Abington
results.description: Designed for kids ages 8–14, this program encourages participants to unleash their creativity through a variety of artistic explorations. Each morning, campers dive into a brand-new art medium to create four unique works of art by the end of the week. In the afternoon, the fun continues as students bring their projects to life using integrated art-and-technology techniques. Campers experiment with diverse materials ranging from traditional paint and clay to modern digital tools and design elements to discover their personal inspirations as artists.

results.name: Welch Summer Scholar

program_dates.label: D&D: Adventures on the Astral sea (Grades 9-12)
Teen Med Camp 2: Beyond the Basics (Grades 9-12) Session 1
Teen Med Camp 2: Beyond the Basics (Grades 9-12) Session 2
D&D: Escapades in the city of Waterdeep (Grades 9-12)

results.title: Summer Camps: High School
results.subtitle: The University of Texas at Arlington
results.description: The University of Texas at Arlington offers a diverse range of summer camps specifically designed for high school students in grades 9 through 12. Participants can explore specialized subjects such as medicine through the Teen Med Camp series or delve into technical fields with courses like Principles of Engineering and 3D printing in the Fab Lab. Creative interests are supported by programs in analogue photography and workshops on how to publish a book, while tabletop gaming enthusiasts can join Dungeons & Dragons adventures. Each camp session is organized into either morning or afternoon blocks to provide focused instruction on these academic and extracurricular topics. These programs aim to provide students with hands-on experience and deeper knowledge in their chosen areas of interest.

results.name: Architecture Summer Immersion
results.title: Architecture Summer Immersion Program
results.subtitle: Rice University
results.description: The Architecture Summer Immersion Program is designed for high school sophomores and juniors interested in pursuing architecture and design principles through hands-on workshops and creative exercises. Participants test design concepts in two and three dimensions using diverse media such as model making and freehand drawing to produce works for their college application portfolios. Throughout the session, students interact closely with faculty, current students, and professional architects to receive feedback and instruction on portfolio composition. This tuition-free residential program includes room, board, and all necessary supplies, fostering a network of peers while exploring architectural scales and the requirements of architecture school.

results.name: TTUHSC
results.title: Summer Camp for High School Students
results.subtitle: Texas Tech Health El Paso
results.description: The Summer Camp for High School Students offers two separate two-week sessions designed to accommodate up to 30 students per session. The program curriculum features interactive presentations led by various health care professionals and includes several educational field trips. Participants engage in unique hands-on activities such as a mock crime scene investigation and a reality store exercise that simulates real-world life expenses. Students also receive valuable financial aid information and have the opportunity to interact with advisors to discuss their future educational paths. Eligible participants must be available to attend the program in person for the full duration of the daily scheduled activities.

results.name: Engineering & CS Camp
results.title: Engineering & Computer Science Camp
results.subtitle: UTeach Outreach
results.description: The Engineering & Computer Science Camp is an immersive five-week program designed for students who will have graduated from 9th or 10th grade. Participants engage in a variety of activities including technology development, computational thinking, and computer programming in languages such as Scratch and Python. Throughout the session, students receive mentorship from instructors, university student interns, and faculty while attending lab tours and career-focused speaker sessions. Admission requires a completed application, a student survey, and a grade report reflecting high academic achievement in math, science, and English courses. This program focuses on experiential learning and college exploration but is not offered for high school credit.

results.name: Summer Session
results.title: Summer Session
results.subtitle: UC San Diego
results.description: Summer Session at UC San Diego provides an opportunity for students to accelerate progress toward their degrees and enhance their career prospects by enrolling in a wide variety of academic courses. The program is open to current UC San Diego students, incoming first-year and transfer students, visiting UC students, high schoolers, and the general public. Academic offerings include rigorous courses equivalent to those taught during the 10-week academic year, though delivered in condensed sessions. Participants can choose between in-person, fully remote, or hybrid course formats to suit their learning preferences. Additionally, the university offers support services such as summer housing, financial aid options for eligible students, and access to campus recreation facilities.

results.name: Summer Scholars
results.title: Summer Scholars
results.subtitle: Clemson University
results.description: The Summer Scholars program at Clemson University offers rising 7th through 12th-grade students a one-week immersive introduction to college life and various academic subjects of their choice. Participants engage in hands-on courses taught by university instructors that may include laboratory tours, field trips, and interactive experiments or projects. Beyond the classroom, students experience campus culture by staying in residence halls, eating in dining facilities, and meeting with representatives from Admissions and the Honors College. Mentorship is provided by current Clemson students who serve as counselors, while evening activities like planetarium shows and social gatherings foster a sense of community. This American Camp Association-accredited program also features global perspectives through international partnerships with institutions like Gyeonggi Science High School.

results.name: Writing Contest
results.title: EngineerGirl Writing Contest
results.subtitle: National Academy of Engineering
results.description: The EngineerGirl Writing Contest is an annual competition that focuses on various engineering topics and their significant impact on the global community. Participants are invited to explore how engineering solutions shape our world through creative expression and analytical thinking. The contest encourages students to utilize both art and writing to demonstrate the ways in which engineers contribute to creating a better future. This program is co-hosted by the EngineerTeen platform and provides detailed instructions for submissions on an annual basis. All entries are evaluated based on how effectively they communicate the role of engineering in society, with winning participants recognized for their work.

results.name: Biotech Summer Camp
results.title: PROJECT BIOTECH
results.subtitle: Shoreline Community College
results.description: PROJECT BIOTECH offers high school students the opportunity to participate in week-long explorations of biotechnology and DNA sequencing within a professional laboratory environment. Participants engage in hands-on lab and bioinformatics activities designed to provide a deep dive into the world of modern science. The program includes significant face time with professional scientists, offering students valuable exposure to potential career paths in the industry. Campers also get a glimpse of community college life while exploring specific themes such as the causes and cures of cancer through the lens of biotechnology. Through partnerships with major biotech companies, the curriculum integrates real-world applications and tours to broaden the students' perspective of the STEM field.

results.name: W. P. Carey School of Business

deadlines.label: Final deadline to apply to be considered

results.title: Fleischer Scholars Program
results.subtitle: W. P. Carey School of Business
results.description: The Fleischer Scholars Program is a free, transformative pre-college initiative designed for high school juniors who want to develop strategic thinking capabilities and prepare for success in college and business. Admitted students explore various academic and career opportunities while connecting with staff, alumni mentors, and motivated peers to build a master adaptive learner mindset. The selection process prioritizes applicants based on academic performance, financial need, involvement in leadership or community service, and status as first-generation college-bound individuals. Participants gain early access to scholarship resources, professional networking, and a mobile application designed to support work-based learning and college preparation. The required application includes personal and academic information along with a short answer response regarding personal hardships or strategic thinking.

results.name: Summer Concert Camp

program_dates.label: D&D: Adventures on the Astral sea (Grades 9-12)
Teen Med Camp 2: Beyond the Basics (Grades 9-12) Session 1
Teen Med Camp 2: Beyond the Basics (Grades 9-12) Session 2
D&D: Escapades in the city of Waterdeep (Grades 9-12)

results.title: Summer Camps: High School
results.subtitle: The University of Texas at Arlington
results.description: The University of Texas at Arlington offers a diverse selection of summer camps specifically designed for high school students in grades 9 through 12. Participants can explore various disciplines ranging from creative arts like analogue photography and book publishing to technical fields such as 3D printing and the principles of engineering. For those interested in the healthcare field, the program provides multiple sessions of Teen Med Camp, including introductory and advanced levels that cover essential medical concepts. Additionally, students can engage in immersive role-playing experiences through Dungeons & Dragons themed courses focused on creative storytelling and collaborative play. These specialized workshops provide students with hands-on learning opportunities and the chance to dive deep into specific subject areas under university guidance.

results.name: Fall STEM Camp
results.title: Early Outreach
results.subtitle: University of Nevada, Las Vegas
results.description: UNLV Early Outreach provides college and career readiness programming specifically designed for K–10 students and their families. The program aims to help students navigate their path toward higher education through various engagement opportunities such as school visits, community events, and campus tours. Participants in the Young Rebels initiative engage in unique academic and social enrichment activities that support college access and foster critical thinking skills. Students have the opportunity to build academically minded friendships and interact with university faculty and students to envision themselves in a higher education setting. These initiatives allow elementary, middle, and early high school students to build curiosity about potential careers and connect with campus and community partners.

results.name: Siblinghood Academy
results.title: Siblinghood Academy
results.subtitle: Sadie Nash Leadership Project
results.description: Siblinghood Academy is an afterschool leadership program designed for young women and gender-expansive youth in grades 9 through 12. Participants engage in workshops exploring topics such as identity, womanism, youth activism, and the development of healthy relationships. The curriculum includes creative classes, field trips, and conferences that aim to strengthen confidence and communication skills while building a supportive peer community. Both year-long and short-term virtual versions of the program are offered to accommodate different student needs. Applicants do not need to meet specific academic or skill criteria for admission, and participants are eligible for financial stipends based on their level of involvement.

results.name: Virtual Computational Biology Research
results.title: 2026 CB Camp
results.subtitle: miRcore
results.description: The 2026 CB Camp is an intensive program designed for academically motivated high school and incoming ninth-grade students interested in the fields of mathematics, science, medicine, and computation. Participants investigate the roles of genomes and transcriptomes in human diseases by performing computational biology research with patient RNA expression data to identify relevant biomarkers. Working in small groups, students use professional scientific tools to explore novel diagnostics or treatment options through logical exploration and data analysis. Completing this program qualifies students for the miRcore volunteer program and enables them to found or lead Genes in Diseases and Symptoms (GIDAS) school clubs. In-person attendees participate in wet-lab experiments or field trips, while virtual students engage in a dedicated separate program. Partial scholarships are available for students with financial need, and all participants are required to have a computer for the duration of the camp.

results.name: Engineering Camp
results.title: Engineering Camp
results.subtitle: Bucknell University
results.description: Engineering Camp offers an academically challenging, hands-on introduction to engineering where students experiment in real research labs alongside world-class faculty. Participants explore various engineering disciplines, study the latest technologies shaping the world, and learn to apply scientific phenomena to solve practical engineering problems. The program is open to students who have completed grades seven through eleven, with campers placed into age-appropriate sections based on an application review. Students can choose between residential and commuter options, both of which include instruction through lectures, demonstrations, and laboratory experiences. Additional benefits include 24/7 supervision in residence halls for residential students and eligibility for an application fee waiver for future university admissions.

results.name: Summer Student Program
results.title: Summer Student Program
results.subtitle: The Jackson Laboratory
results.description: The Summer Student Program is designed for intellectually curious undergraduate and graduating high school seniors eager to explore how genetics and genomics shape biological systems within a collaborative research environment. Participants join ongoing research labs to implement independent projects under the guidance of experienced scientific mentors, gaining hands-on experience in laboratory discovery. Throughout the fellowship, students engage in professional development sessions and training that covers essential skills such as scientific communication, data visualization, and the responsible conduct of research. The experience includes weekly Journal Club meetings and opportunities to interact with diverse professionals, including grant writers and veterinarians, to explore various career paths in science. At the conclusion of the program, students present their findings to a community of researchers and family members. Participants are provided with a $7,000 stipend as well as coverage for room, board, and travel expenses.

results.name: Research Institute Internship
results.title: Maine Medical Center Research Institute Summer Student Research Program
results.subtitle: Maine Medical Center
results.description: The Maine Medical Center Research Institute Summer Student Research Program provides undergraduate students in their first, second, or third year with an intensive educational experience in the field of biomedical science. Participants engage in research across diverse areas such as stem cell biology, neurobiology, molecular genetics, and clinical research. The program spans ten weeks, during which students are expected to commit 40 hours per week to their assigned projects. While participants gain hands-on experience in laboratory and clinical settings, they are responsible for arranging their own housing and transportation for the duration of the internship. This opportunity allows students to explore advanced topics like vascular biology and vector-borne diseases under the guidance of professionals at the institution.

results.name: Business Competition
results.title: Client Challenge
results.description: The Client Challenge is accessed through an online platform where certain technical requirements must be met to ensure all site components load properly. Participants may encounter difficulties due to browser extensions, network issues, or specific browser settings that prevent the required materials from appearing. To resolve these issues, individuals should verify their internet connection and disable any active ad blockers that might interfere with the site’s functionality. If the program components still do not load, it is recommended to switch to a different web browser to successfully interact with the challenge.

results.name: National Economics Challenge
results.title: National Economics Challenge for High School Students
results.description: The National Economics Challenge for High School Students is a premier academic competition that invites learners to explore the complexities of economic theory. This activity provides a platform for students to test their knowledge through various rounds of competitive testing and problem-solving. Participants engage in a rigorous process that identifies and rewards excellence in the study of economics at the secondary level. The program is designed to foster a deeper understanding of financial systems and global markets among all its participants.

results.name: Summer Humanities
results.title: Stanford Summer Humanities Institute
results.subtitle: Stanford Pre-Collegiate Studies
results.description: The Stanford Summer Humanities Institute is a three-week residential program designed specifically for rising high school juniors and seniors. Participants engage with significant questions regarding the human experience through seminars led by university professors and graduate students. This non-credit enrichment opportunity provides an environment for students to live within a vibrant, intellectual community while pursuing advanced academic study. Academically motivated and intellectually curious individuals are encouraged to apply for this intensive program that delves into complex humanistic disciplines.

results.name: Oakland University
results.title: Summer Mathematics Institute
results.subtitle: Oakland University
results.description: The Summer Mathematics Institute is a free day camp designed for bright and gifted pre-college students to explore advanced mathematical concepts in a university setting. Participants enroll in two four-credit courses led by doctoral-holding faculty, providing an opportunity to earn transferable college credit in subjects like graph theory and algorithm analysis. The curriculum includes intensive academic instruction supplemented by small group sessions where students work with counselors on problem-solving, homework, and mathematical recreations. Lunch is provided daily at no cost to help facilitate full-day engagement in the academic atmosphere. Participants receive certificates of completion and formal testimony of their credits at a concluding banquet held for families and educators.

results.name: Raikes School Summer Camp
results.title: Summer Camp
results.subtitle: Jeffrey S. Raikes School of Computer Science and Management
results.description: The Jeffrey S. Raikes School of Computer Science and Management offers a two-week residential program for high school students to build a foundation in core programming and innovation. Led by school faculty, the curriculum provides project-oriented instruction in widely used languages such as Java and Python for students of all experience levels. Participants engage in collaborative activities and visit research facilities, such as the NIMBUS drone lab, and local business partners to explore career paths in business and computing. The program fee covers housing, meals, and all academic activities, with both full and partial scholarships available to qualified applicants who submit the required essay and academic records.

results.name: NC State
results.title: Catalyst: Creating Opportunities in STEM For Students with Disabilities
results.subtitle: NC State University
results.description: Catalyst is a free, award-winning yearlong program specifically designed for high school students with disabilities who are interested in pursuing STEM careers. Participants engage with various STEM content and skills while gaining workforce and college readiness training to prepare for future success. The program provides unique opportunities such as paid STEM internships, national field studies trips, and the chance to earn specific STEM certifications. To be eligible, applicants must be students in grades 9-12 in North Carolina and have an IEP, 504 Plan, or a documented disability. Prospective students must attend a designated open house to enroll for the upcoming cycle.

results.name: Architecture Pre-College
results.title: Architecture
results.subtitle: Carnegie Mellon University
results.description: The Pre-College Architecture program provides an intensive five-week experience for high school sophomores and juniors interested in exploring the creative energy and professional culture of architectural studies. Participants engage in an interdisciplinary curriculum that includes architectural design studios, seminars on history and theory, and workshops focusing on analog drawing and digital media tools like Photoshop and Rhinoceros. Students work both individually and collaboratively on complex design problems, building foundational skills in analytical thinking, spatial articulation, and conceptual development. Beyond studio work, the program incorporates field trips to construction sites and museum exhibitions, along with special lectures on contemporary practices and portfolio development. Admission to the program requires an online application featuring a transcript, a letter of recommendation, personal essays, and a short video submission to demonstrate the applicant's potential.

results.name: THINK Scholars Program
results.title: MIT THINK Scholars Program
results.subtitle: MIT
results.description: The MIT THINK Scholars Program is a science, research, and innovation initiative catering to high school students who have conducted extensive background research but require additional resources and guidance to complete their projects. Organized by a group of undergraduates at MIT, the program offers selected finalists weekly mentorship meetings for technical support and project updates. Finalists are awarded up to $1,000 in funding to implement their proposals, which can range from green technologies and physical devices to software applications. Participants may also be invited to visit campus labs and present their research to university faculty and students. This opportunity is open to high school students living in the United States who can complete their research within a single semester.

results.name: Journalism Institute
results.title: Cherubs 2023
results.subtitle: Northwestern University
results.description: The Cherubs program at Northwestern University provides students with a rigorous academic environment centered on journalism and media through the Medill School. Participants engage in professional-level experiences including the creation of published work and interaction with a network of successful alumni. Tuition for the program is $5,000, which covers room and board for all participants during their stay. The application requires several components, including a fillable form, an essay, a comprehensive activity list, and specific writing samples. Applicants are also required to submit mid-year or first-semester grades, available test scores, and a teacher's letter of recommendation for evaluation. Financial assistance is available through a $100,000 aid pool and various named scholarships to ensure accessibility for qualified students.

results.name: Quantum Information Program

program_dates.label: New York Hall of Science Session

results.title: Quantum Information Science-Technology Summer Program
results.subtitle: Institute for STEM Education (I-STEM)
results.description: The Quantum Information Science-Technology Summer Program is designed for students entering grades 10 through 12 who are interested in exploring the fundamentals of quantum science and computing. Participants will engage in hands-on activities, including IBM Quantum Composer simulations and experiments focused on concepts like entanglement and wave-particle duality. This educational initiative requires no prior experience in programming or advanced mathematics, making the field accessible to a broad range of high school learners. Throughout the session, students interact with university professors and researchers to gain insights into academic pathways and professional careers in quantum technologies. The program is fully funded by the National Science Foundation, which covers all tuition costs and provides daily lunches for participants.

results.name: 4H-RU Program
results.title: Service Temporarily Unavailable
results.subtitle: Rutgers University
results.description: The electronic service requested from the institution is currently undergoing a period of temporary unavailability. Potential users are advised to revisit the site at a later time to attempt their request again. Should questions or suggestions arise during this downtime, several campus-specific help desks are available to provide technical assistance and support. Furthermore, visitors can explore the main university websites for more information regarding institutional resources and updates.

results.name: Coding Program
results.title: Kode With Klossy
results.subtitle: Kode With Klossy Inc.
results.description: Kode With Klossy creates learning experiences and opportunities for young women and gender expansive youth ages 13-18. These programs are offered for free and are designed to ignite a spark that fuels scholars' agency to pursue their passions in a tech-driven world. No prior coding experience is required for applicants, as the organization welcomes curious and creative individuals regardless of their computer science background. Scholars receive continued support through an alumni network that helps them pursue further education and leadership roles in technology and engineering fields.

results.name: Research Experience Program

program_dates.label: 2026 NIH Obesity Research Task Force Virtual Symposium

results.title: Research Training & Career Development
results.subtitle: NIDDK
results.description: The Research Training & Career Development program supports the educational and professional growth of medical and graduate students, postdoctoral fellows, and physician scientists. Funding is provided through a variety of institutional and individual grants designed to foster expertise in fields such as diabetes, digestive diseases, and kidney health. Opportunities are available for individuals at various career stages, ranging from high school and undergraduate students to junior faculty and established investigators. In addition to grant funding, the program facilitates connections with training staff and offers internships or postdoctoral positions within specialized research labs. Participants can access resources for new investigators, attend workshops on physiology and medical education, and explore career-enhancing pathways in biomedical research.

results.name: Research in Engineering Program
results.title: Duke Research in Engineering Program
results.subtitle: Duke Biomedical Engineering
results.description: The Duke Research in Engineering Program (DukeREP) is a seven-week summer initiative hosted by the Biomedical Engineering Department for high school students interested in science and engineering. This program provides participants with hands-on training through research projects in specialized laboratories and weekly seminars that cover professional skills, college advising, and guest lectures from faculty. Eligible students must be rising high school juniors or seniors residing in North Carolina and at least 16 years of age, with a particular emphasis on recruiting those from first-generation or economically disadvantaged backgrounds. There is no cost to apply or attend, and participants receive a stipend, daily lunch, and transportation assistance to support their involvement. The program aims to promote STEM education and inspire diverse students to pursue academic and professional careers in scientific research.

results.name: Junior Science & Humanities
results.title: Junior Science and Humanities Symposium
results.subtitle: Junior Science and Humanities Symposium
results.description: The Junior Science and Humanities Symposium (JSHS) is a program that invites students to engage with science and humanities disciplines. This initiative is sponsored by the Junior Science and Humanities Symposium and maintains an active presence across various social media platforms, including Facebook, Instagram, and LinkedIn. Currently, the official website for the program is suspended until further notice, and updates will be posted as they become available. Interested participants or those with inquiries are encouraged to direct their questions to the official program email address provided in the announcement.

results.name: YCCI Exposures Program
results.title: For Trainees & Faculty Learners
results.subtitle: Yale Center for Clinical Investigation
results.description: The Yale Center for Clinical Investigation provides comprehensive, career-spanning training programs designed to enhance the clinical and translational research workforce. These offerings are available to members of the Yale University community and Yale-New Haven Health System personnel to support innovative and impactful research. The curricula align with nationally recognized core competency frameworks and include specialized tracks such as pre-doctoral training, post-doctoral training, and a Junior Faculty Scholars program. Participants receive didactic instruction in topics like Good Clinical Practice and research ethics, which is further reinforced through experiential learning and personalized mentorship. Ultimately, the program aims to bridge the gap between laboratory discoveries and improvements in patient care through interdisciplinary, team-based research.

results.name: National Academic Championship

deadlines.label: Final Entry Fee and Registration Deadline

results.title: 41st ANNUAL NATIONAL ACADEMIC CHAMPIONSHIP
results.subtitle: National Academic Association
results.description: The 41st ANNUAL NATIONAL ACADEMIC CHAMPIONSHIP is a premier academic competition designed for students ranging from elementary school to high school varsity levels. This tournament focuses on 'significa' rather than trivia, prioritizing academic relevance and high-quality questions across diverse subject areas. Each participating team consists of three or four starters who compete in at least six guaranteed matches during the preliminary rounds to earn a spot in the single-elimination playoffs. Schools can qualify by winning local or regional events, finishing in the top percentiles of designated tournaments, or applying for a wild-card entry based on their seasonal performance.

results.name: Emory & Henry College
results.title: Summer Scholars Leadership Program
results.subtitle: Emory & Henry
results.description: The Summer Scholars Leadership Program is designed for rising 10th-12th graders looking to develop skills for leadership roles in high school and college. Participants experience a unique mix of learning activities in a college-like setting while living in campus residence halls under the supervision of adult counselors who are present at all times. Students attend morning classes focused on specific leadership modules, such as Servant Leadership, Leadership in Action, Faith Based Leadership, or the Outdoor Adventure Program. The curriculum covers a broad range of topics including leadership assessments, challenge activities, community service, and value exploration. Afternoon and evening sessions complement these lessons with practical experiences like leadership tower activities and participation in outdoor adventures.

results.name: Summer Springboard
results.title: Summer Springboard
results.subtitle: UC San Diego
results.description: High school students participating in this pre-college program can select from a wide range of two-week academic courses or combine them for a four-week immersive experience. The curriculum features hands-on learning in diverse tracks such as biotechnology, trial law, and extended reality, often involving professional lab work or on-site field experiences. Both residential and commuter options are available, with the residential track providing suite-style housing and full meal plans while commuters attend weekday academic and social programming. Participants also benefit from college readiness workshops and a personal development curriculum designed to foster self-discovery and prepare them for higher education. Summer staff reside on-site to provide continuous support and ensure a safe, community-focused environment throughout the duration of the sessions.

results.name: Urban Photography Camp

program_dates.label: D&D: Adventures on the Astral sea (Grades 9-12)
Teen Med Camp 2: Beyond the Basics (Grades 9-12) Session 1
Teen Med Camp 2: Beyond the Basics (Grades 9-12) Session 2
D&D: Escapades in the city of Waterdeep (Grades 9-12)

results.title: Summer Camps: High School
results.subtitle: The University of Texas at Arlington
results.description: The University of Texas at Arlington offers a diverse selection of summer camps specifically designed for high school students in grades 9 through 12. These programs cover a wide range of academic and creative interests, including specialized tracks such as Analogue Photography, Principles of Engineering, and Teen Med Camps that offer introductory and advanced medical training. Students can also explore literary fields through sessions on how to publish a book or engage in technical skill-building at the Fab Lab with 3D Printing 101 workshops. For those interested in collaborative storytelling and gaming, the university provides Dungeons & Dragons adventures set in the Astral Sea and the city of Waterdeep. Each camp is structured to provide hands-on experience and enrichment within a higher education environment.

results.name: Tulane University
results.title: Summer Residential Program
results.subtitle: Tulane Office of Admission
results.description: The Summer Residential Program is an immersive two-week initiative designed for Louisiana high school rising juniors and seniors, particularly those who are first-generation college students or have limited access to college-readiness resources. Participants live on campus, take non-credit enrichment courses without the pressure of exams, and engage in workshops focused on the college search process, financial aid, and application perfection. The curriculum includes visits to various institutions, including community colleges, public and private universities, and HBCUs, to help students find their ideal college fit. Each student is paired with a mentor who is a higher education professional to provide personalized guidance throughout the admission process. Admission is scholarship-based, with funding covering the majority or entirety of the program costs for accepted participants based on financial need.

results.name: Pre-College Enrichment Program
results.title: State Pre-College Enrichment Program (S-PREP)
results.subtitle: Vagelos College of Physicians and Surgeons
results.description: The State Pre-College Enrichment Program (S-PREP) is a free college preparatory program designed for 7th through 12th-grade students who are interested in pursuing careers in medicine or related STEM fields. Participants engage in a rigorous curriculum featuring enrichment courses such as Anatomy, Biochemistry, Chemistry, Physics, and various levels of Mathematics ranging from Algebra to Calculus.
