results.name: STEM Academy
results.title: STEM Academy
results.subtitle: Johns Hopkins University Applied Physics Laboratory
results.description: The STEM Academy at Johns Hopkins University Applied Physics Laboratory provides after-school courses designed for middle school students in grades 6–8 and high school students in grades 9–12. These programs aim to increase participants' knowledge and interest in STEM-related college majors and careers through a supportive learning environment. Students engage in hands-on, project-based courses that help them develop their STEM identity and prepare for future success in technical fields. While the curriculum is designed for all learners, priority for enrollment in these in-person and virtual courses is given to students who reside in the state of Maryland. Participants attend these specialized sessions to explore various scientific and engineering skills under the guidance of expert mentors.

results.name: Scholars Program
results.title: Saint Regis Mohawk Scholars Program
results.subtitle: Roswell Park Comprehensive Cancer Center
results.description: The Saint Regis Mohawk Scholars Program offers three distinct educational paths for students from the Saint Regis Mohawk Tribe to explore Indigenous health issues and cancer science. High school juniors can participate in a weekly afterschool program focused on social wellness factors, research through Indigenous knowledge, and the causes of cancer. Additionally, the program provides paid summer research internships for both high school and college students, pairing them with professional mentors for hands-on experience in specialized oncology fields. Participants engage in diverse activities including laboratory research, community outreach, and peer mentorship to address health disparities within their communities. This collaborative initiative aims to foster interest in health careers while providing students with professional training and academic support.

results.name: Ted R. Lilley CURE Program
results.title: Ted R. Lilley CURE Program
results.subtitle: OHSU Knight Cancer Institute
results.description: The Ted R. Lilley Continuing Umbrella of Research Education (CURE) Program provides hands-on research experiences to Portland-area high school sophomores, juniors, and seniors who excel academically and come from socially or economically disadvantaged backgrounds. Participants spend eight weeks working in a lab alongside a faculty member for up to 40 hours per week, which includes attending weekly seminars and adhering to a professional curriculum. Eligible applicants must be at least 16 years old with a minimum 3.0 GPA and have completed at least one lab science course, preferably in biology. Upon successful completion of the program, interns receive a $4,000 stipend and a Tri-Met pass, concluding their experience with a formal poster presentation shared with institute staff. Prospective students are required to submit an application package featuring a high school transcript, a resume of extracurricular activities, an essay on career goals, and two letters of recommendation.

results.name: City of Albany
results.title: Albany's LIGHT Youth Employment Programs
results.subtitle: City of Albany
results.description: The City of Albany's LIGHT Youth Employment Programs offers employment opportunities specifically designed for youth between the ages of 14 and 18. Standing for Learning Initiatives and Gaining Headway Together, the program utilizes a specialized curriculum to introduce participants to the labor market and help them acquire essential life skills. Participants gain valuable work experience intended to improve school performance, build professional networks, and prepare them for future careers across various local business sectors. Through these initiatives, youth engage in special projects and day-to-day business functions while learning transferable habits from industry leaders.

results.name: Cancer Center
results.title: Summer Student Program
results.subtitle: Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center
results.description: The Summer Student Program is an eight-week internship designed for high school juniors who are interested in pursuing careers in the biomedical sciences. Participants engage in independent research within a laboratory setting where they are paired with a mentor to develop technical skills and complete a self-directed project that supports a Principal Investigator’s objectives. Beyond laboratory work, the program offers professional and personal development events that provide insight into the world of translational medicine and research. Research areas available for exploration include cancer biology, immunology, pharmacology, and computational biology. Eligible students receive a stipend of $1,200 for their full-time commitment to the program.

results.name: Congressional App Challenge
results.title: Congressional App Challenge
results.subtitle: Internet Education Foundation
results.description: The Congressional App Challenge is recognized as a prestigious prize in student computer science designed to inspire the next generation of innovators. The competition engages students from across the country, focusing on reaching underserved, diverse, and rural populations to foster inclusive growth in the tech sector. Participants have the opportunity to showcase their coding skills and app creations to leaders, effectively bridging the gap between today’s Congress and future developers. Through registration and participation in specific congressional districts, students contribute to a movement that has significantly increased the visibility of computer science and STEM within the federal government.

results.name: FIU

program_dates.label: Junior Doctors of Tomorrow Summer Program

results.title: Junior Doctors of Tomorrow Summer Program
results.subtitle: FIU Herbert Wertheim College of Medicine
results.description: The Junior Doctors of Tomorrow Summer Program is a week-long enrichment initiative designed to provide high school juniors and seniors with an immersive journey into the healthcare field. Eligible students must maintain a minimum 3.0 GPA and are selected through an application process that requires a 500-word essay, a high school transcript, and a letter of recommendation. Participants engage in hands-on clinical workshops and interactive sessions while receiving mentorship from experienced medical professionals. This free program is highly selective, with attendance limited to only 30 students per session. All students are responsible for arranging their own transportation to and from the campus throughout the duration of the program.

results.name: Summer Institute

deadlines.label: Computer Science Early Decision Deposit Due

results.title: SI@UCF
results.subtitle: UCF
results.description: SI@UCF provides enrichment opportunities through its Computer Science and Mathematical Exploration tracks for middle and high school students. The Computer Science program accepts applicants in grades 7-11 who demonstrate a strong interest in mathematics and have ideally completed Algebra I. For the Mathematical Exploration program, students entering grades 11 and 12 must show an elevated interest in the subject and have a background in Algebra 2. Admission for both tracks is based on academic transcripts, a minimum 3.0 GPA, and recommendations from teachers or guidance counselors. These competitive programs have limited capacity, accepting a maximum of 35 students for Computer Science and 20 students for Mathematical Exploration.

decisions_date.label: Computer Science Early Decisions Sent Out
Computer Science Final Decisions Sent Out

results.name: CSU
results.title: Summer@CSU: High School
results.subtitle: Cleveland State University
results.description: Summer@CSU: High School offers a diverse range of programs spanning academic enrichment, STEM workshops, athletic clinics, and professional internships designed to jump-start college education. Participants can engage in specialized initiatives like the Legacy ++ Program for Black young women in computer science, the Odyssey Film Camps covering cinematography and editing, or the Tech Talent Pipeline which provides paid internships in university-based research labs. The offerings include Hyland STEM engineering camps, the Sport Management Institute for aspiring industry professionals, and Math Corps, where students earn stipends while tutoring middle school peers. Additionally, the university provides various sports clinics in soccer, basketball, tennis, and volleyball, along with aquatic training and adaptive swimming programs for individuals with special needs. Residential options are available for select programs to foster peer-to-peer learning communities through shared housing and meals.

results.name: VCU Health
results.title: Junior Volunteer Program
results.subtitle: VCU Health
results.description: The Junior Volunteer Program offers local high school students who are at least 14 years old and have completed the 8th grade an opportunity to provide voluntary service within a community healthcare setting. Participants focus on welcoming and wayfinding, assisting patients and visitors in navigating the medical complex to locate appointments or loved ones. This competitive program limits acceptance to forty participants on a first-come, first-served basis, requiring applicants to participate in an interview process. Those selected must complete mandatory training, submit health screening documentation including proof of immunizations, and manage their own service shifts through a self-scheduling portal.

results.name: WIE Aspire Explore Engineering
results.title: WIE Aspire! Explore Engineering
results.subtitle: A. James Clark School of Engineering, University of Maryland
results.description: The WIE Aspire! Explore Engineering program is a week-long commuter experience offered by the Women in Engineering Program for rising 9th and 10th grade students. Participants explore various engineering disciplines, including aerospace, bioengineering, chemical, and mechanical engineering, through department presentations and hands-on workshops. The curriculum introduces students to basic engineering concepts and the interdisciplinary nature of the field through lab tours and interactions with faculty and current University of Maryland students. To apply, interested students must submit an application including an interest statement, their middle or high school academic records, and a recommendation from a STEM teacher. While there is a program fee that covers all materials and activities, the program offers need-based scholarships to ensure access for all admitted participants.

results.name: Arizona State University
results.title: The Science and Engineering Experience (SCENE)
results.subtitle: Arizona State University
results.description: The Science and Engineering Experience (SCENE) provides high school sophomores, juniors, and seniors with the opportunity to conduct original research in professional laboratory settings. Students work under the mentorship of university faculty and research professionals across various disciplines, including Biodesign, Evolution & Medicine, Physics, and Sustainable Engineering. Participants are expected to dedicate six to twelve hours per week to formulate their own research questions, learn lab techniques, and execute experiments. The program culminates in presenting research findings at the Arizona Science and Engineering Fair, where students compete for awards and recognition. This rigorous experience is designed for students who are committed to pursuing careers in science or engineering and possess strong critical thinking skills.

results.name: Science of Smart Cities
results.title: Innovation, Entrepreneurship, and the Science of Smart Cities (ieSoSC)
results.subtitle: New York University
results.description: Innovation, Entrepreneurship, and the Science of Smart Cities (ieSoSC) is a tuition-free program designed for eligible high school students who possess a strong interest in STEM. Participants engage in interactive, hands-on classes taught by university faculty to advance their expertise in computer science, engineering, and urban technology. Working in small teams with a dedicated materials budget, students ideate and prototype devices or apps intended to solve real-world smart city challenges. The experience includes professional public presentation training using improvisation techniques and access to college readiness workshops and on-campus enrichment activities.

results.name: Forensic Science Academy
results.title: Forensic Investigation Academy
results.subtitle: Georgetown University School of Continuing Studies
results.description: Georgetown's Forensic Investigation Academy offers high school students a firsthand look at the world of criminal forensics through interactions with professionals like detectives, investigators, and crime scene technicians. The curriculum covers diverse topics including crime scene diagramming, evidence collection, ballistic forensics, and blood spatter analysis. Students participate in a blend of classroom lectures, mock crime scene examinations, field trips, and hands-on activities to develop their analytical and critical thinking skills. Participants also explore the ethical dimensions of investigative work and learn about specific areas such as gang member investigations, geographic profiling, and interviewing techniques. By engaging in case studies and group discussions, students gain insight into various career opportunities within the field of forensic investigation.

results.name: Bentley University
results.title: Pre-College Programs
results.subtitle: Bentley University
results.description: Pre-College Programs provide high school students with a taste of college academics and the opportunity to experience residential life within a university community. Participants immerse themselves in a rigorous yet supportive learning environment designed to help them gain insights into academic interests and career aspirations through interactive sessions and collaborative projects. The program includes networking opportunities with current students and faculty, as well as a range of extracurricular activities and organized social outings. While students must be 16 years old to live on campus, younger participants can register as commuter students or take part in online sessions. This experience allows like-minded peers from diverse backgrounds to build meaningful connections while gaining a firsthand look at college life.

results.name: Applied Research In Science and Engineering

program_dates.label: Summer session end date & colloquium presentation date

results.title: Applied Research In Science and Engineering (ARISE)
results.subtitle: NYU Tandon School of Engineering
results.description: The Applied Research In Science and Engineering (ARISE) program is a tuition-free, multi-week opportunity designed for high school students currently in the 10th or 11th grade who demonstrate a strong interest in STEM subjects. Participants engage in high-level scientific research across various fields, including life sciences, engineering, and computer science, within specialized laboratories. Under the mentorship of faculty and graduate researchers, students contribute to substantive research objectives while developing technical and analytical skills through hands-on experience. The program structure includes remote workshops followed by a period of full-time lab work where students are immersed in the academic environment. Additionally, students receive specialized training in public speaking and leadership to prepare for a concluding colloquium where they present their findings to a professional audience.

results.name: NC State University
results.title: Residential Programs for Rising 11th/12th Grade Students
results.subtitle: College of Engineering at NC State University
results.description: These week-long residential programs offer rising 11th and 12th grade high school students a comprehensive immersion into college life and various engineering disciplines. Participants reside in university housing and eat in dining halls while focusing on a specific engineering workshop of their choice, such as aerospace, robotics, biomedical, or ecological engineering. Daily schedules include intensive 9 a.m. to 4 p.m. workshops led by faculty and engineering students, supplemented by afternoon and evening social activities supervised by residence counselors. The admission process is competitive and requires applicants to submit an online application including academic achievements and written responses regarding their personal goals and problem-solving interests. On the final day, parents are invited to attend a showcase where students present the projects and research they developed throughout the week.

results.name: Mathematics Program
results.title: Ross Program
results.subtitle: Ross Program
results.description: The Ross Program invites individuals to apply for counselor positions where they will support intensive mathematical studies. Prospective staff members must submit an application that includes short essay responses, official transcripts, a current CV, and a professional reference letter. Returning employees who served in previous years are welcome to reapply and are specifically exempted from the requirement to provide a new recommendation. The selection process involves a comprehensive review of candidate materials by a hiring committee to determine placements across the program's multiple sites.

results.name: Space Astronomy Program
results.title: Space Astronomy Summer Program
results.subtitle: Space Telescope Science Institute (STScI)
results.description: The Space Astronomy Summer Program (SASP) is a competitive internship designed for highly motivated college students, particularly upper-division undergraduates with interests in space-based astronomy, engineering, or public outreach. Participants engage in hands-on projects working alongside professional researchers and staff on tasks ranging from the statistical analysis of astronomical data to the development of internal and external software tools. Every student is matched with a mentor and attends various lectures to gain exposure to leading research in astrophysics and the workings of a space-based observatory. Opportunities within the program span several areas, including instrument calibration for the Hubble and James Webb Space Telescopes, scientific writing, and public outreach through the creation of educational products. In addition to professional development and cohort-building activities, interns receive a stipend, housing assistance, and travel reimbursement for their efforts. The experience culminates in a symposium where students deliver short presentations on their project results and answer questions from the community.

results.name: Inspiring the Next Generation of Women in Physics
results.title: SPINWIP
results.subtitle: Stanford Physics Department
results.description: The Stanford Program for Inspiring the Next Generation of Women in Physics is a virtual three-week summer outreach program designed to engage high school students in the world of modern science. Participants learn about cutting-edge research in fields such as quantum computing, astrophysics, and cosmology while also gaining practical skills by learning to code in Python for physics-based projects. The curriculum includes lectures from university professors, small group sessions led by undergraduate mentors, and workshops focused on college planning and career development. This free program is open to high school students in grades 9 through 11, with a particular emphasis on supporting first-generation students and those from underrepresented or under-resourced backgrounds. Students have the unique opportunity to form mentorship relationships with academic researchers and peers without requiring any prior knowledge of physics or computer programming.

results.name: Summer Academics
results.title: Music Theatre (Advanced/Pre-College)
results.subtitle: Claire Trevor School of the Arts
results.description: The Music Theatre (Advanced/Pre-College) program is a college and career preparatory intensive designed for experienced high school students in grades 9 through 12 and college-aged participants. This academy focuses on advancing triple-threat skills through practical and technical training led by instructors from a top-tier national drama program. The curriculum is modeled after undergraduate studies, providing students with a realistic preview of life as a drama major at the university level. It is specifically intended for individuals who are seriously considering pursuing a future education or a professional career in music theatre. The program fee covers the cost of instruction and includes daily lunch, with additional financial aid, scholarships, and discounts available for eligible applicants.

results.name: Engineering Virtual Summer Program
results.title: Experience Engineering Virtual Summer Program
results.subtitle: A. James Clark School of Engineering, University of Maryland
results.description: The Experience Engineering Virtual Summer Program, hosted by the A. James Clark School of Engineering, University of Maryland, offers high school students entering the 11th or 12th grade an opportunity to explore the interdisciplinary principles of engineering from home. Participants engage in a variety of activities including lectures, discussions, and interactive instruction, while also completing both individual and team design projects. The curriculum allows students to learn more about the eight specific engineering departments within the Clark School while building confidence in their math, science, and engineering skills. To apply, interested students must submit an online application that includes a personal statement and an official or unofficial transcript. The program costs $250 per student, with scholarships available for those with demonstrated financial need, and requires access to a computer with broadband internet and a webcam for live sessions.

results.name: PRISM High School Program
results.title: PRISM High School Outreach Program
results.subtitle: Northwestern University Feinberg School of Medicine
results.description: The PRISM High School Outreach Program encourages students to explore diverse career opportunities within the fields of science and medicine through mentor-guided educational activities. Participants work in small, consistent groups with mentors from the Medical Scientist Training Program to foster long-term mentoring relationships throughout the academic year. The curriculum is organized into three distinct modules, each focusing on a specific physiological system and an associated disease. Students engage in various interactive sessions including patient interview simulations, laboratory activities such as dissections, and collaborative research projects that culminate in medical presentations. Additionally, the program offers special sessions that may include guest lectures from physicians or educational field trips to specialized anatomy labs and hospitals.

results.name: UMBC
results.title: Summer Enrichment Academy
results.subtitle: Institute of Extended Learning – UMBC
results.description: The Summer Enrichment Academy offers dynamic, hands-on programs designed exclusively for high school and middle school students. Participants can dive deep into their interests through immersive experiences in fields such as science, technology, arts, and leadership. The curriculum features interactive workshops, exciting projects, and inspiring discussions led by industry experts and mentors. Students have the opportunity to build new skills and connect with like-minded peers in a growth-oriented environment. Standard pricing for these courses typically ranges from $374 to $499.

results.name: Bug Camp
results.title: Bug Camp
results.subtitle: Department of Entomology | University of Maryland
results.description: Bug Camp: Insects, Science & Society is an educational program designed for youth ages 7 to 12 to explore the abundance and value of insects through hands-on learning. Participants engage in diverse activities including lab experiments involving bug DNA and genetics, field trips to local habitats, and interactive arts and crafts. The non-residential camp is led by 4-H trained and accredited counselors, maintaining a staff-to-camper ratio of approximately 1:7 to ensure quality supervision. Enrollment is managed via a first-come, first-served interest form process, with two identical one-week sessions available to accommodate participants. Beyond scientific exploration, the curriculum includes team-building games and lessons on the vital relationship between humans and insects.

results.name: ARISE UWCCC Summer High School Cancer Research
results.title: ARISE Summer Research Internship
results.subtitle: University of Wisconsin-Madison
results.description: The ARISE Summer Research Internship provides middle and high school students with hands-on laboratory experience within a mentor lab focused on cancer research. Participants engage in laboratory skills training, conduct their own projects, and receive one-on-one check-ins with a Principal Investigator to develop their scientific expertise. Beyond bench work, the program includes enrichment activities such as career exploration in nursing and pharmacy, medical ethics discussions, and pathology experiences. Students also attend career panels and science presentation workshops designed to bolster the skills necessary for advanced degree programs and cancer-related careers. Prospective interns must submit an application including unofficial transcripts, two essays, and a letter of recommendation for consideration.

results.name: TRIO Upward Bound
results.title: Upward Bound
results.subtitle: University of Notre Dame
results.description: Upward Bound is a comprehensive college preparatory program designed to equip high school students with the skills and support needed to enter and succeed in higher education. Participants engage in individualized tutoring, project-based learning, and enrichment sessions focused on core subjects and college readiness skills like SAT/ACT preparation and financial literacy. The program includes a Summer Academy where students can earn high school or college credits in subjects such as lab science, foreign languages, and writing while participating in a residential component on campus. Additional support is provided through college tours, academic advising, and a specialized bridge program for recent graduates to facilitate a smooth transition into the collegiate environment.

results.name: Leadership Seminars
results.title: Leadership Seminars
results.subtitle: University of Notre Dame
results.description: Leadership Seminars is a competitive, 10-day residential program designed for academically talented students who demonstrate impressive leadership within their communities. Admitting approximately 150 students annually, the program offers participants the opportunity to earn one transferable college credit upon successful completion. The University of Notre Dame covers the full cost of tuition, housing, and meals for all admitted students, making it an accessible opportunity for top scholars. Students engage in intensive courses covering diverse topics such as business ethics, global violence and peace, social inequities, AI and data innovation, and financial literacy. The curriculum focuses on applying knowledge to real-world problems and encourages students to confront controversial issues through critical thinking and discussion with university professors.

results.name: Summer Stem
results.title: Summer Programs
results.subtitle: U.S. Naval Academy
results.description: The Summer Programs at the U.S. Naval Academy offer specialized opportunities for students entering grades nine through twelve to experience life at the institution. The Naval Academy Summer Seminar provides rising seniors with a week of first-class academic, athletic, and professional training designed to kick-start their official application process. Younger students from grades nine to eleven can participate in the Summer STEM program, which focuses on problem solving, exploratory learning, and critical thinking within technical fields. Participants in these programs collaborate with peers from across the globe while engaging in team-building activities and hands-on academic workshops. These sessions are ideal for high schoolers interested in a future in science, technology, engineering, and math or those curious about the professional training offered at the Academy.

results.name: Missouri S&T
results.title: Nuclear Engineering Camp
results.subtitle: Missouri University of Science and Technology
results.description: The Nuclear Engineering Camp at Missouri University of Science and Technology offers high school students an immersive introduction to the multifaceted world of nuclear power and engineering. This hands-on program allows participants to explore various career paths within the field, including safe energy production and the utilization of radiation for biomedical research and medical imaging. Campers have the unique opportunity to learn about the operation of a nuclear reactor and the engineering behind nuclear-powered naval vessels like submarines and aircraft carriers. The curriculum is specifically designed to showcase the outstanding professional opportunities available in the nuclear sector for students interested in advanced technology and science.

results.name: UTSA
results.title: UTSA Prefreshman Engineering Program
results.subtitle: UT San Antonio
results.description: The UTSA Prefreshman Engineering Program is a pre-college summer initiative designed to prepare middle and high school students for advanced studies and careers in STEM fields. Participants engage in hands-on learning and collaborative projects that build essential skills in science, technology, engineering, and mathematics. The program features a comprehensive curriculum that includes STEM challenges, professional mentors, and potential internship opportunities to inspire the next generation of leaders. Enrollment involves a two-step process where students must first submit an application for consideration before completing registration upon acceptance. While applying is free of charge, the tuition cost for the full summer session is $500.

results.name: High School Programming
results.title: Circular Innovation Challenge
results.subtitle: Lewis & Clark College
results.description: The Circular Innovation Challenge is an entrepreneurship precollege summer program at Lewis & Clark College designed for high school students entering grades 9 through 12 who are interested in sustainability and innovation. Participants engage in hands-on learning using creative tools such as design thinking, lean startup methods, and the business model canvas to develop sustainable business ideas within the circular economy. The curriculum includes conducting business case studies, interviewing industry leaders, and collaborating on creative teams to build product prototypes based on real-world feedback. Students connect with professional mentors and college student guides throughout the week, culminating in a high-impact team pitch competition for prizes. Participants who complete the program and are later admitted to the college are guaranteed a minimum of $20,000 in annual renewable scholarship funding.

results.name: Student Research Internships
results.title: Student Research Internship
results.subtitle: Scripps Research
results.description: The Student Research Internship Program and the Medical Student Research Internship Program offer immersive summer opportunities focused on cutting-edge translational medical research. These programs are designed for a broad range of participants, including high school, undergraduate, graduate, professional, and medical students interested in health sciences, statistics, and computational fields. Participants engage in research related to personalized health care, utilizing genomic, proteomic, and metabolomic data as well as mobile health monitoring technologies. Interns benefit from unique research projects, translational science seminars, journal club participation, and faculty round table discussions under the guidance of experienced physician-scientists. The primary objective is to equip students with the skills and exposure necessary to become future leaders in the realm of clinical and translational medicine.

results.name: Summer STEM Camp
results.title: Early Outreach
results.subtitle: University of Nevada, Las Vegas
results.description: UNLV Early Outreach provides college and career readiness programming specifically designed for K–10 students and their families to help them navigate the path to higher education. The program carries out its mission through community engagement opportunities, including school visits to college fairs and specialized family nights. Through the Young Rebels initiative, students participate in academic and social enrichment activities that encourage critical thinking and positive interactions with university faculty. These year-round events offer students the chance to build curiosity about various careers and connect with campus partners in a supportive environment.

results.name: GSU
results.title: Summer Institute
results.subtitle: Georgia State International Initiatives
results.description: The Summer Institute is an academic program offered through the Georgia State International Initiatives department. It provides students with the opportunity to engage in intensive coursework and cultural exchange activities. The program focuses on developing leadership qualities and improving academic proficiency within a global context. Participants can expect a curriculum that integrates classroom learning with practical experiences to enhance their overall educational journey.

results.name: SPUN Debate Program
results.title: The National Space Society (NSS) spUN Debate Program
results.subtitle: National Space Society
results.description: The National Space Society (NSS) spUN Debate Program provides an international platform for high school and university students to explore the rapidly evolving space industry and develop vital communication skills. Participants engage in competitive debates designed to hone their speech, leadership, and critical thinking abilities while learning about an economy projected to reach $3 trillion by 2050. The program fosters a diverse and inclusive environment, encouraging students from all backgrounds to address global challenges and develop solutions for a future spacefaring civilization. Involvement in this nonpartisan initiative serves as a significant enhancement for academic resumes and professional career development within the space sector.

results.name: National Youth Science Camp
results.title: 2025 National Youth Science Camp (NYSCamp)
results.subtitle: National Youth Science Academy
results.description: The 2025 National Youth Science Camp (NYSCamp) is a competitive residential program designed for high school juniors and seniors who demonstrate superior academic proficiency and a deep interest in STEAM disciplines. Selected delegates participate in a rigorous curriculum that includes seminars, hands-on activities, and the unique opportunity to propose and lead their own educational sessions. The program seeks individuals with documented leadership abilities, social maturity, and notable achievements in both academic and extracurricular fields. Beyond scientific exploration, the camp encourages delegates to consider the social impacts of science and engage with diverse topics outside of traditional classroom settings. Participation requires a full-time commitment, and applicants must demonstrate a strong desire to pursue higher education and a career within a STEAM-related profession.

results.name: Nash U
results.title: Nash U
results.subtitle: Sadie Nash Leadership Project
results.description: Nash U is a virtual college and career readiness workshop series designed specifically for high school seniors who identify as women or gender-expansive people of color. The program consists of thirteen workshops covering essential topics such as building college lists, navigating the application process, and securing financial aid. Participants engage in weekly virtual sessions to foster a network of care and shared learning among their peers while building tools for their unique professional journeys. Admission requires no specific academic or skill criteria, and students are eligible to receive an end-of-year stipend of up to $260 based on their level of workshop attendance. This initiative aims to equip young leaders with the necessary resources to thrive and prepares them to lead with purpose in their communities and beyond.

results.name: Young Investigators
results.title: Stanford Young Investigators
results.subtitle: Stanford Doerr School of Sustainability
results.description: High school scholars participate in this summer research program by working directly within laboratories to gain first-hand experience in the process of science. Interns are supervised by graduate scholars, postdoctoral researchers, and lab managers across various disciplines including planetary sciences, energy resources, and social sciences. Beyond laboratory work, the program incorporates weekly activities such as group talks, lab tours, and educational field trips to broaden students' understanding of environmental challenges. Specific internship tracks range from one-on-one investigations in oceans and earth systems to group-based research at an educational farm focusing on agriculture and nutrient cycling. Participants must have completed at least one year of high school to be eligible for these research-focused positions.

results.name: Georgia Tech
results.title: STEM Summer Internship Program
results.subtitle: Georgia Institute of Technology
results.description: The STEM Summer Internship Program is an extension of the school-based curriculum designed to expose high school students in the Griffin-Spalding County School System to workplace competencies and real-world experiences. As a part of the Georgia Tech AMP-IT-UP project, the initiative aims to increase the number of students pursuing future STEM careers by providing them with valuable academic qualifications for the postsecondary application process. Participating students spend four weeks working at local businesses for 35 to 40 hours each week, earning a wage of $7.25 per hour. Throughout the internship, participants gain exposure to various industries ranging from manufacturing to healthcare, and they conclude their experience by delivering a presentation on what they have learned. Parents are responsible for coordinating transportation for the student for the duration of the program, and local employers determine the specific hours and weeks of work.

results.name: Summer SAIL
results.title: Summer SAIL
results.subtitle: University of Oregon
results.description: Summer SAIL provides free weeklong day programs for rising high school juniors and seniors to explore various academic disciplines on a university campus. Participants engage with distinguished faculty through fun, social, and interactive activities designed to inspire a passion for higher education and learning. The diverse curriculum covers subjects ranging from computer science and business to biology and the visual arts, allowing students to delve into specific areas of interest. In addition to the hands-on learning experiences, students may also have the opportunity to earn high school credit for their participation in the program.

results.name: CATALYST Academy
results.title: CATALYST Academy
results.subtitle: Cornell University
results.description: CATALYST Academy is an educational initiative managed by the Cornell Engineering Office of Inclusive Excellence. The program focuses on providing students with the opportunity to conduct research projects across several engineering specialties. Applicants must meet specific eligibility requirements and have the chance to apply for scholarships to cover tuition expenses. The curriculum is supported by extensive resources, including a historical record of past projects and a network of program alumni.

results.name: UMass Dartmouth

deadlines.label: Private and State Programs FAFSA Deadline

program_dates.label: STEAM Your Way to College Session 1
STEAM Your Way to College Session 2

results.title: STEAM Your Way to College
results.subtitle: University of Massachusetts Dartmouth
results.description: STEAM Your Way to College is a summer academy at the University of Massachusetts Dartmouth designed specifically for dual language learners entering grades 7 and 8 from New Bedford and Fall River schools. Participants engage in inquiry-based science and engineering hands-on activities, working in teams to collect data and create innovative projects relevant to their communities. The curriculum covers diverse topics such as bioengineering, robotics, marine sciences, artificial intelligence, and data science while introducing students to various STEAM-based careers and degree paths. This free program provides enrolled students with transportation, snacks, and lunch, allowing them to visit research labs, meet with university professors, and experience life on a college campus. By fostering curiosity and academic confidence, the initiative aims to provide a long-term learning experience that continues as students transition into high school.

results.name: MERITS Program
results.title: Maine Research Internships for Teachers and Students (MERITS) Program
results.subtitle: Maine Space Grant Consortium
results.description: The Maine Research Internships for Teachers and Students (MERITS) Program offers high school juniors a six-week summer research experience at various host institutions. Participating students must be U.S. citizens and Maine residents who are currently enrolled in a Maine high school. The program allows interns to experience real-time applications of STEM while conducting research and technology development in a professional environment. Selected participants receive a stipend for their contribution and complete final reports documenting their research outcomes.

results.name: University of Minnesota
results.title: BME High School Internship Program
results.subtitle: University of Minnesota
results.description: The BME High School Internship Program offers rising high school seniors a paid, six-week hands-on experience in the field of biomedical engineering. Participants engage in research under the guidance of graduate student mentors and take tours of advanced facilities such as the Visible Heart Lab. The program provides professional development through skill training in areas like scientific writing and effective communication, alongside opportunities for career exploration in biological and engineering fields. Students conclude the experience with a poster session to showcase their work and may receive letters of recommendation from faculty members. Participants receive a stipend and bus transportation to support their involvement in exploring campus life and networking with department faculty.

results.name: Summer Session
results.title: Summer Academic Sessions
results.subtitle: William & Mary
results.description: Summer Academic Sessions provide students with the opportunity to earn college credits through diverse courses across multiple academic disciplines. Participants can choose to progress toward their degrees, explore new fields of interest, or focus on challenging subjects in an intensive environment. The program features smaller class sizes designed to foster close collaboration between faculty and peers, enhancing the overall learning experience. Courses are available in a wide range of subjects, including natural and lab sciences, computer programming, social sciences, and the performing arts. While the sessions are open to all current university students, individuals from other institutions may also apply as non-degree-seeking students to earn credits that can be transferred elsewhere.

results.name: Human Exploration Rover Challenge
results.title: NASA Human Exploration Rover Challenge
results.subtitle: NASA
results.description: NASA’s Human Exploration Rover Challenge is a nine-month hands-on engineering activity for middle school, high school, and college students worldwide. Participating teams are tasked with designing and building either human-powered or remote-controlled rovers capable of traversing difficult lunar terrain and completing specific mission tasks. The program follows a competitive proposal selection process and includes a series of technical design reviews that mirror the agency’s professional engineering lifecycle. Students interact with subject matter experts and industry professionals to prepare for the future science, technology, engineering, and mathematics workforce. To successfully reach the final excursion, teams must pass multiple milestones, including operational and mission readiness reviews.

results.name: William & Mary
results.title: William & Mary Pre-College Program
results.subtitle: William & Mary
results.description: The William & Mary Pre-College Program provides high school students ages 13 and older with the opportunity to explore various academic topics through flexible online coursework. Led by university professors, the program offers specialized tracks in areas such as Constitutional Law, Entrepreneurship, Medicine, and Psychology. Each course consists of 20 to 30 hours of total instruction featuring video lectures, multimedia simulations, and a final project designed to showcase student learning. Participants benefit from one-on-one mentoring throughout their studies and receive a certificate of completion from the university upon finishing their coursework.

results.name: UML Liftoff
results.title: UMass Lowell (UML) Liftoff for Pre-College Students
results.subtitle: UMass Lowell
results.description: UMass Lowell (UML) Liftoff for Pre-College Students is a signature six-week program designed for rising high school juniors and seniors interested in advancing their academic standing. Participating students have the opportunity to complete up to two courses through either virtual instruction or on-campus classes focused on pre-calculus and calculus. To ensure student success, the university provides comprehensive support services including weekly faculty roundtable discussions, tutoring, and coaching from professional advisors. Those interested in the on-campus math tracks must complete a mandatory placement exam to enroll in the specific coursework. The curriculum is structured to help college-bound students gain experience with university-level progress while receiving regular check-ins on their academic journey.

results.name: Biomechanics at UNO
results.title: YNS Summer Programs
results.subtitle: University of Nebraska System
results.description: YNS Summer Programs provide students with hands-on science experiences through summer camps and high school research opportunities. Students apply based on their current grade level, such as eighth graders applying for ninth-grade programs to prepare for the upcoming summer. The High School Researcher application requires a teacher recommendation and must be completed through an external online platform by the established deadline. Financial assistance is available through need-based scholarships, which can be requested directly within the program application using specific discount codes. Additionally, the initiative offers specialized one-day adventures in fields like food science, which utilize their own dedicated application portals.

results.name: American Rocketry Challenge
results.title: American Rocketry Challenge
results.subtitle: Aerospace Industries Association
results.description: The American Rocketry Challenge is the world’s largest student rocket competition designed specifically for middle and high school students to gain hands-on engineering experience. Participants engage in a yearlong opportunity to design, build, test, and launch model rockets that must meet rigorous requirements, such as safely carrying raw eggs to specific altitudes and durations. The program is intended to foster leadership, teamwork, and problem-solving skills while deepening student interest in aerospace careers and the STEM industry. Top-performing teams qualify for National Finals to compete for $100,000 in prizes and the chance to represent the United States at the International Rocketry Challenge.

results.name: Summer Child Health Internship
results.title: Child Health Research Internship
results.subtitle: Children's Hospital Colorado
results.description: The Child Health Research Internship is a summer program designed for high school seniors aged 18 and older, as well as undergraduate, graduate, and first-year medical students. Participants work directly in laboratories alongside faculty members to engage in research opportunities specifically focused on child health. Interns are required to attend a weekly research seminar series and will conclude their experience by providing a written summary and an oral or poster presentation of their findings. The program provides each intern with a stipend to assist with travel and housing costs during the nine-week commitment. Additionally, students whose research is accepted for presentation at a scientific meeting may receive funding for travel and registration fees.

results.name: Belin-Blank Research Center
results.title: Secondary Student Training Program
results.subtitle: Belin-Blank Center
results.description: The Secondary Student Training Program is a highly selective and intensive summer research opportunity designed specifically for advanced high school students in grades 10 and 11. Participants work under the mentorship of world-class faculty at a research-intensive university to conduct original research within specialized departments such as biology, engineering, or medicine. Students are required to participate in laboratory work from 9 a.m. to 4 p.m. on weekdays, attend evening seminars, and ultimately produce and present a research poster at the conclusion of the program. Upon successful completion, participants earn three semester hours of undergraduate credit and benefit from a residential experience that includes supervised housing, meals, and social activities with intellectual peers. The application process involves submitting academic and character references, standardized test scores, transcripts, and two essays describing research interests and career aspirations.

results.name: Precollege Academic Campus Experience (PACE)
results.title: Precollege Academic Campus Experience (PACE)
results.subtitle: UNIVERSITY of WISCONSIN-MADISON
results.description: The Precollege Academic Campus Experience (PACE) is an enrichment program designed for advanced middle-school learners finishing grades 4 through 8 to explore their academic passions. Participants enroll in week-long sessions involving 25 hours of specialized instruction in subjects ranging from veterinary science and neuropsychology to game design and law. Students build confidence and time management skills through individual and team-based challenges while interacting with a community of intellectually motivated peers. The program includes daily lunch at campus dining facilities and offers both full and partial scholarships to eligible applicants based on academic motivation and financial need.

results.name: WoodWorks
results.title: Wonderworks
results.subtitle: University of Houston and Rice University
results.description: Wonderworks offers several pre-college summer programs designed for talented and intellectually curious high school students. Participants can choose from diverse subject areas including architecture, creative writing, filmmaking, journalism, politics, law, and economics. The curriculum emphasizes arts and humanities to provide a rigorous academic experience through specialized tracks and faculty-led instruction. Full-tuition waivers are available for academically well-qualified students who demonstrate financial need. The application process includes an online form, and specific resources like college access workshops are also provided to assist participants with their future academic goals.

results.name: Livestock Science Camp
results.title: NC State Livestock Science Camp
results.subtitle: NC State University
results.description: The NC State Livestock Science Camp is a residential program designed for high school students aged 15-18 to explore animal science and the livestock industry. Participants engage with faculty, staff, and current students through hands-on activities, including laboratory experiments and visits to beef, dairy, swine, sheep, goat, and horse educational units. The curriculum covers the science, technology, and biotechnology of livestock industries while also examining the interaction between animal production and food safety. Beyond academic learning, students participate in leadership activities, industry tours, and guest speaker sessions to learn about diverse career paths within agriculture. No previous livestock experience is required for this program, which is limited to 40 participants and includes campus housing, meals, and supervision.

results.name: Scholars Program

program_dates.label: 2025 Scholars Program Fall Theme: Brilliant Builders & Bold Breakers

results.title: Scholars Circle: STEAM Leadership Program
results.subtitle: Project Scientist
results.description: Project Scientist’s Scholars Circle is an interactive STEAM Leadership program designed for teens ages 13 to 18 to build confidence and ignite curiosity. Participants engage in hands-on projects such as engineering robotic arms, building shoes, and designing innovative solutions to real-world problems. The curriculum fosters leadership and collaboration by connecting students with professional role models and diverse career pathways within various scientific fields. Available in both English and Spanish, the program provides all necessary STEAM education kits and training materials for students and partner organizations like schools or nonprofits. Through strong partnerships with STEM companies, the initiative offers unique expeditions and networking opportunities to help students see themselves as future innovative scientists and problem solvers.

results.name: Summer Camp
results.title: Youth On-Campus and Online Workshops
results.subtitle: New York Film Academy
results.description: The New York Film Academy provides specialized film, media, and performing arts programs tailored for teens aged 14 to 17 and kids aged 10 to 13. Students can engage in hands-on training across various disciplines, including filmmaking, acting for film, screenwriting, photography, musical theatre, game design, and 3D animation. These offerings include full-time summer camps as well as part-time weekend, after-school, and online workshops designed to build technical skills and artistic voices. Participants learn through creative projects and structured exercises that emphasize collaboration, presentation, and time management. Level-one programs are accessible to beginners with no prior experience, while level-two options allow returning students to tackle more advanced artistic challenges.

results.name: Building Leadership Strategies Summer Academy
results.title: Building Leadership Strategies Summer Academy
results.subtitle: Rutgers–New Brunswick
results.description: Building Leadership Strategies Summer Academy is a residential, in-person intensive program designed for students aged 16 to 18 who have completed their sophomore or junior year. Participants engage in integrated lectures and public speaking workshops focused on identifying personal leadership styles, enhancing critical thinking, and honing communication skills. The curriculum covers theoretical perspectives on organizational leadership, including topics such as emotional and social intelligence, group problem-solving, and the evaluation of ethical dilemmas. Upon successful completion of the academy, students earn 1.5 college credits and a Rutgers Pre-College Digital Badge credential. The experience culminates in final group presentations where students address individual leadership development and practical applications of the theories learned throughout the week.

results.name: Research Immersion

deadlines.label: Undergraduate Students at UC San Diego
Undergraduate students from California State University at Long Beach (CSULB)
Undergraduate students from North Carolina Agriculture & Technology (NCAT)
Undergraduate Students from Other Schools (US citizens or Permanent Residents)
Undergraduate or Graduate Students from Other Schools (non-US citizens or Permanent Residents)
Entering UC San Diego MS or PhD students
Researchers from Industry, Government Laboratory, or Academic Institutions
Researchers from Industry, Government Laboratory, or Academic Institutions (non-US citizens needing visa)

results.title: RIMSE Summer Schools
results.subtitle: UC San Diego Materials Research Science and Engineering Center
results.description: Research Immersion in Materials Science and Engineering (RIMSE) Summer Schools provide immersive, hands-on training for a diverse range of participants including high school and university students, K-12 educators, and industry researchers. Trainees engage in one of three specialized programs focused on silicon nanotechnology, predictive assembly, or engineered living materials through intensive theoretical and laboratory coursework. The curriculum includes training on analytical instrumentation, professional development workshops, and career seminars led by academic and government scientists. Each participant completes a "Discovery Project" capstone, conducting independent research within a small team under the guidance of a faculty mentor. The experience concludes with a final project presentation or poster session at the Summer Research Conference, requiring a full-time commitment to laboratory work and program activities.

results.name: UMKC
results.title: 2025 Cybersecurity Camp for High School Students
results.subtitle: Division of Computing, Analytics and Mathematics
results.description: This one-week nonresidential summer camp is sponsored by the National Security Agency’s GenCyber program and is designed for rising students in grades 9 through 12. Participants explore the field of cybersecurity through a combination of classroom instruction and hands-on lab activities led by university professors and education experts. The curriculum covers a wide array of topics including ethical hacking, digital forensics, internet safety, cryptography, and network scanning. Students also engage with advanced technologies such as blockchain, deepfakes, and Minecraft programming before concluding with a game-building competition. Attendance is free of charge and includes complimentary breakfast and lunch for all participants. No previous experience in cybersecurity or technical knowledge is required for enrollment.

results.name: Bridge Undergraduate Science Jr. Program
results.title: Bridge Undergraduate Science Jr. Program (BUGS Jr.)
results.subtitle: USC Bridge Institute
results.description: The Bridge Undergraduate Science Jr. Program (BUGS Jr.) is an immersive summer research opportunity designed for high school students, including incoming freshmen, who are interested in exploring scientific disciplines and human health. Participants are paired with USC faculty members and laboratory teams, including graduate students and postdoctoral fellows, to perform hands-on research in state-of-the-art facilities. The program features weekly enrichment activities such as journal clubs, career symposia, technical panels, and multi-disciplinary social mixers to help students build professional networks and surmount disciplinary boundaries. Students conclude their experience by presenting their work during a finale symposium, where they showcase their findings through dynamic poster sessions to the university community and their families. Eligibility is open to U.S. citizens, permanent residents, and students already in the U.S. on a valid immigration status, and there is no minimum GPA requirement to apply.

results.name: Summer College Immersion Program

deadlines.label: Visiting student registration and SCIP application opens

results.title: Summer College Immersion Program
results.subtitle: UCLA
results.description: The Summer College Immersion Program offers high school students an opportunity to experience academic life by studying alongside undergraduates and participating in UCLA coursework. Students gain access to a wide range of academic expertise through lectures, seminars, and workshops designed to emulate the standard university experience. The program includes specialized tracks such as SCIP+ for research skills and eSCIP for those seeking a virtual learning environment. Participants who complete the program earn college credit and a certificate while developing essential skills for managing university applications and balancing future academic responsibilities.

results.name: Medical Program
results.title: 0075 - Medical Diagnosis and Treatment
results.subtitle: University of Hawaiʻi at Mānoa Outreach College
results.description: The Medical Diagnosis and Treatment course is a specialized program designed exclusively for high school students through the University of Hawaiʻi at Mānoa Outreach College. Prospective students must complete an application process and receive acceptance into the program before proceeding with payment. Participants explore the epidemiology, pathophysiology, diagnosis, and treatment of common illnesses through a variety of hands-on methods including gross anatomy laboratory demonstrations and clinical skills labs. The curriculum covers essential medical practices such as measuring vital signs, using stethoscopes to monitor heart and lung health, and developing professional techniques for interviewing and counseling patients. Additionally, students engage with computerized manikin simulations and standardized patient interactions to gain practical experience in a clinical setting.

results.name: Bioengineering Research
results.title: Bioengineering
results.subtitle: UC San Diego
results.description: The UC San Diego Department of Bioengineering offers a series of engaging courses for high school students designed to explore the field through interactive, hands-on laboratory activities. Students typically progress through a structured sequence starting with the Bioengineering Broad Overview and Techniques (BE-BOAT) courses before moving on to research-oriented workshops and independent internship projects. Participants utilize custom lab kits for data analysis and experimental design in specialized areas such as BioMechanics, BioImaging, and Tissue Engineering. Advanced students in the Bioengineering Scholar High School Internship Project (BE-SHIP) independently propose and execute research projects in collaboration with university laboratories to produce scholarly outputs like conference abstracts or manuscripts. These non-credit-bearing, pre-college-level courses are intended to help students explore academic interests and prepare for future college admissions.

results.name: Computer & Data Science Camp

program_dates.label: Computer Programming with AI Summer Camp

results.title: Computer Programming with AI Summer Camp
results.subtitle: Lebanon Valley College
results.description: This immersive week-long camp is designed for rising high school juniors and seniors interested in exploring careers in computer programming or data science. Participants work in teams to solve programming challenges using Python and AI-powered tools, moving from initial ideas to full implementation. The program offers hands-on experience with real-world applications and relevant software while providing opportunities to connect with alumni working in the field. Students reside in college residence halls under the supervision of current college majors who serve as mentors and counselors. Enrollment includes access to campus facilities, all meals, and all necessary computer resources for the duration of the program.

results.name: Howling With Cals
results.title: Howling With CALS: Summer Camp for Rising Freshmen
results.subtitle: NC State Extension
results.description: Howling with CALS Camp is a 5-day residential program designed for a small group of rising high-school freshmen from rural North Carolina counties or underrepresented communities. Participants reside on campus to explore academic, career, and professional opportunities within the fields of agriculture and life sciences. Students engage in hands-on learning experiences, such as meeting dairy cows, propagating unique plants, and understanding the science behind food and natural resources. This grant-funded opportunity covers registration and camper fees for selected participants, though travel costs to the university are not included. Campers are led by counselors through activities aimed at preparing them to be successful high school students ready for future college applications.

results.name: Summer Academy
results.title: Engineering Summer Academy at Penn (ESAP)
results.subtitle: University of Pennsylvania
results.description: The Engineering Summer Academy at Penn (ESAP) welcomes highly motivated and talented students to explore engineering at the college level. The academy’s intensive programs combine sophisticated theory with hands-on practical experience in cutting-edge technologies such as biotechnology and robotics. Participants work with leading faculty while earning college credit and gaining exposure to a rigorous academic environment. In addition to the academic curriculum, students connect with new friends from around the world and experience student life within a campus community.

results.name: Summer Research Immersion
results.title: Summer Research Immersion (SRI)
results.subtitle: Binghamton University
results.description: The Summer Research Immersion (SRI) is a research-intensive, structured, and mentored experience consisting of one or two four-credit courses. This program requires a full-time commitment of forty hours per week and focuses on research theory, protocols, and data management followed by team-based experimental application. Participants work in inter-dependent teams of three to five students under the guidance of a dedicated Research Educator and a faculty team to solve novel research questions. Designed primarily for STEM majors who have completed at least one year of college science or engineering courses, the program concludes with a public poster session where students present their results. Admissions are conducted on a rolling basis, evaluating applicants through their academic records, personal essays, and professional letters of recommendation.

results.name: Teen Wellness Summit
results.title: Teen Wellness Summit on Mental Health
results.subtitle: Science & Health Education Partnership | UCSF
results.description: The Teen Wellness Summit on Mental Health is a free educational event organized by teens specifically for high school students in grades 9th through 12th. Participants engage in breakout sessions featuring presentations from University of California, San Francisco researchers, faculty, and local experts in the field of mental health. The summit provides a platform for attendees to meet and interact with peers from across the Bay Area while exploring wellness resources during a dedicated fair. In addition to the educational components, the program includes breakfast, a catered lunch, raffles, and goodie bags to enhance the community experience. The Science & Health Education Partnership aims to build learning, partnerships, and a sense of belonging through this student-focused initiative.

results.name: Captured in Clay
results.title: Michael C. Carlos Museum
results.subtitle: Emory
results.description: The Michael C. Carlos Museum at Emory University offers a diverse range of educational programs and artistic exhibitions for the public. Visitors can explore permanent collections and special exhibitions that focus on art, history, and cultural heritage. The museum provides dedicated resources for university students and faculty, as well as specific programs for K-12 schools and teachers. In addition to on-site viewing, the institution maintains digital programs, recordings, and publications to facilitate remote learning and research. Specialized departments also conduct provenance research and conservation work to preserve the integrity of their acquisitions.

results.name: Neuroscience Program
results.title: Summer Neuroscience Program (SNP)
results.subtitle: The Rockefeller University
results.description: The Summer Neuroscience Program (SNP) is a two-week course led by graduate students for motivated and curious public high school students who are at least 16 years of age. Participants engage in modern neuroscience through interactive lectures and hands-on activities, including dissecting a sheep brain and cow eye to identify anatomical features. Students collaborate with mentors to analyze scientific articles and design original experiments which they present at the conclusion of the program. Throughout the experience, attendees tour active research laboratories and meet with professional scientists to gain insights into biomedical careers. This program covers all associated costs for supplies and meals, requiring applicants to submit a teacher reference and participate in an interview for selection.

results.name: Tufts University
results.title: Teachers and High School Students Program (TAHSS)
results.subtitle: School of Medicine
results.description: The Teachers and High School Students Program (TAHSS), now part of the STEM+M CONNECT collaboration, offers high school sophomores and juniors a unique one-month paid summer experience focused on healthcare and STEM careers. Participants engage in a residential component through either the Mini Med School or Lab Science Investigations tracks, where they explore topics such as antimicrobial resistance and medical case studies. The curriculum features five key strands, including professional skill workshops, networking with diverse role models, and structured weekly mentoring with undergraduate STEM mentors. Highly motivated students from the Boston area, particularly those who are first-generation college-bound or from low-income backgrounds, are encouraged to apply. To be eligible, applicants must have completed at least one biology class and are required to attend a mandatory information session as part of the holistic application process.

results.name: University of North Texas

program_dates.label: End of program presentations and poster session

results.title: UNT AI Summer Research Program
results.subtitle: University of North Texas
results.description: The UNT AI Summer Research Program provides students from various academic backgrounds with the opportunity to supplement traditional coursework through focused, project-oriented research efforts. This immersive experience guides participants through all stages of the research process, starting with project selection and concluding with a formal poster presentation. Participants engage in intensive group work involving daily meetings called "huddles" and project sessions led by faculty and graduate student mentors. Applicants are generally expected to be current students at the institution with substantial programming experience in Python and a minimum GPA of 3.0. The program is designed to accelerate student preparation for more independent research efforts by demonstrating the results of well-organized and intensive group collaboration.

results.name: Solve For Tomorrow
results.title: Samsung Solve For Tomorrow
results.subtitle: Samsung
results.description: Samsung Solve For Tomorrow is a national competition designed for public school students in grades 6 through 12 to address local community issues using STEM innovation. To participate, teams must come from schools that are at least 50% publicly funded, with teachers handling the formal application submission process. Students collaborate to develop project plans that utilize cutting-edge technology, such as AI, while fostering an entrepreneurial mindset and social responsibility. Participants have the opportunity to receive one-on-one mentorship from corporate experts and compete for significant prize packages, including thousands of dollars in classroom technology and resources. Additionally, the program supports educators by providing free professional development and networking opportunities through a specialized teacher academy.

results.name: CURE Internship
results.title: CURE Research Internship Program
results.subtitle: University of California San Francisco
results.description: The CURE Research Internship Program provides an intensive research experience for current high school juniors and City College of San Francisco students interested in health-related careers. Participants are immersed in various scientific fields, including basic, clinical, behavioral, and population sciences, while working under the mentorship of faculty, post-docs, and graduate students. Throughout the program, interns conduct original scientific research and conclude their experience by presenting their findings at a formal Research Symposium. Beyond laboratory work, the initiative offers comprehensive college preparation, career advising, and professional development to help students transition into biomedical research majors. Eligible applicants must be at least 16 years old, maintain a minimum 2.5 GPA, and have completed coursework in biology or chemistry with a grade of B or better. The program requires a full-time weekly commitment and involves a competitive application process requiring transcripts and a letter of recommendation.

results.name: Emergent Quantum Materials and Technologies
results.title: YNS Summer Programs
results.subtitle: University of Nebraska System
results.description: The YNS Summer Programs offer a variety of interactive learning opportunities through specialized summer camps and high school research tracks focused on STEM fields. Students are placed into specific programs based on their grade level at the time of application, generally applying for the level they will enter in the following fall. The application process is conducted through an external online system that requires participants to create a login, where they can save their progress and manage requirements such as teacher recommendations for research positions. Financial assistance is available in the form of need-based scholarships, which can be applied for directly within the registration portal to obtain specific discount codes. All essential communication and status updates regarding the application are delivered via the email address associated with the student’s account.

results.name: The Emerson Prize
results.title: The Emerson Prize
results.subtitle: The Concord Review, Inc.
results.description: The Emerson Prize is an annual award presented to high school students who have demonstrated outstanding promise in the field of history. To be eligible for this recognition, students must have had their work published in The Concord Review during the preceding academic year. Each recipient of the Emerson Prize receives a $1,000 award for their historical research and writing contributions. In addition to this prize, the organization also awards the Fitzhugh Prize, which grants $5,000 to a select student in honor of the journal's founder, Will Fitzhugh. Since the program's inception in 1995, over 200 students have been honored for their exceptional academic work and published contributions.

results.name: SVRA Research and Data Analysis Intern
results.description: The input text is currently empty and contains no program details. No information is provided about the title or the hosting institution. Specific logistics and curriculum goals are also missing from the source text. Consequently, no relevant subject tags can be assigned to this entry at this time. Please provide the complete raw text to receive an organized summary of the activity.

results.name: Research Scholars Program

deadlines.label: High School Research Scholars Program Application Deadline

program_dates.label: Sanford PROMISE Biomedical Research Investigation Days

results.title: High School Research Scholars Program
results.subtitle: Sanford Research
results.description: The High School Research Scholars Program is a 10-week summer research internship designed for motivated high school juniors with an aptitude for biomedical sciences. Participants engage in a total-immersion experience by working alongside professional scientists as integral members of a research team in a real-time laboratory setting. In addition to intensive laboratory work, students connect with peers through in-house scientific interest groups and conclude their experience by presenting a scientific poster at the Sanford Research Symposium. Successful scholars earn three undergraduate elective credits from the University of South Dakota and are awarded a $4,000 scholarship for their dedication to the program. Applicants must be at least 16 years old, exhibit a strong interest in scientific careers, and be able to commit to a minimum of 35 hours per week throughout the internship.

results.name: Utah Entrepreneur Challenge
results.title: Tim Draper High School Utah Entrepreneur Challenge
results.subtitle: Lassonde Entrepreneur Institute at the University of Utah
results.description: The Tim Draper High School Utah Entrepreneur Challenge (HSUEC) is an opportunity for high school students to showcase their innovation and entrepreneurial spirit by entering original ideas for a chance to win cash and scholarships. Open to all Utah high school students aged 14-18, the competition encourages participants to explore creative entrepreneurship and develop world-changing concepts. The program is managed by the Lassonde Entrepreneur Institute and includes a rigorous selection process involving online judging and public voting for the top finalists. Participants compete for a total of $30,000 in prizes, provided by sponsors including venture capitalist Tim Draper and the Gregg Rosann Social Impact Grant.

results.name: Shadow Program
results.title: IFSS Program (for High School students)
results.subtitle: Stanford University
results.description: The Inspiring Future Scientists through Shadowing (IFSS) program provides local rising high school juniors and seniors with a unique opportunity to learn about cutting-edge chemical research through direct observation. Participants spend two weeks shadowing and conversing with various graduate students within the Department of Chemistry to gain broad exposure to diverse scientific topics and techniques. To be eligible, students must be at least 16 years old by the program's start and reside and attend school within Alameda, Santa Clara, San Francisco, or San Mateo counties.
