results.subtitle: American Academy of Neurology
results.description: The Neuroscience Research Prize is an award designed for high school students in grades 9 through 12 who conduct original research on the brain and nervous system. Applicants must submit a completed application form, a 300-word abstract, a formal research report, and a bibliography to be considered for the competition. While teachers are encouraged to provide guidance, each entry must represent the work of an individual student rather than a group project. Winners receive a $1,000 honorarium and a certificate of recognition, along with the opportunity to present their findings at a scientific poster session during professional annual meetings. The prize package also includes covered travel expenses such as airfare, lodging, and a daily per diem for both the winning student and a parent or mentor.

results.name: Machine Learning Program
results.title: Machine Learning
results.subtitle: NYU
results.description: NYU Tandon's Summer Program for Machine Learning introduces high school students in grades 9, 10, or 11 to the computer science, data analyses, and mathematical techniques that drive artificial intelligence. Participants explore fundamental logic behind daily technologies like autonomous vehicles and medical diagnostics while learning core principles such as neural networks and model development through cross-validation. This non-credit program requires applicants to have a minimum 3.0 GPA, successful completion of Algebra 2, and previous experience with at least one programming language. Students engage in daily assignments and weekly projects overseen by faculty and student mentors, choosing between living on-campus in residence halls or commuting to classes. The curriculum emphasizes engineering problem-solving techniques to tackle societal challenges and provides exposure to higher levels of data science and electrical engineering.

results.name: Center for Neurotechnology
results.title: Young Scholars Program-Reach
results.subtitle: Center for Neurotechnology
results.description: The Young Scholars Program-Reach (YSP-REACH) provides high school students and graduating seniors with a comprehensive introduction to neuroscience, neural engineering, and neuroethics. Participants explore the latest developments in brain-computer interfaces and engage in scientific communication training throughout the program. Students attend required lectures, seminars, focus groups, and workshops while also touring partner labs in departments such as Computer Science and Electrical Engineering. This educational initiative aims to prepare students for college-level STEM studies and future careers by offering significant exposure to the field of neural engineering. Applicants must commit to full participation in all program activities, which are designed to provide basic preparation for future professional paths.

results.name: Sci-High Program
results.title: SciHigh Program
results.subtitle: Northwestern University Feinberg School of Medicine
results.description: The SciHigh Summer Program, organized by the Northwestern University George O'Brien Kidney Research Core Center, is an immersive enrichment experience designed for rising high school seniors with a strong interest in STEM. Scholars participate in a paid research internship where they contribute to active projects under the guidance of experienced scientists, physicians, and medical trainees. Each student is matched with a faculty mentor to develop and execute a specific research project aligned with their unique skills and aspirations. In addition to hands-on lab work, interns attend weekly workshops focused on research development, evaluation, and communication led by experts across various scientific fields. The program concludes with students presenting their findings, helping them build the confidence and practical skills necessary for future careers in science and research.

results.name: Physics Program
results.title: Physics Summer Program
results.subtitle: Institute for STEM Education (I-STEM)
results.description: The Physics Summer Program is a one-week, hands-on experience designed for high school students entering 10th, 11th, or 12th grade who have not yet taken a formal physics course. Participants explore fascinating physical phenomena through topics such as Newtonian Mechanics, Light, Electricity, and Quantum Mechanics while engaging in projects they design, build, and test. Throughout the week, students take measurements, analyze results, and attend guided tours of cutting-edge research labs and university facilities. Interested applicants must demonstrate a strong interest in math and science and provide recommendations from both a math and science teacher for the application process. This $650 program concludes with a Family Showcase where students present their final projects and discoveries, though housing is not provided for participants.

results.name: Pre-College
results.title: Brown Pre-College Programs
results.subtitle: Brown University
results.description: Brown Pre-College Programs offer high school students the opportunity to explore college-level academics through a wide range of rigorous courses without the pressure of formal grades. Students can choose from over 300 course offerings in fields such as medicine, law, visual arts, and leadership, with durations ranging from one to six weeks. The curriculum includes diverse options such as the Leadership Institute, environmental labs, and course-based research experiences designed to challenge independent thinkers. Participants engage in a balance of academic study and enriching social activities while interacting with a global cohort of motivated and curious peers from around the world.

results.name: Summer College Opportunity Program
results.title: Summer College Opportunity Program in Education
results.subtitle: Penn State College of Education
results.description: The Summer College Opportunity Program in Education (S.C.O.P.E) provides current tenth-grade high school students from diverse backgrounds an intensive academic experience to explore college life and professional paths in the education field. Participants engage in various college preparatory courses and a specialized research and writing course, for which they receive one college credit upon successful completion. The program specifically targets students from backgrounds traditionally underrepresented in education, with priority given to first-generation college-bound learners from lower socioeconomic families. Eligible candidates must be U.S. citizens or permanent residents enrolled in a college-prep curriculum with a cumulative grade-point average of 3.00 or higher. Prospective students must be nominated by a school or organization official and complete a comprehensive application process to be considered for participation. All program expenses are covered by the Office of Education and Social Equity with support from donors, ensuring that the opportunity is accessible to all qualifying students.

results.name: Summer Strings

program_dates.label: D&D: Adventures on the Astral sea (Grades 9-12)
Teen Med Camp 2: Beyond the Basics (Grades 9-12) Session 1
Teen Med Camp 2: Beyond the Basics (Grades 9-12) Session 2
D&D: Escapades in the city of Waterdeep (Grades 9-12)

results.title: Summer Camps: High School
results.subtitle: The University of Texas at Arlington
results.description: The University of Texas at Arlington offers a variety of summer camp programs specifically designed for high school students in grades 9 through 12. Participants can explore diverse interests ranging from Analogue Photography and book publishing to specialized technical courses like 3D Printing 101 and Principles of Engineering. Future healthcare professionals have multiple opportunities to engage with the medical field through several sessions of Teen Med Camp, including an advanced "Beyond the Basics" option. These camps provide hands-on learning experiences, such as creative storytelling in Dungeons & Dragons sessions or mastering technical skills in the university's Fab Lab. All sessions are structured to provide academic enrichment and practical skill-building in a university environment.

results.name: Study How the U.S. Political System Works
results.title: U.S. Politics and Government: To Form a More Perfect Union
results.subtitle: Georgetown University
results.description: This course offers students ages 13 and up an in-depth examination of the American political system, exploring how laws, government regulations, and political actors shape the nation's future. Participants study the U.S. Constitution, political institutions such as the presidency and judiciary, and the inner workings of political parties and election campaigns. Students learn to identify media misinformation, understand public opinion divisions, and receive mentorship from Georgetown University faculty and student experts. The 100% online program requires 20 to 30 hours of total instruction and culminates in a final capstone project where students deliver a presidential campaign nomination speech to earn a Certificate of Completion.

results.name: Math Contest
results.title: Caribou Contests
results.subtitle: Caribou Contests
results.description: Caribou Contests is an online learning platform and mathematics competition designed to make math fun, accessible, and enriching for students. The program has supported over 50,000 participants through a variety of interactive challenges and educational materials across a global community. Although the organization has transitioned away from running formal contests, it continues to provide its extensive library of math games and resources to all students and site visitors free of charge. This online collection includes interactive puzzles such as Sudoku, Magic Squares, and various logic-based activities intended to foster a love for mathematics.

results.name: DaVinci Summer Camp
results.title: Summer Institute
results.subtitle: DaVinci Camp
results.description: The Summer Institute is a non-residential program designed for talented and highly motivated middle school and high school students in rising 6th through 12th grades. This comprehensive program seamlessly integrates academic and social components from the arts and applied sciences in the spirit of a Renaissance scholar. Participants engage in a fast-paced environment that blends mathematics, engineering, science, and art instruction with hands-on workshops to develop critical thinking and collaborative skills. Led by alumni from Berkeley, Stanford, MIT, and Caltech, the curriculum exposes students to various fields through university lab tours, visits to national research centers like NASA, and professional performing arts attendance. The institute emphasizes the ability to solve complex mathematical expressions and encourages students to discover their diverse talents through both analytical and creative challenges.

results.name: OSU
results.title: AWS Foundation & Mₐ²JIC High School Internship Program
results.subtitle: Manufacturing & Materials Joining Innovation Center (Mₐ²JIC)
results.description: The AWS Foundation & Mₐ²JIC High School Internship Program is an immersive, paid research opportunity for high school students with a strong interest in Welding Engineering, materials science, and manufacturing processes. Participants collaborate on industry-funded research projects alongside university faculty and graduate researchers, gaining hands-on experience in engineering laboratories. Throughout the program, interns engage in activities such as testing welding materials, data analysis, coding, and modeling. To conclude their experience, students develop a capstone research poster and presentation, which may be submitted to national competitions. Applicants must be rising juniors or seniors who are U.S. citizens or permanent residents with a background in STEM coursework or extracurriculars.

results.name: Summer Immersion Program
results.title: Girls Who Code
results.subtitle: Girls Who Code
results.description: Girls Who Code is an initiative that invites both students and adults to join a growing community of over 670,000 individuals. The program facilitates engagement through a sign-up process that requires participants to be at least thirteen years old. Users can access various resources including a frequently asked questions section and a dedicated news portal to stay informed. Additionally, the organization provides a member headquarters for signing in and managing personal accounts to track progress within the network.

results.name: PRIMES
results.title: MIT PRIMES
results.subtitle: Massachusetts Institute of Technology
results.description: MIT PRIMES is a free year-long after-school program designed for high school juniors and sophomores who demonstrate extraordinary mathematical ability and self-motivation. Participants work on exciting unsolved problems in mathematics, theoretical computer science, and computational biology under the guidance of academic mentors such as graduate students and postdoctoral scholars. The program structure consists of four distinct phases including an advanced reading period, an active research period, independent study, and a final write-up period. Throughout the program, students complete milestones such as interim reports and conference presentations, eventually producing a final research paper suitable for publication or national science competitions. Admission is highly competitive, as a very advanced background is expected from candidates seeking to conduct original research.

results.name: Summer Camp LBL
results.title: SAGE Summer Camp
results.subtitle: A-LIFT: Pre-College Programs
results.description: SAGE (Science Accelerating Growth and Engagement) Summer Camp is a program designed for high school students aged 14 to 17 who are curious and passionate about exploring STEM fields. Hosted by National Laboratory scientists and engineers, the program offers participants a firsthand look into professional life through job shadowing, hands-on projects, and professional development opportunities. The curriculum is structured to demonstrate the interdisciplinary nature of STEM, showing how logical thinking and computational ability can be integrated with interests in artistic expression, historical research, and creative writing. Students will connect with STEM professionals at various career stages and join a community of peers dedicated to discovery and innovation. The camp aims to foster a diverse and inclusive environment where all eligible students are encouraged to apply and explore potential career paths in science and technology.

results.name: TAMU
results.title: Youth Adventure Program
results.subtitle: Texas A&M
results.description: The Youth Adventure Program (YAP) is a residential camp for gifted and talented students in grades 7-12 designed to encourage career exploration across diverse fields. Courses are taught by university faculty and industry professionals through a combination of traditional lectures, group discussions, and interactive hands-on learning experiences. Participants can choose from various one-week sessions covering subjects such as engineering design, veterinary medicine, law, biotechnology, and performing arts. Beyond academic instruction, the daily schedule includes recreational activities like swimming at the rec center, scavenger hunts, and team competitions to foster peer engagement. Tuition includes housing in suite-style dormitories, meals, and all instructional materials, with need-based scholarships available for eligible families.

results.name: Vision for High School Students
results.title: Vision for High School Students
results.subtitle: University of Notre Dame
results.description: This immersive conference is open to high school students ranging from entering freshmen to newly-graduated seniors who are looking to deepen their faith and explore theological concepts. Participants engage in a program that features nationally-known keynote speakers and small-group sessions led by undergraduate mentors who provide pastoral guidance and accompaniment. The experience incorporates communal dining and residential living in campus dormitories, fostering an environment of trust for exploring deeper questions of faith and vocational calling. Beyond the standard conference, a joint program called Saints and Scholars is available for those seeking an additional week of formation focused on applying theology to specific academic disciplines. Financial aid is accessible through a scholarship application process, and registration options are available for both individuals and school or church groups.

results.name: Medical Student Research Internship Program
results.title: Student Research Internship
results.subtitle: Scripps Research
results.description: The Scripps Research Translational Institute offers the Student Research Internship Program and the Medical Student Research Internship Program to advance personalized health care through cutting-edge translational research. These programs are designed for high school, undergraduate, graduate, and professional students, as well as medical students seeking immersive research experience. Participants engage in designing and conducting unique research projects focused on genomic, proteomic, and metabolomic correlates of health and disease. Students also participate in translational science seminars, intern journal clubs, and faculty round table discussions while receiving mentorship from physician-scientists. The internship aims to equip future leaders in health sciences, statistics, and computational science with the skills necessary for careers in the realm of translational medical research.

results.name: Swarthmore College
results.title: Summer Scholars Program
results.subtitle: Swarthmore College
results.description: The Swarthmore Summer Scholars Program (S3P) is a competitive-entry, invitation-only initiative designed for incoming students who have a self-described interest in STEM fields. Targeted specifically toward individuals who are first-generation to college, come from low-income backgrounds, or have faced significant educational barriers, the program provides a full academic immersion experience to prepare participants for the rigors of higher education. Sixteen selected scholars receive complete financial support, covering all program costs including books and necessary learning materials. Throughout the experience, students acclimate to college life, develop familiarity with challenging coursework, and form a supportive cohort of peers and professors. Beyond the initial sessions, participants are matched with faculty mentors who provide guidance on individual academic goals and future plans for the duration of their four-year college career.

results.name: Summer at Tisch

deadlines.label: Summer Session I Domestic Student Application Deadline
Summer Session II Domestic Student Application Deadline

results.title: Summer at Tisch
results.subtitle: Tisch School of the Arts
results.description: Participants in this program pursue academic studies of the arts or professional-conservatory training with a faculty comprised of artists and scholars. The courses are open to a wide range of individuals, including NYU and visiting undergraduate and graduate students, high school students, working professionals, and adult learners. Students can choose to take classes for credit, enroll in credit-bearing intensives, or earn non-credit professional certificates. This educational experience allows attendees to create and collaborate with peers from around the world, fostering significant networking opportunities. Participants engage in various artistic disciplines such as film, television, dance, drama, and emerging media through both in-person and online formats.

results.name: STEM Academy
results.title: Sustainable Futures Academy
results.subtitle: Rice University
results.description: The Sustainable Futures Academy is a one-week, free enrichment program designed to introduce high school students to scientific principles and engineering challenges focused on sustainability. Participants explore complex scientific concepts and their real-world impact through hands-on activities such as building landing capsules, designing roller coasters, and learning about circuits using Microbits. The curriculum further includes exploring motion concepts with TI Nspire Rovers and engaging in deep-dive discussions with university faculty and graduate students regarding physics and green design. This competitive program is primarily open to high school girls entering the 10th or 11th grade, though students of all genders in those grade levels are encouraged to apply for the limited available spaces.

results.name: Speech & Debate Camp

program_dates.label: D&D: Adventures on the Astral sea (Grades 9-12)
Teen Med Camp 2: Beyond the Basics (Grades 9-12) Session 1
Teen Med Camp 2: Beyond the Basics (Grades 9-12) Session 2
D&D: Escapades in the city of Waterdeep (Grades 9-12)

results.title: Summer Camps: High School
results.subtitle: The University of Texas at Arlington
results.description: The University of Texas at Arlington offers a diverse range of summer camps specifically designed for high school students in grades 9 through 12. Students can explore creative interests through courses such as Analogue Photography and instructional sessions on how to publish a book. For those interested in STEM and health sciences, the university provides immersive experiences like Teen Med Camp and Principles of Engineering. Technical skills are further developed in the Fab Lab with 3D Printing 101, while thematic programs like D&D: Adventures on the Astral Sea offer unique social and narrative engagement. Each session is structured to provide hands-on learning within various academic disciplines to encourage exploration and skill-building.

results.name: Biotechnology for Science & Health Academy
results.title: Biotechnology for Science & Health Academy
results.subtitle: Georgetown University School of Continuing Studies
results.description: The Biotechnology for Science & Health Academy offers high school students aged 15 and older a deep dive into the role of biotechnology within the medical and scientific fields. Participants engage in a rigorous curriculum that combines classroom lectures with hands-on laboratory exercises, covering advanced topics such as gene cloning, DNA ligation, and protein purification. Beyond laboratory work, the program includes guest speaker sessions with industry experts and off-site visits to research facilities to explore career paths in forensics, agriculture, and food science. Students develop practical skills in using biotechnological tools and bioinformatics while learning to present complex scientific concepts effectively. Upon successful completion of the two-week program, which is available in both residential and commuter formats, participants receive a Certificate of Participation.

results.name: Michigan State University
results.title: OsteoCHAMPS
results.subtitle: Michigan State University
results.description: The OsteoCHAMPS program is an intensive eight-day residential experience designed to foster interest in health care careers among Michigan high school sophomores and juniors. Participants engage in a rigorous academic curriculum featuring courses in anatomy and biochemistry alongside a dedicated medical research project and writing sessions. Beyond the classroom, students gain experiential learning through clinical skills development, osteopathic manipulative medicine, and various athletic activities such as ice skating. Applicants must maintain a minimum 3.0 GPA and demonstrate a strong interest in medical fields through application essays and letters of recommendation to be considered for admission. The program also provides access to university admissions offices and valuable mentorship from both undergraduate and medical students to support long-term academic success.

results.name: Art Camp: Methods of Making
results.title: Children's and Family Programs
results.subtitle: Michael C. Carlos Museum
results.description: Children's and Family Programs at the Michael C. Carlos Museum provide families with interactive ways to explore a wide range of art and historical collections. These educational offerings include guided tours and special activities designed to engage visitors of all ages with the museum's permanent and rotating exhibitions. Beyond physical visits, the museum offers digital programs and recordings through platforms like Carlos from Home to support learning from any location. Participants can also benefit from teacher resources and specialized materials that help connect museum content with broader educational goals while exploring topics like art conservation and provenance research.

results.name: Summer Session
results.title: Summer Session
results.subtitle: Cornell University
results.description: Cornell University Summer Session provides the opportunity to choose from more than 250 regular university classes taught by distinguished instructors and experts. Students can earn official credits to fulfill requirements, lighten their course loads, or potentially accelerate their degree progress. Enrollment is open to a diverse group of learners including undergraduates, professionals, alumni, and high school students interested in precollege studies. The program offers a range of learning formats such as in-person instruction, online classes, and international study abroad opportunities. Participants benefit from small class sizes that encourage close interaction with faculty and a global community of peers.

results.name: Summer Science Research Program
results.title: Summer Science Research Program
results.subtitle: The Rockefeller University
results.description: The Summer Science Research Program (SSRP) is a team-based mentored research initiative designed for high school juniors and seniors who are at least 16 years old. Participants are organized into four research teams where they conduct hands-on laboratory research under the guidance of scientific trainees from the Tri-Institutions. In addition to intensive lab work, students participate in elective courses, guest lectures, and networking opportunities to broaden their scientific perspective. Throughout the seven-week experience, scholars progress from learning research techniques to analyzing data and designing posters for a final program symposium. This full-time commitment requires approximately 35 hours per week as students work collaboratively to explore original scientific questions.

results.name: Washington University in St. Louis
results.title: 2026 High School Summer Scholars Program Courses
results.subtitle: Washington University in St. Louis
results.description: The High School Summer Scholars Program offers pre-college students the opportunity to enroll in credit-bearing undergraduate courses taught by faculty and researchers from various campus disciplines. Participants can choose from a wide array of subjects including American politics, biology, microeconomics, and mathematics, with both in-person and online asynchronous formats available. These accelerated courses include lectures, group work, and assignments, requiring students to dedicate at least two hours of independent study for every hour spent in class. In addition to academic coursework, the program features noncredit Exploration Courses and community events designed to help students reflect and socialize with their peers. Admission to the program allows for registration on a first-come, first-served basis, ensuring students can build a strong foundation for their future undergraduate studies.

results.name: Summer College
results.title: Summer College
results.subtitle: Georgetown University School of Continuing Studies
results.description: Summer College provides high school students the opportunity to earn college credit by taking classes alongside current undergraduate students. Participants learn from prestigious faculty through a combination of lectures, class discussions, and featured guest speakers in either on-campus or online formats. Students can choose to enroll in up to two courses per session and will receive an official university transcript upon completion of their studies. In addition to core coursework, the program offers optional academic and test prep seminars focusing on areas like algebra, analytical reading, and SAT/ACT strategies. Those seeking a more intensive experience can earn up to 12 total credits to receive a special honors certificate.

results.name: Reischhauer Program
results.title: Stanford Pre-Collegiate Global Learning
results.subtitle: Stanford University
results.description: The Stanford Program on International and Cross-Cultural Education (SPICE) offers specialized distance-learning courses designed for high school students. These academic offerings focus on international and cross-cultural education, providing students with unique opportunities to engage with global perspectives. Since 2003, the program has served high school students in the United States, Japan, and China, inviting all eligible applicants to choose the course that best fits their academic interests. Prospective participants are encouraged to thoroughly review specific course descriptions and eligibility requirements before starting the online application process. The program utilizes a registration portal for students to sign up and manage their applications efficiently.

results.name: Junior Science & Humanities Competition
results.title: Junior Science and Humanities Symposium
results.subtitle: Junior Science and Humanities Symposium
results.description: The Junior Science and Humanities Symposium (JSHS) is an educational program that focuses on engaging students in science and humanities through research and organized symposia. Sponsored by the Junior Science and Humanities Symposium, the initiative provides various program benefits for participants looking to advance their academic skills. While the program's official website is currently suspended until further notice, updates are regularly posted across their social media channels including Facebook, Twitter, and LinkedIn. Prospective students and educators are encouraged to reach out via the provided email address to obtain current information regarding participation and program updates.

results.name: Summer Preview Program
results.title: Pre-College And Youth Summer Programs
results.subtitle: Boston University
results.description: Boston University offers a wide variety of pre-college and youth summer programs designed for middle and high school students to explore academic interests and gain valuable academic experience. These offerings cover a broad spectrum of disciplines, including biotechnology, mathematics, engineering, and the visual and performing arts. Students may participate in specialized tracks such as academic immersion, research internships, and creative institutes to enhance their existing skill sets. Additionally, the university provides recreational camps for elementary and middle school students to engage in physical activities and sports through FitRec. These programs serve as a unique opportunity for young learners to discover their passions while experiencing a challenging and exciting environment.

results.name: Program in Music Technology
results.title: Music Technology Pre-College Courses
results.subtitle: NYU Steinhardt
results.description: The Music Technology Pre-College Courses at NYU Steinhardt provide high school and undergraduate students with a solid foundation in the science and art of creating music through technology. Participants can enroll in Fundamentals of Music Technology, which explores room acoustics, analog audio systems, and studio recording techniques. Another option, Computer Music Synthesis, introduces students to digital audio workstations and the Reaktor visual programming language for sound synthesis and arrangement. Students earn university-level credits that can be applied toward the Bachelor of Music degree program for those who continue their studies in this field. These six-week sessions feature small class sizes with a combined enrollment cap of fifteen students per course to ensure an intensive learning environment.

results.name: ASPIRE
results.title: ASPIRE
results.subtitle: Johns Hopkins University Applied Physics Laboratory
results.description: The ASPIRE program at the Johns Hopkins University Applied Physics Laboratory is an intensive internship designed for high school juniors and seniors to explore professional career paths. Participants are paired with staff mentors to engage in hands-on projects, solve complex technical problems, and develop essential interpersonal skills within a professional environment. This unpaid experience requires students to work independently and persist through challenges while committing to thirty to forty hours of engagement per week during the summer. Selection for this highly competitive program is based on a student’s potential for innovation and creative thinking rather than focusing solely on grade point averages or previous experience. Ultimately, the initiative provides a dynamic educational setting where scholars can cultivate technical expertise and gain insight into diverse fields before choosing a college major.

results.name: High School Competitions
results.title: COMPETITIONS
results.subtitle: Technology Student Association
results.description: TSA competitions provide an opportunity for middle and high school students to explore various career interests through more than 75 competitive events that can be integrated into a STEM curriculum. Participants engage in a wide range of activities including creating animatronic devices, developing architectural plans, and producing original audio podcasts based on annual themes. The competition structure often requires students to submit documented research, construct physical or computer-generated models, and deliver multimedia presentations to a panel of judges. Semifinalists may also participate in interviews, mock job applications, or parliamentary procedure demonstrations to showcase their comprehensive understanding of technology and leadership topics. These events are designed to take learning beyond the classroom while fostering skills in areas such as biotechnology, computer science, and manufacturing technology.

results.name: SMU
results.title: Engineering Summer Camps
results.subtitle: Lyle School of Engineering
results.description: The Engineering Summer Camps offer programs tailored for students in 6th through 12th grades to explore various aspects of technical disciplines. These camps utilize unique facilities, staff, and curriculum from the institution to provide a creative environment for learning the fundamentals of engineering and STEM. Participants engage in hands-on, interactive team projects, with specific sessions like Introduction to Engineering for middle schoolers and Advanced Engineering for early high schoolers. The Engineering Design Experience is a residential camp for rising juniors and seniors that allows for deeper exploration into the five main disciplines of engineering.

results.name: Academy for Youth Success
results.title: Pomona College Academy for Youth Success
results.subtitle: Pomona College
results.description: The Pomona College Academy for Youth Success (PAYS) is a selective academic program that admits 30 participants annually based on demonstrated academic potential. To be eligible, applicants must be current 9th-grade students who reside in Los Angeles, Orange, Riverside, San Bernardino, or Ventura counties. The program is specifically designed to support first-generation college-bound and low-income students, covering all costs including housing, food, activities, and transportation for field trips. Interested students must submit an application featuring multiple essays, academic transcripts, and recommendation forms from core subject teachers or community leaders. Additionally, all admitted scholars are required to show proof of COVID-19 vaccination and boosters for participation in the residential experience.

results.name: Research Experience for High School Students
results.title: Research Experience for High School Students
results.subtitle: Vanderbilt University
results.description: The Research Experience for High School Students (REHSS) is an intensive internship program designed for current Interdisciplinary Science and Research students. Participants complete a six-week scientific research experience that involves full immersion into a laboratory at Vanderbilt University or the Vanderbilt University Medical Center. During the program, rising seniors engage in an independent research project under the direct mentorship of a Vanderbilt research faculty member. This initiative aims to support students who demonstrate a strong interest in pursuing future careers within the fields of science, technology, engineering, or mathematics.

results.name: ACE
results.title: Accelerated College Education (ACE)
results.subtitle: Stony Brook University
results.description: Stony Brook's Accelerated College Education (ACE) program enables high school students to earn college credit for courses they are already taking within their own high schools. To be eligible for enrollment, students must attend a participating partner school and be registered in an approved course taught by authorized teachers. Instead of relying on a single high-stakes standardized exam, the program awards credit based on the overall grade earned through regular assignments and exams. Successful participants receive an official Stony Brook University transcript, making the credits transferable to many other institutions and providing a head start on a university degree. Enrollment is finalized by submitting an online registration form and paying a non-refundable program fee.

results.name: Summer Science Internship
results.title: 2024 Summer Science Internship
results.subtitle: Arthritis Foundation
results.description: The Summer Science Internship program, sponsored by the Arthritis Foundation, provides high school juniors, seniors, and college undergraduates with the opportunity to gain hands-on experience in rheumatology and immunology research. Participants engage in basic laboratory research, clinical translational studies, or bioinformatics projects focused on arthritis and autoimmune diseases within leading clinical laboratories. Eligible applicants must be U.S. citizens or permanent residents, at least 17 years of age, and willing to commit to a forty-hour work week for the duration of the eight-week program. Interns receive a total stipend of $2,500 and are required to present their work at a poster session and submit a final two-page summary paper. The application process involves submitting an online form, two letters of reference on official letterhead, and unofficial academic transcripts for review by a committee of medical professionals.

results.name: Fellowship Program
results.title: Fellowship
results.subtitle: YouthBridge-NY
results.description: The YouthBridge-NY Fellowship is a two-year program designed for high school sophomores to participate throughout their junior and senior years. Participants engage in intensive training focused on leadership and diversity, starting with an orientation retreat that features team-building activities and workshops on social justice. During the first year, Fellows attend interactive skill-building workshops and join social action teams dedicated to exploring issues such as healthcare disparities, criminal justice reform, or food justice. In the second year, participants transition to the Bridger phase, where they receive professional mentoring, build partnerships with organizations, and identify leadership opportunities for college. The application process includes a written form, a recommendation letter from an adult reference, and a group interview to evaluate candidates for the cohort.

results.name: Early College Credit Program

deadlines.label: ECCP Agreement Form Submission to High School Counselor - Summer
ECCP Agreement Form Submission to High School Counselor - Fall
ECCP Agreement Form Submission to High School Counselor - Spring
University Special Student Application - Fall Term
University Special Student Application - Spring Term
University Special Student Application - Summer Term
Submit ECCP Agreement Form and Transcript - Summer/Fall Term
Submit ECCP Agreement Form and Transcript - Spring Term

results.title: Early College Credit Program (ECCP)
results.subtitle: University of Wisconsin–Madison
results.description: Wisconsin public and private high school juniors and seniors with a minimum cumulative 3.0 GPA can apply to earn college credit through this state-funded initiative. Admitted participants are recognized as University Special students and may enroll in up to two courses per term, which can be delivered in online, blended, or in-person formats. Under this program, tuition costs are typically shared between the school district, the state, and the student, while all completed coursework establishes a permanent university transcript and grade point average. Prospective students should note that enrollment is not guaranteed and occurs after degree-seeking students have registered, requiring high levels of individual responsibility and the completion of a mandatory orientation.

results.name: VCU
results.title: Dental Careers Exploration
results.subtitle: VCU School of Dentistry
results.description: Dental Careers Exploration is a five-day summer program designed for high school students who are interested in pursuing a career in dentistry through hands-on learning. Participants engage in interactive workshops and laboratory activities such as tooth carving, dental impressions, suturing, and digital dentistry. The program is open to rising 10th graders through graduating seniors who maintain a minimum GPA of 3.0 and hold U.S. citizenship or permanent residency. While the program is free and provides lunch and all necessary materials, students must commit to full attendance for all sessions including an orientation and closing event. Interested applicants must submit an online application along with a personal statement, a letter of reference, and an unofficial transcript.

results.name: Summer Scholars Program
results.title: Pre-College Summer Scholars Program
results.subtitle: Rutgers, The State University of New Jersey
results.description: The Rutgers Summer Scholars Program provides high school students aged 16 and older the opportunity to engage in rigorous, college-level academics at a top research university. Participants can select from over 60 courses across various subjects and earn official college credit upon completion. Students experience a genuine collegiate environment by sharing classrooms with undergraduate students and learning from university faculty and doctoral students. Enrolled individuals are permitted to take up to two program-approved courses, which are offered in online, hybrid, and in-person formats depending on availability. This program is specifically designed for students to explore potential majors and academic interests before they graduate from high school.

results.name: Life Sciences Research
results.title: Life Sciences
results.subtitle: UC San Diego
results.description: In collaboration with the Boz Institute, this program offers a distinctive research-based learning experience focusing on molecular biology and fieldwork. Participants engage in core scientific topics while receiving training in modern laboratory techniques, bioinformatics, and statistical analysis. The curriculum integrates foundational knowledge with critical research skills, including hypothesis development, experimental design, sample processing, and data analysis. Students culminate their experience with a formal poster presentation to showcase their discoveries to scientists and industry professionals. These pre-college courses are non-credit-bearing and utilize a rolling admission process where students are accepted until enrollment capacity is met.

results.name: Writing & Culture
results.title: Writing & Culture
results.subtitle: Carnegie Mellon University
results.description: Writing & Culture is an intensive pre-college program designed for high school sophomores and juniors to develop their skills as reflective storytellers through various mediums. Guided by faculty from the Department of English, students explore the intersection of writing, film, and culture by producing work in digital poetics, short-form writing, and film production. The curriculum emphasizes critical thinking and effective communication, moving participants through a series of written and visual formats that culminate in the creation of a short film. Beyond classroom instruction, students engage in professional development, mentorship, and cultural enrichment activities like touring museum collections and attending local readings. Prospective students must meet specific GPA requirements and submit a portfolio of creative work to be considered for admission.

results.name: Online Summer
results.title: Online Summer
results.subtitle: Columbia University
results.description: Columbia University’s Online Summer program offers high school students a rigorous academic experience through virtual classrooms featuring debates, simulations, and collaborative projects. Students may select from over 40 diverse courses taught by world-class instructors who are experts in their respective fields. The curriculum includes specialized opportunities like the Columbia Writers Academy, which focuses on helping participants craft powerful college application essays. Beyond academics, the program provides comprehensive college preparation through seminars, workshops, and student life activities designed to foster university-level success. Successful participants earn a Columbia University Certification of Participation and a formal evaluation letter to enhance their college application portfolios.

results.name: Coding and Robotics Intern
results.title: --- MAIN PAGE ---

It appears to be a placeholder or a loading screen indicating that the content has not yet been rendered or retrieved. Consequently, details about the host institution, program objectives, and participant requirements are currently unavailable in the raw input. Please provide the actual program content to allow for a comprehensive summary and extraction of relevant data.

results.name: Badger Precollege
results.title: Badger Precollege
results.subtitle: UNIVERSITY of WISCONSIN-MADISON
results.description: Badger Precollege offers a wide range of academic programs designed for students between the ages of 9 and 18, spanning grades 4 through 12. These programs provide learners the opportunity to explore advanced academic subjects, STEM fields, and music clinics while utilizing the university's professional facilities and resources. Participants can engage in immersive college-prep experiences, social impact leadership training, or specialized arts and music sessions to hone their specific talents. Financial assistance is available for most programs to ensure accessibility for a diverse range of students, including international applicants. The offerings are categorized into junior and senior levels to provide age-appropriate challenges and foster community among peers.

results.name: College Bridge
results.title: College Bridge Program
results.subtitle: Northwestern University
results.description: The College Bridge Program is a partnership between Chicago Public Schools and Northwestern University that admits 25 high school juniors to earn college credit through undergraduate summer courses. Eligible participants must be currently enrolled in Chicago Public Schools and maintain a minimum cumulative GPA of 3.5 on a 4.0 scale. Admitted students can enroll in one undergraduate course at the 100 or 200 level, choosing from a wide variety of subjects that include intensive science and general education classes. The program provides free tuition and textbooks, allowing students to experience academic and social life while gaining confidence for their future college careers. Application materials include a personal statement, a list of extracurricular activities, and official high school transcripts which must be submitted for consideration.

results.name: National Mock Trial Championship

program_dates.label: 2026 National High School Mock Trial Championship
2027 National High School Mock Trial Championship
2028 National High School Mock Trial Championship

results.title: National High School Mock Trial Championship
results.subtitle: National High School Mock Trial Championship, Inc.
results.description: The National High School Mock Trial Championship is an academic program designed to promote an understanding and appreciation of the American judicial system among high school students. The organization facilitates intensive competitions that include a primary mock trial event as well as specialized contests for courtroom artists and courtroom journalists. Participants engage with complex legal procedures governed by specific rules of evidence and competition standards to ensure a professional and educational experience. In addition to the competitive rounds, the program honors excellence through various awards, such as the Justice Franchini Golden Gavel and the Larry Bakko Professionalism and Civility Award. Managed by a dedicated board and state coordinators, the initiative also offers grants and resources to further its educational mission across the country.

results.name: Leadership Scholars
results.title: LEADERSHIP SCHOLARS
results.subtitle: Sadie Nash Leadership Project
results.description: Leadership Scholars is a year-long program designed for young women and gender-expansive youth in the 10th and 11th grades to develop core skills for post-secondary success. Participants explore various leadership styles, build personal confidence, and improve creative problem-solving through public speaking and facilitation exercises. The curriculum focuses on exploring different educational and career pathways while analyzing the challenges marginalized groups face in higher education. Students network with professionals in their fields of interest and create actionable plans to achieve their long-term professional goals. This program emphasizes a network of care and mutual support, and participants are eligible to receive a stipend for their involvement. There are no academic or skill-based criteria for admission into this inclusive learning community.

results.name: Summer Session
results.title: Summer Session
results.subtitle: Binghamton University
results.description: Binghamton University offers a Summer Session that allows students to take courses online or on-campus to get ahead in their studies or satisfy General Education requirements. The program is open to a diverse range of participants, including current Binghamton University students, visiting college students from other institutions, and high school students looking for advanced coursework. Participants can choose from an extensive variety of subjects spanning fields such as engineering, business, visual arts, health sciences, and computer science. These sessions often feature smaller class sizes and offer unique courses not typically available during the fall or spring semesters, providing opportunities for students to improve their GPA or graduate early.

results.name: Research & Stats Camp
results.title: Research & Statistics Camp
results.subtitle: UTeach Outreach
results.description: The Research & Statistics Camp is a five-week program designed for students who have graduated from 8th or 9th grade and are interested in university-level research experiences. Participants work on independent inquiry projects while taking courses in Research & Inquiry, Statistics, and Technical Writing to supplement their academic work. The curriculum is enhanced with lab tours, career speakers, and various college and career exploration opportunities to provide a comprehensive look at the field. To apply, students must provide a completed application, a UT EID, a student survey, and a grade report demonstrating a minimum grade of 85 in core subjects like Math, Science, and English. The registration fee covers all necessary materials, lunch, snacks, and a t-shirt, though participants should note the program is not for high school credit.

results.name: UCIGATI
results.title: BEAM Virtual
results.subtitle: UCI x GATI
results.description: BEAM Virtual is an immersive online research and innovation program designed for high school students interested in the interdisciplinary fields of science, technology, engineering, and medicine. Participants engage in college-level research by joining faculty-led teams from UC Irvine, exploring topics such as biomedical engineering, neurology, and micro manufacturing. Beyond scientific research, the curriculum emphasizes holistic skill development through collaborative multidisciplinary projects, effective communication training, and a focus on entrepreneurship and innovation. Fellows have the opportunity to earn transferable college credits through the UCI Division of Continuing Education while receiving high-touch mentorship from research and innovation professionals. The program also includes specialized laboratory safety certifications and, for those in the comprehensive session, dedicated publication coaching to assist with written drafts and future academic success.

results.name: Gear Up
results.title: GEAR UP
results.subtitle: University of Nevada, Las Vegas
results.description: GEAR UP is a comprehensive initiative designed to significantly increase the number of low-income students who are prepared to enter and succeed in postsecondary education. Serving students in grades 6-12 at targeted middle and high schools, the program offers a wide range of services including academic counseling, tutoring, and preparation for college-entrance exams. Participants gain valuable experience through mentoring programs, career exploration, and leadership development activities while receiving assistance with college admission and financial aid applications. Furthermore, the program fosters family involvement by providing parents with workshops on scholarship opportunities and resources to support their child's transition to higher education.

results.name: Business Academy
results.title: Global Business Academy
results.subtitle: Georgetown University School of Continuing Studies
results.description: The Global Business Academy is a program designed for high school students to provide a comprehensive and up-to-date overview of international business principles and challenges. Participants explore current drivers of global business, including market globalization and the emergence of national economies, while examining the roles of institutions like the World Bank and the World Trade Organization. Students engage in a hands-on business simulation to run a startup and participate in investment challenges, group presentations, and dynamic faculty lectures. Throughout the program, attendees study with professors from the McDonough School of Business to gain practical skills in identifying international market opportunities and developing marketing strategies. The curriculum features residential and commuter options and awards a Certificate of Participation upon successful completion.

results.name: Swarthmore College
results.title: Discover Swarthmore Fly-In Program
results.subtitle: Swarthmore College
results.description: Discover Swarthmore is an all-expenses-paid overnight fly-in program designed for high-achieving high school seniors to experience the college environment firsthand. Selected participants receive full funding for transportation, meals, and on-campus housing while they attend classes and stay in residence halls with current students. The program features a series of panel discussions and informal conversations with faculty, staff, alumni, and students to provide insight into the campus community. All applicants receive a $60 application fee waiver and the opportunity to use their program essay in their formal application for admission. While the program is open to all seniors attending school in the United States, preference is given to first-generation students and those from low-income backgrounds.

results.name: Miami SAO
results.title: High School Volunteer Internship Program
results.subtitle: Office of Miami-Dade State Attorney Katherine Fernandez Rundle
results.description: The High School Volunteer Internship Program provides students with an immersive look into the operations of one of the nation’s largest prosecutorial offices. Interns gain hands-on experience by assisting the public with legal inquiries, researching case law, and evaluating evidence for prosecution. The program includes structured training on professional ethics, court procedures, and trial practice across various divisions like the Domestic Violence and Victim/Witness units. To qualify, applicants must pass a criminal background check and commit to a minimum of 16 to 20 hours per week for at least three months. This opportunity is particularly beneficial for those interested in careers as attorneys or social workers and may offer school credit for participation.

results.name: Summer Internship Program
results.title: High School Summer Internship Program
results.subtitle: Magee-Womens Research Institute & Foundation
results.description: The High School Summer Internship Program is designed for high school sophomores and juniors interested in exploring careers in biomedical research through hands-on experience in reproductive biology, women’s health, and infant health. Participants engage in a 6-week, 240-hour internship where they conduct their own research projects under the direct guidance of investigators and staff from the University of Pittsburgh and the Swanson School of Engineering. Beyond laboratory work, students attend Lunch & Learn sessions to hear personal perspectives from established investigators and ultimately present their findings via a PowerPoint presentation on a formal presentation day. Applicants must be residents of the local southwest Pennsylvania region and over 16 years of age, with eligible students qualifying for an $1,800 stipend based on household income guidelines. To apply, candidates must submit a comprehensive application packet including a demographic form, transcript, personal statement, and two letters of recommendation from teachers or counselors.

results.name: Engineering Summer Academy
results.title: Engineering Summer Academy
results.subtitle: Rutgers, The State University of New Jersey
results.description: The Engineering Summer Academy is an immersive residential program designed for high school students who have completed their sophomore or junior years and are between the ages of 16 and 18. Participants explore a wide range of engineering disciplines, including aerospace, biomedical, civil, and mechanical engineering, through hands-on collaborative projects and real-world problem-solving activities. The curriculum includes lab experiments, technology demonstrations in cutting-edge facilities, and direct interaction with expert faculty, researchers, and student mentors. In addition to attending academic workshops and alumni talks, students engage in unique challenges like designing cardboard canoes and touring facilities such as a Makerspace. Upon successful completion of the program, participants earn a Rutgers Pre-College Digital Badge credential to recognize their achievement.

results.name: Scholastic Press Association

program_dates.label: CSPA 2026 Crown Awards: Announcement of Finalists

results.title: Columbia Scholastic Press Association
results.subtitle: Columbia University Pre-College Programs
results.description: The Columbia Scholastic Press Association provides a national gathering and comprehensive training programs for student editors and faculty advisers representing newspapers, websites, yearbooks, magazines, and broadcast media. This organization offers expert-level instruction through events such as the Spring Convention, Fall Conference, and a Summer Journalism Workshop where students can develop their talent and polish their storytelling skills alongside their peers. Participants have access to various resources including quick courses in a video series format that covers content planning, recruiting, and advising for both new and established publications. Excellence in the field is recognized through prestigious awards programs like the Crown Awards and Gold Circle Awards, which honor superior work by individual student journalists and entire publication staffs. The association also supports leadership development through specialized scholarship opportunities for student journalists looking to further hone their craft.

results.name: Civic Engagement Leadership Academy
results.title: Early Outreach
results.subtitle: University of Nevada, Las Vegas
results.description: UNLV Early Outreach provides comprehensive college and career readiness programming specifically designed for K–10 students and their families. The program facilitates various engagement opportunities including school visits for career days and college fairs, as well as year-round events that help students build curiosity about their future paths. Participants can take part in the Young Rebels initiative, which offers unique academic and social enrichment to support early college access and readiness. Through these activities, students engage in critical thinking, build academically minded friendships, and interact with university faculty to better envision themselves in a higher education setting.

results.name: Experience in Research
results.title: Experiences in Research
results.subtitle: Berkeley Lab
results.description: Experiences in Research is a paid internship program designed for current 10th, 11th, and 12th-grade high school students who have demonstrated experience in independent work. Participants work directly on cutting-edge projects alongside experts in STEM and STEM-adjacent careers to gain hands-on professional experience. Projects focus on various aspects of STEM professions, including administration, science communication, data science, and experimental research. Applicants are encouraged to express their interests and project preferences during the submission process to develop skills in their preferred fields. Interns can expect to form connections with mentors, build professional skills for higher education, and gain experience in collaboration.

results.name: UAB
results.title: Pre-College Research Internship for Scholarship and Mentoring (PRISM)
results.subtitle: UAB Department of Surgery
results.description: The Pre-College Research Internship for Scholarship and Mentoring (PRISM) provides promising high school juniors with hands-on research experiences under the mentorship of surgeons and faculty. This eight-week full-time commitment involves completing a mentored research project in a team-based environment alongside undergraduate and medical students. Participants engage in supplemental activities such as seminars, workshops, and clinical shadowing to gain exposure to clinical practice and surgical careers. Five students are selected annually to receive a $1,000 stipend for successful completion, though they must manage their own meals and transportation. To be eligible, applicants must be U.S. citizens or permanent residents from disadvantaged backgrounds or be the first in their family to pursue college.

results.name: UNR
results.title: Community of Bilingual English-Spanish Speakers (CBESS)
results.subtitle: University of Nevada, Reno
results.description: The Community of Bilingual English-Spanish Speakers (CBESS) provides a unique pipeline program for bilingual high school juniors interested in pursuing careers in healthcare and STEM fields. Selected participants engage in career exploration events where they interact with healthcare professionals and take part in a multi-week summer research program involving both on-campus and virtual components. During this experience, students conduct student-led research projects on community health issues while receiving instruction in hypothesis-driven research, STEM content, and communication skills in both English and Spanish. Additionally, students are paired with undergraduate mentors for monthly guidance during their senior year and participate in an outreach internship to implement initiatives based on their summer research. A secondary group of students may also participate by completing questionnaires to receive a certificate of completion and access to career exploration resources.

results.name: Leadership Institute
results.title: Leadership Institute
results.subtitle: Brown University
results.description: The Leadership Institute is designed for students completing grades 9 to 12 who are passionate about social justice and advocating for change. Participants can choose between a two-week on-campus residential experience or a four-week online program that includes both asynchronous and synchronous components. Throughout the program, students engage in courses focused on complex social issues, honing skills in active listening, public speaking, and collaborative problem-solving while working toward the development of a personal Action Plan. This academic experience allows learners to explore topics like social entrepreneurship, law, and intercultural communication in a non-graded environment alongside a global community of peers. Successful completion of the program results in a Digital Certificate of Completion and a Course Performance Report for those in sessions two weeks or longer.

results.name: Summer Research Program (SRP)

deadlines.label: CRISP, EPCR, JSU, and SPARC Application Deadline

program_dates.label: CRISP, EPCR, JSU, and SPARC Program Sessions

results.title: Summer Programs
results.subtitle: Indiana University Melvin and Bren Simon Comprehensive Cancer Center
results.description: The Indiana University Melvin and Bren Simon Comprehensive Cancer Center offers several summer programs that allow students to work directly with mentor physicians or researchers on progressive oncology studies. Participants gain hands-on exposure to basic science, translational, and clinical research activities while developing professional skills and references. The offerings include specialized tracks such as the Cancer Research Internship Summer Program (CRISP) for undergraduates and the Future Scientist Program for high school juniors. These full-time paid internships involve designing experiments, attending regular seminars, and conducting supervised laboratory work under the guidance of principal investigators. Applicants must submit an online application with a letter of recommendation and may be selected for Zoom interviews during the holistic evaluation process. By the conclusion of the program, every intern is expected to create and present a scientific poster detailing their research findings at a dedicated summer session.

results.name: Summer Healthcare Experience
results.title: Summer Healthcare Experience
results.subtitle: UC Irvine School of Medicine
results.description: The Summer Healthcare Experience is a career exploration and empowerment program specifically designed for rising high school juniors and seniors between the ages of 16 and 18. Participants explore careers in women's health and healthcare leadership while gaining hands-on experience through surgery simulation labs, suturing techniques, and Basic Life Support certification. Throughout the program, students engage with a diverse range of professionals including physicians, nurses, and research scientists to learn about various roles in the industry. Beyond clinical skills, the curriculum provides practical tools for future success such as interview coaching, essay preparation, and mentorship opportunities. Students also collaborate on a health awareness project and graduate with a certificate of completion and a letter of reference.

results.name: Biotech Academy
results.title: Rice Bio Academies
results.subtitle: Rice University
results.description: The Rice Bio Academies is an immersive summer enrichment program designed for high school students in grades 9 through 11 who have completed or are currently enrolled in biology. Participants choose between two specialized tracks, Biotech or Biomed, where they explore genetics and the intersection of medicine and technology through hands-on experiments and project-based design challenges. Students engage in advanced lab activities such as DNA extraction, bacterial transformation, and PTC gene testing while receiving mentorship from university faculty and graduate students. The curriculum includes guest speakers and field experiences to medical facilities to help participants develop critical thinking skills and build confidence in their scientific knowledge. Registration includes daily lunch for all participants, and a limited number of scholarships are available for those who apply by the designated deadline.

results.name: Oakland University
results.title: Experience OU
results.subtitle: Oakland University
results.description: The Experience OU College Day program is a partnership with the WDA-KCP Initiative designed as an introduction to higher education for pre-college students. Students spend a day visiting the university to meet faculty, staff, and students while learning about the feasibility of higher education. The program includes academic and career exploration presentations provided by various professional schools and academic departments. Students also attend informational sessions regarding critical areas such as admissions and financial aid to better understand the college enrollment process. Additionally, the visit features campus tours led by program mentors, lunch at the Vandenberg Dining Center, and access to recreational amenities like the gymnasium and 50-meter pool.

results.name: Advanced Science Ambassador Program
results.title: Regional Ambassadors
results.subtitle: Advanced Science Exploratory Program
results.description: The Regional Ambassadors program is designed for exceptional high school students in grades 9 through 12 who want to bridge the gap between their schools and scientific resources. Participants work to partner high schools in their geographic region with the Advanced Science Exploratory Program to ensure more students can access educational seminars and mentorship opportunities. By serving as ambassadors, students help maximize the reach of scientific content and serve as a direct link for their peers to discover program-specific tools. Those selected for this role may receive various benefits, including free registration for select seminars, 1:1 mentorship sessions with professional scientists, and a signed Certificate of Excellence. Additionally, ambassadors have the chance to be featured on the program website and may publish an article review in the ASciencePro online journal, C&C Editorials.

results.name: Summer Research Internship
results.title: SHTEM: Summer Internships for High Schoolers
results.subtitle: Stanford Compression Forum
results.description: The SHTEM: Summer Internships for High Schoolers program provides high school juniors and seniors with early exposure to multifaceted research projects that bridge the gap between technical and humanistic disciplines. Participants are grouped into projects mentored by program faculty, staff, and student researchers to explore diverse themes such as information science, engineering, the arts, and psychology. Applicants must be US Citizens or Permanent Residents who are at least 14 years old and entering their junior or senior year of high school. This eight-week internship requires a commitment of 20 to 30 hours per week and focuses on research that integrates the human element into STEM fields. Although the program is unpaid, financial aid is available to cover application fees and support commuting costs for eligible participants.

results.name: Sounds of New York City
results.title: Sounds of New York City (SONYC)
results.subtitle: NYU
results.description: Sounds of New York City (SONYC) is an immersion into the study of noise pollution designed for students aged 12 to 14 with a strong interest in science. Participants explore how sounds travel and amplify in urban settings by sampling sound waves, building monitoring devices, and evaluating the impact of noise on human well-being. The curriculum emphasizes STEM skills such as coding, circuitry, and the use of microcontrollers and sensors to solve real-world challenges. In addition to technical training, students engage in mandatory improv-based communication workshops to enhance their public speaking abilities. The experience culminates in a final expo where students showcase original smart city technologies and research projects developed in a materials-rich environment. This non-credit program is offered as a full scholarship through a research collaboration with the National Science Foundation and specialized university laboratories.

results.name: VSGC

deadlines.label: High School STEM Teacher Application Deadline

results.title: Virginia Aerospace Science and Technology Scholars (VASTS)
results.subtitle: Virginia Space Grant Consortium
results.description: The Virginia Aerospace Science and Technology Scholars (VASTS) program is a free, interactive online STEM learning experience designed for high school juniors and seniors who are Virginia residents and U.S. citizens or permanent residents. During the school year, participating scholars complete seven web-based modules involving real-world questions, technical writing, and the design of upgrades for the International Space Station. Students who perform well in the online course may be selected to attend a week-long residential summer academy where they work in teams to design a human mission to Mars. Participants engage in aerospace workshops, coding simulations, and hands-on scientific activities while receiving mentorship from engineers, scientists, and technologists. Applicants must have a minimum GPA of 2.7 and a demonstrated interest or aptitude in math, science, engineering, or technology to qualify for this competitive program.

results.name: Math Minutes Video Contest

deadlines.label: Entry form emailed to primary sponsors

results.title: Mathematical Minutes Video Contest
results.subtitle: Mu Alpha Theta
results.description: The Mathematical Minutes Video Contest invites chapter members to produce original, educational, and entertaining videos focused on a specific mathematics topic. Participating teams must create a two- to five-minute video that is closed captioned and contains only G-rated material suitable for a broad audience. Entries are categorized into three levels based on mathematical content: Theta for algebra or geometry, Alpha for precalculus, and Mu for calculus. Each school may submit a maximum of three entries, which must be approved and signed off by a chapter sponsor to ensure content quality and appropriateness. Eight finalist videos are selected for a final round of judging where chapters vote to determine the ranking and distribution of prize money among the winners.

results.name: Aspirnaut Summer Research
results.title: Aspirnaut Summer Research Internship
results.subtitle: The Regents of the University of Michigan
results.description: The Aspirnaut Summer Research Internship offers high school juniors the opportunity to engage in a professional research environment. Applicants are evaluated based on their academic records and participation in a variety of extracurricular activities. The submission process requires a completed application form, official high school transcripts, and two letters of recommendation. Candidates must be rising seniors with proper employment authorization or citizenship who are available for a residential program. All participants under the age of eighteen must obtain consent from a parent or legal guardian to participate in the cohort.

results.name: Ignite Your Passion for International Law
results.title: International Law: Protecting the World's Interests
results.subtitle: Georgetown University
results.description: International Law: Protecting the World's Interests is a flexible online program designed for students ages 13 and up to explore the complexities of global legal systems. Participants study how international treaties are negotiated, the nature of state jurisdiction across land, sea, and air, and the relationship between military force and the U.N. Charter. The curriculum includes 20 to 30 hours of total instruction through video lessons and case studies covering historical conflicts and emerging issues like cyberattacks and climate change. Students receive personalized guidance from mentors while completing a final capstone project where they take on the role of advisor in a simulated international conflict. Upon finishing the course, participants earn a Certificate of Completion from the university to demonstrate their foundational knowledge in legal and governmental affairs.

results.name: MITE Summer Camp
results.title: My Introduction to Engineering (MITE)
results.subtitle: Cockrell School of Engineering - University of Texas at Austin
results.description: My Introduction to Engineering (MITE) is a five-day summer camp designed for current high school juniors to explore the world of engineering through an immersive and engaging experience. Student participants stay in campus residence halls and work collaboratively on team projects, participate in hands-on activities, and connect with faculty, staff, and alumni. The curriculum provides an authentic look into the reality of pursuing an engineering education and career, supplemented by access to Role Model Monday webinars featuring STEM professionals. Applications are open to students residing in the United States who demonstrate a strong interest in science, mathematics, or engineering and are selected through a holistic review process.

results.name: IFAL
results.title: Institute for Future Agricultural Leaders (IFAL)
results.subtitle: North Carolina Farm Bureau
results.description: The Institute for Future Agricultural Leaders (IFAL) is a week-long leadership development program tailored for rising high school seniors with an interest in agricultural careers. During the program, students focus on leadership development, citizenship, and the exploration of emerging technologies within the industry. Participants engage in diverse activities such as visiting university laboratories, touring research farms, and meeting with representatives at the General Assembly and various agribusinesses. To provide a true collegiate experience, students reside in campus dormitories and utilize dining halls while receiving supervision from university faculty, conference counselors, and organization staff.

results.name: CMIMC Math Competition
results.title: Carnegie Mellon Informatics and Mathematics Competition
results.subtitle: Carnegie Mellon University
