results.description: The Carnegie Mellon Informatics and Mathematics Competition (CMIMC) is an entirely student-run organization that provides academic challenges for high school students from around the world. This organization hosts both math and computer science competitions designed to test participants' skills through rigorous problem sets. The competition structure includes various formats and scoring methods, as well as unique mini-events for those involved. Students can explore a wide range of past problems and programming resources provided by the organizers to support their preparation.

results.name: Neuroscience Immersion
results.title: Clinical Neuroscience Immersion Experience (CNI-X)
results.subtitle: Stanford University
results.description: The Clinical Neuroscience Immersion Experience (CNI-X) at Stanford University is an intensive summer program designed for high school students who have completed their sophomore, junior, or senior year. Participants engage in interactive seminars led by expert faculty and researchers to explore diverse topics such as clinical neuropsychiatry, psychiatric epidemiology, and behavioral sciences. Throughout the ten-day session, students collaborate in small teams to develop innovative solutions for social issues related to mental health and neuroscience as part of a final capstone project. The curriculum also addresses professional career opportunities in medicine and science while providing essential self-care strategies for the transition into adulthood. Financial assistance is available through scholarships for qualified applicants who demonstrate need during the application process.

results.name: Tufts University

program_dates.label: Principles of Economics with Environmental Applications - A

results.title: Business Programs for High School Students
results.subtitle: Tufts University College
results.description: Tufts University College offers a variety of business-oriented educational tracks for high school students, including summer intensives, workshops, and traditional college courses. Students may explore specialized topics such as finance essentials, marketing, entrepreneurship, and innovation through hands-on bootcamps and seminars. Beyond core business subjects, the curriculum includes principles of economics and college preparatory workshops designed to help students master college essay writing and navigate the admissions process. Available in residential, commuter, and online formats, these programs are led by experienced faculty from the School of Engineering and the School of Arts and Sciences to provide a comprehensive preview of the college experience.

results.name: Citizens Thinkers Writers
results.title: Citizens Thinkers Writers
results.subtitle: Yale Center for Civic Thought
results.description: Citizens Thinkers Writers is a tuition-free two-week summer residential program and year-long fellowship for public high school sophomores and juniors interested in exploring fundamental human questions in a college setting. Participants engage in small discussion seminars led by professors to examine transformative texts from the history of political thought and link these readings to contemporary civic challenges and local government. The program emphasizes the development of essential citizenship skills through writing workshops, public speaking exercises, and the close reading of diverse genres including philosophy, poetry, and social theory. Students receive ongoing mentorship from faculty and university students, participate in field trips with city leaders, and benefit from dedicated support during the college application process. Eligible participants are provided with a $500 stipend and join an intellectually ambitious fellowship community that continues to meet regularly throughout the following academic year.

results.name: RPI
results.title: Polymer Chemistry Research Experience
results.subtitle: Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute
results.description: The Polymer Chemistry Research Experience is a virtual program designed for high school students who have completed a prerequisite chemistry course. Participants engage in hands-on virtual research, including making samples through 3D printing and laser cutting, as well as characterizing plastic materials using FTIR spectroscopy and thermal analysis. The curriculum covers fundamental polymer chemistry concepts, molecule drawing, and the analysis of raw data from tensile mechanical tests and gel permeation chromatography. Throughout the program, students process material information, attend faculty-led lectures, and complete in-depth study assignments to be shared in a final 15-minute presentation. Necessary equipment for the program includes a laptop computer and access to WebEx, Microsoft Office, or Google Drive for completing assignments and research reports.

results.name: Summer Scholars Program
results.title: Dartmouth Precollege
results.subtitle: Dartmouth
results.description: Dartmouth Precollege provides high school students from around the world the opportunity to experience a challenging college environment through a variety of intensive academic programs. Participants can choose from on-campus courses in fields such as business, engineering, medicine, and the humanities, or opt for flexible online learning modules. These programs are taught primarily by expert faculty and staff, offering a deep dive into subjects without the pressure of grades or credits. The curriculum is designed to foster intellectual curiosity and personal growth by encouraging exploration into new areas of study. Additionally, the institution strives to reduce financial barriers by offering aid through the Dartmouth Precollege Summer Scholars Fund for qualified applicants.

results.name: Red Hat Shelton Challenge
results.title: Shelton Challenge
results.subtitle: Shelton Leadership Center
results.description: The Shelton Challenge is a leadership development program designed for high school students to explore personal leadership styles guided by their core values. Participants engage in classroom lessons and hands-on activities, such as low ropes courses and group volunteer projects focused on social responsibility. The experience allows students to transition from first-year participants to Peer Leaders and Leadership Coaches, providing opportunities to guide new students through leadership development activities and provide peer support. Through these service-learning excursions and collaborative projects, students learn to leverage their unique perspectives and strengths to become more outspoken and innovative leaders within their own communities.

results.name: Research Intensive in Food Science.

program_dates.label: Food & Environmental Chemical Impact on Development of Obesity (Park Lab)

results.title: Food & Environmental Chemical Impact on Development of Obesity (Park Lab)
results.subtitle: UMass Amherst
results.description: This Research Intensive program invites high-achieving high school students, specifically rising juniors and seniors, to work alongside distinguished faculty and graduate students in a professional lab setting. Participants will explore the link between persistent organic pollutants and the development of obesity while searching for food bioactives that can assist in prevention. Research projects involve utilizing Caenorhabditis elegans as a eukaryotic multi-organ model to investigate biochemical mechanisms and altered lipid metabolism. Throughout the program, students gain hands-on experience with university-level research methodologies and contribute to ongoing studies. The experience concludes with a final session where each student creates and presents a research poster to faculty and peers.

results.name: Summer Journalism Workshop
results.title: CSPA Summer Journalism Workshop
results.subtitle: Columbia University
results.description: The CSPA Summer Journalism Workshop is designed for secondary school students from public, private, faith-based, and international schools following an American curriculum. Participants can choose between in-person residential, in-person commuter, or virtual tracks that cover specialized topics like reporting and writing, editorial leadership, digital media, broadcast journalism, and design. The program provides students with intensive training to polish their skills while connecting with like-minded peers through various academic and social channels. In addition to classroom instruction, residential and commuter students receive access to university gym facilities, co-curricular activities, media visits, and a Broadway show experience. Participation is restricted to senior high school students, as middle school and junior high students are not eligible for admission.

results.name: Neuroscience Journal Club
results.title: Stanford Neuroscience Journal Club
results.subtitle: Stanford Medicine
results.description: The Stanford Neuroscience Journal Club offers high school students a unique opportunity to engage in the critical analysis of scientific publications under the mentorship of expert Stanford scientists. Initiated by faculty members from the Departments of Neurosurgery and Neurology, the program aims to encourage participants to consider future careers in the neurosciences. During once-per-month meetings, students discuss scientific literature and significant developments in the field within a low-pressure environment. There are no specific coursework prerequisites for participation, making the program accessible to any high school student with a curiosity for science and a desire to learn. International students are also welcome to apply for the club during the annual application period.

results.name: International Biology Olympiad
results.title: International Biology Olympiad
results.subtitle: International Biology Olympiad
results.description: The International Biology Olympiad is a premier high school competition that brings together gifted biology talents from over 70 countries and regions annually. The program aims to identify, inspire, and empower the next generation of leaders in the life sciences while fostering a worldwide network of talented students. Participants are typically winners of their respective National Biology Olympiads and engage in assessments designed to set new educational standards. Beyond the competition, the organization offers an alumni network for former participants to stay connected and discover various research projects. The event also features an Educational Conference and promotes cross-cultural dialogue among young biologists from around the world.

results.name: Stem Academy
results.title: Appalachian STEM Academy at Oak Ridge
results.subtitle: ORAU
results.description: The Appalachian STEM Academy at Oak Ridge is an all-expenses-paid residential program that provides hands-on STEM learning experiences for students and teachers from the Appalachian region. Middle school participants in grades 6-8 work alongside master teachers to apply current STEM knowledge to real-world problems affecting their communities. High school students in grades 9-11 conduct intensive research projects mentored by professional scientists, while a specialized Bridge Program is available for younger high schoolers who have previously attended the academy. STEM teachers also have the opportunity to participate in professional development through collaborative research projects designed to enhance their classroom expertise. The program fosters a sense of teamwork and college readiness while promoting the cultural richness and historical importance of the region.

results.name: MSU
results.title: OsteoCHAMPS
results.subtitle: Michigan State University
results.description: The OsteoCHAMPS program is an eight-day residential experience designed for Michigan high school sophomores and juniors who maintain a minimum overall GPA of 3.0. Participating students engage in a rigorous academic curriculum that covers anatomy, biochemistry, writing, and a dedicated medical research project. In addition to classroom learning, the program provides experiential opportunities in clinical skills and Osteopathic Manipulative Medicine alongside extracurricular athletic activities like ice skating. Applicants must demonstrate a strong interest in the health care field through essays and provide a letter of recommendation to be considered for admission. The program costs $1,000 plus a small application fee, though full-tuition scholarships are available for candidates who complete a leadership essay.

results.name: Essentials of Leadership
results.title: Essentials of Leadership
results.subtitle: Wharton Global Youth Program
results.description: Essentials of Leadership is an intensive two-week online program designed for high school students in grades 9 through 12 who possess demonstrated leadership potential. Participants engage in a rigorous curriculum that includes live lectures from Wharton instructors, TA-led recitations, interactive business simulations, and a final industry leadership project. The course covers essential themes such as emotional intelligence, strategic planning, negotiation strategies, and crisis management through business simulations like OPEQ and Wildfire. Students must participate in daily group activities and collaborative sessions to develop interpersonal communication skills and effective teamwork habits. Upon successful completion of all program requirements, participants earn a Wharton Global Youth Certificate of Completion and gain access to the Wharton Youth Network.

results.name: Discover Architecture
results.title: Discover Architecture
results.subtitle: Oklahoma State University
results.description: Discover Architecture is a summer workshop held at the Oklahoma State University School of Architecture for high school students interested in exploring careers in architecture and architectural engineering. Participants engage in a series of hands-on design projects that provide firsthand experience with the architectural design process to help them determine if they want to pursue a degree in the field. This residential program includes meals and dormitory housing within the workshop fee, creating an immersive introduction to college-level studies. Students are required to bring a Windows 10 laptop meeting specific processor and memory requirements to participate effectively in the program's technical components. All other necessary project materials are provided to ensure students can focus on developing their skills and understanding of these professional disciplines.

results.name: UCSF
results.title: High School Intern Program
results.subtitle: University of California, San Francisco
results.description: The High School Intern Program provides rising seniors from San Francisco public and charter schools with the opportunity to conduct authentic biomedical research within professional laboratory settings. Participants spend thirty hours per week working directly with mentors to develop a unique research project, learn foundational science content, and master essential lab techniques. In addition to laboratory work, interns engage in five hours of weekly programming with staff to develop critical science communication skills, including abstract writing and public speaking. The experience culminates in a ten-minute oral presentation and a science poster session where students showcase their independent research findings. Selection is based on student interest and motivation assessed through essays and interviews rather than academic grades, and all participants receive a stipend for their involvement.

results.name: Trails AI
results.title: TRAILS AI Summer Academy
results.subtitle: Computing Catalyst at UMD
results.description: The TRAILS AI Summer Academy is a three-week, nonresidential program focused on computer programming and artificial intelligence for rising 10th and 11th grade students. Participants explore the field of AI through hands-on team projects, industry field trips, and informative presentations from guest speakers. The curriculum introduces students to how AI can be utilized to help people while providing insight into various career opportunities within the technology sector. While the first week of the program is conducted asynchronously through a learning management system, subsequent weeks involve intensive classroom instruction and collaborative lab sessions. A program fee covers all materials and activity costs, though need-based scholarships are available for those experiencing financial hardship.

results.name: CityLab Biotechnology SummerLab
results.title: Pre-College And Youth Summer Programs
results.subtitle: Boston University
results.description: Boston University offers a diverse range of pre-college and youth summer programs designed for middle and high school students to gain valuable academic experience and enhance their existing skill sets. These programs cover a wide array of interests including biotechnology, mathematics, engineering, and science research through specialized institutes. In addition to academic tracks, the university provides opportunities in arts and culture such as theatre and visual arts programs. Younger students can also participate in recreational sports camps through the FitRec department. The curriculum is built to challenge participants while allowing them to explore their specific interests in a collaborative and engaging environment.

results.name: Fashion Technology Summer Program
results.title: UT Summer Discovery Program
results.subtitle: The University of Texas at Austin
results.description: The UT Summer Discovery Program is a fully online three-week course designed for high school students between the ages of 14 and 18 who are interested in the intersection of fashion and technology. Participants develop introductory skills using Adobe Illustrator to create a variety of industry-standard materials, including coordinated fashion design presentations, flat sketches, and mood boards. The curriculum emphasizes digital line design development techniques and proficiency in creating fashion designs while also exploring fashion editorial trend boards and portfolio layout techniques. Assignments focus on establishing fundamental fashion design principles and marketing materials, providing students with a comprehensive introduction to professional industry techniques.

results.name: SPS High School Academy

program_dates.label: SPS High School Academy: Weekend Workshops

results.title: SPS High School Academy: Weekend Workshops
results.subtitle: NYU School of Professional Studies
results.description: The SPS High School Academy: Weekend Workshops are designed for high school students in grades 9 through 12 who are currently in good academic standing. Participants explore professional paths in diverse fields such as financial technology, architecture, fashion design, law, healthcare, and business development. The curriculum focuses on college and career readiness, allowing students to gain first-hand experience through interactive courses led by practicing experts and experienced executives. Applicants must submit an online application along with a high school transcript or report card to be considered for this selective, non-credit program. Upon successful completion, students receive an official NYU transcript featuring a letter grade to demonstrate their academic participation and achievement.

results.name: University of Maryland

deadlines.label: Pathway to the Profession Best Consideration Deadline

results.title: Ania Picard Pathways Program
results.subtitle: Maryland Robotics Center
results.description: The Ania Picard Pathways Program offers diverse initiatives designed to support graduate and undergraduate students pursuing various career paths within the robotics field. Participants can engage in specialized tracks including the Pathway to the PhD for research experience, the Pathway to the Profession for industry internships, and the Pathway to Entrepreneurship for those launching robotics startups. Depending on the specific track, students may receive benefits such as hourly compensation for research assistants, cost-of-living grants, or prototype development funds for commercialization. Applicants must generally maintain specific GPA standards and submit formal requirements like a letter of interest, faculty endorsement, and academic transcripts for consideration. The program aims to empower the next generation of robotics leaders through hands-on internships, professional mentoring, and community outreach.

results.name: USC
results.title: Young Researchers Program
results.subtitle: University of Southern California
results.description: The Young Researchers Program offers a six-week summer research experience for motivated rising high school seniors from underrepresented backgrounds and underresourced areas. Each participant is paired with a graduate student mentor to conduct a hands-on, university-level scientific project focused on the mentor's specific area of expertise. In addition to laboratory work, students participate in weekly seminars designed to provide fundamental knowledge about college applications, scholarship opportunities, and careers in STEM fields. The curriculum also features field trips to Catalina Island for environmental science studies and a tour of NASA’s Jet Propulsion Laboratory. To conclude the program, students showcase their findings by presenting a research poster at a public symposium for friends and family.

results.name: Summer Experience
results.title: Coriell Summer Experience for High School Students
results.subtitle: Coriell Institute for Medical Research
results.description: The Coriell Summer Experience for High School Students is a four-week unpaid program designed for individuals at least 17 years of age who have a strong interest in science and biotechnology. Participants work alongside professional scientists and technicians in production, stem cell, and molecular biology laboratories to gain hands-on experience with fundamental techniques like DNA extraction and cell freezing. The curriculum includes attending weekly scientific seminars hosted by research faculty and participating in small-group sessions focused on resume-building, interviewing, and career path exploration. At the conclusion of the experience, students receive training in public speaking and deliver a formal PowerPoint presentation to staff and peers summarizing their learned insights.

results.name: W. P. Carey School of Business

deadlines.label: Final deadline to apply to be considered

results.title: Fleischer Scholars Program
results.subtitle: W. P. Carey School of Business
results.description: The Fleischer Scholars Program at Arizona State University is a free, transformative pre-college initiative designed specifically for Arizona high school juniors seeking to enhance their strategic thinking and leadership capabilities. Admitted students participate in virtual programming with staff and mentor support, gaining early access to alumni connections and professional success keys while learning how to thrive in college and the business world. The application process requires students to provide academic information, involvement details in clubs or community service, and a short answer response regarding personal hardships or strategic thinking. Selection criteria prioritize students based on academic performance, financial need, involvement in community service, and status as the first in their family to pursue a college education. Participants also gain access to a new mobile application and resources for discovering scholarships, financial aid, and admission tools to support their transition to higher education.

results.name: Science Training Program

deadlines.label: Out of State/International High School Student Deadline

results.title: Student Science Training Program
results.subtitle: University of Florida
results.description: The Student Science Training Program is a seven-week residential research experience designed for academically talented students entering their senior year who are at least 16 years old. Participants engage in ongoing laboratory research with a faculty mentor for 30 hours each week, focusing on fields such as science, medicine, mathematics, computer science, or engineering. The academic curriculum includes a daily lecture series on current research topics and a UF honors seminar course where students develop technical writing and communication skills. Beyond laboratory work, participants are required to produce a scientific research paper, present a research poster, and deliver two oral presentations. The program also fosters personal growth through leadership workshops, social activities, and community service projects. Florida high school students may have the opportunity to earn dual enrollment credit for their participation.

results.name: Scholastic Art & Writing Awards
results.title: Scholastic Art & Writing Awards
results.subtitle: Alliance for Young Artists & Writers
results.description: The Scholastic Art & Writing Awards serves as the nation’s longest-running and most prestigious recognition program for creative teenagers. Students currently in grades 7–12 who are at least 13 years old can submit original work into 29 distinct categories of art and writing. All submissions undergo a rigorous judging process by luminaries within the visual and literary arts communities to ensure high-quality evaluation. Recognized students earn opportunities for exhibition and publication, while National Medalists can qualify for scholarships totaling up to $12,500.

results.name: Bentley University
results.title: Wall Street 101
results.subtitle: Bentley University
results.description: Wall Street 101 is a competitive experiential learning program designed for rising high school juniors and seniors with a strong interest in finance and macroeconomics. Participants engage in faculty-led courses covering diverse topics such as stock valuation, investment research, financial technology, and artificial intelligence. Students gain practical experience by working in small teams to prepare stock pitches, participate in macroeconomic simulations, and utilize industry-standard tools like Bloomberg and FactSet in a state-of-the-art trading room. This immersive environment allows attendees to explore various Wall Street careers while developing essential professional skills in leadership, presentation, and financial analysis.

results.name: UTSA
results.title: UT San Antonio Citymester Program
results.subtitle: UT San Antonio
results.description: The UT San Antonio Citymester Program is a student engagement initiative designed to educate future leaders through a combination of internships, service-learning projects, and networking opportunities. Open to undergraduate students from any academic major, the program consists of three distinct components known as City Skills, City Solutions, and City Sites. Participants engage in professional internships with local businesses and non-profits, work with civic partners to develop community improvements, and attend interdisciplinary seminars at various institutional landmarks. To be eligible, applicants must generally maintain a 3.25 GPA or higher and be enrolled at the university for the semester prior to the program's start. Although students do not need to be members of the Honors College to participate, the experience offers nine credit hours that focus on professional development and public service.

results.name: Machine Learning Program
results.title: High School Summer Program
results.subtitle: Sunrise Technology Inc.
results.description: This premium one-week program for students in grades 9 through 12 focuses on artificial intelligence and self-driving robotics through a combination of professor-led lectures and guided computer labs. Participants gain hands-on experience with a patent-pending RC car platform derived from a DOE SBIR-funded research project, learning to master machine learning and deep learning methodologies. With a maximum capacity of 24 seats per session, the curriculum ensures individual attention from university experts and teaching assistants as students build functional models for their college portfolios. Upon successful completion of the course, attendees are issued an official certificate co-signed by the university's Center of Excellence in Wireless and Information Technology.

results.name: Fordham University
results.title: STEP Summer Program
results.subtitle: Fordham University
results.description: The Fordham University Science and Technology Entry Program (STEP) Summer Program is an academic enrichment initiative designed for rising 8th through 12th grade students who are residents of New York State. Participants engage in morning math and science classes intended to prepare them for the upcoming school year, followed by afternoon elective courses and educational field trips. Beyond classroom instruction, scholars receive mentoring and tutoring from undergraduate students, along with advising focused on the academic and social rigors of high school and college life. The program provides exposure to STEM-related and health professions, and offers additional opportunities such as data science internships, research with university faculty, and community-based service learning initiatives. Applicants should maintain approximately an 85 average in math and science courses, and once accepted, students must adhere to a strict attendance policy requiring presence at all sessions. While there is no fee to apply, a registration fee is required for participation in the summer session.

results.name: University of Utah
results.title: STEP-UP Program
results.subtitle: University of Utah Health
results.description: The STEP-UP Program provides hands-on biomedical research opportunities for high school juniors and seniors from diverse backgrounds. Coordinated by the University of Utah's College of Health and funded by the NIDDK, the initiative consists of an eight-week intensive summer research experience followed by a nine-month mentorship phase. Participants are paired with experienced researchers to explore topics such as diabetes, endocrinology, nutrition, and renal health. Eligible students must be at least 16 years old, hold U.S. citizenship or legal residency, and be enrolled in high school during the application period. Selected participants receive stipends for their work and gain access to an expanded professional network that supports future career development in the health sciences.

results.name: Computer Engineering for Good
results.title: Computer Engineering for Good
results.subtitle: New York University
results.description: Computer Engineering for Good is a two-week intensive where high school students in grades 8 through 11 learn to design and build their own smart devices. Participants apply principles of computer and electrical engineering to create internet-connected applications addressing global challenges such as sustainability, climate change, and public health. The curriculum covers advanced fields including robotics, remote sensing, artificial intelligence, and cloud computing using platforms like Arduino and Raspberry Pi. Applicants are required to submit an online application featuring a high school transcript and four short essay responses. Students may elect to live in on-campus residence halls or commute while engaging in collaborative project work and organized extracurricular activities.

results.name: OSU

deadlines.label: Stamps Eminence Scholarship Program Early Action Deadline
Morrill Scholarship Program Early Action Deadline (Highly Recommended)
Ohio State Scholars Program Early Action Deadline

results.title: Scholars Programs
results.subtitle: Office of Undergraduate Education
results.description: The Scholars Programs provide a variety of community and engagement opportunities for students with specific interests, academic goals, or unique life experiences. Key offerings include the Young Scholars Program for first-generation middle-schoolers and the Stamps Eminence Scholarship Program, which focuses on research and service. The Morrill Scholarship Program highlights leadership and civic engagement, while the Ohio State Scholars Program offers sixteen themed living-learning communities that connect academics with outside experiences. Further support is provided through Kessler Scholars for first-generation college students and the RiSE Initiative for transfer students or those who have experience in foster care. Prospective students typically apply for these competitive opportunities during the university admission process or through specialized application cycles depending on the specific program requirements.

results.name: Summer Stem Academy
results.title: Duke Summer STEM Academy
results.subtitle: Duke
results.description: The Duke Summer STEM Academy is a summer intensive program designed specifically for high school students. This program provides an immersive educational experience focused on science, technology, engineering, and mathematics. Students engage in academic projects and document their progress through the development of comprehensive portfolios. Although the program is no longer being offered, its curriculum was associated with the Department of Mechanical Engineering and Materials Science to expose participants to high-level technical concepts.

results.name: Los Angeles Institute
results.title: LOS ANGELES INSTITUTE
results.subtitle: CHICANO LATINO YOUTH LEADERSHIP PROJECT
results.description: The Los Angeles Institute (LAI) is an intensive leadership development program open to 50 high school sophomores and juniors who reside in Los Angeles County. Participants engage in a comprehensive curriculum designed to increase their knowledge of the regional cultural and political landscape while connecting with education, business, and community leaders. The program features a Civic Day where students participate in mock hearings to learn about the legislative process and a College & Careers Day focused on financial aid and university requirements. All housing, meals, and program materials are provided at no cost to the participants or their families to ensure accessibility for all selected students. Additionally, the institute includes a specialized Parent Institute where families receive bilingual information on the college admissions process and advice on supporting first-generation college students.

results.name: SEES STEM Enhancement in Earth Sciences

deadlines.label: Earth and Space Science/Python Modules Due

program_dates.label: Earth and Space Distance Learning Module
On-site Projects for SEES Interns at UT

results.title: STEM Enhancement in Earth Science (SEES)
results.subtitle: University of Texas Center for Space Research
results.description: The STEM Enhancement in Earth Science (SEES) program is a nationally competitive summer internship for motivated high school students interested in pursuing careers in science, technology, engineering, or mathematics. Participants collaborate with NASA, academic, and industry experts to engage in authentic mission-based research using real data across disciplines such as aerospace, planetary science, and remote sensing. The program structure includes distance learning modules in Python and Earth science followed by remote work and an intensive research period where students build technical expertise in data analysis and engineering design. Interns are selected based on academic records, a written application with essays, an introduction video, and recommendation forms, with the experience culminating in a virtual science symposium. Housing, meals, and local transportation are provided for scholarship and fee-based participants, ensuring students can focus on developing critical professional skills like systems thinking and communication.

results.name: Imagine Cup
results.title: Imagine Cup
results.subtitle: Microsoft
results.description: The Imagine Cup is a global competition designed for the next generation of student startup founders to solve real-world problems through technology and innovation. Participants can choose between the Launch path for early-stage AI-powered solutions or the Scale path for student-led startups with existing traction and early capital. The competition focuses on diverse categories such as Cybersecurity, Education, Financial Services, Health and Life Sciences, and Retail. Eligible high-school and university students gain access to mentorship from industry leaders, free Azure credits, and enterprise-grade tools from partners like GitHub and Replit. Top winners receive significant financial prizes of up to $100,000 USD and the opportunity for a mentorship session with Microsoft Chairman and CEO Satya Nadella.

results.name: MEEP
results.title: MEEP Application
results.subtitle: AMNH
results.description: The MEEP Application represents the entry point for students interested in the Museum Education and Employment Program at AMNH. Participants in this program receive specialized training regarding the museum's artifacts and scientific research to prepare them for public-facing roles. Interns spend their time engaging with diverse audiences to explain complex natural history topics and exhibit themes. This experience is designed to build professional skills in education, communication, and leadership while providing a deeper look into museum operations.

results.name: HSHP
results.title: High School Honors Science, Math and Engineering Program
results.subtitle: Michigan State University
results.description: The Michigan State University High School Honors Science, Math and Engineering Program (HSHSP) is a seven-week intensive summer research program designed for motivated students from across the United States who are entering the 12th grade. Participants engage in hands-on research work and interact with a diverse group of peers who share a passion for science, engineering, and mathematics. As the oldest continuously running program of its kind in the U.S., it offers research apprenticeships across various STEM fields within a research-intensive university environment. The program focuses on enriching students' knowledge about intellectual work and fostering lasting friendships rather than solely producing award-winning projects. Alumni of this highly selective residential experience frequently continue their studies at prestigious institutions and go on to pursue careers in science-related fields.

results.name: NSTI Summer Camp
results.title: NSTI Summer Camp
results.subtitle: Oklahoma State University
results.description: The NSTI Summer Camp is an educational program offered through Oklahoma State University's College of Engineering, Architecture and Technology (CEAT) K-12 STEM initiative. Participants in this camp receive morning refreshments, lunch, a camp shirt, and all necessary STEM supplies required for the scheduled activities. Due to the program's popularity, a waitlist is maintained for interested students once the initial registration reaches capacity. To participate in the program, students must complete and submit several required documents, including forms for conduct, media release, medical information, and a minor waiver. The camp is managed by Dr. Jovette Dew and focuses on providing hands-on STEM experiences for students interested in technical fields.

results.name: Clinical Summer Internship
results.title: Clinical Summer Internship
results.subtitle: Stanford Medicine
results.description: The Clinical Summer Internship offers a transformative experience for rising high school juniors, seniors, and undergraduate pre-medical students interested in exploring the healthcare field. Participants engage in hands-on clinical training and interactive sessions designed to bring medical skills to life while working alongside dedicated medical students, residents, and faculty. The program features various learning formats, including an immersive full-day on-campus track, a live virtual learning option, and a ten-week fall intensive consisting of weekly interactive sessions. Through these active environments, curious learners can discover the art and science behind world-class medicine while making meaningful professional connections and friendships.

results.name: University of Denver
results.title: Access DU
results.subtitle: University of Denver
results.description: Access DU is a transformative summer program designed for high-achieving rising high school juniors and seniors, including U.S. citizens, permanent residents, and DACA recipients. Participants engage in three days of programming focused on cultural competency, leadership development, and college access with support from university faculty, staff, and current students. The curriculum provides insight into the college admission process through interactive case studies and guidance on writing effective college essays. While there is no cost to attend the program, students who complete it benefit from a waived university application fee and eligibility for renewable scholarships. Attendees will explore various leadership styles and gain a deeper understanding of intersectionality and social systems to empower them as leaders in their own communities.

results.name: UCLA Health
results.title: Summer High School Research Internship
results.subtitle: UCLA Health
results.description: The Summer High School Research Internship offers rising juniors the opportunity to work alongside a multidisciplinary team of research scientists, clinicians, and researchers within the UCLA Steve Tisch BrainSPORT Concussion Program. Interns work directly with study staff to recruit patients, enter research data, and conduct study protocols for comprehensive projects such as CARE4Kids, which investigates persistent post-concussion symptoms in adolescents through neuroimaging and cognitive assessments. Participants attend weekly Traumatic Brain Injury lab meetings with the BrainSPORT team to gain insight into the daily operations of clinical research while collaborating with medical students and other interns. The program culminates in a final project where students present on a research topic of interest based on their clinical experiences and data collection efforts. Applicants should be interested in clinical research and may have the opportunity to extend their involvement as a mentor or intern into the following academic year.

results.name: Business Competition
results.title: Competitive Events Program
results.subtitle: DECA Inc.
results.description: DECA’s industry-validated Competitive Events Program is designed for high school and college students to demonstrate their career knowledge in clusters such as marketing, finance, hospitality, and management. Participants engage in diverse competition formats, including role-plays, case studies, prepared written projects, and online business simulations. Students can compete individually or in teams across various categories like entrepreneurship, personal financial literacy, and project management to earn recognition like the DECA Glass. The curriculum-aligned events require students to apply core business concepts to real-world scenarios, ranging from managing investment portfolios in stock market games to developing integrated marketing campaigns.

results.name: Arizona State University
results.title: Barrett Summer Scholars
results.subtitle: College of Health Solutions
results.description: Barrett Summer Scholars is a program designed for academically talented and motivated high school students to help them prepare for future success at Arizona State University and Barrett, the Honors College. Participating students engage in rigorous college-level coursework while building a community with peers from across the state. For 10th grade students, the program offers an elective course titled Integrated Approaches to Health Care, which explores various health care disciplines and settings. This elective introduces both current and futuristic concepts of the health care system and provides exposure to multiple professional paths within the field. By the end of the curriculum, students gain a deeper appreciation for the diverse and evolving nature of health care professions.

results.name: Biotechnology Sequencing (BTS) Camp
results.title: 2026 BTS Camp
results.subtitle: miRcore
results.description: The 2026 BTS Camp is a computational biotechnology program designed for academically motivated high school students interested in the intersection of science and technology. Participants gain hands-on experience in Next Generation Sequencing data analysis by utilizing the Linux operating system and the University of Michigan’s high-performance computing cluster. Throughout the week, students work on a real-world research project identifying viral infections and variants from human data while learning about thermodynamics and nucleotide hybridization. The curriculum also includes career exploration in fields such as biomedicine, law, and industry, culminating in a group business pitch based on their research findings. Applicants must have completed a high school biology course, and while no prior programming experience is required, partial scholarships are available for students demonstrating financial need.

results.name: GEnYuS
results.title: SpHERES High School Research Program
results.subtitle: Carle Illinois College of Medicine
results.description: The SpHERES High School Research Program provides scholars with the opportunity to collaborate with research faculty and mentors on projects at the intersection of medicine, science, and engineering. Students participate in authentic research experiences and attend weekly seminars that cover topics such as college readiness, innovation, entrepreneurship, and clinical skills. Throughout the program, participants receive multi-layered mentorship from university staff, medical students, and practicing physicians to help prepare them for future healthcare careers. Beyond gainful professional development and resume-building opportunities, scholars are awarded a $2,400 stipend for their participation. This initiative aims to help students gain confidence in a university setting while exploring diverse research areas ranging from bioengineering to molecular physiology.

results.name: STEM Camp

deadlines.label: SAME STEM Camps Program 2026 Application Deadline

program_dates.label: SAME/U.S. Navy Camp - NAS Jacksonville, Fla.
SAME/U.S. Marine Corps Camp - Camp Lejeune, N.C.
SAME/U.S. Air Force Academy Camp - Colorado Springs, Colo.
SAME/U.S. Navy Camp - Port Hueneme, Calif.

results.title: STEM/Engineering & Construction Camps
results.subtitle: Society of American Military Engineers
results.description: The STEM/Engineering & Construction Camps provide high school students with an immersive week-long residential experience focused on hands-on project-based learning in engineering, construction, and design. Participants engage in real-world challenges such as building and testing concrete beams, using professional-grade survey equipment, and operating drones or robotics under the guidance of industry professionals and military volunteers. Eligible applicants must be at least 15 years old, maintain a recommended minimum GPA of 3.2, and demonstrate leadership characteristics through extracurricular involvement. Registration fees ranging from $100 to $800 include all lodging, meals, and instructional materials, with many participants receiving financial sponsorships from local organization chapters to offset costs. This program aims to develop technical skills and foster collaborative problem-solving for students pursuing future careers in architecture, engineering, and related STEM fields.

results.name: Global Youth Program
results.title: Global Engagement
results.subtitle: The Wharton School, The University of Pennsylvania
results.description: Wharton offers a comprehensive suite of global engagement programs designed to cultivate leaders who can navigate international economies and organizations. The initiative serves a diverse audience including high schoolers, university students, faculty, and executives through international courses, immersion ventures, and research collaborations. High school students and educators specifically benefit from resources focused on business, personal finance, and essential skills for the global marketplace. Participants are supported by a vast network that includes faculty-led seminars and a global community of alumni and professionals spanning 153 countries across all seven continents.

results.name: USAFA
results.title: Cadet Summer Research
results.subtitle: United States Air Force Academy
results.description: The Cadet Summer Research Program offers cadets dynamic opportunities to apply their academic research to real-world challenges through a robust network of national and international partnerships. Participants engage in hands-on problem-solving across diverse fields such as bionic limb control, satellite research, and economic system analysis while collaborating with prestigious institutions like NASA, Boeing, and the RAND Corporation. These projects allow students to utilize advanced facilities and mentorship to contribute to award-winning research, including the development of novel enzymes and LiDAR data processing. Beyond technical skill development, the program broadens global perspectives and prepares participants for military life by facilitating collaboration with various private sector and government organizations.

results.name: China Scholars Program
results.title: Pre-Collegiate Global Learning
results.subtitle: Stanford Program on International and Cross-Cultural Education (SPICE) at Stanford University
results.description: The Stanford Program on International and Cross-Cultural Education (SPICE) at Stanford University provides distance-learning courses for high school students seeking to engage with global topics. Since 2003, these courses have facilitated cross-cultural exchange and international learning for students in various regions, including the United States, Japan, and China. Interested high school applicants are invited to explore the diverse course offerings to find the program that best aligns with their eligibility and personal interests. Prior to beginning the application process, students are encouraged to thoroughly review all specific course requirements and descriptions to ensure a suitable fit.

results.name: NeuroScience Summer Program
results.title: Neuroscience Summer Student Program
results.subtitle: UW Department of Neurological Surgery
results.description: The Neuroscience Summer Student Program offers high school and college undergraduate students aged 18 and older an immersive "Bench to Bedside" exposure in the field of neurosciences. Participants engage in an eight-week laboratory placement where they complete a research project and gain hands-on experience under the mentorship of faculty. The curriculum includes clinical observations in neurological surgery clinics, opportunities to observe procedures in the operating room, and attendance at weekly Grand Rounds and faculty lecture series. In addition to these clinical and research experiences, students participate in resident education hour discussions and conclude the program by presenting their individual focus areas. This NIH-funded initiative provides a $3,200 stipend and offers limited program-sponsored housing for eligible out-of-town participants.

results.name: CED emBARC Academy

deadlines.label: Priority Application Deadline (Financial Aid and Housing)

results.title: embARC Summer Design Academy
results.subtitle: UC Berkeley
results.description: embARC Summer Design Academy is a four-week intensive course designed for high school rising seniors and exceptional rising juniors who are at least 16 years old. Participants explore the fields of architecture, urban design, and city planning through a multidisciplinary curriculum that includes studio instruction, materials exploration, and digital design workshops. Students engage in a hands-on community build project for a local nonprofit, fostering civic responsibility while developing technical skills and a design portfolio for future college applications. This rigorous program requires a minimum 3.0 GPA and awards participants official college credit on a transcript upon completion. The application process requires the submission of an essay, high school transcripts, and a letter of recommendation addressing academic achievements and work ethic. Daily activities involve architecture and urban design studios, guest lectures from professionals, and workshops covering sustainable planning and digital tools.

results.name: ESTEEM/SER-Quest Summer Program
results.title: ESTEEM/SER-Quest Summer Program
results.subtitle: A. James Clark School of Engineering, University of Maryland
results.description: The ESTEEM/SER-Quest Summer Program is an intensive four-week research-focused initiative designed for rising high school seniors with a strong interest in engineering. Participants engage in hands-on research projects where they develop proposals, conduct literature searches, and explore fundamental engineering concepts under the guidance of mentors. Beyond technical research, the program provides comprehensive support for the college application process, including sessions on financial aid, career readiness, and academic preparation. Selected students attend at no cost, though they must meet strict eligibility requirements such as a minimum 3.2 GPA and successful completion of advanced math and science coursework. This commuter-only program aims to prepare talented students to become competitive candidates for admission to the engineering school through departmental tours and interactions with current university students.

results.name: University of Delaware

deadlines.label: Domestic Enrollment Forms and Deposit Priority Deadline
International Enrollment Forms and Deposit Priority Deadline

results.title: Edge Summer College Program
results.subtitle: University of Delaware
results.description: The Edge Summer College Program is a competitive residential experience designed for motivated rising high school juniors and seniors looking to prepare for a successful transition to higher education. Participants live in residence halls and enroll in one to two college-level courses taught by faculty, earning up to six transferable credits in subjects ranging from engineering and art to hospitality and leadership. Beyond academic coursework, students attend a mandatory seminar focused on college readiness, admissions workshops, and skill-building activities such as creating competitive college essays. The program fee covers tuition, housing, and a daily meal plan, while also providing full access to campus facilities like libraries and recreational centers. To apply, prospective students must submit academic transcripts, a recommendation form, and a video essay to demonstrate their academic potential and maturity.

results.name: OU Health
results.title: High School & Undergraduate Programs
results.subtitle: Stephenson Cancer Center - OU Health
results.description: OU Health Stephenson Cancer Center offers a variety of educational opportunities for high school and undergraduate students interested in biomedical research and health professions. Programs like the Building Research and Investment in Developing the Next Generation (BRIDGE) and the Cancer Undergraduate Research Experience (CURE) provide participants with hands-on laboratory training, mentorship, and professional development. Participants engage in activities ranging from microscopy and tumor observation to nursing and biomedical engineering explorations, alongside networking opportunities with oncology experts. Many of these initiatives, such as the YES Oklahoma program for Native American youth, are specifically designed to support students from underserved populations or rural communities in pursuing careers as scientists and clinicians. Students across various levels of education can gain valuable experience through intensive summer internships that culminate in poster presentations and skill-building sessions.

results.name: FAA Summer Intensive

program_dates.label: Visual Arts (Comic Illustration, Fashion, Graphic Design, Painting & Drawing, Photography, Printmaking)
Performing Arts (Acting, Dance, Theatre Tech & Design)

results.title: FAA Summer Intensive
results.subtitle: College of Fine and Applied Arts
results.description: The FAA Summer Intensive is an immersive weeklong program designed for high school students who have completed their freshman, sophomore, or junior years. Participants select a specialized track from a wide range of disciplines, including acting, dance, theatre tech, fashion design, graphic design, and various studio arts. Instruction is provided by current faculty members and graduate students, offering a realistic preview of the collegiate experience in the arts. Beyond classroom training, the program includes evening social activities such as museum trips and scavenger hunts, alongside professional development opportunities like portfolio counseling and audition preparation. Students can choose between a residential experience in campus residence halls or a commuter option, both of which include a meal plan.

results.name: Summer Academy
results.title: High School Summer Academy in Architecture
results.subtitle: Roger Williams University
results.description: The High School Summer Academy in Architecture is an intensive residential program designed for rising high school juniors and seniors to explore architecture as a field of study and a potential career path. Participants have the opportunity to earn three college credits for the ARCH 100 course by engaging in a variety of design studios, seminars, and team challenges. Students learn to communicate and conceptualize design ideas through digital drawing, modeling techniques, and freehand perspective exercises. The curriculum includes mentoring from undergraduate and graduate teaching assistants, along with workshops focused on college admissions and the development of high-quality portfolio materials. In addition to individual assignments, participants collaborate on large-scale team design projects and attend keynote lectures to gain a broader perspective on contemporary architectural practice.

results.name: Discovery to Cure Program
results.title: Peter E. Schwartz Discovery to Cure Internship Program
results.subtitle: Yale School of Medicine
results.description: The Peter E. Schwartz Discovery to Cure Internship Program exposes talented students to advanced biomedical laboratories to foster future careers in science and medicine. This highly competitive program has an acceptance rate of less than 12% and is open to high school juniors at least 16 years of age, as well as undergraduates and teachers. Participants conduct rigorous research that often leads to recognition at major competitions like the International Science and Engineering Fair and the Siemens Westinghouse Science and Technology Competition. Approximately 20% of interns have successfully published their research findings in peer-reviewed scientific journals. Since its inception, more than 300 participants have completed the program, gaining immersive experience within the Department of Obstetrics, Gynecology & Reproductive Sciences.

results.name: Sports Journalism Summer Camp
results.title: Shirley Povich Sports Journalism Summer Camp
results.subtitle: Philip Merrill College of Journalism
results.description: The Shirley Povich Sports Journalism Summer Camp is a popular program designed for high school students entering grades 9-12 who are interested in pursuing careers in sports media. Participants receive instruction from seasoned professionals and faculty members, gaining hands-on experience in areas such as sports writing, play-by-play broadcasting, and video production for social media. The curriculum covers a wide range of modern topics including eSports production, sports analytics, and the role of social media management within professional athletic organizations. Throughout the week, students attend workshops led by reporters from major outlets like The Washington Post and the Baltimore Sun, culminating in the presentation of their own original camp stories.

results.name: Scholars Program
results.title: College Prep Scholars Program
results.subtitle: QuestBridge
results.description: The College Prep Scholars Program is designed for high-achieving high school juniors from low-income backgrounds who have excelled academically despite financial hardships. Participants gain access to exclusive resources such as summer program scholarships, national college admissions conferences, and specialized guidance for developing strong college applications. Eligible students are typically those earning primarily A's in challenging courses and living in households with an annual income of less than $65,000 for a family of four. Selected scholars receive a significant head start on applying for full four-year scholarships to fifty-five college partners through the National College Match during their senior year. The program further equips candidates with a supportive community of motivated peers and the potential opportunity to visit top-tier colleges at no cost.

results.name: NM GCM Grosvenor Program
results.title: NM GCM Grosvenor Discovery Program
results.subtitle: Northwestern Medicine
results.description: The NM GCM Grosvenor Discovery Program is designed for high school students interested in health care, particularly those who may have limited access to opportunities to explore related careers. Participants are exposed to a range of healthcare jobs through hospital tours, guest speakers, group discussions, and engaging hands-on activities. In addition to career exploration, the program fosters professional development, provides community service and leadership experiences, and offers networking opportunities with healthcare professionals. To be eligible, students must be entering their sophomore or junior year, maintain at least a 3.0 GPA, and commit to attending monthly meetings throughout the school year.

results.name: Annual Challenge
results.title: 3M Young Scientist Challenge
results.subtitle: 3M Young Scientist Lab
results.description: The 3M Young Scientist Challenge is a premier science competition that invites students in grades 5–8 to develop innovative solutions for real-world problems. Participants must submit an individual 1-2 minute video describing a new invention or scientific solution that impacts their community or the global population. All entries are evaluated based on creativity, the application of STEM principles, persuasiveness, and communication skills. The program offers significant incentives, such as a $25,000 grand prize and a unique summer mentorship where the top ten finalists work directly with a 3M scientist to develop a prototype. This project-based learning opportunity is designed to spark creativity and connection among students from all backgrounds while encouraging them to tackle issues they care about.

results.name: Terrapin Music Camp
results.title: TERRAPIN MUSIC CAMP
results.subtitle: University of Maryland School of Music
results.description: Terrapin Music Camp is a week-long enrichment program for musicians entering grades 6-12, accommodating band, orchestra, and choir performers. Vocalists of all skill levels and instrumentalists with at least one year of experience are eligible to participate in this comprehensive musical experience. Students engage in large ensemble rehearsals, small group lessons, and sectionals led by expert faculty from the School of Music and K-12 educators from throughout the state. Beyond core rehearsals, the program features elective music classes, daily professional performances, and a final culminating concert to showcase student progress. The camp aims to develop musicianship and advance technique while bringing together youth from across the metropolitan area to share their passion for music.

results.name: Finance Camp
results.title: Finance Camp
results.subtitle: Penn State Abington
results.description: Finance Camp at Penn State Abington offers interactive programs designed to help teens ages 12 to 17 develop essential money management skills and financial confidence. Participants in the "Money Moves" and "Path to Financial Success" sessions engage in hands-on activities, including investment simulations, savings competitions, and "Shark Tank"–style pitches. The curriculum covers a wide range of practical topics such as creating personal budgets, understanding bank operations, managing credit and loans, and planning for future expenses like college or a first car. Through games and real-life scenarios, students learn to navigate paychecks and insurance while building the tools necessary for long-term independence.

results.name: Host-Microbe Mutualism
results.title: Host-Microbe Mutualism (Wang Lab)
results.subtitle: University of Massachusetts Amherst
results.description: This competitive Research Intensive program invites high-achieving rising juniors and seniors to work alongside distinguished faculty and graduate students in a professional laboratory setting. Participants will explore the molecular mechanisms of host-microbe mutualistic interactions, specifically focusing on the nitrogen-fixing symbiosis between legumes and bacteria. Potential research projects include discovering novel genes essential for symbiosis and analyzing the effects of specific host proteins on microbial partners. Throughout the program, students gain firsthand experience with university-level research methodologies and the field of biochemistry at a major R1 university. To conclude the experience, each student will create and present a formal research poster to faculty, peers, and family during a final session.

results.name: Summer Session
results.title: Summer Session
results.subtitle: The University of Chicago
results.description: Summer Session at the University of Chicago brings together a global community of idea-driven undergraduate and high school students for virtual intensive study and academic exploration. Participants can choose from a wide variety of offerings, including undergraduate courses, specialized programs like the Parrhesia Summer Academy, and hands-on experiences such as Research in the Biological Sciences. High school students in grades 9 through 12 have access to unique opportunities like the Immersion Program, Stones & Bones, and the Summer Language Institute. The program also provides instructional and residential employment opportunities for current undergraduate and graduate students within the university's scholarly environment. This comprehensive summer initiative focuses on areas such as freedom of expression, public discourse, and quantitative portfolio management to prepare students for advanced academic work.

results.name: Underwater Robotics Competition
results.title: MATE ROV Competition
results.subtitle: Marine Technology Society
results.description: The MATE ROV Competition is an international program that challenges K-12, community college, and university students to design and build remotely operated vehicles (ROVs) to solve real-world problems. Participants apply physics, mathematics, electronics, and engineering skills to complete missions based on scenarios from the workplace, such as monitoring the health of aquatic habitats. The competition provides various classes including SCOUT, NAVIGATOR, RANGER, PIONEER, and EXPLORER to accommodate different skill levels and educational backgrounds. Students are encouraged to work together and network with technical professionals while utilizing sensors, tooling, and complementary technologies to achieve their mission goals. Resources such as scholarships, grants, and professional development are available through the MATE ROV Academy to support the learning process and future careers in marine technology.

results.name: Summer Academics
results.title: Summer Academies
results.subtitle: Penn Arts and Sciences High School Programs
results.description: These residential, non-credit programs are designed for current 9th through 11th grade students, including international applicants who possess a valid tourist visa. Participants engage in subject-intensive courses lasting either two or three weeks that combine advanced scientific or social theory with practical, real-world applications. Science-focused academies utilize cutting-edge campus technology for innovative lab experiences, while humanities tracks explore sociological themes and historical contexts. Led by university faculty and industry professionals, the program provides students with a Certificate of Completion and the opportunity to request letters of recommendation upon successful completion. Eligible students from Philadelphia public or charter high schools may also apply for specific scholarship opportunities to attend the program free of charge.

results.name: University of Maine
results.title: Self-made Engineering Leaders of the Future (SELF) for High School Students
results.subtitle: University of Maine
results.description: The Self-made Engineering Leaders of the Future (SELF) Institute is a residential program designed for rural high school students with an interest in science and technology. Participants explore the responsible use of forest ecosystems as a foundation for sustainable energy through hands-on projects, demonstrations, and field trips to the University Forest. During the program, students engage in research regarding the chemical and physical processes used to create transportation fuels like ethanol and jet fuel from woody biomass. The curriculum also includes analyzing sustainability attitudes and participating in focus groups concerning renewable energy. To apply, prospective students must provide a report card, a letter of recommendation, and an essay explaining their motivation for joining the institute.

results.name: Discover How the Systems of the Body Work Together
results.title: Anatomy & Physiology: How the Body Works in Harmony
results.subtitle: Georgetown University
results.description: Designed for students ages 13 and older, this course provides a comprehensive view of major body regions and systems including the musculoskeletal, nervous, respiratory, and renal systems. Participants learn through engaging course videos and simulations featuring educational tools such as cadaver dissection and medical procedures. The curriculum includes 20 to 30 hours of total instruction supported by mentors who offer encouragement and direction on all assignments. Students complete a Final Capstone Project by designing an informational pamphlet for patients undergoing diabetic treatment to demonstrate their mastery of the material. Upon finishing the program, participants receive a Certificate of Completion from Georgetown University to showcase their foundational knowledge in medicine and physiology.

results.name: Marketing & Personal Branding Academy
results.title: Marketing & Personal Branding Academy
results.subtitle: Georgetown University School of Continuing Studies
results.description: The Marketing & Personal Branding Academy provides students with an immersive exploration into the fundamentals of marketing through an intercultural lens at both business and personal levels. Participants engage in a blend of classroom lectures, hands-on activities, and off-site visits to see real-life marketing firms in action and learn from industry experts. Throughout the program, students explore diverse subject areas such as digital marketing, data analytics, creative problem solving, and ethical marketing strategies. Under the guidance of experienced faculty, attendees work in small teams to develop integrated marketing plans for professional clients and create their own personal brand strategies. The experience culminates in a capstone project where students practice pitching their unique marketing campaigns and personal aspirations to better communicate their professional skills.

results.name: Coding for Game Design
results.title: Coding for Game Design
results.subtitle: New York University
results.description: Coding for Game Design is a two-week non-credit program designed for high school students currently in the 9th, 10th, or 11th grade who possess a basic understanding of computer programming. Participants learn fundamental principles of game design and professional development techniques, utilizing C# and Unity scripting to build custom 3D video games. The curriculum is delivered through a combination of lectures, collaborative small-group activities, and individual projects facilitated by experts from NYU Steinhardt’s Consortium for Research and Evaluation of Advanced Technologies in Education (CREATE). Students gain hands-on experience implementing game features such as player controls, sound effects, and user interface design while also mastering pitching and concept development. Admission decisions are made on a rolling basis, and the application requires details regarding the student's academic history as well as their previous coding and gaming experience.

results.name: Harvard
results.title: The Crimson Summer Academy
results.subtitle: Harvard University
results.description: The Crimson Summer Academy invites ninth-grade public school students from Boston, Cambridge, and Somerville who have been nominated for their academic potential to join a transformative three-year educational cohort. Over the course of three consecutive summers, accepted Crimson Scholars engage in an interdisciplinary curriculum featuring integrated mathematics, writing, financial literacy, and science courses focused on data analysis and research. Participants benefit from small group instruction and close mentoring relationships with college undergraduates while preparing for admission to challenging four-year colleges and universities. The program provides full financial support covering tuition, room, and board, alongside stipends for each summer and a final scholarship for use at the college of their choice. In the final year, scholars take credit-bearing courses at the Harvard Summer School and participate in career exploration fieldwork at various professional organizations.

results.name: Quantum Quickstart
results.title: Quantum Quickstart
results.subtitle: University of Chicago
results.description: Quantum Quickstart is a residential enrichment program designed for high-achieving 9th and 10th grade students who have a strong interest in quantum sciences and the physical foundations of quantum mechanics. Participants attend lectures with faculty from the Pritzker School of Molecular Engineering, participate in theoretical discussions, and tour world-class lab facilities to observe the inner workings of quantum computers. Beyond scientific inquiry, the program includes professional development sessions for future STEM careers and meetings with admissions counselors to learn about highly selective college admissions processes. Students are required to reside in campus housing for the duration of the program and must participate in all sessions to receive a program certificate. The admission process requires a complete application including transcripts, essays, and letters of recommendation, with significant need-based financial aid available for eligible domestic students.

results.name: Summer Camp
results.title: GRAMMY Camp
results.subtitle: GRAMMY Museum
results.description: GRAMMY Camp is a national music industry program designed for high school students in grades 9 through 12 who are interested in pursuing professional careers in music. Led by a faculty of industry professionals and GRAMMY winners, the program provides students with real-world insight across various career tracks such as songwriting, music production, and performance. The application process is multi-step and requires students to submit audition materials and a video essay explaining their long-term career goals. This non-residential experience is open to U.S. residents and offers need-based financial assistance to help cover tuition costs for eligible participants.

results.name: Dartmouth College
results.title: Health Careers Institute at Dartmouth
results.subtitle: The New Hampshire Area Health Education Center (AHEC)
results.description: The Health Careers Institute at Dartmouth provides students entering grades 11th and 12th with opportunities to explore various disciplines within the healthcare system. Participants engage with a wide range of professionals, including physicians, direct care providers, research scientists, and public health or health policy specialists. The curriculum features classroom instruction, a team-based research project, and robust dialogue with faculty and health profession students regarding clinical and non-clinical career pathways. In addition to exploring potential innovations in healthcare, students participate in open discussions focused on the college application process to help narrow their future focus. The program offers a college immersion experience where participants live in a dorm on campus while learning from faculty members representing various educational and health institutions.

results.name: Summer Session

deadlines.label: Last day to Enroll Without a $50 Late Fee
Last day to add or drop course(s) without instructor’s signature
Last day to enroll without a $100 late fee

results.title: UC Irvine Summer Session
results.subtitle: University of California, Irvine
results.description: UC Irvine Summer Session provides a comprehensive academic environment with over 800 course offerings, including more than 250 available online. The program serves a diverse student body, ranging from current UC students and incoming freshmen to visiting international students and rising high school juniors or seniors. Participants can engage in specialized pathways such as the Freshman Summer Success Program, the FAST PASS for prerequisite completion, or the Undergraduate Research Opportunities Program. In addition to traditional coursework, students may explore global learning through study abroad initiatives or gain professional experience via internships and various off-campus programs. Support services include academic advising, financial aid eligibility for eligible students, and resources for housing and course management through a centralized student portal.

results.name: Bridges to Social Justice Academy
results.title: Bridges to Social Justice Academy
results.subtitle: Georgetown University School of Continuing Studies
results.description: The Bridges to Social Justice Academy is a three-week program for high school students aged 15 and older that explores diverse pathways toward creating a more just world. Participants engage in academic lectures, workshops, and small group dialogues grounded in the Social Change Model of Leadership and the Pathways of Public Service and Civic Engagement framework. The curriculum examines structural oppression through lenses such as community-engaged research, direct service, public policy advocacy, and social entrepreneurship. Students develop practical skills in public speaking, project design, and facilitation while collaborating with university faculty and undergraduate mentors.
