The program concludes with a capstone project where students design a mission-driven organization dedicated to enacting social change around a specific injustice.

results.name: ICS Summer Academy
results.title: ICS Summer Academy
results.subtitle: UC Irvine
results.description: The ICS Summer Academy provides high school students with technical training in specialized fields like artificial intelligence, data analytics, game development, and software engineering. Participants collaborate with peers and university faculty on real-world projects and hands-on coursework designed by academic and industry leaders. The program offers multiple session lengths where students engage in research lab visits and team-based activities to cultivate critical thinking, communication, and collaboration skills. Each session concludes with a capstone presentation where student groups share their solutions and findings with an audience of peers, parents, and faculty. Students also gain a preview of college life by interacting with undergraduate and graduate mentors while exploring campus culture and academic departments.

results.name: FPE Summer Camp
results.title: FPE Summer Camp
results.subtitle: A. James Clark School of Engineering, University of Maryland
results.description: The Fire Protection Engineering Design Challenge is a week-long camp where participants work in teams of three or four to explore the principles of fire safety and engineering. Students are tasked with designing, testing, and building a two-room apartment model integrated with notification, detection, and suppression systems. The program culminates in a team competition where the constructed apartments undergo rigorous fire-testing in specialized engineering labs. This collaborative enrichment opportunity is facilitated by the SFPE Chesapeake Chapter and university faculty, staff, and students. The camp is open to all interested individuals and provides hands-on experience in the design and construction of fire-protection technology.

results.name: OSU
results.title: AWS Foundation & Mₐ²JIC High School Internship Program
results.subtitle: Manufacturing & Materials Joining Innovation Center (Mₐ²JIC)
results.description: The AWS Foundation & Mₐ²JIC High School Internship Program provides rising juniors and seniors with an immersive research experience in welding engineering and manufacturing processes. This paid opportunity allows motivated students to contribute to industry-funded research projects under the direct mentorship of faculty and graduate researchers. Throughout the program, interns engage in hands-on laboratory work, which may involve testing materials, data analysis, coding, and modeling. Participants develop professional scientific skills and complete a capstone research poster and presentation to share their findings with the engineering community. To apply, interested students must submit a resume, transcript or STEM course list, a personal statement, and a letter of recommendation.

results.name: BFS Internship
results.title: Biological Field Station Internships for College and High School Students
results.subtitle: SUNY Oneonta
results.description: The Biological Field Station Internships offer intensive summer research opportunities for both undergraduate college students and high school students interested in environmental and natural sciences. Participants engage in a diverse mix of field work, such as fisheries surveys and water sampling, along with laboratory analyses and data interpretation. Throughout the program, interns are responsible for conducting independent research projects, which culminate in a technical report and a large-format poster presentation. Successful candidates receive a stipend and earn at least one semester hour of college credit for their contributions to monitoring projects in the Susquehanna watershed. Undergraduate interns may also be eligible for complementary housing, while all participants must demonstrate self-motivation and the ability to work effectively within a research team.

results.name: UMass
results.title: Research Intensives
results.subtitle: The University of Massachusetts Amherst
results.description: The Research Intensives program at the University of Massachusetts Amherst is a competitive six-week summer experience designed for high-achieving rising high school juniors and seniors. Participants are placed in professional working labs alongside distinguished faculty and university students to conduct advanced research in fields such as Biology, Engineering, Chemistry, and Psychology. To be eligible for admission, students should maintain grades of B or above in their mathematics and science coursework and must submit a personal statement indicating their top laboratory choices. This residential program allows students to experience college life by living in campus residence halls, utilizing award-winning dining commons, and participating in organized social events with the support of live-in resident counselors.

results.name: Summer Cancer Research

program_dates.label: High School Summer Research Experience in Cancer (SURE-CAN) Program

results.title: High School Summer Research Experience in Cancer (SURE-CAN) Program
results.subtitle: Roswell Park Comprehensive Cancer Center
results.description: The High School Summer Research Experience in Cancer (SURE-CAN) Program is an immersive six-week internship designed for high school juniors interested in scientific research careers. Participants engage in a comprehensive curriculum featuring lectures, group discussions, and hands-on "wet" or "dry" laboratory research under the mentorship of expert faculty. The program introduces students to fundamental cancer sciences, including cancer biology, genomics, medical imaging, and the application of artificial intelligence in oncology research. Interns also receive training in research ethics, basic statistics, and scientific communication to help prepare them for professional environments. The experience concludes with a formal research symposium where students present their scientific rationale and findings through poster presentations. Participation requires a full-time commitment of forty hours per week, adhering to laboratory safety dress codes and professional conduct standards.

results.name: Wake Forest University
results.title: Wake Forest LEAP Internship Program
results.subtitle: Wake Forest University
results.description: The Wake Forest LEAP Internship Program, also known as Wake Forest Lab Experiences: Academics and Professions, is a six-week paid internship designed for high school juniors and seniors from select Title I schools. Participants explore their STEM interests through hands-on experience in professional lab settings, focusing on disciplines such as biology, chemistry, engineering, physics, and computer science. Each intern is paired with a primary faculty mentor and a student co-mentor who provide guidance on lab etiquette, technical skills, and scientific research principles. Beyond laboratory work, the program emphasizes professional and career development through workshops, training sessions, and networking opportunities. The experience concludes with a symposium where students demonstrate their growth by presenting final projects to their peers, mentors, and families.

results.name: Robotics Competition

deadlines.label: Initial Proposal for New Signature Event concepts

results.title: VEX V5 Robotics Competition
results.subtitle: Robotics Education & Competition Foundation
results.description: The VEX V5 Robotics Competition Push Back is a competitive challenge played on a 12’ x 12’ square field involving two alliances of two teams each. Matches are divided into a fifteen-second autonomous period and a longer driver-controlled period where participants operate their robots manually. Teams earn points by scoring eighty-eight blocks into four goals, controlling specific zones within those goals, and parking robots in designated areas before time expires. Additional scoring incentives include a ten-point autonomous bonus and the opportunity to earn an autonomous win point through the completion of assigned tasks. This program emphasizes technical execution and strategic teamwork as students navigate a field containing both long and center goals.

results.name: RBS-PREP Pre-College Enrichment
results.title: Service Temporarily Unavailable!
results.subtitle: Rutgers University
results.description: The service provided by Rutgers University is currently experiencing temporary unavailability, and users are encouraged to try accessing the platform again at a later time. Support is available through the Camden, Newark, or New Brunswick/Piscataway help desks for those with specific questions, comments, or suggestions. Users may also visit the individual campus websites for Camden, Newark, and New Brunswick to find additional information regarding the university. We apologize for any inconvenience this disruption may cause to students and visitors seeking to use these online resources.

results.name: OGStem Program
results.title: GSTEM
results.subtitle: NYU
results.description: GSTEM provides a Summer Research Program and a Spring Data Science Class tailored for talented, STEM-savvy high school students. Participants learn within an inclusive and supportive environment intended to help high school scientists further develop their interest in STEM fields. The summer program features diverse activities including independent research, educational field trips, and opportunities for peer networking. Students can also take advantage of an online Data Science course that focuses on building essential technical skill sets. To ensure accessibility, a scholarship fund provides financial aid to students who demonstrate financial need.

results.name: Summer Scholars Research Program
results.title: Summer Scholars Research Program
results.subtitle: Winship Cancer Institute of Emory University
results.description: The Summer Scholars Research Program at Winship Cancer Institute of Emory University offers a six-week immersion experience designed to expose rising and graduating high school seniors to the field of cancer research. Participating students are paired one-on-one with a physician or lab-based researcher to conduct hands-on projects in active laboratories, culminating in a formal presentation at a final symposium. Beyond laboratory work, the curriculum includes faculty-led lectures on cancer biology and oncology careers, roundtable discussions with cancer survivors, and field trips to specialized medical facilities. Applicants must be at least 16 years old and provide transcripts along with recommendation letters, with those completing the in-person internship receiving a $2,400 stipend. A virtual-only option is also available, featuring live lectures on clinical and laboratory research methods for students unable to attend the full-time, on-site program.

results.name: Investigation and Training in Careers in Health
results.title: Program for the Investigation and Training in Careers in Health (PITCH)
results.subtitle: University of California San Francisco
results.description: The Program for the Investigation and Training in Careers in Health (PITCH) is an immersive experience designed to inspire and empower first-generation and low-income rising 10th and 11th graders interested in medical sciences. Participants explore the healthcare landscape to gain a deeper understanding of connections across professional fields while collaborating with mentors to investigate critical health issues. Beyond scientific exploration, students receive expert guidance on navigating postsecondary options and planning for future college success. The program culminates in the PITCH Health Symposium, where participants present their research findings to the community. Eligibility is based on maintaining a minimum 2.5 GPA, and the application process requires short response questions along with the submission of unofficial transcripts.

results.name: Bridge Building Contest
results.title: Bridge Building Contest
results.subtitle: Illinois Institute of Technology
results.description: The Bridge Building Contest involves the construction and testing of model bridges by high school students to promote the study and application of fundamental physics principles. Participants develop hands-on skills while designing structures to a set of specifications and observing their performance during testing to see if they meet their intended functions. This academically-oriented extracurricular activity allows students to experience the practical application of engineering by seeing how their designs perform in a competitive environment. The program includes both regional and international levels of competition, with official bridge specifications provided to guide the building process for all participants. Additionally, the event offers resources such as tutorial videos and archival documentation to assist students and schools in organizing their own local contests.

results.name: Morse Summer Music Academy
results.title: Morse Summer Music Academy
results.subtitle: Yale School of Music
results.description: The Morse Summer Music Academy is a free, month-long intensive music program designed for students entering grades 5 to 11 within the New Haven Public Schools. Participants engage in a comprehensive curriculum that includes performance opportunities in both chamber and larger ensembles, formal instruction in music theory, and an introduction to musical composition. To be eligible, students must be in good academic standing, enrolled in their school’s music program when available, and receive a recommendation from their music teacher. Admission requires an in-person placement audition where students are expected to perform a short solo, play a scale, and complete a sight-reading exercise. Daily lunch is provided at no cost, and participants must commit to attending the full duration of the program to remain enrolled.

results.name: Washington University in St. Louis
results.title: Research Development Institute
results.subtitle: Washington University in St. Louis
results.description: The Research Development Institute is a two-week noncredit residential program designed for high school students who are new to the research process. Participants explore academic topics of their choice through practical application of primary and secondary sources, emphasizing critical thinking and diverse research methods over laboratory work. The daily schedule consists of morning lectures and discussions followed by instructor-led afternoon sessions dedicated to individual projects and skills application. Applicants must submit an online application including short essays, a transcript, and a teacher recommendation, and while there is a program fee, need-based scholarships are available. This academically rigorous experience is geared toward motivated students seeking to prepare for the demands of college-level inquiry in a collaborative and supportive environment.

results.name: Business & Marketing Internship
results.title: Social Media Intern Form
results.subtitle: Capplica.com
results.description: This social media internship is open to high school students who are looking to develop their skills in the fields of business and marketing. Applicants must provide details regarding their previous experience in marketing as well as their involvement in school-based activities like student council or other clubs. The position includes opportunities to create digital content and appear on camera, though there are alternative roles for those who do not wish to be filmed. Interested students are required to indicate their weekly availability and may provide referrals for friends who might also be interested in content creation.

results.name: SYCCL
results.title: ONLINE Summer Youth Camp for Computational Linguistics (SYCCL)
results.subtitle: Institute for Advanced Computational Science
results.description: The ONLINE Summer Youth Camp for Computational Linguistics (SYCCL) is an educational program hosted by the Institute for Advanced Computational Science. This camp focuses on the intersection of language and technology, introducing students to the field of computational linguistics through an online platform. Participants will explore how computer models can be used to process and analyze human language, bridging the gap between social sciences and computer science. The curriculum is designed to provide youth with a foundational understanding of the technical skills required for this interdisciplinary field. As a remote offering, the program ensures accessibility for students interested in advanced computational techniques regardless of their physical location.

results.name: Discover the Fast-Paced World of Journalism
results.title: Journalism and Media in the Digital Age
results.subtitle: Georgetown University
results.description: Designed for students ages 13 and up, this program introduces participants to the evolving field of journalism through a focus on multimedia editing, podcasting, and social media storytelling. Participants explore essential reporting techniques, including how to gather facts, conduct interviews, and navigate ethical and legal challenges within the industry. The curriculum features insights from professional news correspondents and prize-winning journalists, culminating in a Final Capstone Project where students create their own news story for print, digital, or video platforms. This 100% online course offers a flexible learning environment with 20 to 30 hours of total instruction, guided by experienced mentors who provide feedback and brainstorming support. For a fee of $1,895, students gain a comprehensive understanding of diverse news platforms and earn a Certificate of Completion from the university.

results.name: CEAT - Automation and Robotics Discovery
results.title: Automation and Robotics Discovery
results.subtitle: Oklahoma State University
results.description: Automation and Robotics Discovery is a one-week summer program designed for high school students in grades 9 through 12 who are interested in electrical engineering, industrial automation, and mechatronics systems. The curriculum combines college-level introductory courses with hands-on activities, including soldering practice, basic electrical circuit work, and LabVIEW graphical programming. Participants explore the integration of electrical and mechanical systems by learning about sensor and actuator interfacing and the concepts of industrial automation. Throughout the week, students work toward a final project demo such as an obstacle avoidance robot, a traffic light control system, or a processing plant. The registration fee covers all necessary supplies, meals, accommodations, and a camp shirt, though seats are limited for this intensive engineering experience.

results.name: William & Mary
results.title: William & Mary Youth Talent Search Program - Camp Ignite
results.subtitle: Center for Gifted Education
results.description: Camp Ignite is a specialized program designed for motivated rising 7th through 9th graders who wish to explore advanced academic courses in a supportive, inclusive community. To ensure a high level of academic rigor, students must demonstrate eligibility through above-level ACT or SAT testing scores that meet specific criteria in math, science, reading, or English. Participants can choose between residential and day program formats, both of which provide six hours of daily instruction and include field trip fees. The curriculum features expert-taught, inquiry-driven courses such as Physics and Oceanography, where students engage in hands-on exploration, mathematical modeling, and experimental investigation. This program aims to foster talent development and build scientific reasoning skills by connecting abstract concepts to real-world phenomena.

results.name: Innovation in Music Academy
results.title: High School Summer Discovery
results.subtitle: UCLA Anderson School of Management
results.description: High School Summer Discovery at UCLA Anderson School of Management provides students in grades 9-12 with a foundational understanding of careers in media, entertainment, and sports through college-level academics. Participants choose from intensive academies such as Sports Business, Digital Marketing and Social Media, or Innovation in the Music Business to deepen their professional interests. The curriculum emphasizes hands-on experiences and essential skill development in areas like teamwork, communication, and business frameworks including finance and strategy. Students also engage with industry professionals and participate in site visits to movie studios and athletic stadiums to gain a real-world perspective on their chosen fields. Upon finishing the program, participants receive a Certificate of Completion from the university to highlight their academic growth.

results.name: Pre-College
results.title: Hoya Summer High School Sessions
results.subtitle: Georgetown University
results.description: Hoya Summer High School Sessions provide students with the opportunity to explore academic interests and experience college life at Georgetown University. Participants can choose from various tracks including accelerated non-credit Academies, the five-week College Prep Program, or Summer College courses taken alongside current undergraduate students. The programs feature collaborative exercises, simulations, and group discussions led by prestigious faculty and industry experts to prepare students for future success. In addition to earning college credit in specific tracks, students engage in hands-on learning through field trips to prominent institutions and presentations from professional leaders. Virtual options are also available through year-round online programs, allowing students to access Georgetown's curriculum from anywhere in the world.

results.name: Upward Bound Program

program_dates.label: D&D: Adventures on the Astral sea (Grades 9-12)
Teen Med Camp 2: Beyond the Basics (Grades 9-12) Session 1
Teen Med Camp 2: Beyond the Basics (Grades 9-12) Session 2
D&D: Escapades in the city of Waterdeep (Grades 9-12)

results.title: Summer Camps: High School
results.subtitle: The University of Texas at Arlington
results.description: The University of Texas at Arlington offers a diverse selection of summer camps specifically designed for high school students in grades 9 through 12. Participants can explore creative interests through courses such as Analogue Photography and specialized sessions on how to publish a book. For those interested in technical fields, the university provides programs in engineering and 3D printing technology at the campus Fab Lab. Students pursuing health sciences can enroll in multiple levels of Teen Med Camp, which range from introductory concepts to advanced curriculum in the Beyond the Basics track. Additionally, unique themed offerings like Dungeons & Dragons adventures provide engaging social and imaginative experiences for attendees.

results.name: UChicago Medicine
results.title: ResearcHStart
results.subtitle: UChicago Medicine
results.description: ResearcHStart is a multi-institutional cancer research training program designed for high school juniors and seniors residing in Illinois or Lake County, Indiana. Participants work full-time for eight weeks in the laboratories of established researchers to gain hands-on experience in cutting-edge fields such as cancer immunology, bioengineering, and experimental therapeutics. This intensive research experience is supplemented by career development workshops, skill-building opportunities, and a faculty lecture series intended to promote career opportunities in biomedicine. Students benefit from a dedicated network of faculty and peer mentors and receive a taxable stipend for their commitment to the program. The experience culminates in a research symposium where participants present their work to family, friends, and members of the scientific community.

results.name: High School Honors
results.title: UCI x GATI Programs
results.subtitle: UC Irvine
results.description: UCI x GATI Programs bridge high school talent with university-level research and innovation through comprehensive enrichment opportunities. Gifted and talented students from around the world engage in hands-on experiments across disciplines such as neuroscience, artificial intelligence, biotechnology, and medicine. Participants may have the chance to earn UC Irvine credit through the Division of Continuing Education while working on research projects that can lead toward publication. The program utilizes the ACT® Holistic Framework during its interview process to evaluate cross-cutting capabilities and behavioral skills alongside core academic proficiency. Additionally, the curriculum connects academic studies to future career paths by offering access to university resources like the ANTrepreneur Center for building start-ups and exploring engineering principles.

results.name: Brown University
results.title: Brown Experiential Education: Oxford
results.subtitle: Brown University
results.description: Students completing grades 10 to 12 delve into the fast-moving field of biotechnology through this intensive 12-day experiential program. Participants enroll in a course titled Basics in Biotech: From Genes to Innovation, where they explore the fundamental science behind DNA and proteins alongside modern advances like CRISPR gene editing and artificial intelligence. The curriculum combines interactive, discussion-based classes with site visits to world-leading research centers, hospitals, and biomedical incubators to observe the journey from lab discovery to clinical application. Throughout the program, scholars engage with experts to understand how innovations such as immunotherapy and brain-computer interfaces are shaping the future of global medicine. Upon finishing the program, students receive a Course Performance Report and a Digital Certificate of Completion to acknowledge their academic growth and collaboration.

results.name: UCI
results.title: Summer Youth Science Fellowship Program
results.subtitle: UC Irvine Cancer Research Institute
results.description: The Summer Youth Science Fellowship Program provides high school students with early exposure to cancer research through hands-on learning in mentored laboratory and research-team settings. Participants are paired with experienced research mentors to gain foundational skills in scientific inquiry and communication while exploring diverse career pathways in the biomedical field. Beyond their laboratory work, fellows engage in interactive scientific seminars and professional development workshops to enhance their academic growth. Students typically commit 30 hours per week to the program, following the specific schedules and needs of their assigned research labs. The experience concludes with a Scientific Poster Symposium, where fellows present their work to faculty, peers, and family members to celebrate their accomplishments.

results.name: Pre-Baccalaureate
results.title: Pre-Baccalaureate
results.subtitle: Brown University
results.description: The Brown University Pre-Baccalaureate Program is a highly selective initiative for rising or recently graduated high school seniors who are ready to engage in rigorous, credit-bearing undergraduate study. Participants enroll in courses alongside Brown undergraduates during the university’s Summer Session, choosing from a variety of options in the natural sciences, mathematics, social sciences, and humanities. Students can take up to two online courses, which are typically asynchronous but may include synchronous meetings, requiring an average of 25 to 30 hours of work per week for each class. Courses are taken for academic credit and are evaluated using a letter grade system or a satisfactory/no-credit basis, potentially providing students with advanced standing at their future undergraduate institutions. In addition to their academic coursework, students have access to a range of virtual Pre-College Student Life programs to build a virtual community.

results.name: Summer School for Mathematics & Science
results.title: California State Summer School for Mathematics & Science (COSMOS)
results.subtitle: University of California
results.description: The California State Summer School for Mathematics & Science (COSMOS) is an intensive four-week summer residential pre-college program designed for high school students who demonstrate an aptitude for academic and professional careers in STEM fields. Talented and motivated students completing grades 8-12 have the opportunity to work with renowned faculty, researchers, and scientists while exploring advanced topics far beyond the standard high school curriculum. This competitive program requires applicants to have a typical GPA of 3.5 or above and focuses on fostering skills through a challenging, hands-on, and lab-intensive curriculum. Participants apply to a specific University of California campus program where they engage with unique teaching and research expertise within state-of-the-art facilities. The program is limited to California high-school students and is designed to prepare the next generation of leaders in science, technology, engineering, and mathematics.

results.name: National Economics Challenge
results.title: National Economics Challenge
results.subtitle: Council for Economic Education
results.description: The National Economics Challenge is a premier competition where student teams compete across various states to test their knowledge of economic principles. Each state champion team advances to participate in a national semi-final round to determine the top scoring teams in each division. Finalists are invited to engage in a rigorous competition that includes a Critical Thinking Round and a Quiz Bowl for the top-performing groups. Successful participants have the opportunity to earn trophies and cash prizes ranging from $200 to $1,000 for students and their teacher coaches. This program is sponsored by the Council for Economic Education and local state councils to promote economic literacy and academic excellence.

results.name: Psychology and Its Impact on Everyday Life
results.title: Psychology: How the Brain Influences Behavior
results.subtitle: Georgetown University
results.description: This online program from Georgetown University, designed for students ages 13 and up, offers two distinct tracks: a college credit course and an enrichment option. Participants explore how the brain influences behavior by studying topics such as neuroscience, learning and memory, and the psychological impact of social media. Students learn to apply the scientific method to real-world situations, test investigative methods by creating experiments, and delve into the causes of disorders like anxiety and depression. The curriculum features dynamic video lessons from university faculty, access to mentors or teaching assistants, and a final capstone project titled "My Psychological Life." Depending on the chosen track, students can earn a certificate of completion or a university transcript while gaining insight into future college majors and careers in fields like social work and counseling.

results.name: Pre-College
results.title: Pre-College Program
results.subtitle: School of Visual Arts
results.description: The SVA Pre-College Program is designed for high school students aged 14 to 18 who wish to enhance their creative skills and explore specific fields within the visual arts. Students can choose from a wide variety of courses, including 3D animation, comics, film production, painting, photography, and interior design, all taught by industry-leading professional faculty. Participants can earn three college credits during the summer session or one credit for completing the fall or spring programs, with options available for both in-person and online learning. The program emphasizes a college-like experience where students can develop their professional portfolios, live in residence halls, and navigate the independence of a major urban campus environment.

results.name: Summer Session
results.title: Summer Session
results.subtitle: Carnegie Mellon University
results.description: Pre-College Summer Session allows high school sophomores and juniors to earn college credit by taking undergraduate-level courses alongside university students. Participants can choose from approximately thirty courses across various disciplines, including engineering, computer science, social sciences, and the humanities. Residential students are required to enroll in two courses for the duration of the six-week program, while commuters living within a local radius have the option to take one or two classes. To support student success, a special grade forgiveness policy is applied, where only grades of A and B are recorded on official permanent transcripts for those in good academic standing. This rigorous academic experience prepares students for college success through authentic classroom environments and access to university faculty and support resources.

results.name: Sports Industry Management Academy
results.title: Sports Industry Management Academy
results.subtitle: Georgetown University School of Continuing Studies
results.description: Georgetown's Sports Industry Management Academy introduces high school students to the diverse career paths within the multi-billion dollar sports business world. Participants engage in a comprehensive curriculum featuring classroom lectures, field trips, and hands-on activities covering topics such as marketing, media, sponsorships, and finance. Students also explore specialized areas including sports and business law, contract negotiations, and brand management while hearing from guest lecturers and industry experts. The program is structured as a two-week experience with both residential and commuter tuition options available for attendees. Throughout the session, students gain unique insights by visiting sports venues and speaking with executives from major organizations like the Washington Capitals and the Washington Football Team.

results.name: Economics Policy Academy
results.title: Economics Policy Academy
results.subtitle: Georgetown University School of Continuing Studies
results.description: Georgetown University's Economics Policy Academy offers an interdisciplinary exploration of the relationship between governing entities and markets through the perspectives of economics and political science. Students engage in academic programming that includes lectures, guest speakers, hands-on activities, and off-site visits to local economic policy organizations. The curriculum covers diverse subject areas such as globalization, microeconomics, poverty, and international trade policy to help participants evaluate complex policy solutions. Participants will also develop networking skills with like-minded peers and complete a research-based poster project related to a program theme. Upon successful completion of the three-week academy, students receive a Certificate of Participation.

results.name: Summer Songwriters Workshop
results.title: NYU Summer Songwriters Workshop
results.subtitle: NYU Steinhardt
results.description: The NYU Summer Songwriters Workshop is a world-renowned intensive program for individuals ages 15 and up dedicated to the art and craft of creating original words and music. Led by GRAMMY-nominated faculty, the curriculum provides in-depth presentations and hands-on exploration of the skills and strategies essential for working songwriters. Participants are divided into small groups to engage in targeted assignments, professional peer-to-peer critiques, and assigned collaborations. To apply, prospective students must submit a portfolio consisting of three original songs with corresponding lyrics, an explanation of their creative contributions, and a resume highlighting their musical experience. The program also offers an auditor track for those who wish to attend sessions and performances without receiving direct critiques on their work.

results.name: Writing Project Summer Camp
results.title: College-Ready Writing: Personal and Academic, Both! (Rising 9-12th Graders)
results.subtitle: UCLA Center X
results.description: This workshop is designed for rising 9-12th grade students looking to develop their writing skills while engaging with relevant social issues in a close-knit community of learners. Participants will explore a variety of genres, including poetry, narrative essays, and argumentative writing, to help cultivate their unique personal academic voice. Throughout the program, students read stimulating texts, participate in debates, and engage in the full writing process to refine their expression. The curriculum includes personalized feedback from both instructors and peers to help students fine-tune their ideas while maintaining authorial authority over their work. Led by experienced educators Gilda De La Cruz and Sasha Avila, the workshop accommodates various writing abilities and offers both in-person and online enrollment options for a fee of $650.

results.name: Tech Camp
results.title: Tech Camp
results.subtitle: College of Engineering and Physical Sciences
results.description: Tech Camp offers a variety of weeklong day and residential programs designed for students entering grades 5 through 12. These dynamic STEM sessions cater to all levels of experience, welcoming both beginners and those with a deep passion for science and technology. Participants explore a wide range of topics that encourage a curious mind and an adventurous spirit. The curriculum includes specialized tracks such as TechSplorers, TechVenturers, and TechLeaders, with some programs even providing opportunities to earn high school credit. To ensure accessibility, scholarships are available for students demonstrating financial need, supported by the generosity of donors and sponsors.

results.name: Upward Bound Program
results.title: Upward Bound
results.subtitle: NC State University
results.description: Upward Bound is an early intervention pre-college program designed to help high school students prepare for the rigors of higher education. The program provides academic instruction in core subjects such as mathematics, laboratory sciences, composition, literature, and foreign languages. Students also benefit from a range of support services, including tutoring, counseling, mentoring, cultural enrichment, and work-study opportunities. Serving 186 students annually from five regional high schools, the program focuses on providing the tools necessary for college enrollment and degree completion. Having been a part of the university since 1978, it has a long history of assisting students in achieving their academic goals.

results.name: Citizen Entrepreneurship Competition
results.title: Citizen Entrepreneurship Competition
results.subtitle: Stiftung Entrepreneurship
results.description: The Citizen Entrepreneurship Competition is a global initiative designed to empower aspiring entrepreneurs age 13 and older to develop innovative solutions for a more sustainable world. Participants work to create projects that address one or more of the 17 UN Sustainable Development Goals, utilizing free online courses and the Entrepreneurial Design Canvas to refine their business models. The competition progresses through three distinct phases including idea submission, public voting, and a final evaluation by an expert jury. Throughout the program, members gain access to a vibrant international community of founders from over 140 nations for networking, peer support, and professional feedback. This activity is endorsed by UNESCO's Education for Sustainable Development framework and aims to combine economic viability with meaningful social impact.

results.name: Program for Automation Robotics and Coding
results.title: Summer Program for Automation Robotics and Coding (SPARC)
results.subtitle: NYU Tandon School of Engineering
results.description: The Summer Program for Automation Robotics and Coding (SPARC) is a two-week intensive designed for rising 9th through 12th-grade students interested in robotics, mechatronics, and programming. Participants receive hands-on experience by building two fully functional robots, including a remote-controlled car and a mobile manipulator with an infrared-controlled arm. The curriculum covers essential technical areas such as electronics, circuitry, microcontrollers, and computer programming constructs like variables and data representations. In addition to daily workshops and a final mobile manipulator challenge, students can participate in social events and field trips alongside other high school program participants. Eligible applicants must have a minimum 3.0 GPA, have completed Algebra 2, and possess some prior programming experience in any language.

results.name: Young Scholars Program
results.title: Young Scholars Program
results.subtitle: UC Davis School of Education
results.description: The Young Scholars Program is a summer residential research program designed for approximately 40 high-achieving high school students interested in conducting original research. Participants engage in hands-on work alongside researchers in state-of-the-art labs within the biological, agricultural, environmental, and natural sciences. The program curriculum includes a comprehensive lecture series where students learn from professors in a wide range of science fields. Beyond lab work, students participate in scientific field trips and experience campus life by living, studying, and eating on campus. Financial support is available for students who require assistance with the cost of attendance to ensure the program remains accessible to a diverse group of scholars.

results.name: NMU
results.title: Summer Pre-College Programs
results.subtitle: The College of New Jersey
results.description: The College of New Jersey offers Summer Pre-College Programs specifically designed for high school students to explore academic interests before entering university. These programs allow participants to engage with various disciplines across the institution's diverse schools, including Arts and Communication, Business, Education, Engineering, Humanities and Social Sciences, Nursing and Health Sciences, and Science. Students have the opportunity to experience exceptional academics and high-quality instruction typically associated with elite colleges. By participating, students can get a head start on their undergraduate journey while discovering potential majors and specializations through immersive learning experiences.

results.name: SEAD
results.title: SEAD
results.subtitle: Dartmouth College
results.description: Strengthening Educational Access with Dartmouth (SEAD) equips high-potential youth from under-resourced communities with the necessary skills to excel in high school and gain admission to suitable colleges. This program follows a four-year model that supports a cohort of first-generation and low-income students starting in their sophomore year of high school and continuing through their sophomore year of college. The initiative features three primary components: an immersive summer session on campus with enrichment courses, an academic year curriculum focused on mentoring and skill-building, and ongoing support for college transition and persistence. Dartmouth undergraduate students facilitate these efforts by serving in roles such as Educational Access Advisors and summer mentors, helping high school scholars capitalize on their strengths while building a continuum of support for high-impact college success.

results.name: PUMaC Math Competition
results.title: Princeton University Mathematics Competition
results.subtitle: Princeton University Math Club
results.description: The Princeton University Mathematics Competition (PUMaC) is an annual event organized and run entirely by student volunteers since 2006. Now in its 20th year, the competition invites participants to engage with complex problem sets, including a dedicated Power Round that influences overall team standings. To participate, students must be registered by a coach who manages applications and handles disputes through a dedicated portal. The program accepts team applications on a rolling basis and has recently updated its rules to include new acceptable answer formats and modified weighting for specific competitive rounds.

results.name: Leadership Institute for Future Teachers
results.title: Leadership Institute for Future Teachers (LIFT)
results.subtitle: NC State College of Education
results.description: The Leadership Institute for Future Teachers (LIFT) is an invitational program specifically for rising high school seniors in North Carolina who have an interest in the teaching profession. Participants engage in field-based school activities and interact with prominent leaders in the field of education to explore various career options and related fields. The curriculum focuses on developing student leadership and communication skills while providing direct mentorship from current university students. This immersive experience allows future educators to gain a deeper understanding of the profession and build lasting connections with their peers and mentors.

results.name: Entrepreneurship Competition
results.title: SAGE World Cup
results.subtitle: SAGE Global
results.description: The SAGE World Cup is an international competition where top teenage entrepreneurs showcase businesses that address critical social challenges to a global audience. Teams compete for recognition and prizes by presenting their innovations to a panel of expert judges who evaluate their business success and social impact. Participants gain access to a wealth of resources, including coaching and mentorship, to help them develop professional skills in accounting and business report writing. This initiative connects a global network of teens, educators, and business leaders across five continents to foster collaboration, innovation, and leadership.

results.name: Poultry Summer Science Institute
results.title: Poultry Summer Science Institute 2023
results.subtitle: NC State Extension
results.description: The Poultry Summer Science Institute 2023 provides high school students with an intensive 5-day, 4-night immersion experience into the field of poultry science. Throughout the program, students explore diverse scientific disciplines ranging from embryology to immunology. This educational opportunity is designed to give participants a deep dive into agricultural sciences through hands-on learning and departmental exposure. Interested students are required to complete an online application process by the specified deadline to be considered for this competitive summer session.

results.name: Antimicrobial Drug Discovery
results.title: Antimicrobial Drug Discovery (Riley Lab)
results.subtitle: University of Massachusetts Amherst
results.description: This competitive Research Intensive program invites high-achieving rising high school juniors and seniors to work alongside distinguished faculty and graduate students in a professional lab setting. Participants in the Riley Lab focus on discovering and developing bacteriocins, a novel family of antimicrobials designed to target specific pathogens while preserving the healthy human microbiome. Students engage in ongoing projects such as creating bacteriocin-based ointments and medical device coatings while gaining firsthand experience with advanced research methodologies. The program culminates in each participant creating and presenting a professional research poster to faculty, peers, and family members. Beyond technical skills, attendees earn six college credits and gain valuable insight into the opportunities available for undergraduate researchers at a major R1 university.

results.name: Summer Engineering Experience
results.title: Women in STEM
results.subtitle: The University of Texas at Austin
results.description: Women in STEM (WiSTEM) is a self-sustaining unit dedicated to broadening participation in technical fields by building an inspired community of confident leaders. The organization serves a wide audience, offering diverse programs for both K-12 students and undergraduates of any gender. Specific opportunities include STEM Girl Day, high school summer camps, Role Model Monday webinars, and extensive outreach initiatives. Undergraduate participants can engage with a Living Learning Community, iConnect, externships, and a specialized Student Leadership Ecosystem to fuel their academic and professional journeys. These initiatives aim to ignite curiosity and propel students toward innovation through mentorship and engagement with corporate partners and alumni.

results.name: RPI

program_dates.label: PREFACE: The RPI Summer Engineering Design Program

results.title: PREFACE: The RPI Summer Engineering Design Program
results.subtitle: Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute
results.description: PREFACE is a summer engineering experience hosted by Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute specifically designed for rising junior and senior high school students interested in engineering and technology careers. Since 1978, the program has introduced participants to various engineering disciplines and the design and manufacturing processes used to solve global challenges. This year's curriculum focuses on the promises and challenges of nuclear energy, featuring a deep dive into nuclear reactor design, waste management, and the social implications of nuclear reliance. Students also participate in a computer system engineering workshop where they explore computer hardware design and its connection to AI and Machine Learning through hands-on activities. Participants will work alongside faculty and students to perform tasks such as designing radiation shielding, conducting computer simulations, and building radiation detectors.

results.name: MOP Mathematical Olympiad Summer Program
results.title: Mathematical Olympiad Summer Program
results.subtitle: Art of Problem Solving
results.description: The Mathematical Olympiad Summer Program is a three-week intensive problem-solving camp designed to help high school students prepare for high-level math competitions. Invitations are exclusively extended to top finishers on the USAMO and USAJMO, and the program is offered free of charge to all participants. Students are divided into color-coded groups, such as Black, Blue, and Red, based on their previous scores and experience levels to receive tailored instruction. The curriculum features daily instructional sessions, student-led solution presentations, and rigorous timed Olympiad-style tests to build advanced mathematical skills. Beyond training the United States team for the International Mathematical Olympiad, the program aims to broaden the mathematical horizons of younger students through deep engagement with complex material.

results.title: Grainger Engineering Summer Camps
results.subtitle: University of Illinois Urbana-Champaign
results.description: These programs offer middle and high school-aged students in rising 7th through 12th grades the opportunity to engage in authentic STEM projects and activities. Participants experience a collegiate environment at a top-tier engineering school through hands-on demonstrations, laboratory tours, and classroom presentations led by world-class instructors. The curriculum spans over ten different engineering disciplines, including aerospace, bioengineering, chemical, and nuclear engineering, as well as focused sessions on electronics and cybersecurity. Students have the chance to interact directly with current university students, staff, and professors to gain insights into various career fields and academic majors. Available in residential, commuter, and day camp formats, these sessions are designed for all genders and aim to provide a deeper dive into specific technical disciplines.

results.name: Buffalo Zoo
results.title: Experiences
results.subtitle: Buffalo Zoo
results.description: The Buffalo Zoo provides a variety of general and specifically tailored programming at the zoo and in the community for children and adults of all ages. These educational experiences are designed to awaken the senses while providing unique opportunities to connect with wildlife. Visitors can encounter some of the world's most exotic, endangered, and local animal species through these specialized offerings. The institution also hosts a full calendar of events and provides memberships that allow for frequent engagement with its diverse collection of wildlife and programming.

results.name: Perusing through the Americas
results.title: Michael C. Carlos Museum
results.subtitle: Emory
results.description: The Michael C. Carlos Museum provides a wide array of educational opportunities ranging from permanent collection viewings to specialized exhibitions. Visitors can engage with various program offerings tailored for adults, children, families, and university students. The institution supports academic growth through teacher resources, school programs, and faculty-led initiatives. Beyond physical galleries, the museum offers digital projects, publications, and conservation research focused on art and provenance. Participants can explore the bookshop or join the Docent Guild to further support the museum’s mission of preservation and public learning.

results.name: GUIC Summer Camp
results.title: Early Outreach
results.subtitle: University of Nevada, Las Vegas
results.description: UNLV Early Outreach provides college and career readiness programming specifically designed for K–10 students and their families. This initiative aims to help students navigate their path to higher education through a variety of engagement opportunities and community programming. Participants can attend various events that foster curiosity about academic careers while connecting with campus partners and peers. The Young Rebels component offers unique academic and social enrichment where students engage in critical thinking and interact with university faculty. Through school visits and age-appropriate campus tours, the program works to build academically minded friendships and helps students envision themselves in a university setting.

results.name: University of Chicago
results.title: UChicago Youth Internship Program
results.subtitle: The University of Chicago
results.description: The UChicago Youth Internship Program is a multi-year paid summer employment initiative designed for Chicago public high school students interested in exploring STEM careers and preparing for the college application process. During the first year, participants engage in an earn-and-learn experience featuring professional leadership lessons, workplace tours, and guest speaker series with various STEM professionals. Students who successfully complete the first year are eligible to apply for Year 2 internships, which involve six-week placements in health sciences, computer sciences, or IT services within University units. To qualify, applicants must be at least 16 years old, authorized to work in the United States, and residents of Chicago attending a local public or charter high school. Participants earn an hourly wage while gaining valuable professional skills through hands-on assignments, formal presentations, and comprehensive post-secondary planning workshops.

results.name: NYLF Medicine & Health Care
results.title: National Youth Leadership Forum (NYLF): Medicine & Health Care
results.subtitle: Envision
results.description: The National Youth Leadership Forum (NYLF): Medicine & Health Care is an immersive pre-college program designed for high school students in grades 9 through 12 who are interested in pursuing careers in health care. Participants engage in hands-on clinical simulations such as mastering suturing techniques, taking vital signs, and performing phlebotomy in a realistic training environment. Beyond clinical skills, the curriculum includes workshops on medical ethics, seminars on the path to medical school, and interactive sessions with practicing healthcare professionals like surgeons and nurses. Students also participate in high-intensity simulations, including disaster triage and outdoor emergency medicine, while earning one to two college credits through George Mason University. This residential or commuter experience allows students to live on top-tier university campuses and collaborate with peers on diagnostic challenges to build a foundation for their future medical careers.

results.name: CU Boulder
results.title: Aquetza Academic Summer Program
results.subtitle: University of Colorado Boulder
results.description: The Aquetza Academic Summer Program is a free, residential summer enrichment experience designed for Colorado high school students in grades 9, 10, and 11 with ties to Chicano/Latino communities. Students participate in interactive academic sessions focused on ethnic studies, literature, health science, and social issues to develop leadership skills and scholarly identities. The curriculum involves rigorous reading, writing, and science activities that help attendees examine relevant political and cultural issues within their communities. No GPA requirement is mandated for admission, and the program specifically encourages applications from students with nontraditional academic or social backgrounds. Participants are provided with both housing and food for the duration of the program at no cost.

results.name: OKStars Summer Research Program
results.title: OKStars Summer Research Program
results.subtitle: Oklahoma State University
results.description: This competitive summer program invites high school juniors and seniors to participate in hands-on biomedical research within various professional laboratories. Student interns are paired with faculty mentors to contribute to ongoing research projects in specialized fields such as forensic sciences, anatomy, biochemistry, and data analytics. In addition to intensive laboratory work, participants attend weekly professional development sessions focused on resume writing, scientific presentation skills, and the medical school application process. Program benefits include access to modern instrumentation and the unique opportunity to present research findings at formal university symposiums alongside graduate students. While all program fees are covered by the institution, participants must commit to a flexible schedule of up to 20 hours per week and are responsible for arranging their own transportation.

results.name: American Computer Science League
results.title: American Computer Science League
results.subtitle: American Computer Science League
results.description: The American Computer Science League organizes computer programming and computer science contests for K-12 schools, organizations, and local groups. This competition offers multiple divisions to provide appropriate challenges for students of varying ages and abilities. Each season consists of four contests that test fundamental concepts such as number systems, boolean algebra, and digital electronics. In the upper divisions, participants also solve programming problems using languages like Python, C++, or Java. Contests are administered through an online platform where team advisors facilitate student access and manage submissions. At the end of the season, top-performing students are invited to participate in an online Finals competition.

results.name: Keller BLOOM Program
results.title: Keller BLOOM Program
results.subtitle: Bigelow Laboratory for Ocean Sciences
results.description: The Keller BLOOM Program offers Maine high school juniors a hands-on ocean science research experience working alongside professional researchers to explore marine environments. Participants engage in field sampling and data collection on a research cruise before spending several days in the laboratory using state-of-the-art techniques to study phytoplankton, nutrients, and marine viruses. The program focuses on immersive research activities, including data synthesis and analysis, culminating in a final presentation of findings to friends and families. Beyond laboratory work, students participate in discussions regarding scientific ethics and public policy and attend a career night to learn about undergraduate marine science opportunities. Housing and meals are provided for the sixteen selected students during their stay, and there is no cost to participate in this competitive program.

results.name: Bruin Ascent Summer Experience (BASE)

program_dates.label: Bruin Ascent Summer Experience (BASE) Session A

results.title: Bruin Ascent Summer Experience (BASE)
results.subtitle: UCLA
results.description: The Bruin Ascent Summer Experience (BASE) is a transformative six-week online scholarship program designed for high-achieving California high school students in grades 10 and 11 from economically under-resourced communities. Participants have the opportunity to earn UCLA college credit by enrolling in one approved online summer course completely free of charge. Beyond academics, the program provides comprehensive support through one-on-one mentorship with current UCLA students and co-curricular workshops focusing on college admissions, financial wellness, and social-emotional health. Students must commit approximately 7-10 hours per week to engage in lectures, mentorship meetings, and peer study groups to build a strong foundation for higher education success.

results.name: Medicine Art and Anatomy
results.title: Stanford Medicine Art and Anatomy Summer Program
results.subtitle: Stanford Medical Humanities & the Arts
results.description: The Stanford Medicine Art and Anatomy Summer Program offers an immersion in visual storytelling through a combination of art and science. Participants engage with a speaker series featuring leading anatomists, physicians, and creatives who explore the intersection of medical practice and artistic expression. Following these lectures, students receive drawing mentorship to help them develop and resolve a final illustration for their portfolio. The program concludes with students presenting their completed projects to a professional panel consisting of artists, museum curators, and physicians. Designed for individuals interested in both the sciences and arts, the curriculum aims to improve visual, technical, and anatomical knowledge without requiring prior experience in drawing or anatomy.

results.name: YSP

program_dates.label: Information Session for Accepted Students and Their Parents/Guardians
Student Presentations and Presentation of Certificates

results.title: Young Scholars Summer Program in Biostatistics and Clinical Research
results.subtitle: Yale Center for Analytical Sciences
results.description: The Young Scholars Summer Program in Biostatistics and Clinical Research is an intensive day program designed for high school students entering the 11th and 12th grades who excel in mathematics and are interested in medical research. Participants are introduced to basic statistical methods and study designs used in clinical environments while receiving instruction in the "R" computer programming language. Working in collaborative teams, students analyze real health science data to address specific study questions and prepare a final presentation of their findings. Applicants are expected to be motivated team players with strong academic records, and it is highly recommended that they possess prior experience in programming languages such as Java, C++, or Python. Additionally, each student must provide their own laptop computer to complete the required coursework and team projects.

results.name: Jim Baen Memorial Short Story Award
results.title: Jim Baen Memorial Short Story Award
results.subtitle: Baen Books
results.description: The Jim Baen Memorial Short Story Award is a fiction contest sponsored by Baen Books and the National Space Society to celebrate the role of science fiction in advancing real science and technology. Participants are invited to submit original short stories of no more than 8,000 words that depict the near future of manned space exploration, focusing on realistic themes such as moon bases, orbital habitats, or asteroid mining. The contest is open to writers from any country, though all entries must be written in English and cannot be generated using artificial intelligence tools. Submissions must be sent via email as RTF attachments in standard manuscript format, with the author’s name removed from the document to facilitate a fair, anonymous judging process. The Grand Prize winner receives professional payment for publication on the official website, an engraved award, and membership in the National Space Society.

results.name: Art Pre-College
results.title: Art
results.subtitle: Carnegie Mellon University
results.description: The Pre-College Art program at Carnegie Mellon University offers high school sophomores and juniors a rigorous introduction to college-level studio practice through three-week or six-week immersive sessions. Participants explore creative ideas using both traditional tools and cutting-edge technologies across diverse subjects such as drawing, sculpture, animation, and digital photography. A core component of the curriculum is the Concept Studio, where students develop personal, non-medium-specific approaches to artmaking through readings, collaborative projects, and individual critiques. In addition to regular coursework, students participate in elective Friday workshops and receive one-on-one portfolio reviews from faculty to prepare for the competitive college application process. The program provides a residential experience in campus residence halls or a commuter option for local students, supported by comprehensive material kits and 24-hour supervision.

results.name: American Regions Mathematics League
results.title: American Regions Mathematics League
results.subtitle: American Regions Mathematics League
results.description: The American Regions Mathematics League (ARML) is an annual in-person mathematics competition that brings together high-achieving students from various regions to solve challenging problems. Participating teams compete in a structured environment that includes specific division assignments and adheres to established contest rules and a formal code of conduct. In addition to the main event, the organization offers various competition formats such as the International Regions Mathematics League (IRML), the Power Contest, and ARML Local to accommodate different participant needs. Students and coaches can prepare for these events using official resources including previous years' contest files, comprehensive competition books, and specific guidelines on how to form and register a team.
